AI.tldr: Task-informed reinforcement learning explores how to estimate object properties for dynamic tasks by rewarding sensitivity of a privileged task policy to estimation errors, with an uncertainty-based switch to execution; achieves fast, high-accuracy property estimation and robust task execution, validated on simulation and a KUKA iiwa robot.
AI.motivation: In dynamic tasks where object properties are critical to success and failures cannot be easily retried, the agent must quickly learn which properties matter and how to estimate them to complete the task.
AI.method: Train an exploration policy with rewards derived from how sensitive the privileged task policy is to errors in estimated properties; use an uncertainty-based criterion to decide when exploration is sufficient and to transition to task execution; validate in striking pucks, CartPole, and a physical KUKA iiwa setup.
AI.result: Achieves 90% success in the striking task with average exploration time under 1.2 seconds; baselines reach at most 40% or require inefficient simulator retraining; the task-informed rewards reflect the relative importance of properties across tasks; successful identification of object properties and adjusted execution in a physical setup.
AI.conclusion: Task-informed exploration with uncertainty-based switching enables efficient property estimation and robust task execution, with demonstrated generalization to classic control tasks and physical robotic hardware.

title: Dual-Stage Global and Local Feature Framework for Image Dehazing
summary:
Addressing the challenge of removing atmospheric fog or haze from digital
images, known as image dehazing, has recently gained significant traction in
the computer vision community. Although contemporary dehazing models have
demonstrated promising performance, few have thoroughly investigated
high-resolution imagery. In such scenarios, practitioners often resort to
downsampling the input image or processing it in smaller patches, which leads
to a notable performance degradation. This drop is primarily linked to the
difficulty of effectively combining global contextual information with
localized, fine-grained details as the spatial resolution grows. In this
chapter, we propose a novel framework, termed the Streamlined Global and Local
Features Combinator (SGLC), to bridge this gap and enable robust dehazing for
high-resolution inputs. Our approach is composed of two principal components:
the Global Features Generator (GFG) and the Local Features Enhancer (LFE). The
GFG produces an initial dehazed output by focusing on broad contextual
understanding of the scene. Subsequently, the LFE refines this preliminary
output by enhancing localized details and pixel-level features, thereby
capturing the interplay between global appearance and local structure. To
evaluate the effectiveness of SGLC, we integrated it with the Uformer
architecture, a state-of-the-art dehazing model. Experimental results on
high-resolution datasets reveal a considerable improvement in peak
signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) when employing SGLC, indicating its potency in
addressing haze in large-scale imagery. Moreover, the SGLC design is
model-agnostic, allowing any dehazing network to be augmented with the proposed
global-and-local feature fusion mechanism. Through this strategy, practitioners
can harness both scene-level cues and granular details, significantly improving
visual fidelity in high-resolution environments.

AI.tldr: Introduces SGLC, a global-and-local feature fusion framework for high-resolution image dehazing, combining a Global Features Generator and Local Features Enhancer; plugged into Uformer; demonstrates PSNR gains on high-res datasets; model-agnostic.
AI.motivation: High-resolution dehazing is challenging due to difficulty fusing global scene context with fine-grained details; downsampling or patch-based processing leads to performance loss; need a framework to preserve global and local information.
AI.method: Two components: Global Features Generator to capture scene-level context and generate initial dehazed output; Local Features Enhancer refines with detailed, pixel-level features; integrates with Uformer; claims model-agnostic; can augment other dehazing networks.
AI.result: Experimental results show considerable PSNR improvement using SGLC on high-resolution datasets; demonstrates effectiveness on high-res imagery; SGLC is a plug-in module for existing networks.
AI.conclusion: SGLC bridges global and local cues for robust high-resolution dehazing; versatile, architecture-agnostic; enables better preservation of scene-level information and fine details in high-res images.

title: Exploring and Reshaping the Weight Distribution in LLM
summary:
The performance of Large Language Models is influenced by their
characteristics such as architecture, model sizes, decoding methods and so on.
Due to differences in structure or function, the weights in different layers of
large models have varying distributions. This paper explores the correlations
between different types of layers in terms of weights distribution and studies
the potential impact of these correlations on LoRA training effectiveness.
Firstly, the study reveals that in the model the cosine distances between
weights of different layers manifest power-law distribution. We extract
Query-projection, down-projection and other weight matrices from the
self-attention layers and MLP layers, calculate the singular values of the
matrices using singular value decomposition, and organize a certain number of
singular values into matrices according to projection's type. By analyzing the
probability distribution of the cosine distances between these matrices, it is
found that the cosine distances values between them have distinct power-law
distribution characteristics. Secondly, based on the results of distance
calculations and analysis across different layers of model, a qualitative
method is proposed to describe the distribution characteristics of different
models. Next, to construct weights that align with the distribution
characteristics, a data generator is designed using a combination of Gaussian
process and Pareto distribution functions. The generator is used to simulate
the generation of data that aligns with specific distribution characteristics.
Finally, based on the aforementioned distribution characteristics and data
generation method, the weights in LoRA initialization are reshaped for
training. Experimental results indicate that, without altering the model
structure or training process, this method achieves a certain improvement in
the performance of LoRA training.

AI.tldr: Layer-wise weight distributions in LLMs exhibit power-law cosine distances; a distribution-aware initialization for LoRA via a Gaussian-Pareto generator yields modest gains without changing training.
AI.motivation: To understand cross-layer weight correlations across layers with different architectures and their potential impact on LoRA (LoRA) training effectiveness.
AI.method: 1) Extract Query-projection, down-projection, and other matrices from self-attention and MLP layers. 2) Compute singular values via SVD and organize them by projection type. 3) Analyze cosine-distance distributions between these matrices and identify power-law characteristics. 4) Propose a qualitative descriptor for distribution across models. 5) Design a data generator combining Gaussian process and Pareto distributions to simulate distributions matching the characteristics. 6) Reshape LoRA initialization weights based on these distributions.
AI.result: Demonstrates power-law characteristics in inter-layer cosine distances; provides a qualitative descriptor for model distribution characteristics; introduces a Gaussian-Pareto data generator to shape weight initializations for LoRA; reports modest improvements in LoRA training without changing model structure or training process.
AI.conclusion: Distribution-aware initialization informed by cross-layer weight distribution characteristics can modestly improve LoRA training efficacy and points to new directions for PEFT (parameter-efficient fine-tuning) design.

title: Adaptive Monitoring and Real-World Evaluation of Agentic AI Systems
summary:
Agentic artificial intelligence (AI) -- multi-agent systems that combine
large language models with external tools and autonomous planning -- are
rapidly transitioning from research laboratories into high-stakes domains. Our
earlier "Basic" paper introduced a five-axis framework and proposed preliminary
metrics such as goal drift and harm reduction but did not provide an
algorithmic instantiation or empirical evidence. This "Advanced" sequel fills
that gap. First, we revisit recent benchmarks and industrial deployments to
show that technical metrics still dominate evaluations: a systematic review of
84 papers from 2023--2025 found that 83% report capability metrics while only
30% consider human-centred or economic axes [2]. Second, we formalise an
Adaptive Multi-Dimensional Monitoring (AMDM) algorithm that normalises
heterogeneous metrics, applies per-axis exponentially weighted moving-average
thresholds and performs joint anomaly detection via the Mahalanobis distance.
Third, we conduct simulations and real-world experiments. AMDM cuts
anomaly-detection latency from 12.3 s to 5.6 s on simulated goal drift and
reduces false-positive rates from 4.5% to 0.9% compared with static thresholds.
We present a comparison table and ROC/PR curves, and we reanalyse case studies
to surface missing metrics. Code, data and a reproducibility checklist
accompany this paper to facilitate replication.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces Adaptive Multi-Dimensional Monitoring (AMDM) for agentic AI, linking multi-axis evaluation with an algorithm that normalizes metrics and detects anomalies; it improves detection latency and reduces false positives in simulations and real-world tests, and provides reproducibility resources.
AI.motivation: Evaluation of agentic AI is dominated by capability metrics; there is a gap in algorithmic instantiation and empirical evidence for monitoring multi-axis safety/economic impact; need for systematic anomaly detection across heterogeneous metrics.
AI.method: Formalize AMDM: normalize heterogeneous metrics; apply per-axis exponentially weighted moving-average thresholds; perform joint anomaly detection via Mahalanobis distance; assess on benchmarks and deployments; provide ROC/PR analyses; include code/data and reproducibility checklist.
AI.result: AMDM reduces anomaly-detection latency from 12.3 s to 5.6 s; false positives drop from 4.5% to 0.9% compared with static thresholds; supported by simulations and real-world experiments; 84 papers reviewed show 83% report capability metrics and 30% consider human-centered/economic axes.
AI.conclusion: AMDM offers a practical, scalable approach to monitoring agentic AI across multiple axes; highlights need for broader evaluation axes beyond capability; emphasizes reproducibility and surface-murface metrics; invites adoption and further experimentation.

title: First Order Model-Based RL through Decoupled Backpropagation
summary:
There is growing interest in reinforcement learning (RL) methods that
leverage the simulator's derivatives to improve learning efficiency. While
early gradient-based approaches have demonstrated superior performance compared
to derivative-free methods, accessing simulator gradients is often impractical
due to their implementation cost or unavailability. Model-based RL (MBRL) can
approximate these gradients via learned dynamics models, but the solver
efficiency suffers from compounding prediction errors during training rollouts,
which can degrade policy performance. We propose an approach that decouples
trajectory generation from gradient computation: trajectories are unrolled
using a simulator, while gradients are computed via backpropagation through a
learned differentiable model of the simulator. This hybrid design enables
efficient and consistent first-order policy optimization, even when simulator
gradients are unavailable, as well as learning a critic from simulation
rollouts, which is more accurate. Our method achieves the sample efficiency and
speed of specialized optimizers such as SHAC, while maintaining the generality
of standard approaches like PPO and avoiding ill behaviors observed in other
first-order MBRL methods. We empirically validate our algorithm on benchmark
control tasks and demonstrate its effectiveness on a real Go2 quadruped robot,
across both quadrupedal and bipedal locomotion tasks.

AI.tldr: A hybrid RL method that unrolls trajectories with the (non-differentiable) simulator while backpropagating through a learned differentiable surrogate of the simulator to enable efficient first-order policy optimization.
AI.motivation: Simulator gradients can greatly improve learning but are often unavailable or costly to obtain; model-based RL that estimates them can suffer from compounded prediction errors and inefficiency.
AI.method: Unroll trajectories with the simulator while computing gradients via backpropagation through a learned differentiable model of the simulator; optionally learn a critic from simulation rollouts to improve value estimates; aim for efficient, stable first-order policy optimization with broad applicability.
AI.result: The approach attains sample efficiency and speed comparable to specialized optimizers like SHAC, while preserving the generality of PPO and avoiding instability seen in other first-order MBRL methods; validated on benchmark control tasks and on a real Go2 quadruped robot, across quadrupedal and bipedal locomotion tasks.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling trajectory generation from gradient computation—by unrolling with the simulator and differentiating through a learned simulator model—yields efficient, stable first-order policy optimization when simulator gradients are unavailable, combining strengths of model-based and model-free approaches.

title: Self-supervised large-scale kidney abnormality detection in drug safety assessment studies
summary:
Kidney abnormality detection is required for all preclinical drug
development. It involves a time-consuming and costly examination of hundreds to
thousands of whole-slide images per drug safety study, most of which are
normal, to detect any subtle changes indicating toxic effects. In this study,
we present the first large-scale self-supervised abnormality detection model
for kidney toxicologic pathology, spanning drug safety assessment studies from
158 compounds. We explore the complexity of kidney abnormality detection on
this scale using features extracted from the UNI foundation model (FM) and show
that a simple k-nearest neighbor classifier on these features performs at
chance, demonstrating that the FM-generated features alone are insufficient for
detecting abnormalities. We then demonstrate that a self-supervised method
applied to the same features can achieve better-than-chance performance, with
an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 0.62 and a
negative predictive value of 89%. With further development, such a model can be
used to rule out normal slides in drug safety assessment studies, reducing the
costs and time associated with drug development.

AI.tldr: A large-scale self-supervised approach improves abnormality detection for kidney toxicologic pathology over a kNN baseline on UNI foundation-model features, but performance is modest (AUC 0.62; NPV 89%), suggesting potential for ruling out normals and reducing screening costs with further development.
AI.motivation: To enable scalable, cost-effective screening of thousands of kidney histology slides in preclinical drug safety studies by detecting subtle abnormalities without exhaustive manual review.
AI.method: Extract features from whole-slide images using the UNI foundation model. Compare a simple k-nearest neighbor classifier on these features (baseline) to a self-supervised method applied to the same features for abnormality detection across 158 compounds. Evaluate using AUC and NPV.
AI.result: KNN on UNI FM features performs at chance level. A self-supervised method on the same features yields better-than-chance performance with AUC = 0.62 and NPV = 89%.
AI.conclusion: The approach shows potential to rule out normal slides and cut costs/time in drug safety studies, but the modest AUC indicates substantial room for improvement before deployment; further development and validation across datasets and models are needed.

title: Teaching AI to Remember: Insights from Brain-Inspired Replay in Continual Learning
summary:
Artificial neural networks (ANNs) continue to face challenges in continual
learning, particularly due to catastrophic forgetting, the loss of previously
learned knowledge when acquiring new tasks. Inspired by memory consolidation in
the human brain, we investigate the internal replay mechanism proposed
by~\citep{brain_inspired_replay1}, which reactivates latent representations of
prior experiences during learning. As internal replay was identified as the
most influential component among the brain-inspired mechanisms in their
framework, it serves as the central focus of our in-depth investigation. Using
the CIFAR-100 dataset in a class-incremental setting, we evaluate the
effectiveness of internal replay, both in isolation and in combination with
Synaptic Intelligence (SI). Our experiments show that internal replay
significantly mitigates forgetting, especially when paired with SI, but at the
cost of reduced initial task accuracy, highlighting a trade-off between memory
stability and learning plasticity. Further analyses using log-likelihood
distributions, reconstruction errors, silhouette scores, and UMAP projections
reveal that internal replay increases representational overlap in latent space,
potentially limiting task-specific differentiation. These results underscore
the limitations of current brain-inspired methods and suggest future directions
for balancing retention and adaptability in continual learning systems.

AI.tldr: Internal replay reduces forgetting in continual learning, especially when combined with Synaptic Intelligence (SI), but at the cost of reduced initial task accuracy and greater latent-space overlap that may blur task-specific distinctions.
AI.motivation: To critically evaluate the internal replay mechanism as a core brain-inspired strategy to combat catastrophic forgetting in continual learning, using CIFAR-100 in a class-incremental setting and examining its interaction with Synaptic Intelligence.
AI.method: Empirical evaluation on CIFAR-100 in a class-incremental setting comparing internal replay alone and in combination with Synaptic Intelligence (SI). Various analyses (log-likelihood distributions, reconstruction errors, silhouette scores, and UMAP projections) to assess representational changes and forgetting.
AI.result: Internal replay substantially mitigates forgetting, with enhanced effect when paired with SI, but it reduces initial task accuracy and increases representational overlap in latent space, potentially reducing task-specific differentiation.
AI.conclusion: Brain-inspired internal replay offers a notable stability benefit but introduces a plasticity-cost and representational blurring. Balancing retention and adaptability remains a key challenge; future work should address controllable trade-offs to preserve task-specific distinctions while mitigating forgetting.

title: Know When to Explore: Difficulty-Aware Certainty as a Guide for LLM Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Feedback (RLVF) has become a key
technique for enhancing the reasoning abilities of Large Language Models
(LLMs). However, its reliance on sparse, outcome based rewards, which only
indicate if a final answer is correct or not, fails to provide granular
guidance on the reasoning process itself. This limitation hinders efficient
learning, as the model cannot distinguish between high quality and inefficient
solutions, nor can it learn effectively from different types of failures. To
address this, we observe that an LLMs self-certainty often correlates with task
difficulty and solution quality. We introduce Difficulty Aware Certainty guided
Exploration (DACE), a novel RL algorithm that leverages this insight to
dynamically balance the exploration exploitation trade-off. DACE assesses task
difficulty online based on the policys success rate. It then uses this signal
to modulate an intrinsic reward: for difficult tasks where the model is
struggling, DACE encourages exploration by penalizing high certainty; for
easier tasks, it encourages learning efficiency by rewarding high certainty.
Experiments on challenging mathematical reasoning benchmarks (AIME, MATH) show
that DACE significantly outperforms strong baselines. The DACE-trained models
not only achieve higher accuracy but also demonstrate more robust performance
when scaling test-time compute, validating that our adaptive approach fosters
effective exploration without sacrificing precision.

AI.tldr: DACE is a reinforcement learning algorithm for LLM reasoning that uses self-assessed certainty as an intrinsic signal to balance exploration and exploitation. It dynamically estimates task difficulty from the policy’s success rate and modulates intrinsic rewards: encourage exploration (lower certainty) on hard tasks and encourage efficient learning (higher certainty) on easy tasks. It yields improved accuracy and robustness on challenging mathematical benchmarks (AIME, MATH) and scales well with more compute.
AI.motivation: Sparse, outcome-based rewards in RL for LLMs provide limited guidance on reasoning quality and process, making learning inefficient. There is a signal—the model’s self-certainty—that correlates with task difficulty and solution quality, which can be exploited to provide denser feedback.
AI.method: Introduce Difficulty Aware Certainty guided Exploration (DACE). Online estimation of task difficulty via the policy’s success rate. Use this difficulty signal to modulate an intrinsic reward: for difficult tasks, penalize high certainty to encourage exploration; for easy tasks, reward high certainty to reinforce good solutions. Apply within an RL framework to improve reasoning on challenging benchmarks.
AI.result: On math reasoning benchmarks (AIME, MATH), DACE outperforms strong baselines, achieving higher accuracy and showing more robust performance when test-time compute is scaled.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive, certainty-aware intrinsic rewards enable more effective exploration without sacrificing precision, improving LLM reasoning on challenging tasks via DACE.

title: Embodied AI in Social Spaces: Responsible and Adaptive Robots in Complex Setting - UKAIRS 2025 (Copy)
summary:
This paper introduces and overviews a multidisciplinary project aimed at
developing responsible and adaptive multi-human multi-robot (MHMR) systems for
complex, dynamic settings. The project integrates co-design, ethical
frameworks, and multimodal sensing to create AI-driven robots that are
emotionally responsive, context-aware, and aligned with the needs of diverse
users. We outline the project's vision, methodology, and early outcomes,
demonstrating how embodied AI can support sustainable, ethical, and
human-centred futures.

AI.tldr: A multidisciplinary, ethics‑driven project develops responsible, adaptive multi-human multi-robot (MHMR) systems for dynamic settings, using co-design, ethical frameworks, and multimodal sensing to create emotionally responsive, context‑aware AI robots aligned with diverse users, with early results supporting sustainable, human‑centered futures.
AI.motivation: Address the challenge of designing AI-driven robotic systems that can operate safely, ethically, and effectively in complex social environments with multiple human and robot agents, while being responsive to diverse user needs and sustainable practices.
AI.method: Integrates co-design with stakeholders, ethical frameworks, and multimodal sensing; aims to build embodied AI robots that are emotionally responsive and context-aware; outlines a project vision, methodology, and preliminary outcomes to support human-centered futures.
AI.result: Early outcomes demonstrating feasibility and potential for responsible, adaptive MHMR systems and illustrating the value of embodied AI in sustaining ethical, human-centered interactions.
AI.conclusion: Embodied AI can underpin sustainable, ethical, and human-centered futures by enabling responsible, adaptive MHMR collaboration in complex settings.

title: Waste-Bench: A Comprehensive Benchmark for Evaluating VLLMs in Cluttered Environments
summary:
Recent advancements in Large Language Models (LLMs) have paved the way for
Vision Large Language Models (VLLMs) capable of performing a wide range of
visual understanding tasks. While LLMs have demonstrated impressive performance
on standard natural images, their capabilities have not been thoroughly
explored in cluttered datasets where there is complex environment having
deformed shaped objects. In this work, we introduce a novel dataset
specifically designed for waste classification in real-world scenarios,
characterized by complex environments and deformed shaped objects. Along with
this dataset, we present an in-depth evaluation approach to rigorously assess
the robustness and accuracy of VLLMs. The introduced dataset and comprehensive
analysis provide valuable insights into the performance of VLLMs under
challenging conditions. Our findings highlight the critical need for further
advancements in VLLM's robustness to perform better in complex environments.
The dataset and code for our experiments will be made publicly available.

AI.tldr: A dataset and evaluation framework for Vision LLMs in cluttered real-world waste classification, revealing robustness gaps and prompting further improvements.
AI.motivation: To push VLLMs beyond standard natural images by testing them on cluttered environments with deformed objects, addressing real-world waste classification challenges.
AI.method: Create a novel dataset of waste in complex environments; develop an in-depth evaluation approach; benchmark VLLMs on this data; provide dataset and code publicly.
AI.result: Findings show robustness limitations of VLLMs in complex scenes with deformed shapes; insights into where improvements are needed; dataset and code released for the community.
AI.conclusion: Enhance VLLM robustness for complex, cluttered real-world settings; encourage further research and dataset development; facilitate reproducibility via public release.

title: Adaptive Physics-Informed Neural Networks with Multi-Category Feature Engineering for Hydrogen Sorption Prediction in Clays, Shales, and Coals
summary:
Accurate prediction of hydrogen sorption in clays, shales, and coals is vital
for advancing underground hydrogen storage, natural hydrogen exploration, and
radioactive waste containment. Traditional experimental methods, while
foundational, are time-consuming, error-prone, and limited in capturing
geological heterogeneity. This study introduces an adaptive physics-informed
neural network (PINN) framework with multi-category feature engineering to
enhance hydrogen sorption prediction. The framework integrates classical
isotherm models with thermodynamic constraints to ensure physical consistency
while leveraging deep learning flexibility. A comprehensive dataset consisting
of 155 samples, which includes 50 clays, 60 shales, and 45 coals, was employed,
incorporating diverse compositional properties and experimental conditions.
Multi-category feature engineering across seven categories captured complex
sorption dynamics. The PINN employs deep residual networks with multi-head
attention, optimized via adaptive loss functions and Monte Carlo dropout for
uncertainty quantification. K-fold cross-validation and hyperparameter
optimization achieve significant accuracy (R2 = 0.979, RMSE = 0.045 mol per kg)
with 67% faster convergence despite 15-fold increased complexity. The framework
demonstrates robust lithology-specific performance across clay minerals (R2 =
0.981), shales (R2 = 0.971), and coals (R2 = 0.978), maintaining 85-91%
reliability scores. Interpretability analysis via SHAP, accumulated local
effects, and Friedman's H-statistics reveal that hydrogen adsorption capacity
dominates predictions, while 86.7% of feature pairs exhibit strong
interactions, validating the necessity of non-linear modeling approaches. This
adaptive physics-informed framework accelerates site screening and enables
risk-informed decision-making through robust uncertainty quantification.

AI.tldr: Adaptive physics-informed neural network (PINN) with multi-category feature engineering improves hydrogen sorption prediction in clays, shales, and coals, delivering high accuracy, lithology-specific performance, and uncertainty quantification.
AI.motivation: To accelerate site screening for underground hydrogen storage, natural hydrogen exploration, and radioactive waste containment by moving beyond time-consuming, error-prone traditional experiments and capturing geological heterogeneity.
AI.method: An adaptive PINN framework that combines classical isotherm models with thermodynamic constraints. Uses multi-category feature engineering across seven categories, deep residual networks with multi-head attention, adaptive loss functions, and Monte Carlo dropout for uncertainty. Trained on 155 samples (50 clays, 60 shales, 45 coals) with K-fold cross-validation and hyperparameter optimization. Interpretability via SHAP, accumulated local effects, and Friedman's H-statistics.
AI.result: Achieves R2 = 0.979 and RMSE = 0.045 mol/kg on the overall dataset. Lithology-specific R2: clays 0.981, shales 0.971, coals 0.978. 67% faster convergence despite a 15-fold increase in complexity. Reliability scores between 85–91%. 86.7% of feature pairs show strong interactions.
AI.conclusion: The adaptive PINN framework provides robust, physically consistent hydrogen sorption predictions with quantified uncertainty, enabling faster site screening and risk-informed decision-making; the results also underscore the importance of non-linear modeling and feature interactions in capturing sorption dynamics.

title: Optimizing Health Coverage in Ethiopia: A Learning-augmented Approach and Persistent Proportionality Under an Online Budget
summary:
As part of nationwide efforts aligned with the United Nations' Sustainable
Development Goal 3 on Universal Health Coverage, Ethiopia's Ministry of Health
is strengthening health posts to expand access to essential healthcare
services. However, only a fraction of this health system strengthening effort
can be implemented each year due to limited budgets and other competing
priorities, thus the need for an optimization framework to guide prioritization
across the regions of Ethiopia. In this paper, we develop a tool, Health Access
Resource Planner (HARP), based on a principled decision-support optimization
framework for sequential facility planning that aims to maximize population
coverage under budget uncertainty while satisfying region-specific
proportionality targets at every time step. We then propose two algorithms: (i)
a learning-augmented approach that improves upon expert recommendations at any
single-step; and (ii) a greedy algorithm for multi-step planning, both with
strong worst-case approximation estimation. In collaboration with the Ethiopian
Public Health Institute and Ministry of Health, we demonstrated the empirical
efficacy of our method on three regions across various planning scenarios.

AI.tldr: Proposes Health Access Resource Planner (HARP) for sequential facility planning in Ethiopia, optimizing population coverage under budget uncertainty with regional proportionality targets; introduces a learning-augmented single-step method and a greedy multi-step planner with strong worst-case guarantees; validated in three regions.
AI.motivation: Address Universal Health Coverage (SDG3) by expanding access to essential healthcare through health posts within tight budgets, requiring principled regional prioritization.
AI.method: Develop HARP optimization framework for sequential facility planning; design two algorithms: (i) a learning-augmented approach improving expert recommendations at a single step, and (ii) a greedy algorithm for multi-step planning; establish strong worst-case approximation guarantees; validate via collaboration with Ethiopian Public Health Institute and Ministry of Health across three regions and multiple scenarios.
AI.result: Empirical demonstration of efficacy across three regions and various planning scenarios; improved guidance over expert recommendations under budget uncertainty; robust planning with proportionality constraints.
AI.conclusion: HARP and its algorithms provide a practical decision-support tool for region-wide, budget-constrained health post expansion toward Universal Health Coverage, with demonstrated real-world applicability and potential policy impact.

title: Learn from What We HAVE: History-Aware VErifier that Reasons about Past Interactions Online
summary:
We introduce a novel History-Aware VErifier (HAVE) to disambiguate uncertain
scenarios online by leveraging past interactions. Robots frequently encounter
visually ambiguous objects whose manipulation outcomes remain uncertain until
physically interacted with. While generative models alone could theoretically
adapt to such ambiguity, in practice they obtain suboptimal performance in
ambiguous cases, even when conditioned on action history. To address this, we
propose explicitly decoupling action generation from verification: we use an
unconditional diffusion-based generator to propose multiple candidate actions
and employ our history-aware verifier to select the most promising action by
reasoning about past interactions. Through theoretical analysis, we demonstrate
that employing a verifier significantly improves expected action quality.
Empirical evaluations and analysis across multiple simulated and real-world
environments including articulated objects, multi-modal doors, and uneven
object pick-up confirm the effectiveness of our method and improvements over
baselines. Our project website is available at:
https://liy1shu.github.io/HAVE_CoRL25/

AI.tldr: History-Aware Verifier (HAVE) decouples action generation from verification to disambiguate uncertain manipulation tasks by using an unconditional diffusion generator to propose actions and a history-based verifier to pick among them, improving expected action quality in varied environments.
AI.motivation: Robots face visually ambiguous objects where outcomes are uncertain until interaction; generative models alone underperform in ambiguity; leveraging past interactions can help disambiguate and select better actions.
AI.method: Generate multiple candidate actions with an unconditional diffusion-based generator; use a history-aware verifier that reasons about past interactions to select the most promising action; provide theoretical analysis showing verifier improves expected action quality; evaluate on simulated and real-world tasks (articulated objects, multi-modal doors, uneven object pick-up).
AI.result: Empirical results show HAVE and verifier outperform baselines and improve action quality across tasks; ablations/analysis support the effectiveness of history-aware verification.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling action generation from verification and incorporating action history yields more reliable disambiguation and improved manipulation performance in uncertain scenarios; the approach is validated in diverse environments and demonstrated on a public project page.

title: Category-level Text-to-Image Retrieval Improved: Bridging the Domain Gap with Diffusion Models and Vision Encoders
summary:
This work explores text-to-image retrieval for queries that specify or
describe a semantic category. While vision-and-language models (VLMs) like CLIP
offer a straightforward open-vocabulary solution, they map text and images to
distant regions in the representation space, limiting retrieval performance. To
bridge this modality gap, we propose a two-step approach. First, we transform
the text query into a visual query using a generative diffusion model. Then, we
estimate image-to-image similarity with a vision model. Additionally, we
introduce an aggregation network that combines multiple generated images into a
single vector representation and fuses similarity scores across both query
modalities. Our approach leverages advancements in vision encoders, VLMs, and
text-to-image generation models. Extensive evaluations show that it
consistently outperforms retrieval methods relying solely on text queries.
Source code is available at: https://github.com/faixan-khan/cletir

AI.tldr: A diffusion-based text-to-image query transformation with an aggregation network improves text-to-image retrieval over text-only queries.
AI.motivation: Bridge the modality gap in open-vocabulary text-to-image retrieval where text-only queries (e.g., via CLIP) map to distant regions in representation space, limiting performance; leverage generative and vision models to better align queries with images.
AI.method: A two-step approach: (1) transform the text query into a visual query using a diffusion generative model; (2) estimate image-to-image similarity with a vision model. An aggregation network combines multiple generated images into a single vector and fuses similarity scores across both the original text and generated visual modalities.
AI.result: Extensive evaluations show the proposed method consistently outperforms retrieval methods that rely solely on text queries (text-only baselines).
AI.conclusion: Transforming text into visual representations via diffusion and fusing with generated visuals improves open-vocabulary text-to-image retrieval, demonstrating the benefit of cross-modal query construction and aggregation; code is provided.

title: Applying Deep Learning to Anomaly Detection of Russian Satellite Activity for Indications Prior to Military Activity
summary:
We apply deep learning techniques for anomaly detection to analyze activity
of Russian-owned resident space objects (RSO) prior to the Ukraine invasion and
assess the results for any findings that can be used as indications and
warnings (I&W) of aggressive military behavior for future conflicts. Through
analysis of anomalous activity, an understanding of possible tactics and
procedures can be established to assess the existence of statistically
significant changes in Russian RSO pattern of life/pattern of behavior
(PoL/PoB) using publicly available two-line element (TLE) data. This research
looks at statistical and deep learning approaches to assess anomalous activity.
The deep learning methods assessed are isolation forest (IF), traditional
autoencoder (AE), variational autoencoder (VAE), Kolmogorov Arnold Network
(KAN), and a novel anchor-loss based autoencoder (Anchor AE). Each model is
used to establish a baseline of on-orbit activity based on a five-year data
sample. The primary investigation period focuses on the six months leading up
to the invasion date of February 24, 2022. Additional analysis looks at RSO
activity during an active combat period by sampling TLE data after the invasion
date. The deep learning autoencoder models identify anomalies based on
reconstruction errors that surpass a threshold sigma. To capture the nuance and
unique characteristics of each RSO an individual model was trained for each
observed space object. The research made an effort to prioritize explainability
and interpretability of the model results thus each observation was assessed
for anomalous behavior of the individual six orbital elements versus analyzing
the input data as a single monolithic observation. The results demonstrate not
only statistically significant anomalies of Russian RSO activity but also
details anomalous findings to the individual orbital element.

AI.tldr: Deep learning-based anomaly detection on public TLE data reveals statistically significant anomalous activity patterns of Russian RSO around the February 2022 invasion, with per-object analyses and interpretable, element-level insights.
AI.motivation: Provide indications and warnings (I&W) of aggressive space behavior by Russian resident space objects (RSO) using publicly available two-line element data; enable monitoring of pattern of life/behavior to inform future conflict readiness.
AI.method: Apply multiple anomaly-detection models (Isolation Forest, Autoencoder variants including traditional AE, VAE, Kolmogorov Arnold Network, and a novel anchor-loss based Autoencoder). Train per-object models on a five-year baseline of RSO activity using TLE data, focusing on the six months before the invasion (Feb 2022) and post-invasion periods. Use reconstruction-error thresholds (sigma) to flag anomalies, with detailed analysis of each RSO by the six orbital elements to improve explainability.
AI.result: The approaches identified statistically significant anomalies in Russian RSO activity and provided detailed, element-level anomalous findings for individual orbital elements, demonstrating the feasibility of per-object, interpretable anomaly detection on TLE data.
AI.conclusion: Deep-learning-based PoL/PoB anomaly detection on public TLE data can contribute to I&W for space-domain events. Per-object modeling enhances interpretability by highlighting which orbital elements drive anomalies. Further work could expand datasets, refine thresholds, and explore real-time applications.

title: Virtual Group Knowledge and Group Belief in Topological Evidence Models (Extended Version)
summary:
We study notions of (virtual) group knowledge and group belief within
multi-agent evidence models, obtained by extending the topological semantics of
evidence-based belief and fallible knowledge from individuals to groups. We
completely axiomatize and show the decidability of the logic of ("hard" and
"soft") group evidence, and do the same for an especially interesting fragment
of it: the logic of group knowledge and group belief. We also extend these
languages with dynamic evidence-sharing operators, and completely axiomatize
the corresponding logics, showing that they are co-expressive with their static
bases.

AI.tldr: Axiomatizes and proves decidability for (hard/soft) group evidence in multi-agent evidence models, analyzes a fragment for group knowledge/belief, and extends to dynamic evidence-sharing operators with axiomatizations showing co-expressiveness with static bases.
AI.motivation: To extend topological semantics of evidence-based belief and fallible knowledge from individuals to groups, enabling rigorous analysis of collective epistemic states and the impact of evidence sharing.
AI.method: Develop topological/group evidence semantics; provide complete axiomatizations for the full group-evidence logic and its knowledge/belief fragment; introduce dynamic evidence-sharing operators; prove completeness and decidability; analyze co-expressiveness of dynamic extensions with static logics.
AI.result: Complete axiomatizations for hard and soft group evidence and for the group-knowledge/belief fragment; decidability results for these logics; axiomatizations of dynamic evidence-sharing logics; demonstration that dynamic extensions are co-expressive with their static bases.
AI.conclusion: The paper establishes a solid logical foundation for group epistemic states under evidence-based semantics, showing that both static and dynamic group modalities can be fully axiomatized and decidable, with dynamic sharing not increasing expressive power.

title: TReF-6: Inferring Task-Relevant Frames from a Single Demonstration for One-Shot Skill Generalization
summary:
Robots often struggle to generalize from a single demonstration due to the
lack of a transferable and interpretable spatial representation. In this work,
we introduce TReF-6, a method that infers a simplified, abstracted 6DoF
Task-Relevant Frame from a single trajectory. Our approach identifies an
influence point purely from the trajectory geometry to define the origin for a
local frame, which serves as a reference for parameterizing a Dynamic Movement
Primitive (DMP). This influence point captures the task's spatial structure,
extending the standard DMP formulation beyond start-goal imitation. The
inferred frame is semantically grounded via a vision-language model and
localized in novel scenes by Grounded-SAM, enabling functionally consistent
skill generalization. We validate TReF-6 in simulation and demonstrate
robustness to trajectory noise. We further deploy an end-to-end pipeline on
real-world manipulation tasks, showing that TReF-6 supports one-shot imitation
learning that preserves task intent across diverse object configurations.

AI.tldr: A one-shot imitation method (TReF-6) learns a compact 6DoF task-relevant frame from a single trajectory, enabling robust, semantically grounded one-shot skills that generalize to new object configurations by grounding a frame in vision-language models and Grounded-SAM, and parameterizing a DMP for manipulation.
AI.motivation: Generalizing manipulation from a single demonstration is challenging due to lack of a transferable and interpretable spatial representation. A task-relevant frame that captures the essential geometry can enable reliable imitation across variations.
AI.method: Infer a 6DoF Task-Relevant Frame (TReF-6) from trajectory geometry by identifying an influence point that defines the frame origin. Use this frame to parameterize a Dynamic Movement Primitive (DMP). Semantically ground the inferred frame with a vision-language model and localize it in new scenes via Grounded-SAM, enabling cross-scene generalization. Validate in simulation (robust to noise) and deploy an end-to-end real-world imitation pipeline for one-shot learning across diverse object configurations.
AI.result: The approach yields a transferable, interpretable frame that supports DMP-based imitation and cross-scene generalization. It demonstrates robustness to trajectory noise in simulation and enables successful one-shot imitation in real-world tasks with diverse object configurations.
AI.conclusion: TReF-6 provides a concise, semantically grounded, task-relevant frame for one-shot imitation, extending standard DMPs beyond start-goal imitation and improving generalization across object configurations, though its reliance on semantic grounding components may affect performance in visually challenging environments.

title: Safe-LLaVA: A Privacy-Preserving Vision-Language Dataset and Benchmark for Biometric Safety
summary:
Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have demonstrated remarkable
capabilities in vision-language tasks. However, these models often infer and
reveal sensitive biometric attributes - such as race, gender, age, body weight,
and eye color - even when such information is not explicitly requested. This
raises critical concerns, particularly in real-world applications and
socially-sensitive domains. Despite increasing awareness, no publicly available
dataset or benchmark exists to comprehensively evaluate or mitigate biometric
leakage in MLLMs. To address this gap, we introduce PRISM (Privacy-aware
Evaluation of Responses in Sensitive Modalities), a new benchmark designed to
assess MLLMs on two fronts: (1) refuse biometric-related queries and (2)
implicit biometric leakage in general responses while maintaining semantic
faithfulness. Further, we conduct a detailed audit of the widely used LLaVA
datasets and uncover extensive biometric leakage across pretraining and
instruction data. To address this, we present Safe-LLaVA dataset, the first
privacy-preserving MLLM training dataset constructed by systematically removing
explicit and implicit biometric information from LLaVA dataset. Our evaluations
on PRISM reveal biometric leakages across MLLMs for different attributes,
highlighting the detailed privacy-violations. We also fine-tune a model on
Safe-LLaVA dataset and show that it substantially reduces the biometric
leakages. Together, Safe-LLaVA & PRISM set a new standard for privacy-aligned
development and evaluation of MLLMs. The Safe-LLaVA dataset & PRISM benchmark
are publicly available at https://huggingface.co/datasets/kyh9191/Safe-LLaVA,
and the source code is available at
https://github.com/Kimyounggun99/Safe-LLaVA.git.

AI.tldr: PRISM benchmarks biometric leakage in multimodal LLMs; Safe-LLaVA dataset removes biometric info; results show leakage present and reduction after training on safe data; provides privacy-aware evaluation and training standards.
AI.motivation: Growing concerns that multimodal LLMs reveal sensitive biometric attributes (race, gender, age, body weight, eye color) even when not requested; no public benchmarks exist to evaluate or mitigate this leakage.
AI.method: Introduce PRISM for two evaluation axes: (i) refusing biometric-related queries and (ii) detecting implicit biometric leakage in general responses while preserving semantic fidelity. Audit LLaVA datasets to reveal leakage; construct Safe-LLaVA by systematically removing explicit and implicit biometric information from LLaVA data; evaluate MLLMs on PRISM; fine-tune a model on Safe-LLaVA to reduce leakage.
AI.result: Audits reveal extensive biometric leakage across pretraining/instruction data. PRISM exposes biometric leakage across multiple attributes in MLLMs. Fine-tuning on Safe-LLaVA substantially reduces leakage. Safe-LLaVA and PRISM together set a privacy-aligned standard for MLLM development and evaluation.
AI.conclusion: PRISM and Safe-LLaVA provide a privacy-aware framework for evaluating and training MLLMs. Public datasets and code are released to enable widespread adoption and benchmarking.

title: From Data to Decision: A Multi-Stage Framework for Class Imbalance Mitigation in Optical Network Failure Analysis
summary:
Machine learning-based failure management in optical networks has gained
significant attention in recent years. However, severe class imbalance, where
normal instances vastly outnumber failure cases, remains a considerable
challenge. While pre- and in-processing techniques have been widely studied,
post-processing methods are largely unexplored. In this work, we present a
direct comparison of pre-, in-, and post-processing approaches for class
imbalance mitigation in failure detection and identification using an
experimental dataset. For failure detection, post-processing
methods-particularly Threshold Adjustment-achieve the highest F1 score
improvement (up to 15.3%), while Random Under-Sampling provides the fastest
inference. In failure identification, GenAI methods deliver the most
substantial performance gains (up to 24.2%), whereas post-processing shows
limited impact in multi-class settings. When class overlap is present and
latency is critical, over-sampling methods such as the SMOTE are most
effective; without latency constraints, Meta-Learning yields the best results.
In low-overlap scenarios, Generative AI approaches provide the highest
performance with minimal inference time.

AI.tldr: Direct cross-stage comparison of pre-, in-, and post-processing for class-imbalance in ML-based optical-network failure management. Post-processing (notably Threshold Adjustment) yields the largest F1 gains for failure detection, while under-sampling offers fastest inference. For failure identification, Generative AI (GenAI) methods provide the biggest performance gains; post-processing is less impactful in multiclass settings. When class overlap exists and latency matters, oversampling (SMOTE) is most effective; without latency constraints, Meta-Learning performs best. In low-overlap scenarios, Generative AI achieves high performance with minimal inference time.
AI.motivation: Addresses a persistent challenge in ML-based optical-network failure management: severe class imbalance. While pre- and in-processing techniques are well-studied, post-processing methods remain under-explored. The study aims to directly compare pre-, in-, and post-processing approaches on an experimental dataset to guide practical imbalance mitigation.
AI.method: Experimental dataset with failure detection (binary) and failure identification (multiclass). Systematically compares pre-, in-, and post-processing approaches for imbalance mitigation. Evaluates performance under various conditions: class overlap and latency constraints. Reported metrics include F1 score improvements and inference time (latency). Methods mentioned include Random Under-Sampling, SMOTE (oversampling), Threshold Adjustment (post-processing), GenAI approaches, Meta-Learning, etc.
AI.result: For failure detection: post-processing approaches—especially Threshold Adjustment—achieve the highest F1-score improvement (up to 15.3%), while Random Under-Sampling offers fastest inference. For failure identification: GenAI methods yield the largest gains (up to 24.2%), with post-processing showing limited impact in multiclass settings. When class overlap exists and latency is critical, SMOTE (oversampling) is most effective; without latency constraints, Meta-Learning performs best. In low-overlap scenarios, Generative AI approaches provide the highest performance with minimal inference time.
AI.conclusion: The study provides a direct, task- and constraint-aware comparison across preprocessing stages for imbalance mitigation. Practical guidance depends on the task (detection vs. identification), latency tolerance, and class-overlap level. Post-processing is valuable for detection; GenAI and generative methods dominate identification under various conditions; oversampling is preferred for latency-sensitive scenarios; meta-learning is advantageous when latency is not a constraint, and low-overlap scenarios favor Generative AI for faster inference.

title: HiVA: Self-organized Hierarchical Variable Agent via Goal-driven Semantic-Topological Evolution
summary:
Autonomous agents play a crucial role in advancing Artificial General
Intelligence, enabling problem decomposition and tool orchestration through
Large Language Models (LLMs). However, existing paradigms face a critical
trade-off. On one hand, reusable fixed workflows require manual reconfiguration
upon environmental changes; on the other hand, flexible reactive loops fail to
distill reasoning progress into transferable structures. We introduce
Hierarchical Variable Agent (HiVA), a novel framework modeling agentic
workflows as self-organized graphs with the Semantic-Topological Evolution
(STEV) algorithm, which optimizes hybrid semantic-topological spaces using
textual gradients as discrete-domain surrogates for backpropagation. The
iterative process comprises Multi-Armed Bandit-infused forward routing,
diagnostic gradient generation from environmental feedback, and coordinated
updates that co-evolve individual semantics and topology for collective
optimization in unknown environments. Experiments on dialogue, coding,
Long-context Q&A, mathematical, and agentic benchmarks demonstrate improvements
of 5-10% in task accuracy and enhanced resource efficiency over existing
baselines, establishing HiVA's effectiveness in autonomous task execution.

AI.tldr: HiVA introduces Hierarchical Variable Agent, a self-organizing workflow framework that optimizes semantic-topological agent structures via the STEV algorithm, using textual gradients as discrete surrogates for backpropagation, achieving improved task accuracy and resource efficiency across diverse benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Current agent paradigms force a trade-off between fixed reusable workflows (which lack adaptability) and purely reactive loops (which struggle to distill transferable reasoning into structure). There is a need for scalable, transferable, autonomous task execution in unknown environments.
AI.method: Model agent workflows as self-organized graphs and optimize hybrid semantic-topological spaces with the STEV algorithm. Use textual gradients as discrete-domain surrogates for backpropagation. The iterative process includes Multi-Armed Bandit–driven forward routing, diagnostic gradient generation from environmental feedback, and coordinated updates that co-evolve semantics and topology.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations across dialogue, coding, long-context Q&A, mathematical, and agentic benchmarks show 5–10% gains in task accuracy and improved resource efficiency over baselines, indicating HiVA’s effectiveness in autonomous task execution.
AI.conclusion: HiVA demonstrates a practical path to balancing stable reusable reasoning and flexible adaptation by enabling co-evolution of semantic and topological structures in unknown environments, suggesting strong potential to advance autonomous AGI systems.

title: A Framework for Task and Motion Planning based on Expanding AND/OR Graphs
comment: Accepted for an oral presentation at ASTRA Conference, 2025
summary:
Robot autonomy in space environments presents unique challenges, including
high perception and motion uncertainty, strict kinematic constraints, and
limited opportunities for human intervention. Therefore, Task and Motion
Planning (TMP) may be critical for autonomous servicing, surface operations, or
even in-orbit missions, just to name a few, as it models tasks as discrete
action sequencing integrated with continuous motion feasibility assessments. In
this paper, we introduce a TMP framework based on expanding AND/OR graphs,
referred to as TMP-EAOG, and demonstrate its adaptability to different
scenarios. TMP-EAOG encodes task-level abstractions within an AND/OR graph,
which expands iteratively as the plan is executed, and performs in-the-loop
motion planning assessments to ascertain their feasibility. As a consequence,
TMP-EAOG is characterised by the desirable properties of (i) robustness to a
certain degree of uncertainty, because AND/OR graph expansion can accommodate
for unpredictable information about the robot environment, (ii) controlled
autonomy, since an AND/OR graph can be validated by human experts, and (iii)
bounded flexibility, in that unexpected events, including the assessment of
unfeasible motions, can lead to different courses of action as alternative
paths in the AND/OR graph. We evaluate TMP-EAOG on two benchmark domains. We
use a simulated mobile manipulator as a proxy for space-grade autonomous
robots. Our evaluation shows that TMP-EAOG can deal with a wide range of
challenges in the benchmarks.

AI.tldr: TMP-EAOG is an expanding AND/OR graph-based Task and Motion Planning framework for space robotics that couples task sequencing with in-the-loop motion feasibility, enabling robust, controllable, and adaptable autonomy; validated on two benchmark tasks with a simulated mobile manipulator.
AI.motivation: Space robotics face high perception and motion uncertainty, strict kinematic constraints, and limited human intervention. A planning framework that integrates task-level abstractions with continuous motion feasibility and can adapt to uncertainty is needed.
AI.method: We propose TMP-EAOG: an expanding AND/OR graph that encodes task-level abstractions; plan expansion happens iteratively during execution; employs in-the-loop motion planning to check feasibility; allows human expert validation of the graph and provides alternative paths to handle unfeasible motions.
AI.result: Evaluation on two benchmarks using a simulated mobile manipulator shows TMP-EAOG handles a wide range of challenges, demonstrating robustness to uncertainty, controlled autonomy, and bounded flexibility.
AI.conclusion: TMP-EAOG provides a versatile, robust, and adaptable framework for autonomous space operations, combining discrete task planning with continuous feasibility checks, and enabling human-in-the-loop validation and fallback strategies.

title: Beyond Pixels: Introducing Geometric-Semantic World Priors for Video-based Embodied Models via Spatio-temporal Alignment
summary:
Achieving human-like reasoning in deep learning models for complex tasks in
unknown environments remains a critical challenge in embodied intelligence.
While advanced vision-language models (VLMs) excel in static scene
understanding, their limitations in spatio-temporal reasoning and adaptation to
dynamic, open-set tasks like task-oriented navigation and embodied question
answering (EQA) persist due to inadequate modeling of fine-grained
spatio-temporal cues and physical world comprehension. To address this, we
propose VEME, a novel cross-modal alignment method that enhances generalization
in unseen scenes by learning an ego-centric, experience-centered world model.
Our framework integrates three key components: (1) a cross-modal alignment
framework bridging objects, spatial representations, and visual semantics with
spatio-temporal cues to enhance VLM in-context learning; (2) a dynamic,
implicit cognitive map activated by world embedding to enable task-relevant
geometric-semantic memory recall; and (3) an instruction-based navigation and
reasoning framework leveraging embodied priors for long-term planning and
efficient exploration. By embedding geometry-aware spatio-temporal episodic
experiences, our method significantly improves reasoning and planning in
dynamic environments. Experimental results on VSI-Bench and VLN-CE demonstrate
1%-3% accuracy and exploration efficiency improvement compared to traditional
approaches.

AI.tldr: VEME introduces a cross-modal, ego-centric world model for embodied AI that enhances VLM reasoning and planning in dynamic, unseen environments, achieving modest gains on VSI-Bench and VLN-CE.
AI.motivation: Current vision-language models excel at static scenes but struggle with spatio-temporal reasoning and adaptation to open-ended embodied tasks; a geometry-aware, episodic, ego-centric world model is needed.
AI.method: Three-part framework: (1) cross-modal alignment across objects, spatial reps, and visual semantics with spatio-temporal cues; (2) a dynamic implicit cognitive map activated by world embedding for memory recall; (3) instruction-based navigation/reasoning leveraging embodied priors for long-term planning and exploration; plus encoding geometry-aware spatio-temporal episodic experiences.
AI.result: Empirical improvements of 1-3% in accuracy and exploration efficiency on VSI-Bench and VLN-CE compared with traditional approaches.
AI.conclusion: Embedding geometry-aware spatio-temporal experiences into an ego-centric world model enhances generalization and reasoning/planning for embodied tasks in dynamic environments.

title: T-MLP: Tailed Multi-Layer Perceptron for Level-of-Detail Signal Representation
summary:
Level-of-detail (LoD) representation is critical for efficiently modeling and
transmitting various types of signals, such as images and 3D shapes. In this
work, we present a novel neural architecture that supports LoD signal
representation. Our architecture is based on an elaborate modification of the
widely used Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), which inherently operates at a single
scale and therefore lacks native support for LoD. Specifically, we introduce
the Tailed Multi-Layer Perceptron (T-MLP) that extends the MLP by attaching
multiple output branches, also called tails, to its hidden layers, enabling
direct supervision at multiple depths. Our loss formulation and training
strategy allow each hidden layer to effectively learn a target signal at a
specific LoD, thus enabling multi-scale modeling. Extensive experimental
results show that our T-MLP outperforms other neural LoD baselines across a
variety of signal representation tasks.

AI.tldr: A new T-MLP architecture attaches tails to hidden layers to enable level-of-detail (LoD) representation, achieving better results than neural LoD baselines across several signal tasks.
AI.motivation: LoD representations enable efficient modeling and transmission of signals (images, 3D shapes). Classical MLPs operate at a single scale and lack native LoD support, creating a need for architectures that support multi-scale representations.
AI.method: Modify the standard MLP by attaching multiple output branches (tails) to hidden layers. Use a loss formulation and training strategy that supervises each hidden layer to learn a target signal at a specific LoD, enabling multi-scale modeling within a single network.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show that the T-MLP outperforms other neural LoD baselines across various signal representation tasks.
AI.conclusion: T-MLP provides native LoD support and multi-scale modeling within a single architecture, offering improved performance and broad applicability for efficient signal representation.

title: Universal Deep Research: Bring Your Own Model and Strategy
summary:
Deep research tools are among the most impactful and most commonly
encountered agentic systems today. We observe, however, that each deep research
agent introduced so far is hard-coded to carry out a particular research
strategy using a fixed choice of tools. We introduce Universal Deep Research
(UDR), a generalist agentic system that wraps around any language model and
enables the user to create, edit, and refine their own entirely custom deep
research strategies without any need for additional training or finetuning. To
showcase the generality of our system, we equip UDR with example minimal,
expansive, and intensive research strategies, and provide a user interface to
facilitate experimentation with the system.

AI.tldr: UDR is a generalist agentic system that lets users build customizable deep-research workflows on top of language models, without requiring training or finetuning.
AI.motivation: Current deep research agents are typically fixed to a single strategy and fixed toolsets, which limits adaptability across diverse tasks; there is a need for a flexible, user-definable framework that can compose and refine research strategies.
AI.method: UDR wraps around any language model and provides interfaces to create, edit, and refine entirely custom deep research strategies. It supports example strategies (minimal, expansive, intensive) and includes a user interface to facilitate experimentation without additional training or finetuning.
AI.result: The paper demonstrates the generality of UDR by equipping it with example strategies and a UI, illustrating how users can experiment with and deploy diverse research workflows.
AI.conclusion: UDR enables flexible, trainer-free deep research automation by letting users define their own research strategies and rapidly test them through an accessible interface.

title: Contact-Aided Navigation of Flexible Robotic Endoscope Using Deep Reinforcement Learning in Dynamic Stomach
summary:
Navigating a flexible robotic endoscope (FRE) through the gastrointestinal
tract is critical for surgical diagnosis and treatment. However, navigation in
the dynamic stomach is particularly challenging because the FRE must learn to
effectively use contact with the deformable stomach walls to reach target
locations. To address this, we introduce a deep reinforcement learning (DRL)
based Contact-Aided Navigation (CAN) strategy for FREs, leveraging contact
force feedback to enhance motion stability and navigation precision. The
training environment is established using a physics-based finite element method
(FEM) simulation of a deformable stomach. Trained with the Proximal Policy
Optimization (PPO) algorithm, our approach achieves high navigation success
rates (within 3 mm error between the FRE's end-effector and target) and
significantly outperforms baseline policies. In both static and dynamic stomach
environments, the CAN agent achieved a 100% success rate with 1.6 mm average
error, and it maintained an 85% success rate in challenging unseen scenarios
with stronger external disturbances. These results validate that the DRL-based
CAN strategy substantially enhances FRE navigation performance over prior
methods.

AI.tldr: A DRL-based Contact-Aided Navigation (CAN) strategy for flexible endoscopes using contact force feedback and PPO in a FEM-based stomach simulation, achieving near-perfect navigation accuracy and strong robustness, outperforming baselines.
AI.motivation: Navigating a flexible endoscope in a deformable stomach is challenging due to dynamic contact with soft walls. Incorporating contact force feedback through DRL can improve stability, precision, and robustness during navigation.
AI.method: Train a CAN DRL policy within a physics-based FEM simulation of a deformable stomach using Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO). The policy leverages contact force feedback to guide motion, validated in static, dynamic, and unseen/uncontrolled disturbance scenarios, and compared against baseline policies.
AI.result: In static and dynamic stomach environments, CAN achieved 100% success with an average end-effector error of 1.6 mm. In challenging unseen scenarios with stronger disturbances, CAN maintained 85% success. It substantially outperformed prior methods.
AI.conclusion: DRL-based CAN with contact force feedback improves FRE navigation performance in deformable environments and shows strong robustness and accuracy, suggesting notable potential for safer and more precise endoscopic procedures.

title: Multimodal Deep Learning for Phyllodes Tumor Classification from Ultrasound and Clinical Data
comment:
IEEE-EMBS International Conference on Body Sensor Networks (IEEE-EMBS
  BSN 2025)
summary:
Phyllodes tumors (PTs) are rare fibroepithelial breast lesions that are
difficult to classify preoperatively due to their radiological similarity to
benign fibroadenomas. This often leads to unnecessary surgical excisions. To
address this, we propose a multimodal deep learning framework that integrates
breast ultrasound (BUS) images with structured clinical data to improve
diagnostic accuracy. We developed a dual-branch neural network that extracts
and fuses features from ultrasound images and patient metadata from 81 subjects
with confirmed PTs. Class-aware sampling and subject-stratified 5-fold
cross-validation were applied to prevent class imbalance and data leakage. The
results show that our proposed multimodal method outperforms unimodal baselines
in classifying benign versus borderline/malignant PTs. Among six image
encoders, ConvNeXt and ResNet18 achieved the best performance in the multimodal
setting, with AUC-ROC scores of 0.9427 and 0.9349, and F1-scores of 0.6720 and
0.7294, respectively. This study demonstrates the potential of multimodal AI to
serve as a non-invasive diagnostic tool, reducing unnecessary biopsies and
improving clinical decision-making in breast tumor management.

AI.tldr: Multimodal deep learning using ultrasound images and clinical data improves classification of breast phyllodes tumors vs benign/probable malignant, outperforming unimodal baselines; ConvNeXt and ResNet18 best in multimodal setup.
AI.motivation: To address preoperative misclassification of phyllodes tumors due to radiologic similarity to benign lesions, leading to unnecessary surgeries, by combining imaging and structured clinical data.
AI.method: Dual-branch neural network fusing features from breast ultrasound images and patient metadata; class-aware sampling; subject-stratified 5-fold cross-validation on 81 confirmed PT cases; evaluated across six image encoders (ConvNeXt, ResNet18 among others).
AI.result: Multimodal model outperforms unimodal baselines in benign vs borderline/malignant PT classification. Best performers in multimodal setting: ConvNeXt (AUC-ROC 0.9427, F1 0.6720) and ResNet18 (AUC-ROC 0.9349, F1 0.7294).
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates the potential of multimodal AI as a non-invasive diagnostic tool to reduce unnecessary biopsies and support clinical decision-making in breast tumor management.

title: AnomalyExplainer Explainable AI for LLM-based anomaly detection using BERTViz and Captum
summary:
Conversational AI and Large Language Models (LLMs) have become powerful tools
across domains, including cybersecurity, where they help detect threats early
and improve response times. However, challenges such as false positives and
complex model management still limit trust. Although Explainable AI (XAI) aims
to make AI decisions more transparent, many security analysts remain uncertain
about its usefulness. This study presents a framework that detects anomalies
and provides high-quality explanations through visual tools BERTViz and Captum,
combined with natural language reports based on attention outputs. This reduces
manual effort and speeds up remediation. Our comparative analysis showed that
RoBERTa offers high accuracy (99.6 %) and strong anomaly detection,
outperforming Falcon-7B and DeBERTa, as well as exhibiting better flexibility
than large-scale Mistral-7B on the HDFS dataset from LogHub. User feedback
confirms the chatbot's ease of use and improved understanding of anomalies,
demonstrating the ability of the developed framework to strengthen
cybersecurity workflows.

AI.tldr: A framework combines anomaly detection with explainable AI visuals (BERTViz, Captum) and attention-based NLP reports to streamline cybersecurity workflows; RoBERTa achieves 99.6% accuracy on HDFS data, outperforming Falcon-7B and DeBERTa and showing greater flexibility than Mistral-7B; user feedback indicates ease of use and better anomaly understanding.
AI.motivation: To address false positives and trust issues in AI for cybersecurity, and to reduce manual remediation by providing high-quality explanations and actionable insights.
AI.method: Developed a framework that detects anomalies and generates explanations using visual tools BERTViz and Captum, plus natural language reports derived from attention outputs; evaluated on the HDFS dataset from LogHub; compared RoBERTa, Falcon-7B, DeBERTa, and Mistral-7B.
AI.result: RoBERTa achieved high accuracy (99.6%) and strong anomaly detection; outperformed Falcon-7B and DeBERTa; more flexible than Mistral-7B on HDFS; user feedback indicates ease of use and improved understanding of anomalies.
AI.conclusion: The framework strengthens cybersecurity workflows by combining anomaly detection with interpretable explanations, speeding remediation and illustrating the value of XAI for security analysts.

title: Instruction-Level Weight Shaping: A Framework for Self-Improving AI Agents
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are fluent but largely static after
pre-training; new or shifting knowledge is typically added with
retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) or fine-tuning. RAG raises latency and
engineering overhead and often fails to integrate facts; prompt engineering is
brittle and can conflict with prior knowledge; fine-tuning is costly and risks
catastrophic forgetting. We propose Instruction-Level Weight Shaping (ILWS):
curated system instructions act as external, auditable pseudo-parameters
updated after each session via reflection and user feedback. A Reflection
Engine inspects conversation traces, diagnoses reasoning successes and
failures, and proposes typed deltas $\Delta K=(\Delta S,\Delta U,\Delta T)$
over instructions, user preferences, and tools. Deltas are version-controlled,
evaluated with a sliding window of 1-5 star ratings, auto-repaired on first
failure, and rolled back on repeated failure. When an edit budget crosses a
threshold, the agent compiles a rating-weighted synthetic set and distills
matured instruction-space gains into parameters, converting prompt-space
improvements into weight-space without downtime. ILWS makes explicit the
low-rank shaping induced by context in transformer blocks, preserves
governance, and removes per-call retrieval. In enterprise support it increased
throughput 2.4-5.0x and cut audited hallucinations by about 80% versus a frozen
baseline. In an Adobe Commerce Cloud proof of concept "L0 Support", it achieved
4-5x more tickets per hour and about 80% lower time per ticket, with autonomous
instruction updates and optional tool synthesis. Because ILWS operates at the
instruction layer until controlled distillation, it generalizes to dynamic
domains (legal, medical, engineering) requiring adaptive reasoning, tool
creation, and low-latency deployment.

AI.tldr: ILWS updates LLM behavior via instruction-space edits guided by a Reflection Engine, enabling adaptive, low-latency reasoning without per-call retrieval.
AI.motivation: Address stagnation of pre-trained LLMs and limitations of RAG, prompt brittleness, and costly fine-tuning that risks forgetting.
AI.method: A Reflection Engine inspects conversations, proposes deltas ΔK over instructions, user preferences, and tools. Deltas are version-controlled, rated with a 1-5 star window, auto-repaired on first failure, rolled back on repeated failure. On budget, synthesize a weighted synthetic set and distill matured instruction-space gains into model weights (prompt-space -> weight-space). Governs changes and avoids downtime. Demonstrates enterprise throughput gains and reduced hallucinations.
AI.result: In enterprise support: throughput 2.4-5.0x and ~80% reduction in audited hallucinations vs frozen baseline. Adobe Commerce Cloud proof-of-concept: 4-5x more tickets/hour; ~80% lower time/ticket; autonomous instruction updates and tool synthesis. Generalizes to dynamic domains.
AI.conclusion: ILWS offers low-latency, auditable, governance-preserving adaptation at the instruction layer, enabling dynamic domain adaptation without retrieval; potential broad applicability but requires robust Reflection Engine and governance checks.

title: Mechanistic interpretability for steering vision-language-action models
summary:
Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models are a promising path to realizing
generalist embodied agents that can quickly adapt to new tasks, modalities, and
environments. However, methods for interpreting and steering VLAs fall far
short of classical robotics pipelines, which are grounded in explicit models of
kinematics, dynamics, and control. This lack of mechanistic insight is a
central challenge for deploying learned policies in real-world robotics, where
robustness and explainability are critical. Motivated by advances in
mechanistic interpretability for large language models, we introduce the first
framework for interpreting and steering VLAs via their internal
representations, enabling direct intervention in model behavior at inference
time. We project feedforward activations within transformer layers onto the
token embedding basis, identifying sparse semantic directions - such as speed
and direction - that are causally linked to action selection. Leveraging these
findings, we introduce a general-purpose activation steering method that
modulates behavior in real time, without fine-tuning, reward signals, or
environment interaction. We evaluate this method on two recent open-source
VLAs, Pi0 and OpenVLA, and demonstrate zero-shot behavioral control in
simulation (LIBERO) and on a physical robot (UR5). This work demonstrates that
interpretable components of embodied VLAs can be systematically harnessed for
control - establishing a new paradigm for transparent and steerable foundation
models in robotics.

AI.tldr: A framework to interpret and steer Vision-Language-Action models via their internal activations, enabling real-time, zero-shot control without fine-tuning—validated on Pi0/OpenVLA across simulation and a UR5 robot.
AI.motivation: VLAs currently lack mechanistic interpretability and controllability, which limits robustness and explainability for real-world robotics. Inspired by mechanistic interpretability in LLMs, the work seeks transparent, intervention-ready control of learned agents.
