AI.method: Project feedforward transformer activations onto the token embedding basis to find sparse, semantically meaningful directions (e.g., speed, direction) that causally influence action selection. Introduce a real-time activation-steering mechanism that modulates behavior without fine-tuning, reward shaping, or environment interaction.
AI.result: Demonstrated zero-shot behavioral control in simulation (LIBERO) and on a physical UR5 robot using two open-source VLAs (Pi0 and OpenVLA). The approach shows actionable, interpretable control signals derived from internal representations.
AI.conclusion: Interpretable components within embodied VLAs can be leveraged for direct control, enabling a transparent and steerable class of foundation models in robotics and raising prospects for safer, more robust deployment.

title: GraViT: Transfer Learning with Vision Transformers and MLP-Mixer for Strong Gravitational Lens Discovery
comment:
Our publicly available fine-tuned models provide a scalable transfer
  learning solution for gravitational lens finding in LSST. Submitted to MNRAS.
  Comments welcome
summary:
Gravitational lensing offers a powerful probe into the properties of dark
matter and is crucial to infer cosmological parameters. The Legacy Survey of
Space and Time (LSST) is predicted to find O(10^5) gravitational lenses over
the next decade, demanding automated classifiers. In this work, we introduce
GraViT, a PyTorch pipeline for gravitational lens detection that leverages
extensive pretraining of state-of-the-art Vision Transformer (ViT) models and
MLP-Mixer. We assess the impact of transfer learning on classification
performance by examining data quality (source and sample size), model
architecture (selection and fine-tuning), training strategies (augmentation,
normalization, and optimization), and ensemble predictions. This study
reproduces the experiments in a previous systematic comparison of neural
networks and provides insights into the detectability of strong gravitational
lenses on that common test sample. We fine-tune ten architectures using
datasets from HOLISMOKES VI and SuGOHI X, and benchmark them against
convolutional baselines, discussing complexity and inference-time analysis.

AI.tldr: GraViT is a PyTorch pipeline for automated strong gravitational lens detection using pre-trained Vision Transformer (ViT) models and MLPMixer, exploring transfer learning under varying data quality and architectures, and benchmarking against CNN baselines; ten architectures are fine-tuned on HOLISMOKES VI and SuGOHI X, with ensemble predictions analyzed.
AI.motivation: The LSST-era goal of discovering ~10^5 gravitational lenses requires scalable automated classifiers. The work studies how pretraining, data quality, model choice, training strategies, and ensemble methods affect lens-detection performance.
AI.method: Fine-tune ten ViT/MLPMixer architectures on HOLISMOKES VI and SuGOHI X datasets, compare with convolutional baselines, evaluate transfer-learning strategies (augmentation, normalization, optimization), assess ensemble predictions, and reproduce prior experiments from a systematic neural-network comparison, including complexity and inference-time analysis.
AI.result: Provides insights into how transfer learning and model selection influence detectability of strong gravitational lenses on the test sample, with performance and efficiency trade-offs discussed across architectures and data conditions; ten architectures are benchmarked against CNN baselines.
AI.conclusion: GraViT demonstrates that extensive pretraining and careful training/ensemble strategies enable effective automated lens detection for LSST-scale data, offering practical guidance on architecture choice, data requirements, and computation costs.

title: SynCircuit: Automated Generation of New Synthetic RTL Circuits Can Enable Big Data in Circuits
summary:
In recent years, AI-assisted IC design methods have demonstrated great
potential, but the availability of circuit design data is extremely limited,
especially in the public domain. The lack of circuit data has become the
primary bottleneck in developing AI-assisted IC design methods. In this work,
we make the first attempt, SynCircuit, to generate new synthetic circuits with
valid functionalities in the HDL format. SynCircuit automatically generates
synthetic data using a framework with three innovative steps: 1) We propose a
customized diffusion-based generative model to resolve the Directed Cyclic
Graph (DCG) generation task, which has not been well explored in the AI
community. 2) To ensure our circuit is valid, we enforce the circuit
constraints by refining the initial graph generation outputs. 3) The Monte
Carlo tree search (MCTS) method further optimizes the logic redundancy in the
generated graph. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed SynCircuit
can generate more realistic synthetic circuits and enhance ML model performance
in downstream circuit design tasks.

AI.tldr: SynCircuit uses a diffusion-based generator for directed cyclic graphs to synthesize valid HDL circuits, refines outputs to enforce circuit constraints, and applies Monte Carlo tree search to reduce logic redundancy, producing more realistic synthetic circuits that improve downstream ML tasks.
AI.motivation: Publicly available circuit data for AI-assisted IC design is severely limited, hindering progress. Generating valid, realistic synthetic HDL data can enable training and evaluation of ML models in IC design.
AI.method: 1) Develop a customized diffusion-based generative model tailored to directed cyclic graphs (DCGs) representing circuits. 2) Refine initial graph outputs to enforce essential circuit constraints and ensure validity. 3) Use Monte Carlo tree search (MCTS) to optimize and reduce logic redundancy in the generated graphs.
AI.result: Experiments show SynCircuit can generate more realistic synthetic circuits and improve ML model performance on downstream circuit design tasks.
AI.conclusion: SynCircuit represents a first attempt at generating valid HDL circuits via synthetic data, addressing data scarcity and providing a pipeline that yields realistic circuits and better downstream performance.

title: SHERPA: A Model-Driven Framework for Large Language Model Execution
summary:
Recently, large language models (LLMs) have achieved widespread application
across various fields. Despite their impressive capabilities, LLMs suffer from
a lack of structured reasoning ability, particularly for complex tasks
requiring domain-specific best practices, which are often unavailable in the
training data. Although multi-step prompting methods incorporating human best
practices, such as chain-of-thought and tree-of-thought, have gained
popularity, they lack a general mechanism to control LLM behavior. In this
paper, we propose SHERPA, a model-driven framework to improve the LLM
performance on complex tasks by explicitly incorporating domain-specific best
practices into hierarchical state machines. By structuring the LLM execution
processes using state machines, SHERPA enables more fine-grained control over
their behavior via rules or decisions driven by machine learning-based
approaches, including LLMs. We show that SHERPA is applicable to a wide variety
of tasks-specifically, code generation, class name generation, and question
answering-replicating previously proposed approaches while further improving
the performance. We demonstrate the effectiveness of SHERPA for the
aforementioned tasks using various LLMs. Our systematic evaluation compares
different state machine configurations against baseline approaches without
state machines. Results show that integrating well-designed state machines
significantly improves the quality of LLM outputs, and is particularly
beneficial for complex tasks with well-established human best practices but
lacking data used for training LLMs.

AI.tldr: SHERPA introduces a model-driven, hierarchical state-machine framework that injects domain-specific best practices into LLM workflows to improve performance on complex tasks.
AI.motivation: LLMs lack structured domain-specific reasoning; multi-step prompts depend on training data and lack fine-grained control; need explicit mechanisms to encode best practices.
AI.method: Propose SHERPA: hierarchical state machines with rules or ML-driven decisions guiding LLM execution; apply to code generation, class name generation, QA; compare configurations to baselines using multiple LLMs.
AI.result: State-machine configurations consistently improve output quality over baselines; benefits are pronounced for tasks with established human best practices but limited training data.
AI.conclusion: Integrating domain-specific best practices via well-designed state machines provides fine-grained control, generalizes across tasks, and enhances LLM performance on complex tasks.

title: Jacobian Exploratory Dual-Phase Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Endoluminal Navigation of Deformable Continuum Robots
summary:
Deformable continuum robots (DCRs) present unique planning challenges due to
nonlinear deformation mechanics and partial state observability, violating the
Markov assumptions of conventional reinforcement learning (RL) methods. While
Jacobian-based approaches offer theoretical foundations for rigid manipulators,
their direct application to DCRs remains limited by time-varying kinematics and
underactuated deformation dynamics. This paper proposes Jacobian Exploratory
Dual-Phase RL (JEDP-RL), a framework that decomposes planning into phased
Jacobian estimation and policy execution. During each training step, we first
perform small-scale local exploratory actions to estimate the deformation
Jacobian matrix, then augment the state representation with Jacobian features
to restore approximate Markovianity. Extensive SOFA surgical dynamic
simulations demonstrate JEDP-RL's three key advantages over proximal policy
optimization (PPO) baselines: 1) Convergence speed: 3.2x faster policy
convergence, 2) Navigation efficiency: requires 25% fewer steps to reach the
target, and 3) Generalization ability: achieve 92% success rate under material
property variations and achieve 83% (33% higher than PPO) success rate in the
unseen tissue environment.

AI.tldr: JEDP-RL: a Jacobian-guided dual-phase RL for deformable continuum robots that estimates a deformation Jacobian via local exploration and augments the state to restore Markovianity, yielding faster convergence, fewer steps, and better generalization than PPO in SOFA simulations.
AI.motivation: DCRs deform nonlinearly and have partial observability, breaking Markov assumptions; rigid-robot Jacobian methods don't transfer due to time-varying kinematics and underactuated deformation.
AI.method: Two-phase training: (1) local exploratory actions to estimate a deformation Jacobian at each step; (2) augment state with Jacobian features and execute policy; compare against PPO in SOFA surgical dynamics simulations.
AI.result: JEDP-RL converges 3.2x faster than PPO, uses 25% fewer steps to reach target, and shows strong generalization: 92% success under material-property variations and 83% (33% higher than PPO) in unseen tissue environments.
AI.conclusion: Jacobian-based state augmentation for deformable robots improves learning efficiency and generalization; promising for planning under nonstationary, partially observable deformation dynamics, with validation in a physics-based simulator.

title: A High-Accuracy Fast Hough Transform with Linear-Log-Cubed Computational Complexity for Arbitrary-Shaped Images
comment:
8 pages, 4 figures. Accepted to International Conference on Machine
  Vision 2025 (ICMV 2025)
summary:
The Hough transform (HT) is a fundamental tool across various domains, from
classical image analysis to neural networks and tomography. Two key aspects of
the algorithms for computing the HT are their computational complexity and
accuracy - the latter often defined as the error of approximation of continuous
lines by discrete ones within the image region. The fast HT (FHT) algorithms
with optimal linearithmic complexity - such as the Brady-Yong algorithm for
power-of-two-sized images - are well established. Generalizations like $FHT2DT$
extend this efficiency to arbitrary image sizes, but with reduced accuracy that
worsens with scale. Conversely, accurate HT algorithms achieve constant-bounded
error but require near-cubic computational cost. This paper introduces $FHT2SP$
algorithm - a fast and highly accurate HT algorithm. It builds on our
development of Brady's superpixel concept, extending it to arbitrary shapes
beyond the original power-of-two square constraint, and integrates it into the
$FHT2DT$ algorithm. With an appropriate choice of the superpixel's size, for an
image of shape $w \times h$, the $FHT2SP$ algorithm achieves near-optimal
computational complexity $\mathcal{O}(wh \ln^3 w)$, while keeping the
approximation error bounded by a constant independent of image size, and
controllable via a meta-parameter. We provide theoretical and experimental
analyses of the algorithm's complexity and accuracy.

AI.tldr: Proposes FHT2SP, a fast and highly accurate Hough transform for arbitrary-shaped images by extending Brady’s superpixel idea into FHT2DT, achieving near-optimal O(wh log^3 w) time with a size-independent constant error bound, tunable by a meta-parameter.
AI.motivation: The classic HT requires a balance between speed and accuracy. While fast HTs like FHT2DT work for power-of-two images, accuracy degrades for arbitrary sizes; exact HTs are too slow. There is a need for an algorithm that is both fast for arbitrary shapes and maintains bounded, controllable accuracy.
AI.method: Extend Brady’s superpixel concept to arbitrary shapes and integrate it into the FHT2DT framework to create FHT2SP. The approach selects a superpixel size to balance complexity and error, achieving O(wh log^3 w) time with a constant, size-independent error bound, and provides theoretical and experimental analyses.
AI.result: FHT2SP achieves near-optimal computational complexity O(wh log^3 w) for an image of size w×h while keeping the approximation error bounded by a constant independent of image size, controllable via a meta-parameter. The paper provides theoretical and experimental validation of both complexity and accuracy.
AI.conclusion: FHT2SP delivers a fast, highly accurate HT for arbitrary-shaped images by unifying the superpixel extension with FHT2DT; the meta-parameter enables a tunable trade-off between speed and precision, with proven guarantees and empirical support.

title: Mitigating Clinician Information Overload: Generative AI for Integrated EHR and RPM Data Analysis
summary:
Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI), particularly Large Language
Models (LLMs), offer powerful capabilities for interpreting the complex data
landscape in healthcare. In this paper, we present a comprehensive overview of
the capabilities, requirements and applications of GenAI for deriving clinical
insights and improving clinical efficiency. We first provide some background on
the forms and sources of patient data, namely real-time Remote Patient
Monitoring (RPM) streams and traditional Electronic Health Records (EHRs). The
sheer volume and heterogeneity of this combined data present significant
challenges to clinicians and contribute to information overload. In addition,
we explore the potential of LLM-powered applications for improving clinical
efficiency. These applications can enhance navigation of longitudinal patient
data and provide actionable clinical decision support through natural language
dialogue. We discuss the opportunities this presents for streamlining clinician
workflows and personalizing care, alongside critical challenges such as data
integration complexity, ensuring data quality and RPM data reliability,
maintaining patient privacy, validating AI outputs for clinical safety,
mitigating bias, and ensuring clinical acceptance. We believe this work
represents the first summarization of GenAI techniques for managing clinician
data overload due to combined RPM / EHR data complexities.

AI.tldr: GenAI/LLMs can help clinicians manage overload from real-time RPM and EHR data by offering natural-language navigation, actionable decision support, and workflow enhancements, while highlighting data integration, privacy, validation, bias, and acceptance challenges.
AI.motivation: Address information overload, improve clinical efficiency, and extract valuable insights from heterogeneous, high-volume RPM and EHR data while preserving privacy and safety.
AI.method: Literature-driven overview (conceptual synthesis) of GenAI capabilities, data sources, integration challenges, and potential applications; discussion of workflow implications and requirements; identification of risks and acceptance factors.
AI.result: A structured synthesis detailing the capabilities of GenAI to navigate longitudinal patient data, provide decision-support, and streamline clinician workflows; a map of opportunities, requirements, and challenges for implementing GenAI in RPM/EHR contexts.
AI.conclusion: This work is the first summarization of GenAI techniques for managing clinician data overload from combined RPM and EHR data complexities, highlighting both high potential and critical considerations for adoption.

title: SIGMUS: Semantic Integration for Knowledge Graphs in Multimodal Urban Spaces
summary:
Modern urban spaces are equipped with an increasingly diverse set of sensors,
all producing an abundance of multimodal data. Such multimodal data can be used
to identify and reason about important incidents occurring in urban landscapes,
such as major emergencies, cultural and social events, as well as natural
disasters. However, such data may be fragmented over several sources and
difficult to integrate due to the reliance on human-driven reasoning for
identifying relationships between the multimodal data corresponding to an
incident, as well as understanding the different components which define an
incident. Such relationships and components are critical to identifying the
causes of such incidents, as well as producing forecasting the scale and
intensity of future incidents as they begin to develop. In this work, we create
SIGMUS, a system for Semantic Integration for Knowledge Graphs in Multimodal
Urban Spaces. SIGMUS uses Large Language Models (LLMs) to produce the necessary
world knowledge for identifying relationships between incidents occurring in
urban spaces and data from different modalities, allowing us to organize
evidence and observations relevant to an incident without relying and
human-encoded rules for relating multimodal sensory data with incidents. This
organized knowledge is represented as a knowledge graph, organizing incidents,
observations, and much more. We find that our system is able to produce
reasonable connections between 5 different data sources (new article text, CCTV
images, air quality, weather, and traffic measurements) and relevant incidents
occurring at the same time and location.

AI.tldr: SIGMUS uses LLMs to semantically integrate multimodal urban data into a knowledge graph for incident analysis, avoiding hand-crafted rules and showing plausible connections across text, images, and sensor data.
AI.motivation: Urban spaces generate diverse, fragmented multimodal data. Reliance on human-driven reasoning to link data and incidents impedes understanding of causes and forecasting. A scalable, automated integration approach is needed to identify relationships and support forecasting of incidents.
AI.method: Propose SIGMUS, a framework that leverages large language models to produce world knowledge for linking multimodal data to incidents and observations, organizing them into a knowledge graph without manually encoded rules. Evaluates connections among five data sources (news articles, CCTV images, air quality, weather, and traffic) and related incidents.
AI.result: The system produces reasonable connections between the five data sources and relevant incidents occurring at the same time and location.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates feasibility of LLM-driven semantic integration for multimodal urban data via knowledge graphs, enabling structured reasoning about incidents without hand-crafted rules and supporting improved understanding and forecasting of urban incidents.

title: Autonomous Aggregate Sorting in Construction and Mining via Computer Vision-Aided Robotic Arm Systems
summary:
Traditional aggregate sorting methods, whether manual or mechanical, often
suffer from low precision, limited flexibility, and poor adaptability to
diverse material properties such as size, shape, and lithology. To address
these limitations, this study presents a computer vision-aided robotic arm
system designed for autonomous aggregate sorting in construction and mining
applications. The system integrates a six-degree-of-freedom robotic arm, a
binocular stereo camera for 3D perception, and a ROS-based control framework.
Core techniques include an attention-augmented YOLOv8 model for aggregate
detection, stereo matching for 3D localization, Denavit-Hartenberg kinematic
modeling for arm motion control, minimum enclosing rectangle analysis for size
estimation, and hand-eye calibration for precise coordinate alignment.
Experimental validation with four aggregate types achieved an average grasping
and sorting success rate of 97.5%, with comparable classification accuracy.
Remaining challenges include the reliable handling of small aggregates and
texture-based misclassification. Overall, the proposed system demonstrates
significant potential to enhance productivity, reduce operational costs, and
improve safety in aggregate handling, while providing a scalable framework for
advancing smart automation in construction, mining, and recycling industries.

AI.tldr: A computer vision–aided robotic arm system for autonomous aggregate sorting achieving 97.5% grasping/sorting rate across four aggregate types, integrating attention-augmented YOLOv8, stereo 3D localization, DH kinematics, and hand-eye calibration; demonstrates high potential but faces small-aggregate and texture misclassification challenges.
AI.motivation: Automate precise, adaptable aggregate sorting to overcome low precision, inflexibility, and safety concerns in manual/mechanical methods, benefiting construction/mining/recycling.
AI.method: Six-degree-of-freedom robotic arm, binocular stereo camera, and a ROS-based control framework. Core techniques include an attention-augmented YOLOv8 model for detection, stereo matching for 3D localization, Denavit-Hartenberg kinematic modeling for motion control, minimum enclosing rectangle analysis for size estimation, and hand-eye calibration for precise alignment.
AI.result: Experimental validation with four aggregate types achieving an average grasping and sorting success rate of 97.5% and comparable classification accuracy; indicates high potential for productivity gains, safety improvements, and scalable smart automation.
AI.conclusion: The system demonstrates significant potential to enhance productivity, reduce costs, and improve safety in aggregate handling, while providing a scalable framework for advancing smart automation in construction, mining, and recycling industries; remaining challenges include reliable handling of small aggregates and texture-based misclassification.

title: Generative AI for Industrial Contour Detection: A Language-Guided Vision System
summary:
Industrial computer vision systems often struggle with noise, material
variability, and uncontrolled imaging conditions, limiting the effectiveness of
classical edge detectors and handcrafted pipelines. In this work, we present a
language-guided generative vision system for remnant contour detection in
manufacturing, designed to achieve CAD-level precision. The system is organized
into three stages: data acquisition and preprocessing, contour generation using
a conditional GAN, and multimodal contour refinement through vision-language
modeling, where standardized prompts are crafted in a human-in-the-loop process
and applied through image-text guided synthesis. On proprietary FabTrack
datasets, the proposed system improved contour fidelity, enhancing edge
continuity and geometric alignment while reducing manual tracing. For the
refinement stage, we benchmarked several vision-language models, including
Google's Gemini 2.0 Flash, OpenAI's GPT-image-1 integrated within a VLM-guided
workflow, and open-source baselines. Under standardized conditions, GPT-image-1
consistently outperformed Gemini 2.0 Flash in both structural accuracy and
perceptual quality. These findings demonstrate the promise of VLM-guided
generative workflows for advancing industrial computer vision beyond the
limitations of classical pipelines.

AI.tldr: A language-guided generative vision pipeline combining a conditional GAN contour generator with vision-language model refinement achieves CAD-like contour precision in manufacturing, outperforming Gemini 2.0 Flash and other baselines on FabTrack data.
AI.motivation: Industrial computer vision is hampered by noise, material variability, and uncontrolled imaging, making classical edge detectors and handcrafted pipelines fail to deliver CAD-level contour accuracy; a flexible, language-guided generative approach may bridge this gap.
AI.method: A three-stage pipeline: (1) data acquisition and preprocessing; (2) contour generation using a conditional GAN; (3) multimodal contour refinement via vision-language modeling with standardized prompts crafted in a human-in-the-loop process, applied through image-text guided synthesis. Evaluation on proprietary FabTrack datasets with comparisons across VLMs (Gemini 2.0 Flash, GPT-image-1 integrated within a VLM-guided workflow, and open-source baselines).
AI.result: Increased contour fidelity, with improved edge continuity and geometric alignment; reduced need for manual tracing. GPT-image-1 consistently outperformed Gemini 2.0 Flash in structural accuracy and perceptual quality under standardized conditions.
AI.conclusion: Vision-language-model-guided generative workflows hold strong promise for advancing industrial computer vision beyond classical pipelines, enabling CAD-level precision in remnant contour detection, though practical considerations like data access and prompt design remain important.

title: Experimental Assessment of a Multi-Class AI/ML Architecture for Real-Time Characterization of Cyber Events in a Live Research Reactor
summary:
There is increased interest in applying Artificial Intelligence and Machine
Learning (AI/ML) within the nuclear industry and nuclear engineering community.
Effective implementation of AI/ML could offer benefits to the nuclear domain,
including enhanced identification of anomalies, anticipation of system
failures, and operational schedule optimization. However, limited work has been
done to investigate the feasibility and applicability of AI/ML tools in a
functioning nuclear reactor. Here, we go beyond the development of a single
model and introduce a multi-layered AI/ML architecture that integrates both
information technology and operational technology data streams to identify,
characterize, and differentiate (i) among diverse cybersecurity events and (ii)
between cyber events and other operational anomalies. Leveraging Purdue
Universitys research reactor, PUR-1, we demonstrate this architecture through a
representative use case that includes multiple concurrent false data injections
and denial-of-service attacks of increasing complexity under realistic reactor
conditions. The use case includes 14 system states (1 normal, 13 abnormal) and
over 13.8 million multi-variate operational and information technology data
points. The study demonstrated the capability of AI/ML to distinguish between
normal, abnormal, and cybersecurity-related events, even under challenging
conditions such as denial-of-service attacks. Combining operational and
information technology data improved classification accuracy but posed
challenges related to synchronization and collection during certain cyber
events. While results indicate significant promise for AI/ML in nuclear
cybersecurity, the findings also highlight the need for further refinement in
handling complex event differentiation and multi-class architectures.

AI.tldr: A multi-layered AI/ML framework integrating IT and OT data can distinguish cyber-related events from normal/abnormal operations in a nuclear reactor use case, showing promise but needing refinement in synchronization and multi-class differentiation; demonstrated on PUR-1 with 13 abnormal states and 13.8M data points.
AI.motivation: Growing interest in applying AI/ML to nuclear safety and cybersecurity; limited live reactor studies exist, necessitating evaluation of feasibility and data-fusion architectures that can detect anomalies and cyber events.
AI.method: Propose a multi-layered AI/ML architecture that fuses information technology and operational technology data streams; apply it to Purdue PUR-1 reactor using a representative use case with multiple concurrent false data injections and DoS attacks; include 14 system states (1 normal, 13 abnormal) and over 13.8 million multivariate data points; assess the model's ability to classify normal, abnormal, and cybersecurity-related events and the impact of IT+OT data fusion.
AI.result: The study demonstrates that AI/ML can differentiate normal, abnormal, and cybersecurity-related events, even under DoS conditions; combining IT and OT data improves classification accuracy, but raises synchronization and data-collection challenges during certain cyber events.
AI.conclusion: AI/ML show significant promise for nuclear cybersecurity; however, refinement is needed for handling complex, multi-class event differentiation and robust data synchronization/collection to support real-time monitoring in reactor environments.

title: NEWSAGENT: Benchmarking Multimodal Agents as Journalists with Real-World Newswriting Tasks
summary:
Recent advances in autonomous digital agents from industry (e.g., Manus AI
and Gemini's research mode) highlight potential for structured tasks by
autonomous decision-making and task decomposition; however, it remains unclear
to what extent the agent-based systems can improve multimodal web data
productivity. We study this in the realm of journalism, which requires
iterative planning, interpretation, and contextual reasoning from multimodal
raw contents to form a well structured news. We introduce NEWSAGENT, a
benchmark for evaluating how agents can automatically search available raw
contents, select desired information, and edit and rephrase to form a news
article by accessing core journalistic functions. Given a writing instruction
and firsthand data as how a journalist initiates a news draft, agents are
tasked to identify narrative perspectives, issue keyword-based queries,
retrieve historical background, and generate complete articles. Unlike typical
summarization or retrieval tasks, essential context is not directly available
and must be actively discovered, reflecting the information gaps faced in
real-world news writing. NEWSAGENT includes 6k human-verified examples derived
from real news, with multimodal contents converted to text for broad model
compatibility. We evaluate open- and closed-sourced LLMs with commonly-used
agentic frameworks on NEWSAGENT, which shows that agents are capable of
retrieving relevant facts but struggling with planning and narrative
integration. We believe that NEWSAGENT serves a realistic testbed for iterating
and evaluating agent capabilities in terms of multimodal web data manipulation
to real-world productivity.

AI.tldr: NEWSAGENT is a benchmark to evaluate autonomous agents in multimodal web data journalism; shows agents can fetch facts but struggle with planning and narrative integration.
AI.motivation: Fill a gap in evaluating agentic, multimodal data manipulation for real-world journalism; measure planning, information discovery, and narrative construction.
AI.method: Introduce NEWSAGENT dataset (~6k, derived from real news), convert multimodal content to text; evaluate open- and closed-sourced LLMs with agent frameworks on tasks including search, selection, editing, and rephrasing to produce articles based on an instruction and firsthand data; metrics focus on ability to discover hidden context.
AI.result: Agents adept at retrieving relevant facts but limited in planning and coherent narrative integration; performance gaps identified.
AI.conclusion: NEWSAGENT provides a realistic testbed for iterating agent capabilities in multimodal web data manipulation and real-world productivity.

title: Generative Visual Foresight Meets Task-Agnostic Pose Estimation in Robotic Table-Top Manipulation
comment: 9th Conference on Robot Learning (CoRL 2025), Seoul, Korea
summary:
Robotic manipulation in unstructured environments requires systems that can
generalize across diverse tasks while maintaining robust and reliable
performance. We introduce {GVF-TAPE}, a closed-loop framework that combines
generative visual foresight with task-agnostic pose estimation to enable
scalable robotic manipulation. GVF-TAPE employs a generative video model to
predict future RGB-D frames from a single side-view RGB image and a task
description, offering visual plans that guide robot actions. A decoupled pose
estimation model then extracts end-effector poses from the predicted frames,
translating them into executable commands via low-level controllers. By
iteratively integrating video foresight and pose estimation in a closed loop,
GVF-TAPE achieves real-time, adaptive manipulation across a broad range of
tasks. Extensive experiments in both simulation and real-world settings
demonstrate that our approach reduces reliance on task-specific action data and
generalizes effectively, providing a practical and scalable solution for
intelligent robotic systems.

AI.tldr: GVF-TAPE is a closed-loop framework that merges generative visual foresight with task-agnostic pose estimation to enable scalable, real-time robotic manipulation from a single side-view RGB image and task description.
AI.motivation: Robotic manipulation in unstructured environments requires generalization across diverse tasks with robust performance, but current approaches depend heavily on task-specific data. A generalizable, data-efficient solution is needed.
AI.method: A generative video model predicts future RGB-D frames from a single side-view RGB image and a task description to provide visual plans. A decoupled pose estimation model extracts end-effector poses from the predicted frames and converts them into executable commands via low-level controllers. The system is closed-loop, iteratively integrating video foresight and pose estimation for real-time adaptation.
AI.result: Real-time, adaptive manipulation across a broad range of tasks demonstrated in both simulation and real-world settings. The approach reduces reliance on task-specific action data and generalizes effectively.
AI.conclusion: GVF-TAPE offers a practical, scalable solution for intelligent robotic systems by leveraging vision-based foresight and pose estimation in a closed loop to achieve broad generalization with less task-specific data.

title: Language-Aware Information Maximization for Transductive Few-Shot CLIP
summary:
Transductive few-shot learning has triggered an abundant literature focusing
on vision-only models, but is still at a nascent stage within the recent
context of foundational vision-language models (VLMs). Only a few recent
methods addressed the problem, pointing to the potential of tranduction in VLMs
and to the need for VLM-tailored methods. Building on this momentum, we
leverage information-theoretic concepts and recent progress in
parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT), developing a highly competitive
transductive few-shot CLIP method. Specifically, we introduce a novel
Language-aware Information MaximizatiOn (LIMO) loss integrating three
complementary terms: (i) the mutual information between the vision inputs and
the textual class descriptions; (ii) a Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence
penalizing deviation of the network's probabilistic outputs from the
text-driven zero-shot predictions; and (iii) a standard cross-entropy loss
based on the labeled shots. Furthermore, we challenge the commonly followed
fine-tuning practices in the context of transductive few-shot learning, and
explore PEFT strategies, completely overlooked in this context. Surprisingly,
we observe substantial boosts in performances, which points to the potential of
adapting a subset of the model's parameters in the transductive few-shot
setting. We report comprehensive evaluations, which show that LIMO outperforms
the very recent transductive few-shot CLIP methods by a large margin and yields
significant gains over the best-performing inductive methods. Our code is
publicly available at:\[
\href{https://github.com/ghassenbaklouti/LIMO}{\text{here}} \]

AI.tldr: A language-aware information-maximization approach (LIMO) for transductive few-shot CLIP that uses mutual information, a KL penalty toward text-driven zero-shot predictions, and cross-entropy with labeled shots, combined with parameter-efficient fine-tuning; yields large gains over recent transductive CLIP methods and strong inductive baselines; code released.
AI.motivation: Transductive few-shot learning in vision-language models is underexplored and potentially ripe for gains by marrying information-theoretic objectives with efficient fine-tuning, enabling data-efficient adaptation of VLMs like CLIP.
AI.method: Introduce LIMO loss that combines (i) mutual information between visual inputs and textual class descriptions, (ii) KL divergence penalizing deviation from text-driven zero-shot predictions, and (iii) standard cross-entropy on labeled shots; explore parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) strategies rather than full fine-tuning in the transductive few-shot setting.
AI.result: LIMO outperforms recent transductive few-shot CLIP methods by a large margin and provides significant gains over the best inductive methods, according to comprehensive evaluations; code is publicly available.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates the potential of transductive few-shot learning for vision-language models when combined with information-theoretic objectives and PEFT; suggests further exploration of PEFT approaches in transductive VLM fine-tuning and release of open-source implementation.

title: Data Cartography for Detecting Memorization Hotspots and Guiding Data Interventions in Generative Models
comment:
6 pages, 2 figures, 1 table; Presented at the 42nd International
  Conference on Machine Learning (ICML), winning the "Best Poster" award at
  ICML's workshop for data in generative models (DIG-BUGS)
summary:
Modern generative models risk overfitting and unintentionally memorizing rare
training examples, which can be extracted by adversaries or inflate benchmark
performance. We propose Generative Data Cartography (GenDataCarto), a
data-centric framework that assigns each pretraining sample a difficulty score
(early-epoch loss) and a memorization score (frequency of ``forget events''),
then partitions examples into four quadrants to guide targeted pruning and
up-/down-weighting. We prove that our memorization score lower-bounds classical
influence under smoothness assumptions and that down-weighting
high-memorization hotspots provably decreases the generalization gap via
uniform stability bounds. Empirically, GenDataCarto reduces synthetic canary
extraction success by over 40\% at just 10\% data pruning, while increasing
validation perplexity by less than 0.5\%. These results demonstrate that
principled data interventions can dramatically mitigate leakage with minimal
cost to generative performance.

AI.tldr: GenDataCarto introduces a data-centric framework that scores training samples by difficulty (early loss) and memorization (forget events), partitions into four quadrants, and uses pruning and weighting to reduce leakage (canaries) with minimal impact on generative performance.
AI.motivation: Generative models are prone to overfitting and memorizing rare training examples, which can leak via adversaries or inflate benchmark results. A data-centric approach, rather than purely model-centric defenses, can mitigate memorization while preserving usefulness.
AI.method: For each pretraining sample, compute a difficulty score from early-epoch loss and a memorization score from the frequency of forget events. Partition samples into four quadrants and apply targeted pruning and up-/down-weighting accordingly. The paper proves that memorization score lower-bounds classical influence under smoothness assumptions and that down-weighting high-memorization hotspots decreases the generalization gap via uniform stability bounds.
AI.result: Empirically, GenDataCarto reduces synthetic canary extraction success by over 40% at just 10% data pruning, while increasing validation perplexity by less than 0.5%. The approach yields leakage reduction with minimal degradation of generative performance.
AI.conclusion: Principled data interventions like GenDataCarto can dramatically mitigate leakage in generative models with modest costs to performance, highlighting the value of data-centric pruning and weighting strategies to improve privacy and generalization.

title: Multi-Agent Data Visualization and Narrative Generation
summary:
Recent advancements in the field of AI agents have impacted the way we work,
enabling greater automation and collaboration between humans and agents. In the
data visualization field, multi-agent systems can be useful for employing
agents throughout the entire data-to-communication pipeline. We present a
lightweight multi-agent system that automates the data analysis workflow, from
data exploration to generating coherent visual narratives for insight
communication. Our approach combines a hybrid multi-agent architecture with
deterministic components, strategically externalizing critical logic from LLMs
to improve transparency and reliability. The system delivers granular, modular
outputs that enable surgical modifications without full regeneration,
supporting sustainable human-AI collaboration. We evaluated our system across 4
diverse datasets, demonstrating strong generalizability, narrative quality, and
computational efficiency with minimal dependencies.

AI.tldr: A lightweight hybrid multi-agent system automates data analysis and narrative generation for data visualization, externalizes key logic from LLMs to improve transparency, and offers modular, updatable outputs; evaluated on four datasets showing good generalizability, narrative quality, and efficiency.
AI.motivation: To address reliability and transparency issues of LLMs in end-to-end data-to-visualization pipelines, enabling scalable, collaborative human-AI data storytelling.
AI.method: Hybrid multi-agent architecture with deterministic components; externalize critical logic from LLMs; data exploration to narrative generation; modular outputs enabling surgical edits without full regeneration; evaluated on four diverse datasets for generalizability, narrative quality, and efficiency; minimal dependencies.
AI.result: Demonstrated strong generalizability, high narrative quality, and computational efficiency; produced granular modular outputs, and supported sustainable human-AI collaboration with low dependencies.
AI.conclusion: The approach enhances transparency and reliability in AI-assisted data analysis and storytelling, improving efficiency and collaboration across the data-to-communication pipeline.

title: Embodied Spatial Intelligence: from Implicit Scene Modeling to Spatial Reasoning
summary:
This thesis introduces "Embodied Spatial Intelligence" to address the
challenge of creating robots that can perceive and act in the real world based
on natural language instructions. To bridge the gap between Large Language
Models (LLMs) and physical embodiment, we present contributions on two fronts:
scene representation and spatial reasoning. For perception, we develop robust,
scalable, and accurate scene representations using implicit neural models, with
contributions in self-supervised camera calibration, high-fidelity depth field
generation, and large-scale reconstruction. For spatial reasoning, we enhance
the spatial capabilities of LLMs by introducing a novel navigation benchmark, a
method for grounding language in 3D, and a state-feedback mechanism to improve
long-horizon decision-making. This work lays a foundation for robots that can
robustly perceive their surroundings and intelligently act upon complex,
language-based commands.

AI.tldr: A thesis introducing Embodied Spatial Intelligence to connect LLMs with robots for real-world language-guided perception and action, via implicit scene representations and 3D-grounded spatial reasoning, including a new navigation benchmark and a state-feedback mechanism for long-horizon planning.
AI.motivation: Bridge the gap between Large Language Models and physical embodiment to enable robots to understand and act from natural language in real-world environments, with robust perception and long-horizon decision-making.
AI.method: Perception uses implicit neural scene representations with self-supervised camera calibration, high-fidelity depth field generation, and large-scale reconstruction. Spatial reasoning enhances LLMs with a navigation benchmark, grounding language in 3D, and a state-feedback mechanism to improve long-horizon planning.
AI.result: Proposes a cohesive framework with key building blocks: advanced perception pipelines (implicit representations, calibration, depth, 3D reconstruction) and a 3D-grounded spatial reasoning setup (navigation benchmark, language grounding, state-feedback). Demonstrates foundations for robust, language-guided robotic action.
AI.conclusion: Lays a foundation for robots that robustly perceive their surroundings and intelligently act upon complex, language-based commands.

title: MorphGen: Morphology-Guided Representation Learning for Robust Single-Domain Generalization in Histopathological Cancer Classification
summary:
Domain generalization in computational histopathology is hindered by
heterogeneity in whole slide images (WSIs), caused by variations in tissue
preparation, staining, and imaging conditions across institutions. Unlike
machine learning systems, pathologists rely on domain-invariant morphological
cues such as nuclear atypia (enlargement, irregular contours, hyperchromasia,
chromatin texture, spatial disorganization), structural atypia (abnormal
architecture and gland formation), and overall morphological atypia that remain
diagnostic across diverse settings. Motivated by this, we hypothesize that
explicitly modeling biologically robust nuclear morphology and spatial
organization will enable the learning of cancer representations that are
resilient to domain shifts. We propose MorphGen (Morphology-Guided
Generalization), a method that integrates histopathology images, augmentations,
and nuclear segmentation masks within a supervised contrastive learning
framework. By aligning latent representations of images and nuclear masks,
MorphGen prioritizes diagnostic features such as nuclear and morphological
atypia and spatial organization over staining artifacts and domain-specific
features. To further enhance out-of-distribution robustness, we incorporate
stochastic weight averaging (SWA), steering optimization toward flatter minima.
Attention map analyses revealed that MorphGen primarily relies on nuclear
morphology, cellular composition, and spatial cell organization within tumors
or normal regions for final classification. Finally, we demonstrate resilience
of the learned representations to image corruptions (such as staining
artifacts) and adversarial attacks, showcasing not only OOD generalization but
also addressing critical vulnerabilities in current deep learning systems for
digital pathology. Code, datasets, and trained models are available at:
https://github.com/hikmatkhan/MorphGen

AI.tldr: MorphGen is a morphology-guided, contrastive learning framework for domain-generalization in histopathology that aligns image representations with nuclear segmentation masks, uses augmentations and SWA, and relies on nuclear morphology and spatial organization to achieve robust OOD performance, including resistance to staining artifacts and adversarial attacks.
AI.motivation: Domain shifts across institutions (staining, preparation, imaging) cause generalization failure in WSI analysis. Pathologists rely on invariant nuclear and morphological cues, suggesting that encoding these priors could improve robustness to domain variability.
AI.method: MorphGen integrates histology images, augmentations, and nuclear segmentation masks into a supervised contrastive learning setup. It aligns latent representations of images and nuclear masks, uses stochastic weight averaging to favor flatter minima, and analyzes attention maps to verify reliance on nuclear morphology and spatial organization.
AI.result: The learned representations emphasize nuclear morphology, cellular composition, and tumor/normal spatial organization. MorphGen shows resilience to image corruption (e.g., staining artifacts) and adversarial attacks, indicating improved out-of-distribution generalization.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating biology-driven priors—nuclear morphology and tissue organization—enables robust domain-generalizable representations in computational histopathology, with accessible code/models/datasets on the project page.

title: Learning to Refine: Self-Refinement of Parallel Reasoning in LLMs
summary:
To further enhance the ability of Large Language Models (LLMs) to solve
complex, multi-step reasoning problems, test-time scaling (TTS) methods have
gained widespread attention. Existing approaches such as Best-of-N and majority
voting are limited as their performance depends on the quality of candidate
responses, making them unable to produce a correct solution when all candidates
are incorrect. Introducing an additional model to select the best response also
incurs significant deployment costs. To this end, we introduce Generative
Self-Refinement (GSR), a novel parallel test-time scaling framework where a
unified model first generates a set of candidate responses in parallel and then
performs self-refinement to synthesize a new superior solution based on a
prompt consisting of the problem and these candidates. However, LLMs struggle
to perform refinement effectively when prompted directly. Therefore, we design
a hybrid training pipeline by jointly optimizing for two complementary
objectives, solving problems directly and refining candidate responses.
Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art
performance across five mathematical benchmarks. We further show that this
learned self-refinement skill is a model-agnostic enhancement, robust across
different model scales and generalizing to out-of-distribution reasoning tasks.

AI.tldr: GSR is a parallel test-time scaling framework that generates candidate solutions with a unified model, then self-refines to produce a superior answer, addressing Best-of-N limitations and avoiding extra deployment costs.
AI.motivation: LLMs struggle with multi-step reasoning and decision quality depends on candidate responses. Traditional test-time strategies like Best-of-N and majority voting fail when all candidates are incorrect, and adding a separate selector model increases deployment costs.
AI.method: GSR first generates multiple candidate responses in parallel and then uses self-refinement to synthesize a superior solution from a prompt that includes the problem and the candidates. The model is trained with a hybrid objective that jointly optimizes direct problem solving and refinement capabilities.
AI.result: The approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on five mathematical benchmarks and the learned self-refinement skill is model-agnostic, robust across model scales, and generalizes to out-of-distribution reasoning tasks.
AI.conclusion: GSR provides a cost-efficient, scalable enhancement for LLM reasoning by enabling effective self-refinement, reducing reliance on candidate quality and limiting deployment costs.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Based Analysis of Ice Cream Melting Behavior Under Various Ingredients
summary:
The stability of ice cream during melting is a critical factor for consumer's
acceptance and product quality. With the commonly added stabilizer to improve
texture, structure and slower melting as the factors to analyze. This report
explores the effects of locust bean gum, guar gum, maltodextrin, and
carrageenan on the melting behavior of homemade ice cream. The main objective
was to assess how these additives influence melting resistance and to identify
a more cost-effective recipe formulation. Ice cream samples incorporating each
additive were prepared and subjected to melting tests under controlled
conditions. Timelapse recordings were used to capture and analyze the
progression of melting over time. Python and OpenCV is used for process and
analysis. Observations revealed that all samples retained a foam-like structure
even after melting, suggesting the stabilizers contributed to the formation of
a stable air-cell matrix. Furthermore, when the melted samples were re-frozen
and subsequently melted again, they displayed increased sturdiness, indicating
improved resilience of the ice cream structure. Comparative analysis of the
different stabilizers highlighted variations in their effectiveness, with some
offering stronger melting resistance and structural support than others.
Overall, the findings provide insights into the functional roles of commonly
used food additives in ice cream formulation. By evaluating both performance
and cost, this study demonstrates the potential for developing recipes that
balance durability with economic efficiency, contributing to practical
applications in both small-scale and commercial ice cream production.

AI.tldr: Stabilizers (locust bean gum, guar gum, maltodextrin, carrageenan) enhance ice cream melting resistance and structural resilience; different stabilizers vary in effectiveness; freezing cycles can improve sturdiness; enables cost-effective formulations.
AI.motivation: To understand how common stabilizers affect melting behavior of ice cream and identify cost-effective formulations.
AI.method: Prepare ice cream samples with each additive, conduct controlled melting tests, record with timelapse, analyze using Python and OpenCV.
AI.result: All samples preserved a foam-like structure post-melting; stabilizers likely fostered a stable air-cell matrix; refreezing increased structural sturdiness; stabilizers varied in effectiveness; some offered stronger melting resistance and support at potentially lower cost.
AI.conclusion: Stabilizers play key roles in melting resistance and structure; results guide formulation of durable, economical ice creams for small-scale and commercial production.

title: Extended Diffeomorphism for Real-Time Motion Replication in Workspaces with Different Spatial Arrangements
summary:
This paper presents two types of extended diffeomorphism designs to
compensate for spatial placement differences between robot workspaces.
Teleoperation of multiple robots is attracting attention to expand the
utilization of the robot embodiment. Real-time reproduction of robot motion
would facilitate the efficient execution of similar tasks by multiple robots. A
challenge in the motion reproduction is compensating for the spatial
arrangement errors of target keypoints in robot workspaces. This paper proposes
a methodology for smooth mappings that transform primary robot poses into
follower robot poses based on the predefined key points in each workspace.
Through a picking task experiment using a dual-arm UR5 robot, this study
demonstrates that the proposed mapping generation method can balance lower
mapping errors for precise operation and lower mapping gradients for smooth
replicated movement.

AI.tldr: Two extended diffeomorphism designs map primary to follower robot poses using predefined workspace key points, enabling smoother and more accurate teleoperation across different workspaces; validated with a dual-arm UR5, showing improved precision and motion smoothness.
AI.motivation: To compensate spatial placement differences between robot workspaces for real-time multi-robot teleoperation and faithful motion reproduction.
AI.method: Develop two extended diffeomorphism designs that generate smooth pose mappings between robots based on predefined key points in each workspace, balancing mapping error (precision) and gradient (smoothness); validated via a dual-arm UR5 picking task.
AI.result: The mapping method reduces both pose error and motion gradient, enabling accurate and smooth replicated movements across workspaces in teleoperation.
AI.conclusion: The proposed extended diffeomorphism-based mapping enhances real-time, precise, and smooth multi-robot teleoperation across spatially different workspaces.

title: Towards Adaptive Visual Token Pruning for Large Multimodal Models
summary:
Large Multimodal Models (LMMs) have achieved significant success across
various tasks. These models usually encode visual inputs into dense token
sequences, which are then concatenated with textual tokens and jointly
processed by a language model. However, the increased token count substantially
raises computational and memory costs during inference. Token pruning has
emerged as a promising approach to address this issue. Existing token pruning
methods often rely on costly calibration or suboptimal importance metrics,
leading to redundant retained tokens. In this paper, we analyze the redundancy
differences between visual and textual tokens and propose pruning exclusively
on visual tokens. Based on this, we propose a visual token pruning strategy
that explicitly preserves both cross-modal alignment and intra-modal
informational diversity. We introduce a mutual information-based token pruning
strategy that removes visual tokens semantically misaligned with textual
tokens, effectively preserving the alignment between the visual and textual
modalities. To further improve the representational quality of the retained
tokens, we additionally prune redundant visual tokens by maximizing the
expected pairwise distances in the embedding space, which is solved efficiently
with a greedy algorithm. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method
maintains strong performance while reducing tokens by 88.9% on models such as
LLaVA-1.5-7B and LLaVA-NEXT-7B, resulting in a 56.7% improvement in inference
speed.

AI.tldr: Proposes visual-token pruning for large multimodal models (LMMs) to reduce inference cost by pruning only visual tokens. The approach uses a mutual information-based strategy to preserve cross-modal alignment and a diversity-based greedy pruning to maximize embedding-space dispersion, achieving 88.9% token reduction and 56.7% speedup on LLaVA-1.5-7B and LLaVA-NEXT-7B while maintaining performance.
AI.motivation: Reduce computational and memory burden of LMMs without sacrificing cross-modal alignment. Visual tokens contribute disproportionately to token counts; pruning them selectively aims to cut cost while preserving textual information and cross-modal fidelity.
AI.method: 1) Mutual information-based pruning to remove visual tokens semantically misaligned with textual tokens, preserving cross-modal alignment. 2) Greedy pruning to maximize expected pairwise distances among retained visual tokens in embedding space, enhancing intra-modal representational diversity. 3) Pruning is restricted to visual tokens; textual tokens are kept intact. 4) Efficient algorithm to enable scalable pruning during inference.
AI.result: Significant token reduction (88.9%) with substantial speedup (56.7%) on specific LMMs (LLaVA-1.5-7B and LLaVA-NEXT-7B) while preserving strong performance.
AI.conclusion: Focusing pruning on visual tokens and optimizing for both cross-modal alignment and intra-modal diversity yields efficient LMM inference. The proposed MI-based alignment pruning plus diversity-driven pruning effectively reduces tokens and accelerates inference without major performance losses.

title: Centralized vs. Federated Learning for Educational Data Mining: A Comparative Study on Student Performance Prediction with SAEB Microdata
comment:
This paper has been prepared to be submitted Brazilian Journal of
  Informatics in Education - RBIE
summary:
The application of data mining and artificial intelligence in education
offers unprecedented potential for personalizing learning and early
identification of at-risk students. However, the practical use of these
techniques faces a significant barrier in privacy legislation, such as Brazil's
General Data Protection Law (LGPD), which restricts the centralization of
sensitive student data. To resolve this challenge, privacy-preserving
computational approaches are required. The present study evaluates the
feasibility and effectiveness of Federated Learning, specifically the FedProx
algorithm, to predict student performance using microdata from the Brazilian
Basic Education Assessment System (SAEB). A Deep Neural Network (DNN) model was
trained in a federated manner, simulating a scenario with 50 schools, and its
performance was rigorously benchmarked against a centralized eXtreme Gradient
Boosting (XGBoost) model. The analysis, conducted on a universe of over two
million student records, revealed that the centralized model achieved an
accuracy of 63.96%. Remarkably, the federated model reached a peak accuracy of
61.23%, demonstrating a marginal performance loss in exchange for a robust
privacy guarantee. The results indicate that Federated Learning is a viable and
effective solution for building collaborative predictive models in the
Brazilian educational context, in alignment with the requirements of the LGPD.

AI.tldr: Federated Learning with FedProx applied to SAEB data across 50 Brazilian schools yields performance close to a centralized model while preserving privacy per LGPD (61.23% vs 63.96% accuracy; 2.73-point drop; dataset >2M records).
AI.motivation: Privacy legislation (LGPD) restricts centralizing sensitive student data; need privacy-preserving ML to personalize learning and identify at-risk students.
AI.method: Federated learning using FedProx with a Deep Neural Network trained across 50 simulated schools; compared against a centralized XGBoost model; evaluation on SAEB microdata >2M records.
AI.result: Centralized model accuracy 63.96%; federated model accuracy 61.23%; performance loss is modest, indicating federated learning is viable for this context.
AI.conclusion: Federated Learning is a viable and effective approach for collaborative predictive modeling in Brazilian education under LGPD, enabling privacy-preserving data utilization without substantial loss in predictive performance.

title: LLM-Assisted Iterative Evolution with Swarm Intelligence Toward SuperBrain
summary:
We propose a novel SuperBrain framework for collective intelligence, grounded
in the co-evolution of large language models (LLMs) and human users. Unlike
static prompt engineering or isolated agent simulations, our approach
emphasizes a dynamic pathway from Subclass Brain to Superclass Brain: (1) A
Subclass Brain arises from persistent, personalized interaction between a user
and an LLM, forming a cognitive dyad with adaptive learning memory. (2) Through
GA-assisted forward-backward evolution, these dyads iteratively refine prompts
and task performance. (3) Multiple Subclass Brains coordinate via Swarm
Intelligence, optimizing across multi-objective fitness landscapes and
exchanging distilled heuristics. (4) Their standardized behaviors and cognitive
signatures integrate into a Superclass Brain, an emergent meta-intelligence
capable of abstraction, generalization and self-improvement. We outline the
theoretical constructs, present initial implementations (e.g., UAV scheduling,
KU/KI keyword filtering) and propose a registry for cross-dyad knowledge
consolidation. This work provides both a conceptual foundation and an
architectural roadmap toward scalable, explainable and ethically aligned
collective AI.

AI.tldr: A dynamic, co-evolutionary framework that builds a hierarchy from personalized user–LLM dyads (Subclass Brains) to a pooled Superclass Brain via GA-driven prompt evolution and swarm coordination, culminating in an emergent meta-intelligence for scalable, explainable collective AI; includes prototype demos (e.g., UAV scheduling, keyword filtering) and a registry for cross-dyad knowledge.
AI.motivation: Addresses limitations of static prompt engineering and isolated agent simulations by enabling adaptive learning, persistent memory, and scalable collective reasoning; aims for explainability, ethical alignment, and generalization across tasks.
AI.method: Four-stage pathway: (1) Form Subclass Brains through persistent user–LLM interaction with adaptive memory; (2) Apply GA-assisted forward–backward evolution to iteratively refine prompts and task performance; (3) Coordinate Subclass Brains via Swarm Intelligence to optimize multi-objective fitness and exchange distilled heuristics; (4) Integrate standardized behaviors and cognitive signatures into a Superclass Brain as an emergent meta-intelligence; outline architecture and a registry for cross-dyad knowledge consolidation.
AI.result: The abstract presents a conceptual framework with initial implementations but does not report empirical results; demonstrations are described at a high level (e.g., UAV scheduling, KU/KI keyword filtering) with an emphasis on architecture and theory.
AI.conclusion: Offers a conceptual foundation and architectural roadmap for scalable, explainable, and ethically aligned collective AI, highlighting abstraction, generalization, and self-improvement as emergent properties of the SuperBrain paradigm.

title: FLUID: A Fine-Grained Lightweight Urban Signalized-Intersection Dataset of Dense Conflict Trajectories
summary:
The trajectory data of traffic participants (TPs) is a fundamental resource
for evaluating traffic conditions and optimizing policies, especially at urban
intersections. Although data acquisition using drones is efficient, existing
datasets still have limitations in scene representativeness, information
richness, and data fidelity. This study introduces FLUID, comprising a
fine-grained trajectory dataset that captures dense conflicts at typical urban
signalized intersections, and a lightweight, full-pipeline framework for
drone-based trajectory processing. FLUID covers three distinct intersection
types, with approximately 5 hours of recording time and featuring over 20,000
TPs across 8 categories. Notably, the dataset averages two vehicle conflicts
per minute, involving roughly 25% of all motor vehicles. FLUID provides
comprehensive data, including trajectories, traffic signals, maps, and raw
videos. Comparison with the DataFromSky platform and ground-truth measurements
validates its high spatio-temporal accuracy. Through a detailed classification
of motor vehicle conflicts and violations, FLUID reveals a diversity of
interactive behaviors, demonstrating its value for human preference mining,
traffic behavior modeling, and autonomous driving research.

AI.tldr: A drone-derived, fine-grained trajectory dataset (FLUID) at urban signalized intersections, with 5h of data, 20k participants, 8 categories, and a full processing pipeline; validated against ground truth and DataFromSky; useful for traffic science and autonomous driving.
AI.motivation: Address limitations of current datasets—scene representativeness, information richness, and data fidelity—by providing dense, high-quality trajectories including conflicts, signals, maps, and video.
AI.method: Collect data via a lightweight drone-based processing pipeline across three intersection types; record ~5 hours; capture 20k trajectories across 8 categories; classify and extract conflicts/violations; provide comprehensive data including trajectories, traffic signals, maps, and raw videos.
AI.result: FLUID achieves high spatio-temporal accuracy; average two vehicle conflicts per minute; ~25% of motor vehicles involved; rich interactive behaviors observed; validated against DataFromSky and ground-truth measurements.
AI.conclusion: FLUID offers a valuable, versatile dataset and processing framework for traffic research, enabling human preference mining, traffic behavior modeling, and autonomous driving research; enhances scene coverage, data fidelity, and reproducibility for method development.

title: CryptoFace: End-to-End Encrypted Face Recognition
summary:
Face recognition is central to many authentication, security, and
personalized applications. Yet, it suffers from significant privacy risks,
particularly arising from unauthorized access to sensitive biometric data. This
paper introduces CryptoFace, the first end-to-end encrypted face recognition
system with fully homomorphic encryption (FHE). It enables secure processing of
facial data across all stages of a face-recognition process--feature
extraction, storage, and matching--without exposing raw images or features. We
introduce a mixture of shallow patch convolutional networks to support
higher-dimensional tensors via patch-based processing while reducing the
multiplicative depth and, thus, inference latency. Parallel FHE evaluation of
these networks ensures near-resolution-independent latency. On standard face
recognition benchmarks, CryptoFace significantly accelerates inference and
increases verification accuracy compared to the state-of-the-art FHE neural
networks adapted for face recognition. CryptoFace will facilitate secure face
recognition systems requiring robust and provable security. The code is
available at https://github.com/human-analysis/CryptoFace.

AI.tldr: End-to-end encrypted face recognition using Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) called CryptoFace; uses patch-based shallow CNNs to enable secure feature extraction, storage, and matching with reduced multiplicative depth and near-latency; outperforms existing FHE-based face recognition methods.
AI.motivation: Biometric privacy risks: unauthorized access to raw face data; need secure processing across all stages of face recognition without exposing sensitive information.
AI.method: Proposes a mixture of shallow patch convolutional networks to handle high-dimensional tensors via patch-based processing; reduces multiplicative depth and inference latency; employs parallel FHE evaluation for near-resolution-independent latency.
AI.result: On standard face recognition benchmarks, CryptoFace accelerates inference and improves verification accuracy compared to state-of-the-art FHE neural networks adapted for face recognition.
AI.conclusion: CryptoFace enables secure, provable-privacy face recognition; code released, paving the way for robust privacy-preserving biometric systems.

title: Yet Unnoticed in LSTM: Binary Tree Based Input Reordering, Weight Regularization, and Gate Nonlinearization
summary:
LSTM models used in current Machine Learning literature and applications, has
a promising solution for permitting long term information using gating
mechanisms that forget and reduce effect of current input information. However,
even with this pipeline, they do not optimally focus on specific old index or
long-term information. This paper elaborates upon input reordering approaches
to prioritize certain input indices. Moreover, no LSTM based approach is found
in the literature that examines weight normalization while choosing the right
weight and exponent of Lp norms through main supervised loss function. In this
paper, we find out which norm best finds relationship between weights to either
smooth or sparsify them. Lastly, gates, as weighted representations of inputs
and states, which control reduction-extent of current input versus previous
inputs (~ state), are not nonlinearized enough (through a small FFNN). As
analogous to attention mechanisms, gates easily filter current information to
bold (emphasize on) past inputs. Nonlinearized gates can more easily tune up to
peculiar nonlinearities of specific input in the past. This type of
nonlinearization is not proposed in the literature, to the best of author's
knowledge. The proposed approaches are implemented and compared with a simple
LSTM to understand their performance in text classification tasks. The results
show they improve accuracy of LSTM.

AI.tldr: Nonlinearized gating, input reordering, and weight-norm optimization to enhance LSTM for text classification, showing improved accuracy over standard LSTM.
AI.motivation: LSTMs' gates and weight norms don't optimally emphasize long-term or specific past inputs; exploring input ordering, Lp-norm weight selection, and nonlinear gate modeling could capture richer temporal dependencies and attention-like effects.
AI.method: 1) Propose input reordering to prioritize certain input indices; 2) study weight normalization by selecting appropriate Lp norm and exponent via main supervised loss; 3) replace/augment gates with a small feedforward network to introduce nonlinearity; 4) implement variants and compare to baseline LSTM on text classification tasks.
AI.result: Empirical results indicate improved accuracy of LSTM-based models over the simple baseline in text classification tasks; proposed methods yield gains.
AI.conclusion: Nonlinearizing gates and reordering inputs, along with norm-aware weight selection, can enhance LSTM performance for text classification, offering an attention-like mechanism and richer nonlinear modeling.

title: Text-to-Layout: A Generative Workflow for Drafting Architectural Floor Plans Using LLMs
summary:
This paper presents the development of an AI-powered workflow that uses Large
Language Models (LLMs) to assist in drafting schematic architectural floor
plans from natural language prompts. The proposed system interprets textual
input to automatically generate layout options including walls, doors, windows,
and furniture arrangements. It combines prompt engineering, a furniture
placement refinement algorithm, and Python scripting to produce spatially
coherent draft plans compatible with design tools such as Autodesk Revit. A
case study of a mid-sized residential layout demonstrates the approach's
ability to generate functional and structured outputs with minimal manual
effort. The workflow is designed for transparent replication, with all key
prompt specifications documented to enable independent implementation by other
researchers. In addition, the generated models preserve the full range of
Revit-native parametric attributes required for direct integration into
professional BIM processes.

AI.tldr: AI-powered workflow uses LLMs to draft schematic architectural floor plans from natural language prompts, producing walls, doors, windows, and furniture layouts that are compatible with Revit; demonstrated via a mid-size residential case study; aims for replication-ready BIM outputs with minimal manual effort.
AI.motivation: Automate and accelerate early-stage architectural drafting while delivering BIM-ready, parametric outputs; enable transparent, replicable workflows and bridge natural language prompts with spatial design.
AI.method: Combine prompt engineering, a furniture placement refinement algorithm, and Python scripting to interpret natural language prompts and generate layout options (walls, doors, windows, furniture). Produce spatially coherent draft plans compatible with design tools such as Autodesk Revit. Document key prompts to enable independent replication by researchers. Validate with a mid-sized residential case study.
AI.result: Generated functional and structured draft plans with minimal manual effort; models preserve Revit-native parametric attributes for direct BIM integration; case study demonstrates practical feasibility.
AI.conclusion: The workflow supports transparent replication and easy adoption by researchers and practitioners, with direct integration into professional BIM processes; demonstrated feasibility in a mid-sized residential layout; potential for broader application and refinement.

title: NeuralSVCD for Efficient Swept Volume Collision Detection
summary:
Robot manipulation in unstructured environments requires efficient and
reliable Swept Volume Collision Detection (SVCD) for safe motion planning.
Traditional discrete methods potentially miss collisions between these points,
whereas SVCD continuously checks for collisions along the entire trajectory.
Existing SVCD methods typically face a trade-off between efficiency and
accuracy, limiting practical use. In this paper, we introduce NeuralSVCD, a
novel neural encoder-decoder architecture tailored to overcome this trade-off.
Our approach leverages shape locality and temporal locality through distributed
geometric representations and temporal optimization. This enhances
computational efficiency without sacrificing accuracy. Comprehensive
experiments show that NeuralSVCD consistently outperforms existing
state-of-the-art SVCD methods in terms of both collision detection accuracy and
computational efficiency, demonstrating its robust applicability across diverse
robotic manipulation scenarios. Code and videos are available at
https://neuralsvcd.github.io/.

AI.tldr: NeuralSVCD introduces a neural encoder–decoder for swept-volume collision detection that achieves higher accuracy and efficiency than existing SVCD methods by exploiting shape and temporal locality in a distributed geometric representation, enabling robust, real-time capable collision detection for robotic manipulation.
AI.motivation: Traditional SVCD methods face a trade-off between speed and accuracy, risking missed collisions. A reliable and efficient collision detector along entire trajectories is essential for safe motion planning in unstructured environments.
AI.method: Proposes NeuralSVCD: a neural encoder–decoder architecture that exploits shape locality and temporal locality using distributed geometric representations and temporal optimization to accurately and efficiently detect collisions along trajectories.
AI.result: Comprehensive experiments show NeuralSVCD outperforms state-of-the-art SVCD methods in collision detection accuracy and computational efficiency across diverse manipulation scenarios; code and videos available.
AI.conclusion: NeuralSVCD offers robust applicability for safe robot manipulation, delivering a favorable accuracy–efficiency balance that makes SVCD practical for real-time planning.

title: LUT-Fuse: Towards Extremely Fast Infrared and Visible Image Fusion via Distillation to Learnable Look-Up Tables
summary:
Current advanced research on infrared and visible image fusion primarily
focuses on improving fusion performance, often neglecting the applicability on
real-time fusion devices. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that
towards extremely fast fusion via distillation to learnable lookup tables
specifically designed for image fusion, termed as LUT-Fuse. Firstly, we develop
a look-up table structure that utilizing low-order approximation encoding and
high-level joint contextual scene encoding, which is well-suited for
multi-modal fusion. Moreover, given the lack of ground truth in multi-modal
image fusion, we naturally proposed the efficient LUT distillation strategy
instead of traditional quantization LUT methods. By integrating the performance
