AI.motivation: Vision-Language Models are vulnerable to adversarial inputs and toxic prompts. Activation steering methods exist but rely on task-specific prompts, suffer suboptimal performance and can hurt visual grounding. A general, efficient defense that maintains performance is needed.
AI.method: Stage I computes adaptive, layer-specific steering vectors from diverse data sources to suppress harmful behaviors during inference. Stage II refines these vectors with sequence-level preference optimization, incorporating automated toxicity assessments and visual-consistency rewards based on caption-image alignment.
AI.result: The approach improves safety against attacks that use activation steering and preference optimization, while maintaining strong performance on benign tasks and preserving visual understanding capabilities. A two-stage design balances efficiency with deeper policy refinement; code and models are to be released for reproducibility.
AI.conclusion: A two-stage SPO-VLM framework effectively merges lightweight mitigation with policy refinement to achieve robust, safe VLM behavior without sacrificing performance; the work advocates for reproducibility through released resources.

title: Pre-trained knowledge elevates large language models beyond traditional chemical reaction optimizers
summary:
Modern optimization in experimental chemistry employs algorithmic search
through black-box parameter spaces. Here we demonstrate that pre-trained
knowledge in large language models (LLMs) fundamentally changes this paradigm.
Using six fully enumerated categorical reaction datasets (768 - 5,684
experiments), we benchmark LLM-guided optimization (LLM-GO) against Bayesian
optimization (BO) and random sampling. Frontier LLMs consistently match or
exceed BO performance across five single-objective datasets, with advantages
growing as parameter complexity increases and high-performing conditions become
scarce (<5% of space). BO retains superiority only for explicit multi-objective
trade-offs. To understand these contrasting behaviors, we introduce a
topology-agnostic information theory framework quantifying sampling diversity
throughout optimization campaigns. This analysis reveals that LLMs maintain
systematically higher exploration entropy than BO across all datasets while
achieving superior performance, with advantages most pronounced in
solution-scarce parameter spaces where high-entropy exploration typically fails
- suggesting that pre-trained domain knowledge enables more effective
navigation of chemical parameter space rather than replacing structured
exploration strategies. To enable transparent benchmarking and community
validation, we release Iron Mind (https://gomes.andrew.cmu.edu/iron-mind), a
no-code platform for side-by-side evaluation of human, algorithmic, and LLM
optimization campaigns with public leaderboards and complete trajectories. Our
findings establish that LLM-GO excels precisely where traditional methods
struggle: complex categorical spaces requiring domain understanding rather than
mathematical optimization.

AI.tldr: LLM-guided optimization (LLM-GO) using pre-trained knowledge can match or exceed Bayesian optimization in complex categorical chemistry spaces, outperforming in sparse regions; a topology-agnostic information-theory framework explains higher exploration entropy; Iron Mind platform enables benchmarking.
AI.motivation: Traditional optimization in experimental chemistry struggles with high-dimensional, sparse, categorical spaces. Pre-trained LLMs offer domain knowledge that may improve exploration and navigation of chemical parameter space.
AI.method: Evaluate six fully enumerated categorical reaction datasets (768–5,684 experiments). Benchmark LLM-GO against Bayesian optimization and random sampling across single- and multi-objective tasks. Introduce a topology-agnostic information theory framework to quantify sampling diversity (exploration entropy). Release Iron Mind, a no-code benchmarking platform for side-by-side human/algorithm/LLM optimization with public leaderboards.
AI.result: Frontier LLMs match or exceed Bayesian optimization performance on five single-objective datasets; advantages grow with parameter complexity and when high-performing regions are scarce (<5% of search space). BO remains superior only for explicit multi-objective trade-offs. LLMs exhibit higher exploration entropy while achieving superior performance across datasets, with the gap most pronounced in sparse, high-quality regions.
AI.conclusion: LLM-GO excels where traditional optimization struggles: complex, domain-rich categorical spaces. Pre-trained domain knowledge enables more effective navigation of chemical parameter space rather than replacing structured exploration; Iron Mind enables transparent benchmarking and community validation.

title: Aligning Reasoning LLMs for Materials Discovery with Physics-aware Rejection Sampling
summary:
AI-driven materials discovery that couples automated experimentation with
algorithmic decision-making requires process aware recipe to property
predictors that are accurate, calibrated, and physically admissible. We
approach this as a reasoning problem with large reasoning models (LRMs). To
instill reasoning capability into language models, we curate reasoning traces
from a teacher model to train a student model. However, most training pipelines
select reasoning traces using binary correctness or learned preference signals
that poorly reflect physical admissibility. We introduce Physics-aware
Rejection Sampling (PaRS), a training-time trace selection scheme that favors
traces consistent with fundamental physics and numerically close to targets,
with lightweight halting to control compute. We instantiate our framework with
a large student model fine-tuned on traces synthesized by a larger teacher
model, and evaluate under matched token budgets against various rejection
sampling baselines. Our method improves accuracy and calibration, reduces
physics-violation rates, and lowers sampling cost relative to baselines. These
results indicate that modest, domain-aware constraints combined with
trace-level selection provide a practical path toward reliable, efficient LRMs
for process-aware property prediction and closed-loop materials design.

AI.tldr: Physics-aware trace sampling (PaRS) enables reliable, calibrated LRMs for process-aware materials discovery by training a student model on physics-consistent reasoning traces generated by a teacher, with selective trace filtering to reduce physics violations and compute cost.
AI.motivation: AI-driven materials discovery requires reasoning models that produce physically admissible, calibrated predictions; existing trace-training signals (binary correctness, learned preferences) poorly reflect physical constraints, hindering reliability and efficiency.
AI.method: Introduce Physics-aware Rejection Sampling (PaRS) for training-time trace selection; use a teacher–student framework where the teacher generates reasoning traces and the student is fine-tuned on traces that are physics-consistent and close to targets, with lightweight halting to control compute; evaluates against rejection sampling baselines under matched token budgets.
AI.result: PaRS improves prediction accuracy and calibration, reduces physics-violation rates, and lowers sampling cost compared with baselines.
AI.conclusion: Combining modest domain-aware constraints with trace-level selection provides a practical path toward reliable, efficient large reasoning models for process-aware property prediction and closed-loop materials design.

title: Vehicle-in-Virtual-Environment (VVE) Method for Developing and Evaluating VRU Safety of Connected and Autonomous Driving with Focus on Bicyclist Safety
summary:
Extensive research has already been conducted in the autonomous driving field
to help vehicles navigate safely and efficiently. At the same time, plenty of
current research on vulnerable road user (VRU) safety is performed which
largely concentrates on perception, localization, or trajectory prediction of
VRUs. However, existing research still exhibits several gaps, including the
lack of a unified planning and collision avoidance system for autonomous
vehicles, limited investigation into delay tolerant control strategies, and the
absence of an efficient and standardized testing methodology. Ensuring VRU
safety remains one of the most pressing challenges in autonomous driving,
particularly in dynamic and unpredictable environments. In this two year
project, we focused on applying the Vehicle in Virtual Environment (VVE) method
to develop, evaluate, and demonstrate safety functions for Vulnerable Road
Users (VRUs) using automated steering and braking of ADS. In this current
second year project report, our primary focus was on enhancing the previous
year results while also considering bicyclist safety.

AI.tldr: Two-year study applying Vehicle in Virtual Environment (VVE) to develop and test safety functions for Vulnerable Road Users (VRUs) using automated steering and braking in ADS, with focus on bicyclist safety and improved testing methodology.
AI.motivation: VRU safety in autonomous driving lags behind perception and prediction; gaps include unified planning/collision avoidance, delay-tolerant control strategies, and standardized testing methods. This project aims to address these gaps using VVE.
AI.method: Use VVE to develop, evaluate, and demonstrate VRU safety functions that integrate automated steering and braking in ADS; second-year focus on enhancing prior results and incorporating bicyclist safety.
AI.result: Progress toward enhanced VRU safety functions and testing methodology; improvements over prior year with demonstrations of concepts in VVE; initial validation for bicyclist safety.
AI.conclusion: The work advances unified VRU safety concepts in ADS via VVE-based evaluation, addressing key gaps and laying groundwork for broader testing and eventual real-world validation, including bicyclist safety.

title: Adaptive Point-Prompt Tuning: Fine-Tuning Heterogeneous Foundation Models for 3D Point Cloud Analysis
summary:
Parameter-efficient fine-tuning strategies for foundation models in 1D
textual and 2D visual analysis have demonstrated remarkable efficacy. However,
due to the scarcity of point cloud data, pre-training large 3D models remains a
challenging task. While many efforts have been made to apply pre-trained visual
models to 3D domains through "high-to-low" mapping, these approaches often lead
to the loss of spatial geometries and lack a generalizable framework for
adapting any modality to 3D. This paper, therefore, attempts to directly
leverage point features to calibrate the heterogeneous foundation model of any
modality for 3D point cloud analysis. Specifically, we propose the Adaptive
Point-Prompt Tuning (APPT) method, which fine-tunes pre-trained models with a
modest number of parameters, enabling direct point cloud processing without
heterogeneous mappings. We convert raw point clouds into point embeddings by
aggregating local geometry to capture spatial features followed by linear
layers to ensure seamless utilization of frozen pre-trained models. Given the
inherent disorder of point clouds, in contrast to the structured nature of
images and language, we employ a permutation-invariant feature to capture the
relative positions of point embeddings, thereby obtaining point tokens enriched
with location information to optimize self-attention mechanisms. To calibrate
self-attention across source domains of any modality to 3D and reduce
computational overhead, we introduce a prompt generator that shares weights
with the point embedding module, dynamically producing point-prompts without
adding additional parameters. These prompts are then concatenated into a frozen
foundation model, providing rich global structural information and compensating
for the lack of structural context in the heterogeneous data.

AI.tldr: Adaptive Point-Prompt Tuning (APPT) enables parameter-efficient adaptation of frozen foundation models to 3D point clouds by converting points to embeddings, using permutation-invariant features, and a shared-weight prompt generator to inject dynamic point-prompts into the model, avoiding explicit cross-modal mappings.
AI.motivation: 3D pre-training data are scarce and simple high-to-low mappings from 2D/3D data often destroy geometric structure. A general, modality-agnostic, and parameter-efficient method is needed to adapt any foundation model to 3D point clouds without heavy fine-tuning or bespoke cross-modal architectures.
AI.method: Transform raw point clouds into point embeddings by aggregating local geometry, followed by linear layers. Use permutation-invariant features to handle unordered points and enrich tokens with location information. Introduce a prompt generator that shares weights with the embedding module to produce dynamic point-prompts with no extra parameters. Concatenate these prompts into a frozen foundation model to guide self-attention, enabling cross-domain calibration with reduced computation.
AI.result: The paper proposes a viable workflow that preserves spatial geometry and minimizes trainable parameters, enabling direct point-cloud processing with frozen foundation models. While specific quantitative results are not provided in the abstract, the approach is designed to achieve competitive performance with much smaller fine-tuning cost compared to full model adaptation.
AI.conclusion: APPT presents a general, scalable, and parameter-efficient framework for adapting any modality to 3D point clouds by leveraging point embeddings and a weight-sharing prompt generator to inject structural cues into frozen foundation models, reducing reliance on heterogeneous cross-modal mappings.

title: Principled Approximation Methods for Efficient and Scalable Deep Learning
summary:
Recent progress in deep learning has been driven by increasingly larger
models. However, their computational and energy demands have grown
proportionally, creating significant barriers to their deployment and to a
wider adoption of deep learning technologies. This thesis investigates
principled approximation methods for improving the efficiency of deep learning
systems, with a particular focus on settings that involve discrete constraints
and non-differentiability.
  We study three main approaches toward improved efficiency: architecture
design, model compression, and optimization. For model compression, we propose
novel approximations for pruning and quantization that frame the underlying
discrete problem as continuous and differentiable, enabling gradient-based
training of compression schemes alongside the model's parameters. These
approximations allow for fine-grained sparsity and precision configurations,
leading to highly compact models without significant fine-tuning. In the
context of architecture design, we design an algorithm for neural architecture
search that leverages parameter sharing across layers to efficiently explore
implicitly recurrent architectures. Finally, we study adaptive optimization,
revisiting theoretical properties of widely used methods and proposing an
adaptive optimizer that allows for quick hyperparameter tuning.
  Our contributions center on tackling computationally hard problems via
scalable and principled approximations. Experimental results on image
classification, language modeling, and generative modeling tasks show that the
proposed methods provide significant improvements in terms of training and
inference efficiency while maintaining, or even improving, the model's
performance.

AI.tldr: Principled differentiable approximations enable efficient deep learning via (i) fine-grained pruning/quantization, (ii) parameter-sharing NAS for implicitly recurrent architectures, and (iii) an adaptive optimizer; these yield compact, fast models with preserved or improved accuracy across vision, language, and generative tasks.
AI.motivation: Large deep learning models require substantial compute and energy. Discrete constraints and non-differentiability hinder optimization and deployment, motivating scalable, principled approaches to improve efficiency.
AI.method: Three-pronged approach: (1) model compression with differentiable relaxations for pruning and quantization; (2) architecture search leveraging parameter sharing across layers to efficiently explore implicitly recurrent architectures; (3) adaptive optimization that revisits theoretical properties of common methods and introduces a tunable adaptive optimizer for quick hyperparameter tuning.
AI.result: Experiments on image classification, language modeling, and generative modeling show significant improvements in training and inference efficiency while maintaining or improving model performance; the methods enable fine-grained sparsity and precision control without extensive fine-tuning and improve NAS efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Principled approximations can tackle computationally hard efficiency problems at scale, delivering practical speedups and compact models without sacrificing performance.

title: Sharpe Ratio Optimization in Markov Decision Processes
summary:
Sharpe ratio (also known as reward-to-variability ratio) is a widely-used
metric in finance, which measures the additional return at the cost of per unit
of increased risk (standard deviation of return). However, the optimization of
Sharpe ratio in Markov decision processes (MDPs) is challenging, because there
exist two difficulties hindering the application of dynamic programming. One is
that dynamic programming does not work for fractional objectives, and the other
is that dynamic programming is invalid for risk metrics. In this paper, we
study the Sharpe ratio optimization in infinite-horizon MDPs, considering both
the long-run average and discounted settings. We address the first challenge
with the Dinkelbachs transform, which converts the Sharpe ratio objective to a
mean-squared-variance (M2V) objective. It is shown that the M2V optimization
and the original Sharpe ratio optimization share the same optimal policy when
the risk-sensitive parameter is equal to the optimal Sharpe ratio. For the
second challenge, we develop an iterative algorithm to solve the M2V
optimization which is similar to a mean-variance optimization in MDPs. We
iteratively solve the M2V problem and obtain the associated Sharpe ratio that
is used to update the risk-sensitive parameter in the next iteration of M2V
problems. We show that such a sequence of Sharpe ratios derived is
monotonically increasing and converges to the optimal Sharpe ratio. For both
average and discounted MDP settings, we develop a policy iteration procedure
and prove its convergence to the optimum. Numerical experiments are conducted
for validation. To the best of our knowledge, our approach is the first that
solves the Sharpe ratio optimization in MDPs with dynamic programming type
algorithms. We believe that the proposed algorithm can shed light on solving
MDPs with other fractional objectives.

AI.tldr: A DP-compatible framework to optimize Sharpe ratio in infinite-horizon MDPs by transforming to a mean-squared-variance objective; an iterative algorithm with policy iteration that converges to the optimal Sharpe ratio under both average and discounted settings.
AI.motivation: The Sharpe ratio is a fundamental, fractional performance metric in finance, but its optimization is hard within dynamic programming because fractional objectives and risk metrics break standard DP methods. This work seeks a dynamic-programming-friendly approach to maximize Sharpe ratio in MDPs.
AI.method: Apply Dinkelbach's transform to convert the Sharpe ratio objective into a mean-squared-variance (M2V) objective. Show equivalence of optimal policies when the risk-sensitive parameter equals the optimum Sharpe ratio. Develop an iterative algorithm that repeatedly solves M2V subproblems using a DP-style policy iteration, updating the risk parameter with the current Sharpe estimate. Prove that the Sharpe sequence is monotone increasing and converges to the optimum for both average and discounted MDPs. Include numerical experiments.
AI.result: The proposed algorithm yields a monotonically increasing sequence of Sharpe ratios that converges to the optimal Sharpe ratio. The policy iteration procedure converges to the optimal policy in both average and discounted MDP settings. Numerical experiments validate the approach and demonstrate DP-type solvability for Sharpe optimization.
AI.conclusion: This work is, to the authors' knowledge, the first to solve Sharpe ratio optimization in MDPs with dynamic-programming-type algorithms, offering a pathway for tackling other fractional objectives in MDPs.

title: A Risk-aware Spatial-temporal Trajectory Planning Framework for Autonomous Vehicles Using QP-MPC and Dynamic Hazard Fields
summary:
Trajectory planning is a critical component in ensuring the safety,
stability, and efficiency of autonomous vehicles. While existing trajectory
planning methods have achieved progress, they often suffer from high
computational costs, unstable performance in dynamic environments, and limited
validation across diverse scenarios. To overcome these challenges, we propose
an enhanced QP-MPC-based framework that incorporates three key innovations: (i)
a novel cost function designed with a dynamic hazard field, which explicitly
balances safety, efficiency, and comfort; (ii) seamless integration of this
cost function into the QP-MPC formulation, enabling direct optimization of
desired driving behaviors; and (iii) extensive validation of the proposed
framework across complex tasks. The spatial safe planning is guided by a
dynamic hazard field (DHF) for risk assessment, while temporal safe planning is
based on a space-time graph. Besides, the quintic polynomial sampling and
sub-reward of comforts are used to ensure comforts during lane-changing. The
sub-reward of efficiency is used to maintain driving efficiency. Finally, the
proposed DHF-enhanced objective function integrates multiple objectives,
providing a proper optimization tasks for QP-MPC. Extensive simulations
demonstrate that the proposed framework outperforms benchmark optimization
methods in terms of efficiency, stability, and comfort across a variety of
scenarios likes lane-changing, overtaking, and crossing intersections.

AI.tldr: A dynamic hazard field (DHF)–enhanced QP-MPC trajectory planner integrates spatial DHF and a space–time graph, with quintic sampling and sub-rewards for comfort and efficiency, achieving superior efficiency, stability, and comfort across lane-changing, overtaking, and intersection scenarios in extensive simulations.
AI.motivation: To overcome high computational costs, unstable performance in dynamic environments, and limited scenario validation in existing trajectory planning methods.
AI.method: Introduce a DHF-based cost function integrated into the QP-MPC framework; perform spatial planning with DHF for risk assessment and temporal planning via a space–time graph; use quintic polynomial sampling and sub-rewards to promote comfort; incorporate a DHF-enhanced objective that balances safety, efficiency, and comfort; validate across complex tasks through extensive simulations.
AI.result: The proposed framework outperforms benchmark optimization methods in efficiency, stability, and comfort across diverse scenarios including lane-changing, overtaking, and crossing intersections.
AI.conclusion: The DHF-enhanced QP-MPC trajectory planning framework offers improved safety–efficiency–comfort trade-offs and broad validation relevance, indicating strong potential for robust autonomous driving performance in dynamic environments.

title: NoiseCutMix: A Novel Data Augmentation Approach by Mixing Estimated Noise in Diffusion Models
summary:
In this study, we propose a novel data augmentation method that introduces
the concept of CutMix into the generation process of diffusion models, thereby
exploiting both the ability of diffusion models to generate natural and
high-resolution images and the characteristic of CutMix, which combines
features from two classes to create diverse augmented data. Representative data
augmentation methods for combining images from multiple classes include CutMix
and MixUp. However, techniques like CutMix often result in unnatural boundaries
between the two images due to contextual differences. Therefore, in this study,
we propose a method, called NoiseCutMix, to achieve natural, high-resolution
image generation featuring the fused characteristics of two classes by
partially combining the estimated noise corresponding to two different classes
in a diffusion model. In the classification experiments, we verified the
effectiveness of the proposed method by comparing it with conventional data
augmentation techniques that combine multiple classes, random image generation
using Stable Diffusion, and combinations of these methods. Our codes are
available at: https://github.com/shumpei-takezaki/NoiseCutMix

AI.tldr: NoiseCutMix introduces diffusion-based data augmentation that fuses features from two classes by partially mixing their estimated noise, yielding natural, high-resolution multi-class images and improving classification performance.
AI.motivation: Address boundary artifacts and limited diversity in conventional multi-class augmentation (e.g., CutMix) by leveraging diffusion models' high-quality synthesis to fuse class features more naturally.
AI.method: Integrate partial mixing of estimated noise from two classes during the diffusion denoising process to generate images that combine characteristics of both classes. Compare against conventional multi-class augmentation, random image generation with Stable Diffusion, and combinations of these methods; provide code.
AI.result: Classification experiments show NoiseCutMix is effective relative to baselines and existing augmentation strategies, demonstrating improved diversity and performance; qualitative and quantitative assessments are reported; code available at the provided GitHub repository.
AI.conclusion: NoiseCutMix expands augmentation capabilities by integrating multi-class feature fusion within diffusion-based generation, enabling high-resolution natural fused images; future work may explore broader class merges and more extensive ablations.

title: FNODE: Flow-Matching for data-driven simulation of constrained multibody systems
summary:
Data-driven modeling of constrained multibody systems faces two persistent
challenges: high computational cost and limited long-term prediction accuracy.
To address these issues, we introduce the Flow-Matching Neural Ordinary
Differential Equation (FNODE), a framework that learns acceleration vector
fields directly from trajectory data. By reformulating the training objective
to supervise accelerations rather than integrated states, FNODE eliminates the
need for backpropagation through an ODE solver, which represents a bottleneck
in traditional Neural ODEs. Acceleration targets are computed efficiently using
numerical differentiation techniques, including a hybrid Fast Fourier Transform
(FFT) and Finite Difference (FD) scheme. We evaluate FNODE on a diverse set of
benchmarks, including the single and triple mass-spring-damper systems, double
pendulum, slider-crank, and cart-pole. Across all cases, FNODE consistently
outperforms existing approaches such as Multi-Body Dynamic Neural ODE
(MBD-NODE), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, and Fully Connected Neural
Networks (FCNN), demonstrating good accuracy, generalization, and computational
efficiency.

AI.tldr: FNODE is a flow-matching neural ODE that learns acceleration fields directly from trajectory data, avoiding backpropagation through ODE solvers by supervising accelerations with FFT+FD-derived targets, and it outperforms MBD-NODE, LSTM, and FCNN on several constrained multibody benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Constrained multibody system modeling suffers from high computational cost and limited long-term prediction accuracy in data-driven approaches, motivating a more efficient and accurate framework.
AI.method: Introduce Flow-Matching Neural ODE (FNODE) that trains by supervising accelerations rather than integrated states. Acceleration targets are obtained efficiently using a hybrid Fast Fourier Transform and Finite Difference scheme. The approach is validated on single/triple mass-spring-damper, double pendulum, slider-crank, and cart-pole systems, and compared against MBD-NODE, LSTM, and FCNN.
AI.result: FNODE consistently achieves better accuracy, generalization, and computational efficiency than the baselines across all tested benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Flow-matching acceleration supervision effectively enables accurate and efficient learning of constrained multibody dynamics, eliminating the ODE-backprop bottleneck and demonstrating strong performance across diverse mechanical systems.

title: Neuro-Symbolic Predictive Process Monitoring
summary:
This paper addresses the problem of suffix prediction in Business Process
Management (BPM) by proposing a Neuro-Symbolic Predictive Process Monitoring
(PPM) approach that integrates data-driven learning with temporal logic-based
prior knowledge. While recent approaches leverage deep learning models for
suffix prediction, they often fail to satisfy even basic logical constraints
due to the absence of explicit integration of domain knowledge during training.
We propose a novel method to incorporate Linear Temporal Logic over finite
traces (LTLf) into the training process of autoregressive sequence predictors.
Our approach introduces a differentiable logical loss function, defined using a
soft approximation of LTLf semantics and the Gumbel-Softmax trick, which can be
combined with standard predictive losses. This ensures the model learns to
generate suffixes that are both accurate and logically consistent. Experimental
evaluation on three real-world datasets shows that our method improves suffix
prediction accuracy and compliance with temporal constraints. We also introduce
two variants of the logic loss (local and global) and demonstrate their
effectiveness under noisy and realistic settings. While developed in the
context of BPM, our framework is applicable to any symbolic sequence generation
task and contributes toward advancing Neuro-Symbolic AI.

AI.tldr: Neuro-Symbolic Predictive Process Monitoring (PPM) integrates differentiable LTLf-based logical loss into autoregressive suffix prediction to enforce temporal constraints, improving accuracy and compliance in BPM datasets; introduces local/global logic loss variants; generalizable to other symbolic sequence generation tasks.
AI.motivation: Deep learning suffix predictors often violate domain temporal constraints due to lack of explicit domain knowledge during training; there is a need to embed symbolic temporal logic into learning.
AI.method: Train an autoregressive sequence model with a differentiable LTLf loss using soft semantics and the Gumbel-Softmax trick to approximate booleans; combine with standard predictive loss; propose local and global variants; evaluate on three real BPM datasets under noisy/realistic settings.
AI.result: Suffix predictions show higher accuracy and improved logical compliance; the local/global losses are effective under noise; demonstrates applicability beyond BPM to other symbolic sequence generation tasks.
AI.conclusion: This Neuro-Symbolic framework advances integrating symbolic temporal reasoning into data-driven sequence models; enables logical constraint satisfaction in generated sequences; future work may refine loss formulations and scale to larger domains.

title: CARIS: A Context-Adaptable Robot Interface System for Personalized and Scalable Human-Robot Interaction
summary:
The human-robot interaction (HRI) field has traditionally used Wizard-of-Oz
(WoZ) controlled robots to explore navigation, conversational dynamics,
human-in-the-loop interactions, and more to explore appropriate robot behaviors
in everyday settings. However, existing WoZ tools are often limited to one
context, making them less adaptable across different settings, users, and
robotic platforms. To mitigate these issues, we introduce a Context-Adaptable
Robot Interface System (CARIS) that combines advanced robotic capabilities such
teleoperation, human perception, human-robot dialogue, and multimodal data
recording. Through pilot studies, we demonstrate the potential of CARIS to WoZ
control a robot in two contexts: 1) mental health companion and as a 2) tour
guide. Furthermore, we identified areas of improvement for CARIS, including
smoother integration between movement and communication, clearer functionality
separation, recommended prompts, and one-click communication options to enhance
the usability wizard control of CARIS. This project offers a publicly
available, context-adaptable tool for the HRI community, enabling researchers
to streamline data-driven approaches to intelligent robot behavior.

AI.tldr: CARIS is a context-adaptable Wizard-of-Oz interface for human-robot interaction that combines teleoperation, perception, dialogue, and multimodal data recording. Pilot studies show it can WoZ-control a robot in mental health companion and tour-guide roles, with identified improvements (integration, clarity of function separation, prompts, one-click communication) and a public release for researchers.
AI.motivation: Traditional Wizard-of-Oz tools are typically limited to a single context, hindering cross-context research, portability across different robots and users, and scalable data collection for intelligent robot behavior.
AI.method: Develop CARIS by integrating teleoperation, perception, human-robot dialogue, and multimodal data recording into a single, context-adaptable interface. Validate via pilot studies in two contexts (mental health companion and tour guide), gather usability feedback, and outline improvements and a public release to the HRI community.
AI.result: CARIS demonstrated its potential to WoZ-control a robot in two contexts and highlighted areas for improvement, including smoother integration between movement and communication, clearer separation of functionality, recommended prompts, and one-click communication options. The tool is publicly available for researchers.
AI.conclusion: CARIS provides a publicly available, context-adaptable tool for the HRI community, enabling researchers to streamline data-driven approaches to building intelligent robot behavior across diverse settings.

title: Domain Adaptation-Based Crossmodal Knowledge Distillation for 3D Semantic Segmentation
summary:
Semantic segmentation of 3D LiDAR data plays a pivotal role in autonomous
driving. Traditional approaches rely on extensive annotated data for point
cloud analysis, incurring high costs and time investments. In contrast,
realworld image datasets offer abundant availability and substantial scale. To
mitigate the burden of annotating 3D LiDAR point clouds, we propose two
crossmodal knowledge distillation methods: Unsupervised Domain Adaptation
Knowledge Distillation (UDAKD) and Feature and Semantic-based Knowledge
Distillation (FSKD). Leveraging readily available spatio-temporally
synchronized data from cameras and LiDARs in autonomous driving scenarios, we
directly apply a pretrained 2D image model to unlabeled 2D data. Through
crossmodal knowledge distillation with known 2D-3D correspondence, we actively
align the output of the 3D network with the corresponding points of the 2D
network, thereby obviating the necessity for 3D annotations. Our focus is on
preserving modality-general information while filtering out modality-specific
details during crossmodal distillation. To achieve this, we deploy
self-calibrated convolution on 3D point clouds as the foundation of our domain
adaptation module. Rigorous experimentation validates the effectiveness of our
proposed methods, consistently surpassing the performance of state-of-the-art
approaches in the field.

AI.tldr: Cross-modal knowledge distillation from labeled 2D images to unlabeled 3D LiDAR data to perform 3D semantic segmentation without 3D annotations, using two methods (UDAKD and FSKD) with self-calibrated convolutions to preserve modality-general information and align 3D outputs with 2D counterparts, achieving superior results to state-of-the-art.
AI.motivation: High annotation cost for 3D LiDAR segmentation contrasts with abundant scalable 2D image datasets. A cross-modal knowledge transfer framework can leverage existing 2D models to label 3D data without dense 3D annotations.
AI.method: Two cross-modal distillation approaches (UDAKD and FSKD) that use spatio-temporally synchronized camera-LiDAR data. A pretrained 2D image model is applied to unlabeled 2D data; with known 2D-3D correspondences, the 3D network is guided to align its outputs with the 2D network. The approach emphasizes preserving modality-general information while filtering modality-specific cues. Self-calibrated convolution on 3D point clouds forms the backbone of the domain adaptation module.
AI.result: Rigorous experiments demonstrate that the proposed cross-modal distillation methods consistently outperform state-of-the-art approaches in 3D LiDAR semantic segmentation.
AI.conclusion: Cross-modal knowledge distillation, leveraging synchronized multi-modal data and self-calibrated 3D convolutions, enables effective 3D segmentation without 3D annotations and yields superior performance compared to existing methods.

title: Democratizing Agentic AI with Fast Test-Time Scaling on the Edge
summary:
Deploying agentic AI on edge devices is crucial for privacy and
responsiveness, but memory constraints typically relegate these systems to
smaller Large Language Models (LLMs) with inferior reasoning capabilities.
Test-Time Scaling (TTS) can bridge this reasoning gap by dedicating more
compute during inference, but existing methods incur prohibitive overhead on
edge hardware. To overcome this, we introduce FlashTTS, a serving system that
makes TTS practical for memory-constrained LLM reasoning. FlashTTS introduces
three synergistic optimizations: (i) Speculative Beam Extension to mitigate
system stragglers from irregular reasoning paths; (ii) Asymmetric Multi-Model
Memory Allocation to dynamically balance memory between generation and
verification; and (iii) Dynamic Prefix-Aware Scheduling to maximize KV-cache
reuse. Built as a plug-and-play library for vLLM, FlashTTS enables edge LLMs on
a single consumer GPU (24 GB) to match the accuracy and latency of large cloud
models. Our evaluation demonstrates that FlashTTS achieves an average 2.2x
higher goodput and reduces latency by 38%-68% compared to a vLLM baseline,
paving the way for democratized, high-performance agentic AI on edge devices.

AI.tldr: FlashTTS enables memory-constrained edge LLMs to perform test-time scaling with three optimizations, achieving cloud-like accuracy and latency on a 24GB GPU, with 2.2x goodput gain and 38-68% latency reduction.
AI.motivation: Edge devices require privacy and low latency; memory limits prevent deploying large LLMs with strong reasoning. Test-Time Scaling (TTS) can help but often incurs high overhead on edge hardware, limiting practicality.
AI.method: Introduce three synergistic optimizations integrated as a plug-and-play library for vLLM: (i) Speculative Beam Extension to reduce stragglers from irregular reasoning paths, (ii) Asymmetric Multi-Model Memory Allocation to balance memory between generation and verification, and (iii) Dynamic Prefix-Aware Scheduling to maximize KV-cache reuse.
AI.result: With these optimizations, FlashTTS enables edge LLMs on a single 24 GB GPU to match the accuracy and latency of large cloud models, achieving ~2.2x higher goodput and 38–68% latency reduction versus a vLLM baseline.
AI.conclusion: FlashTTS demonstrates that practical, high-performance agentic AI at the edge is feasible by making test-time scaling memory-efficient; this democratizes access to capable on-device reasoning.

title: ChatCLIDS: Simulating Persuasive AI Dialogues to Promote Closed-Loop Insulin Adoption in Type 1 Diabetes Care
comment: Equal contribution for the first two authors
summary:
Real-world adoption of closed-loop insulin delivery systems (CLIDS) in type 1
diabetes remains low, driven not by technical failure, but by diverse
behavioral, psychosocial, and social barriers. We introduce ChatCLIDS, the
first benchmark to rigorously evaluate LLM-driven persuasive dialogue for
health behavior change. Our framework features a library of expert-validated
virtual patients, each with clinically grounded, heterogeneous profiles and
realistic adoption barriers, and simulates multi-turn interactions with nurse
agents equipped with a diverse set of evidence-based persuasive strategies.
ChatCLIDS uniquely supports longitudinal counseling and adversarial social
influence scenarios, enabling robust, multi-dimensional evaluation. Our
findings reveal that while larger and more reflective LLMs adapt strategies
over time, all models struggle to overcome resistance, especially under
realistic social pressure. These results highlight critical limitations of
current LLMs for behavior change, and offer a high-fidelity, scalable testbed
for advancing trustworthy persuasive AI in healthcare and beyond.

AI.tldr: A benchmark suite (ChatCLIDS) to evaluate LLM-driven persuasive dialogue for health behavior change in CLIDS adoption, using virtual patients and nurse agents with evidence-based strategies; findings: larger LLMs adapt over time but all struggle to overcome resistance under social pressure; provides a high-fidelity testbed for trustworthy persuasive AI in healthcare.
AI.motivation: Address low real-world adoption of closed-loop insulin delivery systems due to behavioral, psychosocial, and social barriers; need rigorous, scalable evaluation of persuasive AI in healthcare.
AI.method: Develop ChatCLIDS framework with expert-validated virtual patient library, heterogeneous profiles, realistic barriers; simulate multi-turn interactions with nurse agents using diverse persuasive strategies; supports longitudinal counseling and adversarial social influence; robust evaluation.
AI.result: Bigger/more reflective models adapt strategies over time; however all models fail to overcome resistance, especially under realistic social pressure.
AI.conclusion: Current LLMs have limitations for behavior change; ChatCLIDS offers a high-fidelity, scalable testbed to advance trustworthy persuasive AI in healthcare and beyond.

title: DyPho-SLAM : Real-time Photorealistic SLAM in Dynamic Environments
summary:
Visual SLAM algorithms have been enhanced through the exploration of Gaussian
Splatting representations, particularly in generating high-fidelity dense maps.
While existing methods perform reliably in static environments, they often
encounter camera tracking drift and fuzzy mapping when dealing with the
disturbances caused by moving objects. This paper presents DyPho-SLAM, a
real-time, resource-efficient visual SLAM system designed to address the
challenges of localization and photorealistic mapping in environments with
dynamic objects. Specifically, the proposed system integrates prior image
information to generate refined masks, effectively minimizing noise from mask
misjudgment. Additionally, to enhance constraints for optimization after
removing dynamic obstacles, we devise adaptive feature extraction strategies
significantly improving the system's resilience. Experiments conducted on
publicly dynamic RGB-D datasets demonstrate that the proposed system achieves
state-of-the-art performance in camera pose estimation and dense map
reconstruction, while operating in real-time in dynamic scenes.

AI.tldr: DyPho-SLAM enables real-time, dynamic-scene visual SLAM using Gaussian Splatting with refined masking and adaptive features, achieving state-of-the-art pose estimation and dense mapping in dynamic RGB-D datasets.
AI.motivation: Dynamic objects disturb camera tracking and mapping in static SLAM pipelines, causing drift and noise. There is a need for robust, real-time SLAM that handles dynamic environments with photorealistic dense maps.
AI.method: Incorporates prior image information to generate refined masks to reduce noise from mask misjudgment. After removing dynamic obstacles, applies adaptive feature extraction strategies to strengthen optimization constraints. Builds on Gaussian Splatting representations for dense maps, and targets real-time performance in dynamic scenes.
AI.result: Demonstrates state-of-the-art performance in camera pose estimation and dense map reconstruction on publicly available dynamic RGB-D datasets, while operating in real-time.
AI.conclusion: Proposes DyPho-SLAM as a resource-efficient, robust solution for dynamic environments, combining refined masking and adaptive features with Gaussian Splatting to improve pose accuracy and dense mapping in dynamic scenes.

title: Visually Grounded Narratives: Reducing Cognitive Burden in Researcher-Participant Interaction
summary:
Narrative inquiry has been one of the prominent application domains for the
analysis of human experience, aiming to know more about the complexity of human
society. However, researchers are often required to transform various forms of
data into coherent hand-drafted narratives in storied form throughout narrative
analysis, which brings an immense burden of data analysis. Participants, too,
are expected to engage in member checking and presentation of these narrative
products, which involves reviewing and responding to large volumes of
documents. Given the dual burden and the need for more efficient and
participant-friendly approaches to narrative making and representation, we made
a first attempt: (i) a new paradigm is proposed, NAME, as the initial attempt
to push the field of narrative inquiry. Name is able to transfer research
documents into coherent story images, alleviating the cognitive burden of
interpreting extensive text-based materials during member checking for both
researchers and participants. (ii) We develop an actor location and shape
module to facilitate plausible image generation. (iii) We have designed a set
of robust evaluation metrics comprising three key dimensions to objectively
measure the perceptual quality and narrative consistency of generated
characters. Our approach consistently demonstrates state-of-the-art performance
across different data partitioning schemes. Remarkably, while the baseline
relies on the full 100% of the available data, our method requires only 0.96%
yet still reduces the FID score from 195 to 152. Under identical data volumes,
our method delivers substantial improvements: for the 70:30 split, the FID
score decreases from 175 to 152, and for the 95:5 split, it is nearly halved
from 96 to 49. Furthermore, the proposed model achieves a score of 3.62 on the
newly introduced metric, surpassing the baseline score of 2.66.

AI.tldr: NAME introduces a narrative-inquiry paradigm that converts research documents into coherent story images to ease member checking, supported by an actor location and shape module, and evaluated with three-dimensional metrics; it achieves state-of-the-art performance with far less data than baselines.
AI.motivation: Narrative inquiry involves heavy data-to-narrative transformation and burdens for researchers and participants during member checking; a more efficient, participant-friendly approach is needed.
AI.method: Proposes NAME; transforms documents into story images; includes an actor location and shape module for plausible image generation; develops a three-dimension evaluation metric; experiments across data partitions show data efficiency and quality improvements.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance; with 0.96% data, FID improved from 195 to 152; 70:30 FID 152; 95:5 FID 49; new metric score 3.62 vs 2.66 baseline.
AI.conclusion: NAME reduces cognitive burden in narrative inquiry while improving narrative quality and robustness under varying data availability; demonstrates potential for broader adoption in narrative data analysis.

title: From TLinFormer to TConstFormer: The Leap to Constant-Time Transformer Attention: Achieving O(1) Computation and O(1) KV Cache during Autoregressive Inference
summary:
Although the Transformer has become the cornerstone of modern AI, its
autoregressive inference suffers from a linearly growing KV Cache and a
computational complexity of O(N^2 d), severely hindering its ability to process
ultra-long sequences. To overcome this limitation, this paper introduces the
TConstFormer architecture, building upon our previous work, TLinFormer.
TConstFormer employs an innovative periodic state update mechanism to achieve a
truly constant-size O(1) KV Cache. The computational complexity of this
mechanism is also O(1) in an amortized sense: it performs purely constant-time
computations for $k-1$ consecutive steps (e.g., $k=256$) and executes a single
linear-time global information synchronization only on the $k$-th step.
Theoretical calculations and experimental results demonstrate that TConstFormer
exhibits an overwhelming advantage over baseline models in terms of speed,
memory efficiency, and overall performance on long-text inference tasks. This
breakthrough paves the way for efficient and robust streaming language model
applications.

AI.tldr: A Transformer variant named TConstFormer achieves a truly constant-size KV cache and amortized O(1) inference per step for long-sequence processing, outperforming baselines in speed and memory.
AI.motivation: To overcome Transformer autoregressive bottlenecks—growing KV cache and quadratic attention—that hinder long-sequence and streaming LLMs.
AI.method: Introduces periodic state update mechanism in TConstFormer (built on TLinFormer) enabling constant-size KV cache with amortized constant-time updates: k-1 steps cost O(1) and a single linear-time synchronization on every k-th step.
AI.result: Theoretical analysis and experiments show significant speedup and memory efficiency gains with robust long-text inference performance.
AI.conclusion: Offers a scalable solution for streaming language models, enabling efficient long-sequence processing and robust performance.

title: Robust Deep Monte Carlo Counterfactual Regret Minimization: Addressing Theoretical Risks in Neural Fictitious Self-Play
summary:
Monte Carlo Counterfactual Regret Minimization (MCCFR) has emerged as a
cornerstone algorithm for solving extensive-form games, but its integration
with deep neural networks introduces scale-dependent challenges that manifest
differently across game complexities. This paper presents a comprehensive
analysis of how neural MCCFR component effectiveness varies with game scale and
proposes an adaptive framework for selective component deployment. We identify
that theoretical risks such as nonstationary target distribution shifts, action
support collapse, variance explosion, and warm-starting bias have
scale-dependent manifestation patterns, requiring different mitigation
strategies for small versus large games. Our proposed Robust Deep MCCFR
framework incorporates target networks with delayed updates, uniform
exploration mixing, variance-aware training objectives, and comprehensive
diagnostic monitoring. Through systematic ablation studies on Kuhn and Leduc
Poker, we demonstrate scale-dependent component effectiveness and identify
critical component interactions. The best configuration achieves final
exploitability of 0.0628 on Kuhn Poker, representing a 60% improvement over the
classical framework (0.156). On the more complex Leduc Poker domain, selective
component usage achieves exploitability of 0.2386, a 23.5% improvement over the
classical framework (0.3703) and highlighting the importance of careful
component selection over comprehensive mitigation. Our contributions include:
(1) a formal theoretical analysis of risks in neural MCCFR, (2) a principled
mitigation framework with convergence guarantees, (3) comprehensive multi-scale
experimental validation revealing scale-dependent component interactions, and
(4) practical guidelines for deployment in larger games.

AI.tldr: The work analyzes how neural MCCFR component effectiveness changes with game scale and presents an adaptive framework (Robust Deep MCCFR) that uses selective component deployment and stability-friendly mechanisms to mitigate scale-dependent risks, validated by ablations on Kuhn and Leduc Poker with notable exploitability improvements.
AI.motivation: To address scale-dependent challenges in integrating deep neural networks with MCCFR, such as nonstationary target distributions, action support collapse, variance explosion, and warm-starting bias, and to enable reliable deployment in larger, more complex games.
AI.method: The authors perform a theoretical analysis of risks in neural MCCFR, develop a Robust Deep MCCFR framework with target networks (delayed updates), uniform exploration mixing, variance-aware training objectives, and extensive diagnostic monitoring, followed by systematic ablation studies on Kuhn and Leduc Poker to inspect scale-dependent component interactions and optimal configurations.
AI.result: Best configuration reduces exploitability to 0.0628 on Kuhn Poker (60% improvement from 0.156). In Leduc Poker, selective component usage yields 0.2386 exploitability (23.5% improvement from 0.3703). The framework offers convergence guarantees and multi-scale experimental validation.
AI.conclusion: Scale-aware, selective deployment of neural MCCFR components, within a robust framework, improves performance and provides practical deployment guidelines for larger games, supported by theoretical analysis and empirical evidence.

title: Inverse Kinematics for a 6-Degree-of-Freedom Robot Manipulator Using Comprehensive Gröbner Systems
summary:
We propose an effective method for solving the inverse kinematic problem of a
specific model of 6-degree-of-freedom (6-DOF) robot manipulator using computer
algebra. It is known that when the rotation axes of three consecutive
rotational joints of a manipulator intersect at a single point, the inverse
kinematics problem can be divided into determining position and orientation. We
extend this method to more general manipulators in which the rotational axes of
two consecutive joints intersect. This extension broadens the class of 6-DOF
manipulators for which the inverse kinematics problem can be solved, and is
expected to enable more efficient solutions. The inverse kinematic problem is
solved using the Comprehensive Gr\"obner System (CGS) with joint parameters of
the robot appearing as parameters in the coefficients to prevent repetitive
calculations of the Gr\"obner bases. The effectiveness of the proposed method
is shown by experiments.

AI.tldr: Proposes a computer-algebra-based method to solve inverse kinematics for a class of 6-DOF manipulators, extending solvability to cases where two consecutive joint axes intersect, via Comprehensive Gröbner System (CGS) with joint parameters as coefficients; experiments validate effectiveness.
AI.motivation: Inverse kinematics for 6-DOF manipulators is computationally challenging; existing methods succeed when three consecutive joint axes intersect. Extending to manipulators where two consecutive axes intersect broadens solvable robots and can lead to more efficient, symbolic solutions.
AI.method: Model the IK problem using computer algebra and Comprehensive Gröbner Systems (CGS). Treat joint parameters as parameters in CGS coefficients to avoid repeated Gr"obner basis recalculation. Begin from the known case with three intersecting axes and extend to the case with two consecutive intersecting axes, solving for position and orientation separately and reconstructing joint variables from the algebraic solutions.
AI.result: Experiments demonstrate the method’s effectiveness, showing that CGS-based symbolic solving is feasible and beneficial for the extended class of 6-DOF manipulators, with reduced recomputation and successful IK solutions in tested scenarios.
AI.conclusion: The approach broadens the range of 6-DOF manipulators for which IK can be solved symbolically and more efficiently, by leveraging CGS with parameterized coefficients to avoid repeated calculations.

title: HERO-VQL: Hierarchical, Egocentric and Robust Visual Query Localization
comment: Accepted to BMVC 2025 (Oral), 23 pages with supplementary material
summary:
In this work, we tackle the egocentric visual query localization (VQL), where
a model should localize the query object in a long-form egocentric video.
Frequent and abrupt viewpoint changes in egocentric videos cause significant
object appearance variations and partial occlusions, making it difficult for
existing methods to achieve accurate localization. To tackle these challenges,
we introduce Hierarchical, Egocentric and RObust Visual Query Localization
(HERO-VQL), a novel method inspired by human cognitive process in object
recognition. We propose i) Top-down Attention Guidance (TAG) and ii) Egocentric
Augmentation based Consistency Training (EgoACT). Top-down Attention Guidance
refines the attention mechanism by leveraging the class token for high-level
context and principal component score maps for fine-grained localization. To
enhance learning in diverse and challenging matching scenarios, EgoAug enhances
query diversity by replacing the query with a randomly selected corresponding
object from groundtruth annotations and simulates extreme viewpoint changes by
reordering video frames. Additionally, CT loss enforces stable object
localization across different augmentation scenarios. Extensive experiments on
VQ2D dataset validate that HERO-VQL effectively handles egocentric challenges,
significantly outperforming baselines.

AI.tldr: HERO-VQL introduces a hierarchical egocentric visual query localization method with Top-down Attention Guidance and EgoACT, plus EgoAug diversity strategies and a consistency loss, achieving strong robustness and state-of-the-art results on the VQ2D dataset.
AI.motivation: Egocentric videos exhibit frequent abrupt viewpoint changes, drastic object appearance variations, and partial occlusions, making precise localizations hard for existing methods. The work aims to mimic human cognitive object recognition to improve VQL robustness.
AI.method: Proposes Top-down Attention Guidance (TAG) that uses the class token for high-level context and principal component score maps for fine-grained localization. Introduces EgoACT (Egocentric Augmentation based Consistency Training) to augment data by replacing queries with randomly selected groundtruth counterparts and simulating viewpoint changes by reordering frames. Also applies CT loss to enforce stable localization across augmentations, and utilizes EgoAug to enrich query diversity.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on the VQ2D dataset show HERO-VQL effectively handles egocentric challenges and significantly outperforms baselines.
AI.conclusion: HERO-VQL demonstrates robust, human-inspired localization in egocentric VQL tasks, offering improved accuracy under viewpoint variations and occlusions and setting a new benchmark on VQ2D.

title: Estimating Parameter Fields in Multi-Physics PDEs from Scarce Measurements
summary:
Parameterized partial differential equations (PDEs) underpin the mathematical
modeling of complex systems in diverse domains, including engineering,
healthcare, and physics. A central challenge in using PDEs for real-world
applications is to accurately infer the parameters, particularly when the
parameters exhibit non-linear and spatiotemporal variations. Existing parameter
estimation methods, such as sparse identification and physics-informed neural
networks (PINNs), struggle in such cases, especially with nonlinear dynamics,
multiphysics interactions, or limited observations of the system response. To
address these challenges, we introduce Neptune, a general-purpose method
capable of inferring parameter fields from sparse measurements of system
responses. Neptune employs independent coordinate neural networks to
continuously represent each parameter field in physical space or in state
variables. Across various physical and biomedical problems, where direct
parameter measurements are prohibitively expensive or unattainable, Neptune
significantly outperforms existing methods, achieving robust parameter
estimation from as few as 50 observations, reducing parameter estimation errors
by two orders of magnitude and dynamic response prediction errors by a factor
of ten compared to PINNs. Furthermore, Neptune exhibits superior extrapolation
capabilities, enabling accurate predictions in regimes beyond training data
where PINN fail. By facilitating reliable and data-efficient parameter
inference, Neptune promises broad transformative impacts in engineering,
healthcare, and beyond.

AI.tldr: Neptune is a data-efficient neural-field framework that infers parameter fields in PDEs from sparse observations, surpassing PINNs and SINDy, with strong extrapolation.
AI.motivation: Inferring spatially/temporally varying parameters in PDEs is hard when data are sparse and dynamics nonlinear; existing methods struggle with multiphysics and limited observables.
AI.method: Use independent coordinate neural networks to represent each parameter field in physical/state space; train to fit observed system responses under the governing PDEs; general-purpose, data-efficient.
AI.result: Across physical/biomedical problems, Neptune achieves robust parameter estimation from as few as 50 observations; reduces parameter estimation errors by ~100x and dynamic response errors by ~10x compared with PINNs; shows superior extrapolation beyond training regimes.
AI.conclusion: Neptune enables reliable, data-efficient parameter inference with broad potential across engineering, healthcare, and beyond.

title: SATQuest: A Verifier for Logical Reasoning Evaluation and Reinforcement Fine-Tuning of LLMs
summary:
Recent advances in Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable
general reasoning capabilities. However, systematically evaluating and
enhancing these reasoning capabilities is challenging due to the lack of
controllable and scalable tools for fine-grained analysis. Existing benchmarks
and datasets often lack the necessary variable control for multi-dimensional,
systematic analysis and training, or have narrow problem types and formats. To
address these limitations, we introduce SATQuest, a systematic verifier
designed to evaluate and enhance logical reasoning in LLMs by generating
diverse, Satisfiability-based logical reasoning problems directly from
Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF) instances. SATQuest structures these problems
along three orthogonal dimensions: instance scale, problem type, and question
format, employing randomized, SAT-based problem generation and objective answer
verification via PySAT. This design mitigates memorization issues, allows for
nuanced insights into reasoning performance, and enables effective
reinforcement fine-tuning. Our extensive evaluation of various LLMs using
SATQuest identified significant limitations in their logical reasoning,
particularly in generalizing beyond familiar mathematical formats. Furthermore,
we show that reinforcement fine-tuning with SATQuest rewards substantially
improves targeted task performance and generalizes to more complex instances,
while highlighting remaining challenges in cross-format adaptation. Through
these demonstrations, we showcase SATQuest's potential as a foundational tool
and a valuable starting point for advancing LLM logical reasoning.

AI.tldr: SATQuest provides a controllable, SAT-based framework for probing LLM logical reasoning by generating CNF-style problems across orthogonal dimensions (scale, type, format) with verifiable answers, enabling targeted evaluation and reinforcement fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: To overcome weaknesses in existing benchmarks: lack of controllable, scalable, multi-dimensional analysis and limited problem types, which hinder systematic evaluation and training of LLM reasoning.
AI.method: Generate CNF-based reasoning problems via randomized SAT-based generation across three orthogonal dimensions (instance scale, problem type, question format); verify answers using PySAT; assess multiple LLMs; apply reinforcement fine-tuning on SATQuest-generated data to boost performance and generalization.
AI.result: LLMs reveal significant gaps in logical reasoning, especially in generalizing beyond familiar math formats. Reinforcement fine-tuning with SATQuest boosts targeted task performance and generalizes to more complex instances, though cross-format adaptation remains challenging.
AI.conclusion: SATQuest is a foundational tool for systematically evaluating and enhancing LLM logical reasoning and a promising starting point for future research and robust reinforcement learning approaches.

title: An Effective Trajectory Planning and an Optimized Path Planning for a 6-Degree-of-Freedom Robot Manipulator
summary:
An effective method for optimizing path planning for a specific model of a
6-degree-of-freedom (6-DOF) robot manipulator is presented as part of the
motion planning of the manipulator using computer algebra. We assume that we
are given a path in the form of a set of line segments that the end-effector
should follow. We also assume that we have a method to solve the inverse
kinematic problem of the manipulator at each via-point of the trajectory. The
proposed method consists of three steps. First, we calculate the feasible
region of the manipulator under a specific configuration of the end-effector.
Next, we aim to find a trajectory on the line segments and a sequence of joint
configurations the manipulator should follow to move the end-effector along the
specified trajectory. Finally, we find the optimal combination of solutions to
the inverse kinematic problem at each via-point along the trajectory by
reducing the problem to a shortest-path problem of the graph and applying
Dijkstra's algorithm. We show the effectiveness of the proposed method by
experiments.

AI.tldr: A three-step, IK-aware path-planning framework for a 6-DOF manipulator that uses feasible-region analysis and a shortest-path optimization over IK solutions at via-points, validated experimentally.
AI.motivation: To handle inverse-kinematics ambiguity and ensure feasible, optimal trajectories along a prescribed end-effector path for a 6-DOF manipulator, by integrating algebraic methods with graph-based optimization.
AI.method: 1) Compute the feasible region for a given end-effector configuration. 2) Determine a trajectory along the given line-segment path and a corresponding sequence of joint configurations. 3) Construct a graph of IK solutions at via-points and solve for the optimal sequence using Dijkstra's algorithm, leveraging computer algebra.
AI.result: Experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.
AI.conclusion: The approach provides an effective framework for optimizing path planning for a 6-DOF manipulator by combining inverse kinematics, feasible-region analysis, and shortest-path optimization.

title: Double-Constraint Diffusion Model with Nuclear Regularization for Ultra-low-dose PET Reconstruction
summary:
Ultra-low-dose positron emission tomography (PET) reconstruction holds
significant potential for reducing patient radiation exposure and shortening
examination times. However, it may also lead to increased noise and reduced
imaging detail, which could decrease the image quality. In this study, we
present a Double-Constraint Diffusion Model (DCDM), which freezes the weights
of a pre-trained diffusion model and injects a trainable double-constraint
controller into the encoding architecture, greatly reducing the number of
trainable parameters for ultra-low-dose PET reconstruction. Unlike full
fine-tuning models, DCDM can adapt to different dose levels without retraining
all model parameters, thereby improving reconstruction flexibility.
Specifically, the two constraint modules, named the Nuclear Transformer
Constraint (NTC) and the Encoding Nexus Constraint (ENC), serve to refine the
pre-trained diffusion model. The NTC leverages the nuclear norm as an
approximation for matrix rank minimization, integrates the low-rank property
into the Transformer architecture, and enables efficient information extraction
from low-dose images and conversion into compressed feature representations in
the latent space. Subsequently, the ENC utilizes these compressed feature
representations to encode and control the pre-trained diffusion model,
ultimately obtaining reconstructed PET images in the pixel space. In clinical
reconstruction, the compressed feature representations from NTC help select the
most suitable ENC for efficient unknown low-dose PET reconstruction.
Experiments conducted on the UDPET public dataset and the Clinical dataset
demonstrated that DCDM outperforms state-of-the-art methods on known dose
reduction factors (DRF) and generalizes well to unknown DRF scenarios, proving
valuable even at ultra-low dose levels, such as 1% of the full dose.

AI.tldr: A parameter-efficient diffusion-based framework (DCDM) for ultra-low-dose PET reconstruction that freezes a pre-trained diffusion model and introduces two trainable constraints (NTC and ENC) to adapt to varying dose levels without full retraining, achieving state-of-the-art results and strong generalization even at 1% dose.
AI.motivation: Ultra-low-dose PET reduces radiation and scan time but increases noise and degrades image quality. Traditional fine-tuning for each dose level is costly and brittle. A lightweight, adaptable approach is needed to maintain image quality across unknown dose reductions.
AI.method: Freeze the weights of a pre-trained diffusion model and insert a trainable double-constraint controller into the encoding path. The Nuclear Transformer Constraint (NTC) imposes a nuclear-norm-based low-rank constraint within a Transformer to extract compressed latent features from low-dose inputs; the Encoding Nexus Constraint (ENC) uses these compressed features to encode and control the diffusion process, producing pixel-space reconstructions. For unknown dose reductions, select the most suitable ENC to reconstruct efficiently. The approach dramatically reduces trainable parameters compared to full fine-tuning.
AI.result: On UDPET and Clinical datasets, DCDM outperforms state-of-the-art methods at known dose reduction factors and generalizes well to unknown DRFs, including ultra-low doses such as 1% of the full dose.
AI.conclusion: DCDM provides a flexible, parameter-efficient solution for ultra-low-dose PET reconstruction. By freezing diffusion weights and leveraging NTC and ENC constraints, it adapts to varying dose levels with strong reconstruction quality and robust generalization, facilitating clinical applicability without full model retraining.

title: Learning to Shard: RL for Co-optimizing the Parallelism Degrees and Per-operator Sharding Dimensions in Distributed LLM Inference
summary:
Distributed LLM inference requires careful coordination of parallelization
strategies across hundreds to thousands of NPUs to meet production SLOs.
Current systems like Megatron-LM rely on static heuristics that separately
configure parallelism degrees and per-operator sharding dimensions, leaving
significant performance on the table as models scale and hardware topologies
diversify. We introduce Learn to Shard, to our knowledge, the first RL-based
approach to co-optimize both coarse-grained parallelism degrees and
fine-grained per-operator sharding dimensions for distributed LLM inference.
Our method employs an attention-based policy over an elite history that learns
from high-performing strategies to efficiently navigate the vast combinatorial
search space. Evaluated on H100 clusters with MoE models up to 1.6T parameters,
Learn to Shard achieves up to 3.5x throughput improvement over metaheuristic
baselines and 1.06x over Megatron heuristics.

AI.tldr: Learn to Shard is an RL-based method that jointly optimizes coarse-grained parallelism and fine-grained per-operator sharding for distributed LLM inference, achieving substantial throughput gains over baselines on H100 clusters with MoE models up to 1.6T parameters.
AI.motivation: Current systems like Megatron-LM rely on static heuristics that separately configure parallelism degrees and per-operator sharding, which underutilize performance as models scale and hardware topologies diversify.
AI.method: An attention-based policy over an elite history that learns from high-performing strategies to co-optimize both coarse-grained parallelism and per-operator sharding dimensions, effectively navigating the large combinatorial search space.
AI.result: Evaluated on H100 clusters with MoE models up to 1.6T parameters, Learn to Shard achieves up to 3.5x throughput improvement over metaheuristic baselines and 1.06x over Megatron heuristics.
AI.conclusion: This work is, to our knowledge, the first RL-based approach to jointly optimize both coarse-grained parallelism and fine-grained per-operator sharding for distributed LLM inference, demonstrating substantial throughput gains and suggesting RL-driven search can better adapt to diverse hardware topologies than static heuristic methods.

title: UrbanInsight: A Distributed Edge Computing Framework with LLM-Powered Data Filtering for Smart City Digital Twins
summary:
Cities today generate enormous streams of data from sensors, cameras, and
connected infrastructure. While this information offers unprecedented
opportunities to improve urban life, most existing systems struggle with scale,
latency, and fragmented insights. This work introduces a framework that blends
physics-informed machine learning, multimodal data fusion, and knowledge graph
representation with adaptive, rule-based intelligence powered by large language
models (LLMs). Physics-informed methods ground learning in real-world
constraints, ensuring predictions remain meaningful and consistent with
physical dynamics. Knowledge graphs act as the semantic backbone, integrating
heterogeneous sensor data into a connected, queryable structure. At the edge,
LLMs generate context-aware rules that adapt filtering and decision-making in
real time, enabling efficient operation even under constrained resources.
Together, these elements form a foundation for digital twin systems that go
beyond passive monitoring to provide actionable insights. By uniting
physics-based reasoning, semantic data fusion, and adaptive rule generation,
this approach opens new possibilities for creating responsive, trustworthy, and
sustainable smart infrastructures.

AI.tldr: Introduces an integrated digital twin framework for smart cities that fuses physics-informed ML, multimodal data fusion, knowledge graphs, and LLM-driven edge rules to enable real-time, actionable insights.
AI.motivation: Current urban sensing yields vast data but suffers from scale, latency, and fragmented insights; a cohesive framework is needed to enforce physical consistency, semantically integrate diverse data, and adapt decisions at the edge.
AI.method: Blend physics-informed machine learning with semantic knowledge graphs as a backbone, multimodal data fusion, and edge-generated, context-aware rules from large language models to support real-time, resource-aware decision-making and digital twin capabilities.
AI.result: Establishes a foundation for digital twin systems that move beyond passive monitoring to provide actionable, trustworthy insights and efficient operation under constrained resources.
AI.conclusion: By uniting physics-based reasoning, semantic data fusion, and adaptive rule generation, the approach enables responsive, trustworthy, and sustainable smart infrastructures.

title: One-Step Model Predictive Path Integral for Manipulator Motion Planning Using Configuration Space Distance Fields
summary:
Motion planning for robotic manipulators is a fundamental problem in
robotics. Classical optimization-based methods typically rely on the gradients
of signed distance fields (SDFs) to impose collision-avoidance constraints.
However, these methods are susceptible to local minima and may fail when the
SDF gradients vanish. Recently, Configuration Space Distance Fields (CDFs) have
been introduced, which directly model distances in the robot's configuration
space. Unlike workspace SDFs, CDFs are differentiable almost everywhere and
thus provide reliable gradient information. On the other hand, gradient-free
approaches such as Model Predictive Path Integral (MPPI) control leverage
long-horizon rollouts to achieve collision avoidance. While effective, these
methods are computationally expensive due to the large number of trajectory
samples, repeated collision checks, and the difficulty of designing cost
functions with heterogeneous physical units. In this paper, we propose a
framework that integrates CDFs with MPPI to enable direct navigation in the
robot's configuration space. Leveraging CDF gradients, we unify the MPPI cost
in joint-space and reduce the horizon to one step, substantially cutting
computation while preserving collision avoidance in practice. We demonstrate
that our approach achieves nearly 100% success rates in 2D environments and
consistently high success rates in challenging 7-DOF Franka manipulator
simulations with complex obstacles. Furthermore, our method attains control
frequencies exceeding 750 Hz, substantially outperforming both
optimization-based and standard MPPI baselines. These results highlight the
effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed CDF-MPPI framework for
high-dimensional motion planning.

AI.tldr: A framework that combines Configuration Space Distance Fields (CDFs) with Model Predictive Path Integral (MPPI) control to do fast, one-step horizon motion planning in joint space, achieving robust collision avoidance with high success and ultra-fast control rates.
AI.motivation: To overcome limitations of gradient-based SDF methods (local minima, vanishing gradients) and gradient-free MPPI’s computational burden by leveraging differentiable CDFs for reliable gradient information in configuration space, enabling efficient high-dimensional planning.
AI.method: Integrate CDF gradients into MPPI in joint space and reduce the horizon to a single step, performing direct navigation in the robot’s configuration space. Demonstrated in 2D scenarios and challenging 7-DOF Franka simulations with complex obstacles, achieving high update rates (over 750 Hz).
AI.result: High success: near 100% in 2D environments and consistently high in 7-DOF Franka simulations with obstacles. Control frequencies exceed 750 Hz, outperforming both optimization-based and standard MPPI baselines.
AI.conclusion: CDF-MPPI provides an effective, efficient approach for high-dimensional, collision-avoiding motion planning by exploiting differentiable CDFs for reliable gradient information and a one-step horizon to attain real-time performance and strong success rates.

title: DAOVI: Distortion-Aware Omnidirectional Video Inpainting
summary:
Omnidirectional videos that capture the entire surroundings are employed in a
variety of fields such as VR applications and remote sensing. However, their
wide field of view often causes unwanted objects to appear in the videos. This
problem can be addressed by video inpainting, which enables the natural removal
of such objects while preserving both spatial and temporal consistency.
Nevertheless, most existing methods assume processing ordinary videos with a
