narrow field of view and do not tackle the distortion in equirectangular
projection of omnidirectional videos. To address this issue, this paper
proposes a novel deep learning model for omnidirectional video inpainting,
called Distortion-Aware Omnidirectional Video Inpainting (DAOVI). DAOVI
introduces a module that evaluates temporal motion information in the image
space considering geodesic distance, as well as a depth-aware feature
propagation module in the feature space that is designed to address the
geometric distortion inherent to omnidirectional videos. The experimental
results demonstrate that our proposed method outperforms existing methods both
quantitatively and qualitatively.

AI.tldr: Proposes DAOVI, a distortion-aware deep model for omnidirectional video inpainting that uses geodesic-motion evaluation and depth-aware feature propagation, achieving superior spatial-temporal consistency and quality over prior methods.
AI.motivation: Omnidirectional (360°) videos have equirectangular distortion and wide FoV, causing unintended objects to appear and challenging inpainting with existing narrow-FoV methods that fail to preserve spatial/temporal consistency.
AI.method: A deep learning architecture named DAOVI with (1) a temporal motion evaluation module in image space using geodesic distance, and (2) a depth-aware feature propagation module in feature space to compensate for projection distortion in omnidirectional videos.
AI.result: Experiments show that DAOVI outperforms existing methods both quantitatively and qualitatively in inpainting omnidirectional videos.
AI.conclusion: DAOVI effectively addresses distortion and temporal consistency challenges in omnidirectional video inpainting, improving quality for VR, AR, and remote sensing applications.

title: Speech Foundation Models Generalize to Time Series Tasks from Wearable Sensor Data
summary:
Both speech and sensor time series data encode information in both the time-
and frequency- domains, like spectral powers and waveform shapelets. We show
that speech foundation models learn representations that are domain-independent
and achieve state-of-the-art performance on time series tasks from wearable
sensors. Probes trained on features extracted from HuBERT and wav2vec 2.0
outperform those extracted from self-supervised models trained directly on
modality specific datasets for mood classification, arrhythmia detection, and
activity classification tasks. We find a particularly strong relevance of the
convolutional feature encoders from speech models for wearable sensor tasks.
The methods proposed here improve performance and robustness for data-scarce
time series tasks, using simple probing methods. This work is a step towards
generalized time series models for speech and sensor data, a topic for further
exploration.

AI.tldr: Speech foundation models yield domain-independent representations that improve time-series tasks in wearables; probing shows HuBERT/wav2vec2.0 features outperform modality-specific SSL features, with convolutional encoders especially effective.
AI.motivation: Bridge speech and sensor time-series representations to enable generalized, robust models, particularly in data-scarce wearable analytics.
AI.method: Use probes trained on features extracted from HuBERT and wav2vec 2.0 pretrained on speech; compare against probes using modality-specific self-supervised features; evaluate on mood classification, arrhythmia detection, and activity classification; analyze encoder type (convolutional vs others).
AI.result: Speech SSL features outperform modality-specific SSL features for the evaluated tasks; convolutional feature encoders from speech models show strong relevance for wearable sensor tasks; simple probing yields improved performance and robustness in data-scarce settings.
AI.conclusion: Supports domain-independent representations and advances toward generalized time-series models for both speech and sensor data; motivates cross-domain pretraining and probing as a research direction.

title: A Hybrid Ai Framework For Strategic Patent Portfolio Pruning: Integrating Learning To-Rank And Market Need Analysis For Technology Transfer Optimization
comment:
Page 2, Figure 1 shows the conceptual architecture, and Page 11,
  Figure 2 outlines its end to end workflow for strategic patent portfolio
  pruning
summary:
This paper introduces a novel, multi stage hybrid intelligence framework for
pruning patent portfolios to identify high value assets for technology
transfer. Current patent valuation methods often rely on retrospective
indicators or manual, time intensive analysis. Our framework automates and
deepens this process by combining a Learning to Rank (LTR) model, which
evaluates patents against over 30 legal and commercial parameters, with a
unique "Need-Seed" agent-based system. The "Need Agent" uses Natural Language
Processing (NLP) to mine unstructured market and industry data, identifying
explicit technological needs. Concurrently, the "Seed Agent" employs fine tuned
Large Language Models (LLMs) to analyze patent claims and map their
technological capabilities. The system generates a "Core Ontology Framework"
that matches high potential patents (Seeds) to documented market demands
(Needs), providing a strategic rationale for divestment decisions. We detail
the architecture, including a dynamic parameter weighting system and a crucial
Human in the-Loop (HITL) validation protocol, to ensure both adaptability and
real-world credibility.

AI.tldr: A multi-stage hybrid AI framework for pruning patent portfolios using Learning-to-Rank, Need-Agent NLP, Seed-Agent LLMs, plus a Core Ontology and HITL validation to support tech transfer decisions.
AI.motivation: Patent valuation often relies on retrospective indicators and manual, time-consuming analysis. There is a need for an automated, scalable, and credible method to identify high-value assets for technology transfer.
AI.method: A multi-stage pipeline: (1) a Learning-to-Rank (LTR) model evaluating patents across 30+ legal and commercial features; (2) a Need-Agent using NLP to mine unstructured market/industry data for explicit technological needs; (3) a Seed-Agent using fine-tuned LLMs to analyze patent claims and map technological capabilities; (4) a Core Ontology Framework aligning Seeds with Needs to justify divestment decisions; (5) dynamic parameter weighting; (6) Human-in-the-Loop (HITL) validation to ensure adaptability and credibility.
AI.result: The paper presents a conceptual architecture and workflow for an automated/practical system, but does not report empirical results within the abstract. It claims potential improvements in automation, depth of analysis, and strategic decision support for tech transfer.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework is a promising, adaptable approach to automate patent portfolio pruning and divestment decisions, though it requires empirical validation, robust evaluation, and attention to data, bias, and implementation challenges in real-world settings.

title: Enhanced Mean Field Game for Interactive Decision-Making with Varied Stylish Multi-Vehicles
summary:
This paper presents an MFG-based decision-making framework for autonomous
driving in heterogeneous traffic. To capture diverse human behaviors, we
propose a quantitative driving style representation that maps abstract traits
to parameters such as speed, safety factors, and reaction time. These
parameters are embedded into the MFG through a spatial influence field model.
To ensure safe operation in dense traffic, we introduce a safety-critical
lane-changing algorithm that leverages dynamic safety margins,
time-to-collision analysis, and multi-layered constraints. Real-world NGSIM
data is employed for style calibration and empirical validation. Experimental
results demonstrate zero collisions across six style combinations, two
15-vehicle scenarios, and NGSIM-based trials, consistently outperforming
conventional game-theoretic baselines. Overall, our approach provides a
scalable, interpretable, and behavior-aware planning framework for real-world
autonomous driving applications.

AI.tldr: An MFG-based decision-making framework for autonomous driving that models heterogeneous human driving styles via a style-to-parameter map embedded in a mean-field game with a safety-aware lane-changing module, validated on NGSIM data with zero-collision results and outperforms baselines.
AI.motivation: There is a need for scalable, interpretable planning in heterogeneous traffic. Traditional game-theoretic approaches struggle to capture diverse human behavior and dense traffic safety. Providing interpretable driving styles and a safety-aware framework can improve safety and performance in real-world autonomous driving.
AI.method: Define driving styles by abstract traits mapped to concrete parameters (speed, safety factor, reaction time). Embed these parameters into a mean-field game through a spatial influence field. Develop a safety-critical lane-changing algorithm using dynamic safety margins, time-to-collision analysis, and multi-layered constraints. Calibrate style using NGSIM data and validate in real-world-like scenarios.
AI.result: Zero collisions observed across six style combinations, two 15-vehicle scenarios, and NGSIM-based trials. Outperforms conventional game-theoretic baselines and demonstrates scalability, interpretability, and behavior-aware planning.
AI.conclusion: The proposed MFG-based framework offers a scalable, interpretable, and safety-conscious planning approach for autonomous driving in heterogeneous traffic, with demonstrated robustness and real-world applicability.

title: DevilSight: Augmenting Monocular Human Avatar Reconstruction through a Virtual Perspective
summary:
We present a novel framework to reconstruct human avatars from monocular
videos. Recent approaches have struggled either to capture the fine-grained
dynamic details from the input or to generate plausible details at novel
viewpoints, which mainly stem from the limited representational capacity of the
avatar model and insufficient observational data. To overcome these challenges,
we propose to leverage the advanced video generative model, Human4DiT, to
generate the human motions from alternative perspective as an additional
supervision signal. This approach not only enriches the details in previously
unseen regions but also effectively regularizes the avatar representation to
mitigate artifacts. Furthermore, we introduce two complementary strategies to
enhance video generation: To ensure consistent reproduction of human motion, we
inject the physical identity into the model through video fine-tuning. For
higher-resolution outputs with finer details, a patch-based denoising algorithm
is employed. Experimental results demonstrate that our method outperforms
recent state-of-the-art approaches and validate the effectiveness of our
proposed strategies.

AI.tldr: Monocular-avatar reconstruction using Human4DiT-based multi-view supervision, plus video identity fine-tuning and patch-based denoising to boost detail, consistency, and high-resolution outputs, achieving state-of-the-art results.
AI.motivation: Existing monocular-avatar methods struggle to capture fine-grained dynamics and plausible novel-view details due to limited representational capacity and insufficient observational data. Leveraging an advanced video-generation model to provide alternative-view supervision can enrich unseen regions and regularize the avatar model.
AI.method: The framework uses Human4DiT to generate human motions from alternative viewpoints as additional supervision signals. To enhance motion consistency and detail, two strategies are employed: (1) inject physical identity into the model via video fine-tuning, and (2) apply a patch-based denoising algorithm for high-resolution outputs.
AI.result: Experimental results show the proposed method outperforms recent state-of-the-art approaches and validate the effectiveness of the proposed strategies.
AI.conclusion: The approach improves reconstruction quality and robustness, enriching details in previously unseen regions and ensuring consistent motion, with the potential for higher-resolution, artifact-reduced avatar reconstructions.

title: Quantum-Optimized Selective State Space Model for Efficient Time Series Prediction
summary:
Long-range time series forecasting remains challenging, as it requires
capturing non-stationary and multi-scale temporal dependencies while
maintaining noise robustness, efficiency, and stability. Transformer-based
architectures such as Autoformer and Informer improve generalization but suffer
from quadratic complexity and degraded performance on very long time horizons.
State space models, notably S-Mamba, provide linear-time updates but often face
unstable training dynamics, sensitivity to initialization, and limited
robustness for multivariate forecasting. To address such challenges, we propose
the Quantum-Optimized Selective State Space Model (Q-SSM), a hybrid
quantum-optimized approach that integrates state space dynamics with a
variational quantum gate. Instead of relying on expensive attention mechanisms,
Q-SSM employs a simple parametrized quantum circuit (RY-RX ansatz) whose
expectation values regulate memory updates adaptively. This quantum gating
mechanism improves convergence stability, enhances the modeling of long-term
dependencies, and provides a lightweight alternative to attention. We
empirically validate Q-SSM on three widely used benchmarks, i.e., ETT, Traffic,
and Exchange Rate. Results show that Q-SSM consistently improves over strong
baselines (LSTM, TCN, Reformer), Transformer-based models, and S-Mamba. These
findings demonstrate that variational quantum gating can address current
limitations in long-range forecasting, leading to accurate and robust
multivariate predictions.

AI.tldr: Q-SSM is a hybrid quantum-optimized state-space model that uses a variational quantum gate to regulate memory updates, offering a lightweight alternative to attention for long-range multivariate time series forecasting and achieving improved accuracy and stability over strong baselines.
AI.motivation: Long-range time series forecasting is hard due to non-stationarity and multi-scale temporal dependencies, requiring robustness to noise, efficiency, and stability. Transformer-based models have quadratic complexity and degrade on very long horizons, while linear-time SSMs like S-Mamba can be unstable and less robust for multivariate forecasting.
AI.method: Propose Quantum-Optimized Selective State Space Model (Q-SSM) that integrates state-space dynamics with a parametrized quantum circuit (RY-RX ansatz). The expectation values from the quantum circuit regulate memory updates adaptively, serving as a gating mechanism without relying on attention.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on three benchmarks (ETT, Traffic, Exchange Rate) shows Q-SSM consistently improves over strong baselines (LSTM, TCN, Reformer), Transformer-based models, and S-Mamba.
AI.conclusion: Variational quantum gating can address current limitations in long-range forecasting, yielding accurate and robust multivariate predictions with a lightweight, stable alternative to attention-based methods.

title: Ultra Strong Machine Learning: Teaching Humans Active Learning Strategies via Automated AI Explanations
summary:
Ultra Strong Machine Learning (USML) refers to symbolic learning systems that
not only improve their own performance but can also teach their acquired
knowledge to quantifiably improve human performance. In this work, we present
LENS (Logic Programming Explanation via Neural Summarisation), a neuro-symbolic
method that combines symbolic program synthesis with large language models
(LLMs) to automate the explanation of machine-learned logic programs in natural
language. LENS addresses a key limitation of prior USML approaches by replacing
hand-crafted explanation templates with scalable automated generation. Through
systematic evaluation using multiple LLM judges and human validation, we
demonstrate that LENS generates superior explanations compared to direct LLM
prompting and hand-crafted templates. To investigate whether LENS can teach
transferable active learning strategies, we carried out a human learning
experiment across three related domains. Our results show no significant human
performance improvements, suggesting that comprehensive LLM responses may
overwhelm users for simpler problems rather than providing learning support.
Our work provides a solid foundation for building effective USML systems to
support human learning. The source code is available on:
https://github.com/lun-ai/LENS.git.

AI.tldr: LENS uses neuro-symbolic techniques to automatically generate natural-language explanations of learned logic programs using LLMs, outperforming prompt-based prompts and hand-crafted templates; but human-learning transfer is limited, suggesting possible cognitive overload.
AI.motivation: USML aims for systems that not only improve ML performance but also teach humans. Scalable, natural-language explanations are needed to transfer knowledge from symbolic learned logic programs to human users, reducing manual engineering of templates.
AI.method: Integrates symbolic program synthesis with large language models to generate natural-language explanations of machine-learned logic programs. Replaces hand-crafted explanation templates with automated generation; evaluates with multiple LLM judges and human validation; investigates transfer learning in humans across three related domains; code released at the provided URL.
AI.result: LENS produces explanations rated superior to direct prompting and to hand-crafted templates across multiple judges. However, human learning experiments show no significant performance gains, suggesting that comprehensive LLM responses may overwhelm users for simpler problems.
AI.conclusion: LENS provides a solid foundation for USML systems to support human learning and demonstrates scalable automated explanation generation. It also highlights the potential downside of overly comprehensive LLM-driven explanations for easy tasks, indicating directions for more user-adaptive explanations and future work.

title: A Robust Numerical Method for Solving Trigonometric Equations in Robotic Kinematics
summary:
This paper presents a robust numerical method for solving systems of
trigonometric equations commonly encountered in robotic kinematics. Our
approach employs polynomial substitution techniques combined with eigenvalue
decomposition to handle singular matrices and edge cases effectively. The
method demonstrates superior numerical stability compared to traditional
approaches and has been implemented as an open-source Python package. For
non-singular matrices, we employ Weierstrass substitution to transform the
system into a quartic polynomial, ensuring all analytical solutions are found.
For singular matrices, we develop specialized geometric constraint methods
using SVD analysis. The solver demonstrates machine precision accuracy ($<
10^{-15}$ error) with 100\% success rate on extensive test cases, making it
particularly valuable for robotics applications such as inverse kinematics
problems.

AI.tldr: A robust solver for trig systems in robotic kinematics using polynomial substitution, eigenvalue decomposition, Weierstrass substitution for non-singular cases, and SVD-based constraints for singular cases; claims machine-precision accuracy and an open-source Python package.
AI.motivation: There is a need for stable, accurate methods to solve trigonometric equations that arise in robotics, especially near singular configurations, to improve reliability of inverse kinematics.
AI.method: For non-singular matrices, apply Weierstrass substitution to convert the trig system into a quartic polynomial and solve analytically. For singular matrices, develop specialized geometric constraint methods based on SVD analysis. The approach relies on polynomial substitution and eigenvalue decomposition to handle edge cases and singularities, implemented in an open-source Python package.
AI.result: Demonstrates machine-precision accuracy (<1e-15 error) with a 100% success rate across extensive test cases, outperforming traditional approaches in numerical stability.
AI.conclusion: Produces a robust, precise solver for trig systems in robotics, particularly useful for inverse kinematics; the open-source implementation supports adoption and further development.

title: LightVLM: Acceleraing Large Multimodal Models with Pyramid Token Merging and KV Cache Compression
summary:
In this paper, we introduce LightVLM, a simple but effective method that can
be seamlessly deployed upon existing Vision-Language Models (VLMs) to greatly
accelerate the inference process in a training-free manner. We divide the
inference procedure of VLMs into two stages, i.e., encoding and decoding, and
propose to simultaneously accelerate VLMs in both stages to largely improve
model efficiency. During encoding, we propose pyramid token merging to reduce
tokens of different LLM layers in a hierarchical manner by finally only keeping
a few dominant tokens to achieve high efficiency. During decoding, aimed at
reducing the high latency of outputting long sequences, we propose KV Cache
compression to remove unnecessary caches to increase the network throughput.
Experimental results show that LightVLM successfully retains 100% performance
when only preserving 35% image tokens, and maintains around 98% performance
when keeping only 3% image tokens. LightVLM could 2.02$\times$ the network
throughput and reduce the prefilling time by 3.65$\times$. LightVLM also makes
large VLMs faster again by enabling a heavy model (e.g., InternVL2.5 26B) to
infer faster than significantly smaller models (e.g., InternVL2.5 8B),
hopefully facilitating the real-world deployment. When generating long text
sequences (e.g., 4096 tokens), LightVLM could reduce the inference time by
3.21$\times$, largely outperforming existing methods.

AI.tldr: LightVLM accelerates Vision-Language Models by hierarchical encoding token merging and KV-cache compression during decoding, achieving substantial speedups with minimal accuracy loss, enabling faster inference for large VLMs.
AI.motivation: To reduce inference latency and improve throughput of large vision-language models without retraining, addressing bottlenecks in both encoding and decoding stages.
AI.method: A two-stage plug-in approach: (1) encoding uses pyramid token merging across LLM layers to retain a small set of dominant tokens; (2) decoding uses KV-cache compression to remove unnecessary caches, all training-free and compatible with existing VLMs.
AI.result: Maintains 100% performance when preserving 35% of image tokens and ~98% when keeping 3% tokens; achieves 2.02x network throughput and 3.65x prefilling time reduction; enables large models to infer faster than smaller ones; 3.21x faster for 4,096-token generation.
AI.conclusion: LightVLM is an effective, deployment-friendly method to accelerate VLM inference without retraining, delivering substantial speedups while preserving accuracy, and enabling efficient use of large Vision-Language Models in real-world deployment.

title: ReLATE: Learning Efficient Sparse Encoding for High-Performance Tensor Decomposition
summary:
Tensor decomposition (TD) is essential for analyzing high-dimensional sparse
data, yet its irregular computations and memory-access patterns pose major
performance challenges on modern parallel processors. Prior works rely on
expert-designed sparse tensor formats that fail to adapt to irregular tensor
shapes and/or highly variable data distributions. We present the
reinforcement-learned adaptive tensor encoding (ReLATE) framework, a novel
learning-augmented method that automatically constructs efficient sparse tensor
representations without labeled training samples. ReLATE employs an autonomous
agent that discovers optimized tensor encodings through direct interaction with
the TD environment, leveraging a hybrid model-free and model-based algorithm to
learn from both real and imagined actions. Moreover, ReLATE introduces
rule-driven action masking and dynamics-informed action filtering mechanisms
that ensure functionally correct tensor encoding with bounded execution time,
even during early learning stages. By automatically adapting to both irregular
tensor shapes and data distributions, ReLATE generates sparse tensor
representations that consistently outperform expert-designed formats across
diverse sparse tensor data sets, achieving up to 2X speedup compared to the
best sparse format, with a geometric-mean speedup of 1.4-1.46X.

AI.tldr: ReLATE proposes a learning-augmented, reinforcement-learned adaptive tensor encoding to automatically build sparse tensor representations for tensor decomposition, yielding robust performance without labeled data and outperforming expert-designed formats.
AI.motivation: High-dimensional sparse data and irregular access patterns hamper performance; existing formats are hand-designed and inflexible; need data-adaptive encoding without labeled data.
AI.method: Autonomous RL agent with hybrid model-free/model-based learning to discover tensor encodings via interaction with the TD environment; rule-based action masking; dynamics-informed action filtering to guarantee correctness and bounded runtime; learning from real and imagined actions; no labels required.
AI.result: Sparse encodings learned by ReLATE outperform expert-designed formats across diverse datasets with up to 2x speedup over the best sparse format; geometric mean speedup 1.4-1.46x; adaptable to irregular shapes and distributions.
AI.conclusion: ReLATE enables automatic, data-adaptive sparse tensor encoding for TD, reducing manual engineering and delivering consistent performance improvements across datasets.

title: CoreThink: A Symbolic Reasoning Layer to reason over Long Horizon Tasks with LLMs
summary:
We introduce CoreThink, a state-of-the-art Reasoning Layer built upon a novel
reasoning method called General Symbolics. This approach diverges from
reasoning paradigms such as test-time scaling, Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT),
and Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR). CoreThink General
Symbolic Reasoner (GSR) is specifically structured around three key use cases:
tool-calling, code generation, and planning, demonstrating exemplary
performance across a total of seven benchmarks in their respective areas.
Notably, we are achieving SOTA scores of 66.66\% on Livecodebench v6, 89\% on
Instruction-Following Evals, and 24.4\% on ARC-AGI-2. We also present an
agentic coding IDE, developed using the principles of General Symbolics, which
achieves a state-of-the-art accuracy of 62.3\% on \texttt{SWE-Bench Lite}. We
are able to achieve these improvements without any finetuning or training
costs. Our Reasoning Layer is designed to provide a pure performance uplift,
ensuring that a model's accuracy on reasoning tasks is never negatively
impacted. We argue that incumbent methods will eventually lead to diminishing
returns in LLM performance, necessitating the development of new reasoning
techniques. This technical report details our approach at a high level and the
availability of the CoreThink models for reasoning-intensive use cases.

AI.tldr: CoreThink introduces General Symbolics, a new reasoning layer (GSR) that boosts performance on tool-calling, code generation, and planning without fine-tuning, achieving SOTA on several benchmarks and proposing an agentic coding IDE.
AI.motivation: There is a need for new reasoning techniques beyond scaling and standard RL/SFT approaches to push reasoning performance without training overhead and to overcome diminishing returns of incumbent methods.
AI.method: Proposes General Symbolics and CoreThink Reasoning Layer with three targeted use cases (tool-calling, code generation, planning). It avoids test-time scaling, SFT, and RLVR, requires no finetuning or training costs, and claims to achieve pure performance uplift.
AI.result: SOTA scores: 66.66% Livecodebench v6, 89% Instruction-Following Evals, 24.4% ARC-AGI-2; SWE-Bench Lite 62.3%; performance across seven benchmarks; implementation availability; no training cost.
AI.conclusion: Encourages shift from incumbent methods due to diminishing returns and introduces a high-level description of CoreThink; availability for reasoning-intensive use cases.

title: TARA: A Low-Cost 3D-Printed Robotic Arm for Accessible Robotics Education
summary:
The high cost of robotic platforms limits students' ability to gain practical
skills directly applicable in real-world scenarios. To address this challenge,
this paper presents TARA, a low-cost, 3D-printed robotic arm designed for
accessible robotics education. TARA includes an open-source repository with
design files, assembly instructions, and baseline code, enabling users to build
and customize the platform. The system balances affordability and
functionality, offering a highly capable robotic arm for approximately 200 USD,
significantly lower than industrial systems that often cost thousands of
dollars. Experimental validation confirmed accurate performance in basic
manipulation tasks. Rather than focusing on performance benchmarking, this work
prioritizes educational reproducibility, providing a platform that students and
educators can reliably replicate and extend.

AI.tldr: Introduces TARA, a low-cost 3D-printed robotic arm (~$200) with open-source design, aiming for educational reproducibility and basic manipulation performance; experimentally validated on basic tasks.
AI.motivation: Lower the barrier to robotics education by reducing cost and enabling reliable replication of a capable manipulator for learning and experimentation.
AI.method: Design and prototyping of a 3D-printed arm (TARA) with open-source design files, assembly instructions, and baseline code; experimental validation on basic manipulation tasks.
AI.result: Experimental validation showed accurate performance in basic manipulation tasks; platform is affordable and reproducible.
AI.conclusion: TARA provides an accessible, reproducible educational platform that balances affordability with functional capability, enabling students and educators to build, customize, and extend the system.

title: Mixture of Global and Local Experts with Diffusion Transformer for Controllable Face Generation
summary:
Controllable face generation poses critical challenges in generative modeling
due to the intricate balance required between semantic controllability and
photorealism. While existing approaches struggle with disentangling semantic
controls from generation pipelines, we revisit the architectural potential of
Diffusion Transformers (DiTs) through the lens of expert specialization. This
paper introduces Face-MoGLE, a novel framework featuring: (1)
Semantic-decoupled latent modeling through mask-conditioned space
factorization, enabling precise attribute manipulation; (2) A mixture of global
and local experts that captures holistic structure and region-level semantics
for fine-grained controllability; (3) A dynamic gating network producing
time-dependent coefficients that evolve with diffusion steps and spatial
locations. Face-MoGLE provides a powerful and flexible solution for
high-quality, controllable face generation, with strong potential in generative
modeling and security applications. Extensive experiments demonstrate its
effectiveness in multimodal and monomodal face generation settings and its
robust zero-shot generalization capability. Project page is available at
https://github.com/XavierJiezou/Face-MoGLE.

AI.tldr: Face-MoGLE enables controllable face generation via semantic-decoupled latent space, global/local mixture-of-experts, and a dynamic diffusion-gating mechanism for fine-grained control and zero-shot generalization.
AI.motivation: Address the trade-off between semantic controllability and photorealism in face generation by rethinking architectural roles with diffusion transformers and expert specialization.
AI.method: Mask-conditioned space factorization for semantic-decoupled latent modeling; a mixture of global and local experts to capture holistic structure and region-level semantics; a dynamic gating network producing time-step and location-dependent coefficients.
AI.result: Shows effectiveness in both multimodal and monomodal face generation and robust zero-shot generalization, with a project page for implementation.
AI.conclusion: Face-MoGLE offers a powerful, flexible framework for high-quality, controllable face generation with potential applications in generative modeling and security, supported by extensive experiments and a public codebase.

title: Continuously Tempered Diffusion Samplers
summary:
Annealing-based neural samplers seek to amortize sampling from unnormalized
distributions by training neural networks to transport a family of densities
interpolating from source to target. A crucial design choice in the training
phase of such samplers is the proposal distribution by which locations are
generated at which to evaluate the loss. Previous work has obtained such a
proposal distribution by combining a partially learned transport with annealed
Langevin dynamics. However, isolated modes and other pathological properties of
the annealing path imply that such proposals achieve insufficient exploration
and thereby lower performance post training. To remedy this, we propose
continuously tempered diffusion samplers, which leverage exploration techniques
developed in the context of molecular dynamics to improve proposal
distributions. Specifically, a family of distributions across different
temperatures is introduced to lower energy barriers at higher temperatures and
drive exploration at the lower temperature of interest. We empirically validate
improved sampler performance driven by extended exploration. Code is available
at https://github.com/eje24/ctds.

AI.tldr: Proposes continuously tempered diffusion samplers to improve exploration in annealing-based neural samplers by using a temperature-annealed family of distributions.
AI.motivation: Isolated modes and pathologies in annealing paths cause insufficient exploration, leading to degraded sampler performance after training.
AI.method: Introduce a continuously tempered diffusion framework: a family of distributions across temperatures lowers energy barriers at high temperatures to promote exploration, then focuses at the target temperature for sampling.
AI.result: Empirical experiments show improved sampler performance due to the extended exploration enabled by continuous tempering; code is provided.
AI.conclusion: Continuous tempering in diffusion samplers enhances exploratory behavior and performance of annealing-based neural samplers; code release facilitates reproducibility.

title: Self-Exploring Language Models for Explainable Link Forecasting on Temporal Graphs via Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Forecasting future links is a central task in temporal graph (TG) reasoning,
requiring models to leverage historical interactions to predict upcoming ones.
Traditional neural approaches, such as temporal graph neural networks, achieve
strong performance but lack explainability and cannot be applied to unseen
graphs without retraining. Recent studies have begun to explore using large
language models (LLMs) for graph reasoning, but most of them are constrained to
static graphs or small synthetic TGs and lack the evaluation of the quality of
reasoning traces generated by LLMs. In this work, we present Reasoning-Enhanced
Learning for Temporal Graphs (ReaL-TG), a reinforcement learning framework that
fine-tunes LLMs to perform explainable link forecasting on real-world TGs.
ReaL-TG uses outcome-based reward to encourage models to self-explore reasoning
strategies from graph structure and to produce explanations that directly
justify their predictions. To enable evaluation on LLM-generated reasoning
traces, we propose a new evaluation protocol combining ranking metrics with an
LLM-as-a-Judge system that assesses both the quality of reasoning and the
impact of hallucinations. Experiments with ReaL-TG-4B, obtained by fine-tuning
Qwen3-4B under our framework, show that it outperforms much larger frontier
LLMs, including GPT-5 mini, on ranking metrics, while producing high-quality
explanations confirmed by both the LLM judge and human evaluation.

AI.tldr: Proposes ReaL-TG, a reinforcement learning framework that fine-tunes LLMs for explainable temporal-graph link forecasting, using outcome-based rewards and an LLM-as-a-judge evaluation; achieves strong ranking metrics and high-quality explanations with a 4B model (ReaL-TG-4B) that outperforms larger frontier LLMs on ranking tasks and is validated by human judgments.
AI.motivation: To address explainability and generalization in temporal-graph forecasting. Traditional temporal GNNs lack interpretable reasoning and do not generalize to unseen graphs without retraining; while LLM-based graph reasoning offers explainability but has been evaluated mainly on static/small graphs and lacks assessment of reasoning quality. The work targets explainable, scalable TG reasoning with evaluation of reasoning traces.
AI.method: Introduce ReaL-TG, an RL-based framework that fine-tunes LLMs for explainable link forecasting on real-world TGs. Uses outcome-based rewards to encourage self-exploration of reasoning strategies from graph structure and production of explanations that justify predictions. Proposes an evaluation protocol combining ranking metrics with an LLM-as-a-Judge system to assess reasoning quality and hallucinations. Demonstrates ReaL-TG-4B (fine-tuned Qwen3-4B) outperforming larger frontier LLMs on ranking metrics and yielding high-quality explanations per LLM judge and human evaluation.
AI.result: The approach achieves superior ranking performance compared to much larger frontier LLMs (including GPT-5 mini) and produces explanations that are rated high by both the LLM judge and human evaluators.
AI.conclusion: RL fine-tuning of a 4B-class LLM can deliver competitive, explainable temporal-graph link forecasting without resorting to extremely large models. The proposed LLM-driven evaluation protocol enables measuring reasoning quality and mitigating hallucinations, underscoring the viability of explainable TG reasoning with relatively small models.

title: A Reactive Grasping Framework for Multi-DoF Grippers via Task Space Velocity Fields and Joint Space QP
summary:
We present a fast and reactive grasping framework for multi-DoF grippers that
combines task-space velocity fields with a joint-space Quadratic Program (QP)
in a hierarchical structure. Reactive, collision-free global motion planning is
particularly challenging for high-DoF systems, since simultaneous increases in
state dimensionality and planning horizon trigger a combinatorial explosion of
the search space, making real-time planning intractable. To address this, we
plan globally in a lower-dimensional task space, such as fingertip positions,
and track locally in the full joint space while enforcing all constraints. This
approach is realized by constructing velocity fields in multiple task-space
coordinates (or in some cases a subset of joint coordinates) and solving a
weighted joint-space QP to compute joint velocities that track these fields
with appropriately assigned priorities. Through simulation experiments with
privileged knowledge and real-world tests using the recent pose-tracking
algorithm FoundationPose, we verify that our method enables high-DoF arm-hand
systems to perform real-time, collision-free reaching motions while adapting to
dynamic environments and external disturbances.

AI.tldr: A fast, reactive grasping framework for high-DoF robotic hands that merges task-space velocity fields with a hierarchical joint-space QP, enabling real-time, collision-free reaching by planning in low-dimensional task space and tracking in full joint space.
AI.motivation: High-DoF planning suffers combinatorial explosion in state space and planning horizon, making real-time planning difficult. The work targets robust, collision-free grasping in dynamic environments by reducing planning dimensionality and handling constraints.
AI.method: Construct velocity fields in multiple task-space coordinates (e.g., fingertip positions) or a subset of joints, and solve a weighted joint-space QP to compute joint velocities that track these fields with assigned priorities. Plan globally in task space and track locally in the full joint space within a hierarchical framework, enforcing constraints. Evaluations include simulations (with privileged knowledge) and real-world tests using FoundationPose for pose tracking.
AI.result: Demonstrates real-time, collision-free reaching motions for high-DoF arm-hand systems in dynamic environments and under disturbances, validated through simulations and real-world experiments.
AI.conclusion: A hierarchical, task-space velocity-field plus joint-space QP approach enables fast, reactive grasping for high-DoF hands, combining low-dimensional global planning with local, constraint-aware execution.

title: SemaMIL: Semantic Reordering with Retrieval-Guided State Space Modeling for Whole Slide Image Classification
summary:
Multiple instance learning (MIL) has become the leading approach for
extracting discriminative features from whole slide images (WSIs) in
computational pathology. Attention-based MIL methods can identify key patches
but tend to overlook contextual relationships. Transformer models are able to
model interactions but require quadratic computational cost and are prone to
overfitting. State space models (SSMs) offer linear complexity, yet shuffling
patch order disrupts histological meaning and reduces interpretability. In this
work, we introduce SemaMIL, which integrates Semantic Reordering (SR), an
adaptive method that clusters and arranges semantically similar patches in
sequence through a reversible permutation, with a Semantic-guided Retrieval
State Space Module (SRSM) that chooses a representative subset of queries to
adjust state space parameters for improved global modeling. Evaluation on four
WSI subtype datasets shows that, compared to strong baselines, SemaMIL achieves
state-of-the-art accuracy with fewer FLOPs and parameters.

AI.tldr: SemaMIL blends Semantic Reordering (SR) with a Semantic-guided Retrieval State Space Module (SRSM) to improve multiple instance learning on whole-slide images, achieving state-of-the-art accuracy with lower FLOPs and fewer parameters by preserving semantic patch relationships and enabling efficient global modeling.
AI.motivation: MIL on whole-slide images must capture broad histopathological context. Attention-based MIL identifies key patches but neglects relationships; transformers offer global modeling but are costly and prone to overfitting; state-space models are efficient but shuffling patch order degrades interpretability. A method that preserves semantic order while enabling scalable global reasoning is needed.
AI.method: Semantic Reordering (SR) clusters semantically similar patches and arranges them in a reversible permutation to create semantically meaningful sequences. Semantic-guided Retrieval State Space Module (SRSM) selects a representative subset of queries to adapt the state-space parameters, enabling global interactions with linear complexity.
AI.result: Evaluation on four WSI subtype datasets shows SemaMIL achieving state-of-the-art accuracy with fewer FLOPs and parameters compared to strong baselines.
AI.conclusion: SemaMIL effectively integrates semantic ordering with retrieval-based state-space modeling to enhance MIL on WSIs, delivering strong performance gains while maintaining efficiency and interpretability.

title: Chunked TabPFN: Exact Training-Free In-Context Learning for Long-Context Tabular Data
summary:
TabPFN v2 achieves better results than tree-based models on several tabular
benchmarks, which is notable since tree-based models are usually the strongest
choice for tabular data. However, it cannot handle more than 10K context tokens
because transformers have quadratic computation and memory costs.
  Unlike existing approaches that rely on context compression, such as
selecting representative samples via K-nearest neighbors (KNN), we introduce a
\textbf{tiled-block} strategy to compute attention within the TabPFN framework.
This design is compatible with standard GPU setups and, to the best of our
knowledge, is the first to enable TabPFN to \textbf{process long contexts
without any pre-processing}. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach
on the standard TabArena benchmark.

AI.tldr: Proposes a tiled-block attention strategy to enable TabPFN v2 to process long contexts (>10k tokens) without context pre-processing, demonstrated on TabArena.
AI.motivation: TabPFN v2 achieves strong tabular results but is bottlenecked by quadratic memory/computation for transformers, limiting to ~10k tokens; existing context compression (e.g., KNN) loses information. Need a way to handle long contexts directly.
AI.method: Introduce tiled-block attention within TabPFN to compute attention in blocks (tiles), enabling long-context processing on standard GPUs without pre-processing. Compatible with existing TabPFN architecture.
AI.result: Empirically validated on the TabArena benchmark, showing effectiveness in processing long contexts; demonstrates practical scalability.
AI.conclusion: The tiled-block approach removes the need for context compression and enables TabPFN v2 to handle long contexts efficiently, broadening applicability on tabular benchmarks.

title: Causal MAS: A Survey of Large Language Model Architectures for Discovery and Effect Estimation
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in
various reasoning and generation tasks. However, their proficiency in complex
causal reasoning, discovery, and estimation remains an area of active
development, often hindered by issues like hallucination, reliance on spurious
correlations, and difficulties in handling nuanced, domain-specific, or
personalized causal relationships. Multi-agent systems, leveraging the
collaborative or specialized abilities of multiple LLM-based agents, are
emerging as a powerful paradigm to address these limitations. This review paper
explores the burgeoning field of causal multi-agent LLMs. We examine how these
systems are designed to tackle different facets of causality, including causal
reasoning and counterfactual analysis, causal discovery from data, and the
estimation of causal effects. We delve into the diverse architectural patterns
and interaction protocols employed, from pipeline-based processing and debate
frameworks to simulation environments and iterative refinement loops.
Furthermore, we discuss the evaluation methodologies, benchmarks, and diverse
application domains where causal multi-agent LLMs are making an impact,
including scientific discovery, healthcare, fact-checking, and personalized
systems. Finally, we highlight the persistent challenges, open research
questions, and promising future directions in this synergistic field, aiming to
provide a comprehensive overview of its current state and potential trajectory.

AI.tldr: A comprehensive survey of causal multi-agent LLMs, outlining architectural patterns, tasks (causal reasoning, discovery, estimation), evaluation, applications, and open challenges.
AI.motivation: LLMs struggle with complex causality and personalized reasoning; multi-agent collaborations can mitigate hallucinations and spurious correlations and enable more robust, domain-specific causal modeling. A systematic overview is needed to organize methods and guide future work.
AI.method: A literature review and taxonomy of causal multi-agent LLMs. The paper categorizes architectures and interaction protocols (pipeline-based processing, debate frameworks, simulation environments, iterative refinement), surveys evaluation methodologies and benchmarks, and maps application domains. It also synthesizes challenges and open questions to chart future directions.
AI.result: Provides a structured taxonomy of causal multi-agent LLM designs, identifies common design patterns for addressing causality, analyzes evaluation methodologies and benchmarks, and maps current applications (scientific discovery, healthcare, fact-checking, personalized systems). Highlights gaps in benchmarks and evaluation and summarizes practical limitations and potential solutions.
AI.conclusion: Causal multi-agent LLMs are a promising direction for advancing causal reasoning across domains, but significant challenges remain (robust evaluation, data alignment, personalization, and safety). The paper emphasizes standardized benchmarks, richer simulation environments, and cross-domain collaboration as key future directions.

title: Model Predictive Control for a Soft Robotic Finger with Stochastic Behavior based on Fokker-Planck Equation
comment:
6 pages, 7 figures, presented/published at 2025 IEEE 8th
  International Conference on Soft Robotics (RoboSoft)
summary:
The inherent flexibility of soft robots offers numerous advantages, such as
enhanced adaptability and improved safety. However, this flexibility can also
introduce challenges regarding highly uncertain and nonlinear motion. These
challenges become particularly problematic when using open-loop control
methods, which lack a feedback mechanism and are commonly employed in soft
robot control. Though one potential solution is model-based control, typical
deterministic models struggle with uncertainty as mentioned above. The idea is
to use the Fokker-Planck Equation (FPE), a master equation of a stochastic
process, to control not the state of soft robots but the probabilistic
distribution. In this study, we propose and implement a stochastic-based
control strategy, termed FPE-based Model Predictive Control (FPE-MPC), for a
soft robotic finger. Two numerical simulation case studies examine the
performance and characteristics of this control method, revealing its efficacy
in managing the uncertainty inherent in soft robotic systems.

AI.tldr: Proposes FPE-based Model Predictive Control (FPE-MPC) to govern the probability distribution of a soft robotic finger, addressing high uncertainty with stochastic dynamics; demonstrated via two numerical simulations.
AI.motivation: Soft robots' inherent flexibility enables adaptability and safety but leads to highly uncertain, nonlinear dynamics. Open-loop and deterministic models struggle under this uncertainty, motivating a probabilistic control approach using the Fokker-Planck Equation.
AI.method: Model the state distribution evolution with the Fokker-Planck Equation and apply MPC on the distribution (FPE-MPC) to compute control inputs. Validate with two numerical simulation case studies on a soft robotic finger to assess performance under stochastic effects.
AI.result: Two numerical simulations show that FPE-MPC can manage uncertainty in soft robotic systems, effectively shaping the state distribution and improving performance under stochastic dynamics.
AI.conclusion: FPE-MPC is a promising probabilistic control framework for soft robots with uncertain dynamics, capable of steering the probability distribution instead of exact states; future work could include experimental validation, comparison with other stochastic controllers, and computational optimization.

title: Stage-wise Adaptive Label Distribution for Facial Age Estimation
summary:
Label ambiguity poses a significant challenge in age estimation tasks. Most
existing methods address this issue by modeling correlations between adjacent
age groups through label distribution learning. However, they often overlook
the varying degrees of ambiguity present across different age stages. In this
paper, we propose a Stage-wise Adaptive Label Distribution Learning (SA-LDL)
algorithm, which leverages the observation -- revealed through our analysis of
embedding similarities between an anchor and all other ages -- that label
ambiguity exhibits clear stage-wise patterns. By jointly employing stage-wise
adaptive variance modeling and weighted loss function, SA-LDL effectively
captures the complex and structured nature of label ambiguity, leading to more
accurate and robust age estimation. Extensive experiments demonstrate that
SA-LDL achieves competitive performance, with MAE of 1.74 and 2.15 on the
MORPH-II and FG-NET datasets.

AI.tldr: Stage-wise Adaptive Label Distribution Learning (SA-LDL) for age estimation that models stage-specific label ambiguity via adaptive variance and weighted losses, leveraging embedding similarities to reveal stage-wise ambiguity; achieves MAE of 1.74 on MORPH-II and 2.15 on FG-NET.
AI.motivation: Label ambiguity in age estimation is not uniform across ages; existing label-distribution methods model only adjacent-age correlations and overlook varying ambiguity across age stages. A stage-aware approach could better capture structured ambiguity.
AI.method: Proposes SA-LDL with stage-wise adaptive variance modeling and a weighted loss within a label-distribution learning framework. Uses anchor-age embedding similarities to uncover stage-wise ambiguity patterns and jointly optimizes variance-aware distributions and weighted loss for robust age estimation.
AI.result: Demonstrates competitive performance with MAE values of 1.74 on MORPH-II and 2.15 on FG-NET, indicating improved robustness and accuracy.
AI.conclusion: Stage-wise adaptive modeling of label ambiguity captures its structured nature and improves age estimation robustness; SA-LDL offers a viable approach for datasets with stage-dependent ambiguity and may generalize to similar problems.

title: Counterfactual Risk Minimization with IPS-Weighted BPR and Self-Normalized Evaluation in Recommender Systems
comment:
Accepted at Causality, Counterfactuals & Sequential Decision-Making
  Workshop(CONSEQUENCES) at ACM Recommender Systems Conference(RecSys 25)
  Prague, Czech Republic
summary:
Learning and evaluating recommender systems from logged implicit feedback is
challenging due to exposure bias. While inverse propensity scoring (IPS)
corrects this bias, it often suffers from high variance and instability. In
this paper, we present a simple and effective pipeline that integrates
IPS-weighted training with an IPS-weighted Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR)
objective augmented by a Propensity Regularizer (PR). We compare Direct Method
(DM), IPS, and Self-Normalized IPS (SNIPS) for offline policy evaluation, and
demonstrate how IPS-weighted training improves model robustness under biased
exposure. The proposed PR further mitigates variance amplification from extreme
propensity weights, leading to more stable estimates. Experiments on synthetic
and MovieLens 100K data show that our approach generalizes better under
unbiased exposure while reducing evaluation variance compared to naive and
standard IPS methods, offering practical guidance for counterfactual learning
and evaluation in real-world recommendation settings.

AI.tldr: IPS-weighted training with a Propensity Regularizer (PR) improves stability and generalization in offline recommender evaluation by combining IPS-weighted BPR with a variance-reducing regularizer; outperforms naive IPS and DM/SNIPS in biased exposure settings.
AI.motivation: Exposure bias in logged implicit feedback makes offline evaluation and learning unreliable. IPS addresses bias but can have high variance; there's a need for a stable, practical counterfactual learning approach for recommender systems.
AI.method: Proposes an IPS-weighted training pipeline using an IPS-weighted Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR) objective augmented with a Propensity Regularizer. Evaluates Direct Method (DM), IPS, and Self-Normalized IPS (SNIPS) for offline policy evaluation. Validates on synthetic data and MovieLens 100K.
AI.result: IPS-weighted training improves model robustness under biased exposure; the Propensity Regularizer reduces variance amplification from extreme propensity weights, yielding more stable estimates. Experiments show better generalization under unbiased exposure and reduced evaluation variance compared to naive and standard IPS methods.
AI.conclusion: A practical, stable counterfactual learning and evaluation framework for recommender systems: combining IPS-weighted training with a Propensity Regularizer mitigates variance and improves robustness, with demonstrated gains on synthetic data and MovieLens 100K.

title: Supporting Our AI Overlords: Redesigning Data Systems to be Agent-First
summary:
Large Language Model (LLM) agents, acting on their users' behalf to
manipulate and analyze data, are likely to become the dominant workload for
data systems in the future. When working with data, agents employ a
high-throughput process of exploration and solution formulation for the given
task, one we call agentic speculation. The sheer volume and inefficiencies of
agentic speculation can pose challenges for present-day data systems. We argue
that data systems need to adapt to more natively support agentic workloads. We
take advantage of the characteristics of agentic speculation that we identify,
i.e., scale, heterogeneity, redundancy, and steerability - to outline a number
of new research opportunities for a new agent-first data systems architecture,
ranging from new query interfaces, to new query processing techniques, to new
agentic memory stores.

AI.tldr: Proposes agent-first data systems to support agentic workloads driven by LLM agents.
AI.motivation: LLM agents are likely to dominate future data workloads, making current data systems ill-suited for representing, exploring, and steering large-scale agentic workflows. The paper argues for adapting data systems to support agentic speculation.
AI.method: Conceptual analysis that identifies four core properties of agentic speculation (scale, heterogeneity, redundancy, steerability) and outlines a new agent-first data systems architecture, including opportunities in query interfaces, processing techniques, and agentic memory stores.
AI.result: A conceptual framework and set of design directions rather than empirical results; presents concrete research opportunities and architectural components for agent-first data systems.
AI.conclusion: Adopting an agent-first data systems architecture can better support agentic workloads and drive future research across interfaces, processing, and memory components.

title: SR-SLAM: Scene-reliability Based RGB-D SLAM in Diverse Environments
summary:
Visual simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) plays a critical role in
autonomous robotic systems, especially where accurate and reliable measurements
are essential for navigation and sensing. In feature-based SLAM, the
quantityand quality of extracted features significantly influence system
performance. Due to the variations in feature quantity and quality across
diverse environments, current approaches face two major challenges: (1) limited
adaptability in dynamic feature culling and pose estimation, and (2)
insufficient environmental awareness in assessment and optimization strategies.
To address these issues, we propose SRR-SLAM, a scene-reliability based
framework that enhances feature-based SLAM through environment-aware
processing. Our method introduces a unified scene reliability assessment
mechanism that incorporates multiple metrics and historical observations to
guide system behavior. Based on this assessment, we develop: (i) adaptive
dynamic region selection with flexible geometric constraints, (ii)
depth-assisted self-adjusting clustering for efficient dynamic feature removal
in high-dimensional settings, and (iii) reliability-aware pose refinement that
dynamically integrates direct methods when features are insufficient.
Furthermore, we propose (iv) reliability-based keyframe selection and a
weighted optimization scheme to reduce computational overhead while improving
estimation accuracy. Extensive experiments on public datasets and real world
scenarios show that SRR-SLAM outperforms state-of-the-art dynamic SLAM methods,
achieving up to 90% improvement in accuracy and robustness across diverse
environments. These improvements directly contribute to enhanced measurement
precision and reliability in autonomous robotic sensing systems.

AI.tldr: SRR-SLAM: a scene-reliability based framework that makes feature-based SLAM more robust and adaptive by incorporating environment-aware processing and multiple reliability metrics.
AI.motivation: Existing feature-based SLAM struggles with limited adaptability in dynamic feature culling and pose estimation, and with insufficient environmental awareness in assessment/optimization strategies across diverse environments.
AI.method: Introduces a unified scene reliability assessment using multiple metrics and historical data; (i) adaptive dynamic region selection with flexible geometric constraints; (ii) depth-assisted self-adjusting clustering for efficient dynamic feature removal in high-dimensional spaces; (iii) reliability-aware pose refinement that blends direct methods when features are scarce; (iv) reliability-based keyframe selection and a weighted optimization scheme to reduce computation while improving accuracy.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on public datasets and real-world scenarios show SRR-SLAM outperforms state-of-the-art dynamic SLAM methods, achieving up to 90% improvement in accuracy and robustness across diverse environments.
AI.conclusion: The framework enhances measurement precision and reliability in autonomous robotic sensing systems by making SLAM more aware of scene reliability and dynamics, and by adaptively shaping processing and optimization accordingly.

title: Encoder-Only Image Registration
summary:
Learning-based techniques have significantly improved the accuracy and speed
of deformable image registration. However, challenges such as reducing
computational complexity and handling large deformations persist. To address
these challenges, we analyze how convolutional neural networks (ConvNets)
influence registration performance using the Horn-Schunck optical flow
equation. Supported by prior studies and our empirical experiments, we observe
that ConvNets play two key roles in registration: linearizing local intensities
and harmonizing global contrast variations. Based on these insights, we propose
the Encoder-Only Image Registration (EOIR) framework, designed to achieve a
better accuracy-efficiency trade-off. EOIR separates feature learning from flow
estimation, employing only a 3-layer ConvNet for feature extraction and a set
of 3-layer flow estimators to construct a Laplacian feature pyramid,
progressively composing diffeomorphic deformations under a large-deformation
model. Results on five datasets across different modalities and anatomical
regions demonstrate EOIR's effectiveness, achieving superior
accuracy-efficiency and accuracy-smoothness trade-offs. With comparable
accuracy, EOIR provides better efficiency and smoothness, and vice versa. The
source code of EOIR will be publicly available on
https://github.com/XiangChen1994/EOIR.

AI.tldr: Encoder-Only Image Registration (EOIR): an encoder-based feature extractor plus lightweight 3-layer flow estimators to build a Laplacian feature pyramid, enabling accurate, efficient, and smooth large-deformation registration while preserving diffeomorphism.
AI.motivation: Address high computational cost and difficulty handling large deformations in learning-based deformable image registration. The paper posits that ConvNets help by linearizing local intensities and harmonizing global contrast, and leverages these insights via an encoder-only design to improve accuracy-efficiency trade-offs.
AI.method: EOIR uses a 3-layer ConvNet for feature extraction (encoder-only) and a set of 3-layer flow estimators to construct a Laplacian feature pyramid. It progressively composes diffeomorphic deformations under a large-deformation model, guided by analysis of the Horn–Schunck optical flow equation.
AI.result: Evaluated on five datasets across modalities and anatomical regions; EOIR achieves superior accuracy–efficiency and accuracy–smoothness trade-offs. With comparable accuracy, EOIR is more efficient and smoother; when prioritizing accuracy, EOIR yields smoother results.
AI.conclusion: EOIR demonstrates an effective balance between accuracy, efficiency, and deformation smoothness in deformable image registration; the approach separates feature learning from flow estimation and will release source code at the stated repository.

title: Are We Really Learning the Score Function? Reinterpreting Diffusion Models Through Wasserstein Gradient Flow Matching
summary:
Diffusion models are commonly interpreted as learning the score function,
i.e., the gradient of the log-density of noisy data. However, this assumption
implies that the target of learning is a conservative vector field, which is
not enforced by the neural network architectures used in practice. We present
numerical evidence that trained diffusion networks violate both integral and
differential constraints required of true score functions, demonstrating that
the learned vector fields are not conservative. Despite this, the models
perform remarkably well as generative mechanisms. To explain this apparent
paradox, we advocate a new theoretical perspective: diffusion training is
better understood as flow matching to the velocity field of a Wasserstein
Gradient Flow (WGF), rather than as score learning for a reverse-time
stochastic differential equation. Under this view, the "probability flow"
arises naturally from the WGF framework, eliminating the need to invoke
reverse-time SDE theory and clarifying why generative sampling remains
successful even when the neural vector field is not a true score. We further
show that non-conservative errors from neural approximation do not necessarily
harm density transport. Our results advocate for adopting the WGF perspective
as a principled, elegant, and theoretically grounded framework for
understanding diffusion generative models.

AI.tldr: Diffusion models are better understood as flow matching to a Wasserstein Gradient Flow velocity field than as strict score-function learning; empirical evidence shows learned vector fields are non-conservative yet still generate high-quality samples.
AI.motivation: The common view that diffusion models learn a conservative score function is contradicted by observed non-conservative vector fields; this paradox motivates a new principled theoretical framework.
AI.method: Provide numerical evidence that trained diffusion networks violate score constraints; formulate training as flow matching to a Wasserstein Gradient Flow; analyze how probability flow arises under this view and why sampling remains effective despite non-conservative errors.
AI.result: Non-conservative neural vector fields can still transport density effectively; the probability flow emerges naturally from the WGF framework, explaining strong generative performance without relying on reverse-time SDE theory.
AI.conclusion: Adopt the Wasserstein Gradient Flow perspective as a principled, elegant framework for understanding diffusion generative models, clarifying the role of flow rather than strict score learning.

title: Analysis of Error Sources in LLM-based Hypothesis Search for Few-Shot Rule Induction
comment:
This is the preprint version corresponding to our NeurIPS 2025
  Workshop on Multimodal Algorithmic Reasoning submission
summary:
Inductive reasoning enables humans to infer abstract rules from limited
examples and apply them to novel situations. In this work, we compare an
LLM-based hypothesis search framework with direct program generation approaches
on few-shot rule induction tasks. Our findings show that hypothesis search
achieves performance comparable to humans, while direct program generation
falls notably behind. An error analysis reveals key bottlenecks in hypothesis
generation and suggests directions for advancing program induction methods.
Overall, this paper underscores the potential of LLM-based hypothesis search
for modeling inductive reasoning and the challenges in building more efficient
systems.

AI.tldr: LLM-based hypothesis search matches human performance on few-shot rule induction, while direct program generation lags behind, with error analysis highlighting bottlenecks and future directions.
AI.motivation: To understand how to model inductive reasoning computationally and to compare two concrete AI approaches (LLM-driven hypothesis search vs direct program synthesis) on rule induction tasks.
AI.method: Empirically compare hypothesis-search driven by large language models with direct program generation methods on few-shot rule induction tasks; evaluate performance and conduct error analysis to identify bottlenecks in hypothesis generation and program induction.
AI.result: Hypothesis search achieves performance comparable to humans; direct program generation falls notably behind; error analysis identifies bottlenecks in hypothesis generation and suggests directions to improve program induction methods.
AI.conclusion: LLM-based hypothesis search is a promising route for modeling inductive reasoning; there remain challenges in building more efficient and robust program-induction systems.

title: A novel parameter estimation method for pneumatic soft hand control applying logarithmic decrement for pseudo rigid body modeling
summary:
The rapid advancement in physical human-robot interaction (HRI) has
accelerated the development of soft robot designs and controllers. Controlling
soft robots, especially soft hand grasping, is challenging due to their
continuous deformation, motivating the use of reduced model-based controllers
for real-time dynamic performance. Most existing models, however, suffer from
computational inefficiency and complex parameter identification, limiting their
real-time applicability. To address this, we propose a paradigm coupling
Pseudo-Rigid Body Modeling with the Logarithmic Decrement Method for parameter
estimation (PRBM plus LDM). Using a soft robotic hand test bed, we validate
PRBM plus LDM for predicting position and force output from pressure input and
benchmark its performance. We then implement PRBM plus LDM as the basis for
closed-loop position and force controllers. Compared to a simple PID
controller, the PRBM plus LDM position controller achieves lower error (average
maximum error across all fingers: 4.37 degrees versus 20.38 degrees). For force
control, PRBM plus LDM outperforms constant pressure grasping in pinching tasks
on delicate objects: potato chip 86 versus 82.5, screwdriver 74.42 versus 70,
brass coin 64.75 versus 35. These results demonstrate PRBM plus LDM as a
computationally efficient and accurate modeling technique for soft actuators,
enabling stable and flexible grasping with precise force regulation.

AI.tldr: A coupling of pseudo-rigid body modeling with the Logarithmic Decrement Method (PRBM+LDM) for soft robotic hands enables real-time parameter estimation and improved position/force control, outperforming PID in accuracy on grasping tasks.
AI.motivation: Soft robots deform continuously making accurate, real-time control challenging; existing reduced models are too computationally heavy or require hard parameter identification. A fast, accurate parameter estimation method is needed.
AI.method: Combine PRBM with Logarithmic Decrement Method for parameter estimation; validate on a soft hand test bed by predicting position and force from pressure; implement as closed-loop position and force controllers; benchmark against PID and constant-pressure grasping on delicate objects.
AI.result: PRBM+LDM achieved lower position error (average maximum error across fingers: 4.37° vs 20.38°). In force control on delicate objects, grasping accuracy improved (potato chip 86 vs 82.5; screwdriver 74.42 vs 70; brass coin 64.75 vs 35).
AI.conclusion: PRBM+LDM provides a computationally efficient, accurate modeling basis for soft actuators, enabling stable, flexible grasping with precise force regulation.

title: Exploring Decision-Making Capabilities of LLM Agents: An Experimental Study on Jump-Jump Game
summary:
The Jump-Jump game, as a simple yet challenging casual game, provides an
ideal testing environment for studying LLM decision-making capabilities. The
game requires players to precisely control jumping force based on current
position and target platform distance, involving multiple cognitive aspects
including spatial reasoning, physical modeling, and strategic planning. It
illustrates the basic gameplay mechanics of the Jump-Jump game, where the
player character (red circle) must jump across platforms with appropriate force
to maximize score.

AI.tldr: The Jump-Jump game is proposed as a testbed to study LLM decision-making in a physics-based control task requiring spatial reasoning, physics modeling, and planning.
AI.motivation: To assess whether large language models can reason about dynamics and plan actions in a game-like environment, bridging cognitive tasks and AI control.
AI.method: Use a 'Jump-Jump' scenario where a red circle must select jumping force based on current position and distance to the next platform. The mechanics illustrate basic gameplay; the setup emphasizes interpreting state, predicting outcomes, and choosing force to maximize score.
AI.result: The abstract does not report empirical results; it frames the game as a basic demonstration and potential evaluation platform rather than presenting findings.
AI.conclusion: The Jump-Jump game offers a compact, cognitively relevant testbed for evaluating LLM decision-making across spatial reasoning, physical modeling, and strategic planning in dynamic tasks.

title: Scalable Option Learning in High-Throughput Environments
summary:
Hierarchical reinforcement learning (RL) has the potential to enable
effective decision-making over long timescales. Existing approaches, while
promising, have yet to realize the benefits of large-scale training. In this
work, we identify and solve several key challenges in scaling hierarchical RL
to high-throughput environments. We propose Scalable Option Learning (SOL), a
highly scalable hierarchical RL algorithm which achieves a 25x higher
throughput compared to existing hierarchical methods. We train our hierarchical
agents using 20 billion frames of experience on the complex game of NetHack,
significantly surpassing flat agents and demonstrating positive scaling trends.
We also validate our algorithm on MiniHack and Mujoco environments, showcasing
its general applicability. Our code is open sourced at
github.com/facebookresearch/sol.

AI.tldr: SOL: a scalable hierarchical RL method that achieves 25x throughput, trained on 20B frames in NetHack, surpassing flat agents, validated on MiniHack and Mujoco; open-source.
AI.motivation: Address the scalability gap in hierarchical RL for long-horizon, high-throughput tasks; unlock benefits of large-scale training in complex environments.
AI.method: Proposes Scalable Option Learning (SOL), a hierarchical RL algorithm that enables scalable option learning to boost throughput and generalization; evaluated on NetHack (20B frames) and validated on MiniHack and Mujoco; code released.
AI.result: Achieves ~25x throughput over existing hierarchical methods; outperforms flat agents; shows positive scaling with more data; demonstrates general applicability across domains.
AI.conclusion: SOL demonstrates scalable hierarchical RL's practicality and broad applicability, enabling efficient learning in large-scale, long-horizon tasks; open-source release.

title: Quantum-like Coherence Derived from the Interaction between Chemical Reaction and Its Environment
summary:
By uncovering the contrast between Artificial Intelligence and Natural-born
Intelligence as a computational process, we define closed computing and open
computing, and implement open computing within chemical reactions. This
involves forming a mixture and invalidation of the computational process and
the execution environment, which are logically distinct, and coalescing both to
create a system that adjusts fluctuations. We model chemical reactions by
considering the computation as the chemical reaction and the execution
environment as the degree of aggregation of molecules that interact with the
reactive environment. This results in a chemical reaction that progresses while
repeatedly clustering and de-clustering, where concentration no longer holds
significant meaning. Open computing is segmented into Token computing, which
focuses on the individual behavior of chemical molecules, and Type computing,
which focuses on normative behavior. Ultimately, both are constructed as an
interplay between the two. In this system, Token computing demonstrates
self-organizing critical phenomena, while Type computing exhibits quantum
logic. Through their interplay, the recruitment of fluctuations is realized,
giving rise to interactions between quantum logical subspaces corresponding to
quantum coherence across different Hilbert spaces. As a result, spike waves are
formed, enabling signal transmission. This occurrence may be termed
quantum-like coherence, implying the source of enzymes responsible for
controlling spike waves and biochemical rhythms.

AI.tldr: Proposes open computing in chemical reactions by blending computation with execution environment; introduces Token and Type computing; suggests quantum-like coherence and spike waves enable signal transmission.
AI.motivation: To unify artificial and natural intelligence by treating computation as a chemical process and leveraging chemical dynamics to implement adaptive, open systems.
AI.method: Differentiate closed vs open computing and implement open computing in a chemical mixture. Model computation as a chemical reaction and the execution environment as the degree of aggregation of interacting molecules. Analyze Token computing (individual molecular behavior) and Type computing (normative behavior) and their interplay, focusing on fluctuations and clustering–declustering dynamics.
AI.result: Observation of spike waves enabling signal transmission; Token computing exhibits self-organizing critical phenomena, Type computing exhibits quantum logic. The interplay recruits fluctuations, potentially yielding quantum-like coherence across Hilbert spaces; enzymes may control spike waves and biochemical rhythms.
AI.conclusion: Open computing in chemistry can realize dynamic, open-system computation through Token–Type interplay, producing coherent signal dynamics and offering a basis for quantum-like information processing in biochemical contexts.

title: Novel bio-inspired soft actuators for upper-limb exoskeletons: design, fabrication and feasibility study
summary:
Soft robots have been increasingly utilized as sophisticated tools in
physical rehabilitation, particularly for assisting patients with neuromotor
impairments. However, many soft robotics for rehabilitation applications are
characterized by limitations such as slow response times, restricted range of
motion, and low output force. There are also limited studies on the precise
position and force control of wearable soft actuators. Furthermore, not many
studies articulate how bellow-structured actuator designs quantitatively
contribute to the robots' capability. This study introduces a paradigm of upper
limb soft actuator design. This paradigm comprises two actuators: the
Lobster-Inspired Silicone Pneumatic Robot (LISPER) for the elbow and the
