Scallop-Shaped Pneumatic Robot (SCASPER) for the shoulder. LISPER is
characterized by higher bandwidth, increased output force/torque, and high
linearity. SCASPER is characterized by high output force/torque and simplified
fabrication processes. Comprehensive analytical models that describe the
relationship between pressure, bending angles, and output force for both
actuators were presented so the geometric configuration of the actuators can be
set to modify the range of motion and output forces. The preliminary test on a
dummy arm is conducted to test the capability of the actuators.

AI.tldr: Two bellow-structured upper-limb actuators (LISPER for elbow, SCASPER for shoulder) are introduced with analytical models linking pressure, bending, and force to enable tunable ROM/torque for rehabilitation; preliminary validation on a dummy arm demonstrates capability.
AI.motivation: To address slow response, limited range of motion, and low output force in soft rehabilitation actuators, and to provide quantitative models showing how bellow-based designs affect performance.
AI.method: Design LISPER and SCASPER actuators, develop comprehensive analytical models relating input pressure, bending angle, and output force for each actuator, analyze how geometry sets ROM and force, and perform preliminary tests on a dummy arm.
AI.result: LISPER exhibits higher bandwidth, greater output force/torque, and high linearity; SCASPER provides high output force/torque with simplified fabrication; the models describe the pressure-bend-force relationships and enable geometry-driven tuning; preliminary dummy-arm tests confirm actuator capability.
AI.conclusion: A design paradigm with quantitative models enables tunable ROM and output forces for wearable soft actuators in rehabilitation; the approach addresses current limitations, though further validation with real users and dynamic tasks is needed.

title: VideoRewardBench: Comprehensive Evaluation of Multimodal Reward Models for Video Understanding
summary:
Multimodal reward models (MRMs) play a crucial role in the training,
inference, and evaluation of Large Vision Language Models (LVLMs) by assessing
response quality. However, existing benchmarks for evaluating MRMs in the video
domain suffer from a limited number and diversity of questions, a lack of
comprehensive evaluation dimensions, and inadequate evaluation of diverse types
of MRMs. To address these gaps, we introduce VideoRewardBench, the first
comprehensive benchmark covering four core aspects of video understanding:
perception, knowledge, reasoning, and safety. Through our AI-assisted data
pipeline, we curate a high-quality preference dataset of 1,563 annotated
samples, including 1,482 unique videos and 1,559 distinct questions--15 times
the number found in the most question-rich prior benchmark. Each sample is a
triplet consisting of a video-text prompt, a chosen response, and a rejected
response. We also conduct a comprehensive evaluation across 28 multimodal
reward models spanning three categories: generative, discriminative, and
semi-scalar. Results show that even the top-performing model GPT-4o achieves
only 57.0% overall accuracy, and the state-of-the-art open-source model
Qwen2.5-VL-72B reaches merely 53.3%. Our analysis further reveals three key
insights: (i) MRMs trained with reinforcement learning (RL) do not necessarily
exhibit stronger cross-modal generalization than those trained without RL; (ii)
except for discriminative MRMs, other types of MRMs across varying model
capacities can benefit from inference-time scaling; and (iii) variations in
input video frame count have different effects on different types of MRMs. We
believe VideoRewardBench offers a challenging and valuable benchmark for
advancing the evaluation and development of MRMs in the video domain.

AI.tldr: A comprehensive benchmark (VideoRewardBench) for multimodal reward models in video understanding, with a large curated dataset and broad model evaluation; reveals RL does not guarantee cross-modal generalization and scaling effects are model-type dependent.
AI.motivation: Address limitations in existing video MRMs benchmarks: small size, limited diversity, insufficient evaluation dimensions across perception, knowledge, reasoning, safety, and MRM types.
AI.method: AI-assisted data pipeline creates 1,563 samples (1,482 videos, 1,559 questions); each sample is a video-text triplet with a chosen and rejected response; evaluate 28 MRMs across generative, discriminative, and semi-scalar categories.
AI.result: Top performers (GPT-4o: 57.0% accuracy; Qwen2.5-VL-72B: 53.3%) show substantial room for improvement; key insights: RL-trained MRMs do not always improve generalization; non-discriminative MRMs benefit from inference-time scaling; frame-count effects vary by MRM type.
AI.conclusion: VideoRewardBench offers a challenging, valuable benchmark to advance evaluation and development of MRMs in the video domain, guiding future model and dataset design.

title: LLM-Driven Policy Diffusion: Enhancing Generalization in Offline Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Reinforcement Learning (RL) is known for its strong decision-making
capabilities and has been widely applied in various real-world scenarios.
However, with the increasing availability of offline datasets and the lack of
well-designed online environments from human experts, the challenge of
generalization in offline RL has become more prominent. Due to the limitations
of offline data, RL agents trained solely on collected experiences often
struggle to generalize to new tasks or environments. To address this challenge,
we propose LLM-Driven Policy Diffusion (LLMDPD), a novel approach that enhances
generalization in offline RL using task-specific prompts. Our method
incorporates both text-based task descriptions and trajectory prompts to guide
policy learning. We leverage a large language model (LLM) to process text-based
prompts, utilizing its natural language understanding and extensive knowledge
base to provide rich task-relevant context. Simultaneously, we encode
trajectory prompts using a transformer model, capturing structured behavioral
patterns within the underlying transition dynamics. These prompts serve as
conditional inputs to a context-aware policy-level diffusion model, enabling
the RL agent to generalize effectively to unseen tasks. Our experimental
results demonstrate that LLMDPD outperforms state-of-the-art offline RL methods
on unseen tasks, highlighting its effectiveness in improving generalization and
adaptability in diverse settings.

AI.tldr: LLMDPD is a prompt-driven offline RL method that uses LLM-derived task descriptions and trajectory prompts to condition a policy diffusion model, improving generalization to unseen tasks.
AI.motivation: Offline RL suffers from limited and biased data making generalization to new tasks hard; leveraging external task knowledge and structured behavior prompts can guide policy learning to be more adaptable.
AI.method: Process text-based task descriptions with a large language model and encode trajectory prompts with a transformer to capture behavioral patterns; these prompts condition a context-aware policy-level diffusion model trained on offline data to generalize to unseen tasks.
AI.result: LLMDPD outperforms state-of-the-art offline RL methods on unseen tasks, demonstrating improved generalization and adaptability across diverse settings.
AI.conclusion: Prompt-informed diffusion for offline RL is a promising direction; future work may explore richer prompts, scaling LLMs, and broader task distributions to further enhance generalization.

title: Symbolic Planning and Multi-Agent Path Finding in Extremely Dense Environments with Movable Obstacles
summary:
We introduce the Block Rearrangement Problem (BRaP), a challenging component
of large warehouse management which involves rearranging storage blocks within
dense grids to achieve a target state. We formally define the BRaP as a graph
search problem. Building on intuitions from sliding puzzle problems, we propose
five search-based solution algorithms, leveraging joint configuration space
search, classical planning, multi-agent pathfinding, and expert heuristics. We
evaluate the five approaches empirically for plan quality and scalability.
Despite the exponential relation between search space size and block number,
our methods demonstrate efficiency in creating rearrangement plans for deeply
buried blocks in up to 80x80 grids.

AI.tldr: Block Rearrangement Problem (BRaP) is a graph-search-based planning problem for rearranging blocks in dense grids (up to 80x80) inspired by sliding puzzles; five search-based algorithms are proposed and empirically evaluated for plan quality and scalability, showing efficiency despite exponential search space.
AI.motivation: Automate and scale rearrangement of storage blocks in large dense warehouse grids to improve planning quality and scalability over ad-hoc methods.
AI.method: Develop five search-based algorithms that span joint configuration space search, classical planning, multi-agent pathfinding, and expert heuristics; evaluate them empirically on plan quality and scalability in large grids.
AI.result: The approaches enable efficient generation of rearrangement plans for deeply buried blocks in grids up to 80x80, demonstrating scalability despite exponential growth in the search space.
AI.conclusion: BRaP frames block rearrangement as a tractable graph-search problem for large-scale warehouses; the five methods offer viable planning options with favorable trade-offs between plan quality and scalability, indicating practical potential for warehouse applications.

title: OpenMulti: Open-Vocabulary Instance-Level Multi-Agent Distributed Implicit Mapping
comment:
Accepted to IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters. Project website:
  https://openmulti666.github.io/
summary:
Multi-agent distributed collaborative mapping provides comprehensive and
efficient representations for robots. However, existing approaches lack
instance-level awareness and semantic understanding of environments, limiting
their effectiveness for downstream applications. To address this issue, we
propose OpenMulti, an open-vocabulary instance-level multi-agent distributed
implicit mapping framework. Specifically, we introduce a Cross-Agent Instance
Alignment module, which constructs an Instance Collaborative Graph to ensure
consistent instance understanding across agents. To alleviate the degradation
of mapping accuracy due to the blind-zone optimization trap, we leverage Cross
Rendering Supervision to enhance distributed learning of the scene.
Experimental results show that OpenMulti outperforms related algorithms in both
fine-grained geometric accuracy and zero-shot semantic accuracy. In addition,
OpenMulti supports instance-level retrieval tasks, delivering semantic
annotations for downstream applications. The project website of OpenMulti is
publicly available at https://openmulti666.github.io/.

AI.tldr: OpenMulti is a multi-agent open-vocabulary mapping framework that adds instance-level understanding to distributed implicit maps by aligning instances across agents and using cross-rendering supervision, yielding better geometric and zero-shot semantic accuracy and enabling instance-level retrieval.
AI.motivation: Current multi-agent mapping lacks instance-level awareness and semantic interpretation, limiting downstream tasks that require object-level consistency and understanding.
AI.method: Introduce Cross-Agent Instance Alignment with an Instance Collaborative Graph to maintain consistent instance representations across agents, and apply Cross Rendering Supervision to improve distributed scene learning and mitigate blind-zone optimization. OpenMulti is built as an open-vocabulary, implicit mapping framework for distributed agents.
AI.result: OpenMulti achieves superior fine-grained geometric accuracy and zero-shot semantic accuracy compared to related methods and supports instance-level retrieval with semantic annotations for downstream applications.
AI.conclusion: OpenMulti advances multi-agent mapping by enabling instance-level, semantically-aware representations across agents, facilitating downstream tasks that require object-level understanding. The project website is publicly available.

title: Multi-Focused Video Group Activities Hashing
summary:
With the explosive growth of video data in various complex scenarios, quickly
retrieving group activities has become an urgent problem. However, many tasks
can only retrieve videos focusing on an entire video, not the activity
granularity. To solve this problem, we propose a new STVH (spatiotemporal
interleaved video hashing) technique for the first time. Through a unified
framework, the STVH simultaneously models individual object dynamics and group
interactions, capturing the spatiotemporal evolution on both group visual
features and positional features. Moreover, in real-life video retrieval
scenarios, it may sometimes require activity features, while at other times, it
may require visual features of objects. We then further propose a novel M-STVH
(multi-focused spatiotemporal video hashing) as an enhanced version to handle
this difficult task. The advanced method incorporates hierarchical feature
integration through multi-focused representation learning, allowing the model
to jointly focus on activity semantics features and object visual features. We
conducted comparative experiments on publicly available datasets, and both STVH
and M-STVH can achieve excellent results.

AI.tldr: Introduces STVH and its enhanced version M-STVH for fast spatiotemporal video retrieval, focusing on group activities and multi-focused feature representations.
AI.motivation: Addresses the explosion of video data and the need to retrieve videos at activity granularity, not just entire videos, including both activity semantics and object-level visual features.
AI.method: STVH builds a unified framework modeling individual object dynamics and group interactions, capturing spatiotemporal evolution on group visual and positional features; M-STVH adds hierarchical multi-focused representation learning to jointly optimize activity semantics and object visuals.
AI.result: On publicly available datasets, STVH and M-STVH achieve excellent retrieval performance, demonstrating effectiveness in capturing both activity and object features.
AI.conclusion: STVH and M-STVH offer effective solutions for activity-focused video retrieval with a scalable, multi-feature approach; M-STVH's multi-focused design potentially provides greater flexibility for different retrieval scenarios.

title: Theory Foundation of Physics-Enhanced Residual Learning
summary:
Intensive studies have been conducted in recent years to integrate neural
networks with physics models to balance model accuracy and interpretability.
One recently proposed approach, named Physics-Enhanced Residual Learning
(PERL), is to use learning to estimate the residual between the physics model
prediction and the ground truth. Numeral examples suggested that integrating
such residual with physics models in PERL has three advantages: (1) a reduction
in the number of required neural network parameters; (2) faster convergence
rates; and (3) fewer training samples needed for the same computational
precision. However, these numerical results lack theoretical justification and
cannot be adequately explained.
  This paper aims to explain these advantages of PERL from a theoretical
perspective. We investigate a general class of problems with Lipschitz
continuity properties. By examining the relationships between the bounds to the
loss function and residual learning structure, this study rigorously proves a
set of theorems explaining the three advantages of PERL.
  Several numerical examples in the context of automated vehicle trajectory
prediction are conducted to illustrate the proposed theorems. The results
confirm that, even with significantly fewer training samples, PERL consistently
achieves higher accuracy than a pure neural network. These results demonstrate
the practical value of PERL in real world autonomous driving applications where
corner case data are costly or hard to obtain. PERL therefore improves
predictive performance while reducing the amount of data required.

AI.tldr: Theory-backed validation of PERL: learning the residual between physics and ground truth reduces neural capacity needed, accelerates training, and lowers data needs; demonstrated via Lipschitz-based analysis and AV trajectory experiments.
AI.motivation: Explain observed benefits of PERL and provide formal guarantees under Lipschitz continuity.
AI.method: Develop a general Lipschitz framework; relate loss bounds to residual learning; prove theorems about parameter efficiency, convergence, and sample complexity; supplement with numerical demonstrations in automated vehicle trajectory prediction.
AI.result: Theorems justify the three advantages; empirical tests show PERL achieves higher accuracy than pure neural nets with fewer samples.
AI.conclusion: PERL is not only empirically effective but theoretically sound, enhancing predictive performance in autonomous driving with less data and smaller networks.

title: FlashAdventure: A Benchmark for GUI Agents Solving Full Story Arcs in Diverse Adventure Games
summary:
GUI agents powered by LLMs show promise in interacting with diverse digital
environments. Among these, video games offer a valuable testbed due to their
varied interfaces, with adventure games posing additional challenges through
complex, narrative-driven interactions. Existing game benchmarks, however, lack
diversity and rarely evaluate agents on completing entire storylines. To
address this, we introduce FlashAdventure, a benchmark of 34 Flash-based
adventure games designed to test full story arc completion and tackle the
observation-behavior gap: the challenge of remembering and acting on earlier
gameplay information. We also propose CUA-as-a-Judge, an automated gameplay
evaluator, and COAST, an agentic framework leveraging long-term clue memory to
better plan and solve sequential tasks. Experiments show current GUI agents
struggle with full story arcs, while COAST improves milestone completion by
bridging the observation-behavior gap. Nonetheless, a marked discrepancy
between humans and best-performing agents warrants continued research efforts
to narrow this divide.

AI.tldr: A benchmark (FlashAdventure) for 34 Flash-based adventure games to test full story-arc completion; introduces CUA-as-a-Judge automated evaluator and COAST, a memory-enabled planning framework; results show GUI agents lag human performance and COAST helps but a gap remains.
AI.motivation: Address the lack of diverse, story-arc-focused benchmarks for GUI agents, and tackle the observation-behavior gap by enabling long-term memory and planning in agents.
AI.method: Introduce FlashAdventure dataset of 34 Flash-based adventure games; propose CUA-as-a-Judge automated gameplay evaluator; propose COAST framework leveraging long-term clue memory for improved planning and sequential task solving; conduct experiments comparing GUI agents to baselines and analyze progress on milestones and full story arcs.
AI.result: Current GUI agents struggle to complete full story arcs; COAST improves milestone completion by bridging the observation-behavior gap; however, there remains a substantial gap between human performance and best agents.
AI.conclusion: While progress is shown in bridging short-term milestones and linking observations to actions, substantial work remains to close the gap between humans and AI agents in completing full narrative-driven game tasks.

title: Towards Data-Driven Metrics for Social Robot Navigation Benchmarking
summary:
This paper presents a joint effort towards the development of a data-driven
Social Robot Navigation metric to facilitate benchmarking and policy
optimization. We provide our motivations for our approach and describe our
proposal for storing rated social navigation trajectory datasets. Following
these guidelines, we compiled a dataset with 4427 trajectories -- 182 real and
4245 simulated -- and presented it to human raters, yielding a total of 4402
rated trajectories after data quality assurance. We also trained an RNN-based
baseline metric on the dataset and present quantitative and qualitative
results. All data, software, and model weights are publicly available.

AI.tldr: Data-driven Social Robot Navigation metric with a human-rated trajectory dataset; trained an RNN baseline; public release of data, code, and weights to support benchmarking and policy optimization.
AI.motivation: To enable standardized benchmarking and policy optimization in social robot navigation by providing a data-driven metric and a shareable, high-quality dataset.
AI.method: Propose guidelines for storing rated social navigation trajectory datasets, compile a dataset of 4427 trajectories (182 real, 4245 simulated), obtain human ratings resulting in 4402 rated trajectories after QA, train an RNN-based baseline metric on the dataset, and report quantitative/qualitative results.
AI.result: 4402 trajectories rated after quality assurance; a trained RNN-based baseline metric; quantitative and qualitative results; all data, software, and model weights publicly available.
AI.conclusion: The work delivers a data-driven metric and a publicly released dataset/resources to support benchmarking and policy optimization in social robot navigation.

title: TRUST: Token-dRiven Ultrasound Style Transfer for Cross-Device Adaptation
summary:
Ultrasound images acquired from different devices exhibit diverse styles,
resulting in decreased performance of downstream tasks. To mitigate the style
gap, unpaired image-to-image (UI2I) translation methods aim to transfer images
from a source domain, corresponding to new device acquisitions, to a target
domain where a frozen task model has been trained for downstream applications.
However, existing UI2I methods have not explicitly considered filtering the
most relevant style features, which may result in translated images misaligned
with the needs of downstream tasks. In this work, we propose TRUST, a
token-driven dual-stream framework that preserves source content while
transferring the common style of the target domain, ensuring that content and
style remain unblended. Given multiple styles in the target domain, we
introduce a Token-dRiven (TR) module that operates from two perspectives: (1) a
data view--selecting "suitable" target tokens corresponding to each source
token, and (2) a model view--identifying ``optimal" target tokens for the
downstream model, guided by a behavior mirror loss. Additionally, we inject
auxiliary prompts into the source encoder to match content representation with
downstream behavior. Experimental results on ultrasound datasets demonstrate
that TRUST outperforms existing UI2I methods in both visual quality and
downstream task performance.

AI.tldr: TRUST is a token-driven dual-stream UI2I framework for ultrasound that preserves content while adopting common target styles, using a Token-dRiven module to select suitable target tokens for each source token and a behavior mirror loss to align with downstream models, plus auxiliary prompts. It improves both visual quality and downstream task performance.
AI.motivation: Ultrasound images from different devices exhibit varied styles, causing degradation in downstream task performance. Existing UI2I methods do not explicitly filter style features relevant to the downstream task, leading to misalignment between translated images and task needs.
AI.method: A token-driven dual-stream framework (TRUST) with two token-based perspectives. The Token-dRiven (TR) module selects suitable/optimal target tokens for each source token from data and model viewpoints, guided by a behavior mirror loss. Auxiliary prompts are injected into the source encoder to align content representations with downstream behavior.
AI.result: Experimental results on ultrasound datasets show TRUST outperforms existing UI2I methods in both visual quality and downstream task performance.
AI.conclusion: TRUST effectively preserves source content while transferring the common target style, mitigating the style gap for ultrasound UI2I and aligning translations with downstream task requirements through token-level filtering and behavior guidance.

title: Optimized Weight Initialization on the Stiefel Manifold for Deep ReLU Neural Networks
summary:
Stable and efficient training of ReLU networks with large depth is highly
sensitive to weight initialization. Improper initialization can cause permanent
neuron inactivation dying ReLU and exacerbate gradient instability as network
depth increases. Methods such as He, Xavier, and orthogonal initialization
preserve variance or promote approximate isometry. However, they do not
necessarily regulate the pre-activation mean or control activation sparsity,
and their effectiveness often diminishes in very deep architectures. This work
introduces an orthogonal initialization specifically optimized for ReLU by
solving an optimization problem on the Stiefel manifold, thereby preserving
scale and calibrating the pre-activation statistics from the outset. A family
of closed-form solutions and an efficient sampling scheme are derived.
Theoretical analysis at initialization shows that prevention of the dying ReLU
problem, slower decay of activation variance, and mitigation of gradient
vanishing, which together stabilize signal and gradient flow in deep
architectures. Empirically, across MNIST, Fashion-MNIST, multiple tabular
datasets, few-shot settings, and ReLU-family activations, our method
outperforms previous initializations and enables stable training in deep
networks.

AI.tldr: Orthogonal, ReLU-optimized initialization on the Stiefel manifold that preserves pre-activation statistics, prevents dying ReLU, and stabilizes gradient flow in very deep networks; with closed-form solutions and efficient sampling, yielding better empirical performance across MNIST, Fashion-MNIST, tabular data, few-shot settings, and ReLU variants.
AI.motivation: Current initializations (He, Xavier, orthogonal) preserve variance or promote isometry but don't regulate pre-activation mean or sparsity; their effectiveness deteriorates with depth, causing dying ReLU and gradient instability; need initialization that calibrates activation statistics from initialization time.
AI.method: Formulate an optimization on the Stiefel manifold to find orthogonal weight matrices tailored for ReLU, derive a family of closed-form solutions, and provide an efficient sampling scheme to initialize layers with preserved scale and calibrated pre-activation statistics.
AI.result: Theoretical analysis shows reduced dying ReLU probability, slower activation-variance decay, and mitigated gradient vanishing, leading to stable signal and gradient flows in deep architectures.
AI.conclusion: The proposed initialization outperforms prior methods across diverse datasets and ReLU-family activations, enabling stable training of very deep networks and offering a practical, efficient initialization scheme.

title: VerlTool: Towards Holistic Agentic Reinforcement Learning with Tool Use
summary:
Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) has demonstrated
success in enhancing LLM reasoning capabilities, but remains limited to
single-turn interactions without tool integration. While recent Agentic
Reinforcement Learning with Tool use (ARLT) approaches have emerged to address
multi-turn tool interactions, existing works develop task-specific codebases
that suffer from fragmentation, synchronous execution bottlenecks, and limited
extensibility across domains. These inefficiencies hinder broader community
adoption and algorithmic innovation. We introduce VerlTool, a unified and
modular framework that addresses these limitations through systematic design
principles. VerlTool provides four key contributions: (1) upstream alignment
with VeRL ensuring compatibility and simplified maintenance, (2) unified tool
management via standardized APIs supporting diverse modalities including code
execution, search, SQL databases, and vision processing, (3) asynchronous
rollout execution achieving near 2$\times$ speedup by eliminating
synchronization bottlenecks, and (4) comprehensive evaluation demonstrating
competitive performance across 6 ARLT domains. Our framework formalizes ARLT as
multi-turn trajectories with multi-modal observation tokens (text/image/video),
extending beyond single-turn RLVR paradigms. We train and evaluate models on
mathematical reasoning, knowledge QA, SQL generation, visual reasoning, web
search, and software engineering tasks, achieving results comparable to
specialized systems while providing unified training infrastructure. The
modular plugin architecture enables rapid tool integration requiring only
lightweight Python definitions, significantly reducing development overhead and
providing a scalable foundation for tool-augmented RL research. Our code is
open-sourced at https://github.com/TIGER-AI-Lab/verl-tool.

AI.tldr: VerlTool delivers a unified, modular ARLT framework with VeRL-aligned upstream integration, standardized multi-modal tool APIs, asynchronous rollout, and broad evaluation across six domains, achieving competitive performance with faster tool use and easier extensibility.
AI.motivation: Current ARLT work relies on fragmented, task-specific codebases that suffer synchronization bottlenecks and limited cross-domain reuse, hindering adoption and innovation.
AI.method: Design principles and components: VeRL-aligned upstream integration; unified tool management via standardized APIs for code, search, SQL, and vision; asynchronous rollout to near 2x speedup; multi-turn trajectories with multi-modal observations; lightweight Python plugin architecture enabling rapid tool integration; open-source framework.
AI.result: Competitive performance across six ARLT domains (math reasoning, knowledge QA, SQL generation, visual reasoning, web search, software engineering); architecture reduces development overhead and provides scalable training infrastructure; open-source at GitHub.
AI.conclusion: VerlTool establishes a scalable, extensible framework for tool-augmented RL in ARLT, enabling rapid tool integration and broad community adoption.

title: Toward a Holistic Multi-Criteria Trajectory Evaluation Framework for Autonomous Driving in Mixed Traffic Environment
summary:
This paper presents a unified framework for the evaluation and optimization
of autonomous vehicle trajectories, integrating formal safety, comfort, and
efficiency criteria. An innovative geometric indicator, based on the analysis
of safety zones using adaptive ellipses, is used to accurately quantify
collision risks. Our method applies the Shoelace formula to compute the
intersection area in the case of misaligned and time-varying configurations.
Comfort is modeled using indicators centered on longitudinal and lateral jerk,
while efficiency is assessed by overall travel time. These criteria are
aggregated into a comprehensive objective function solved using a PSO based
algorithm. The approach was successfully validated under real traffic
conditions via experiments conducted in an urban intersection involving an
autonomous vehicle interacting with a human-operated vehicle, and in simulation
using data recorded from human driving in real traffic.

AI.tldr: A unified multi-criteria framework for evaluating and optimizing autonomous vehicle trajectories that integrates formal safety (adaptive ellipse safety zones with Shoelace-based intersection area), comfort (jerk-based indicators), and efficiency (travel time) into a single objective solved by PSO, validated in real urban intersections and simulations.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of simultaneously ensuring safety, rider comfort, and efficiency in AV trajectory planning under dynamic traffic, by providing an integrated, quantifiable, and optimizable framework that handles misaligned and time-varying configurations.
AI.method: Proposes a unified optimization framework using adaptive ellipse-based safety zones; computes collision risk via intersection area using the Shoelace formula for misaligned/time-varying configurations; models comfort via longitudinal and lateral jerk indicators; assesses efficiency via travel time; aggregates criteria into a single objective and solves with a PSO-based algorithm; validates with real-traffic experiments at an urban intersection (AV vs. human-driven vehicle) and simulations using real driving data.
AI.result: The method was successfully validated in real traffic experiments at an urban intersection involving an autonomous vehicle interacting with a human-operated vehicle, and in simulation using data recorded from human driving in real traffic.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework offers a comprehensive, data-driven approach to multi-criteria AV trajectory optimization, delivering a robust, PSO-optimized solution with a geometric safety indicator, jerk-based comfort metrics, and travel-time efficiency, applicable to real-world mixed-traffic scenarios.

title: Make me an Expert: Distilling from Generalist Black-Box Models into Specialized Models for Semantic Segmentation
summary:
The rise of Artificial Intelligence as a Service (AIaaS) democratizes access
to pre-trained models via Application Programming Interfaces (APIs), but also
raises a fundamental question: how can local models be effectively trained
using black-box models that do not expose their weights, training data, or
logits, a constraint in which current domain adaptation paradigms are
impractical ? To address this challenge, we introduce the Black-Box
Distillation (B2D) setting, which enables local model adaptation under
realistic constraints: (1) the API model is open-vocabulary and trained on
large-scale general-purpose data, and (2) access is limited to one-hot
predictions only. We identify that open-vocabulary models exhibit significant
sensitivity to input resolution, with different object classes being segmented
optimally at different scales, a limitation termed the "curse of resolution".
Our method, ATtention-Guided sCaler (ATGC), addresses this challenge by
leveraging DINOv2 attention maps to dynamically select optimal scales for
black-box model inference. ATGC scores the attention maps with entropy to
identify informative scales for pseudo-labelling, enabling effective
distillation. Experiments demonstrate substantial improvements under black-box
supervision across multiple datasets while requiring only one-hot API
predictions. Our code is available at https://github.com/yasserben/ATGC.

AI.tldr: Introduces Black-Box Distillation (B2D) for adapting local models using only one-hot API predictions from open-vocabulary, large-scale models; proposes ATGC, which leverages DINOv2 attention to select optimal input scales, improving pseudo-labeling and distillation.
AI.motivation: With AI-as-a-Service, users must train local models using black-box APIs that provide only predictions, not weights, data, or logits. Traditional domain adaptation fails under these constraints. The paper identifies a 'curse of resolution' where open-vocabulary models perform best at different scales, hindering effective distillation.
AI.method: ATtention-Guided sCaler (ATGC) uses DINOv2 attention maps to dynamically pick informative scales for black-box inference. Attention maps are scored with entropy to identify the most informative scales for pseudo-labeling, enabling effective distillation from one-hot API predictions.
AI.result: Experiments show substantial improvements under black-box supervision across multiple datasets, despite only one-hot API outputs; code is provided at the authors' repository.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates the feasibility of Black-Box Distillation with attention-guided scale selection, enabling practical local model adaptation using AIaaS APIs while avoiding access to weights, data, or logits.

title: Unifying Adversarial Perturbation for Graph Neural Networks
summary:
This paper studies the vulnerability of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to
adversarial attacks on node features and graph structure. Various methods have
implemented adversarial training to augment graph data, aiming to bolster the
robustness and generalization of GNNs. These methods typically involve applying
perturbations to the node feature, weights, or graph structure and subsequently
minimizing the loss by learning more robust graph model parameters under the
adversarial perturbations. Despite the effectiveness of adversarial training in
enhancing GNNs' robustness and generalization abilities, its application has
been largely confined to specific datasets and GNN types. In this paper, we
propose a novel method, PerturbEmbedding, that integrates adversarial
perturbation and training, enhancing GNNs' resilience to such attacks and
improving their generalization ability. PerturbEmbedding performs perturbation
operations directly on every hidden embedding of GNNs and provides a unified
framework for most existing perturbation strategies/methods. We also offer a
unified perspective on the forms of perturbations, namely random and
adversarial perturbations. Through experiments on various datasets using
different backbone models, we demonstrate that PerturbEmbedding significantly
improves both the robustness and generalization abilities of GNNs,
outperforming existing methods. The rejection of both random (non-targeted) and
adversarial (targeted) perturbations further enhances the backbone model's
performance.

AI.tldr: PerturbEmbedding: a unified adversarial perturbation framework for GNNs that perturbs all hidden embeddings and improves robustness and generalization against random and targeted attacks.
AI.motivation: GNNs are vulnerable to adversarial perturbations in node features, weights, and structure; prior adversarial training is often dataset/model-specific; there is a need for a unified, broadly applicable defense that enhances robustness and generalization.
AI.method: Introduce PerturbEmbedding, which perturbs every hidden embedding in GNNs during training and integrates adversarial perturbations with standard training; provides a unified perspective by categorizing perturbations as random (non-targeted) or adversarial (targeted); demonstrates compatibility with various backbone models and perturbation strategies.
AI.result: PerturbEmbedding significantly improves robustness and generalization across multiple datasets and backbone models, outperforming existing methods; rejecting both random and adversarial perturbations further enhances the backbone performance.
AI.conclusion: PerturbEmbedding offers a broadly applicable, embedding-level adversarial training framework for GNNs, strengthening defenses against attacks and improving generalization across diverse settings.

title: Robix: A Unified Model for Robot Interaction, Reasoning and Planning
summary:
We introduce Robix, a unified model that integrates robot reasoning, task
planning, and natural language interaction within a single vision-language
architecture. Acting as the high-level cognitive layer in a hierarchical robot
system, Robix dynamically generates atomic commands for the low-level
controller and verbal responses for human interaction, enabling robots to
follow complex instructions, plan long-horizon tasks, and interact naturally
with human within an end-to-end framework. Robix further introduces novel
capabilities such as proactive dialogue, real-time interruption handling, and
context-aware commonsense reasoning during task execution. At its core, Robix
leverages chain-of-thought reasoning and adopts a three-stage training
strategy: (1) continued pretraining to enhance foundational embodied reasoning
abilities including 3D spatial understanding, visual grounding, and
task-centric reasoning; (2) supervised finetuning to model human-robot
interaction and task planning as a unified reasoning-action sequence; and (3)
reinforcement learning to improve reasoning-action consistency and long-horizon
task coherence. Extensive experiments demonstrate that Robix outperforms both
open-source and commercial baselines (e.g., GPT-4o and Gemini 2.5 Pro) in
interactive task execution, demonstrating strong generalization across diverse
instruction types (e.g., open-ended, multi-stage, constrained, invalid, and
interrupted) and various user-involved tasks such as table bussing, grocery
shopping, and dietary filtering.

AI.tldr: Robix is a unified vision-language model that acts as a high-level cognitive layer for robotics, unifying robot reasoning, task planning, and natural-language interaction in an end-to-end framework with chain-of-thought training and a three-stage pedagogy.
AI.motivation: To overcome the fragmentation of perception, reasoning, planning, and interaction in robotic systems by introducing a single, end-to-end model that can reason, plan, and talk to humans while executing long-horizon tasks.
AI.method: A three-stage training strategy (continued pretraining for embodied reasoning → supervised finetuning for reasoning-action sequences → reinforcement learning) combined with a vision-language architecture that emits atomic low-level commands and human-friendly dialogue. Features include proactive dialogue, real-time interruption handling, and context-aware commonsense reasoning within a hierarchical control setup (high-level planner → low-level controller).
AI.result: Robix outperforms open-source and commercial baselines (e.g., GPT-4o, Gemini 2.5 Pro) on interactive task execution, generalizes across diverse instruction types (open-ended, multi-stage, constrained, invalid, interrupted), and handles tasks such as table bussing, grocery shopping, and dietary filtering.
AI.conclusion: A unified, end-to-end vision-language robot model with chain-of-thought reasoning and structured training can achieve strong long-horizon planning, natural human-robot interaction, and robust generalization across tasks, surpassing existing baselines.

title: Disentangled Multi-Context Meta-Learning: Unlocking robust and Generalized Task Learning
comment:
Accepted to The Conference on Robot Learning (CoRL) 2025 Project
  Page: seonsoo-p1.github.io/DMCM
summary:
In meta-learning and its downstream tasks, many methods rely on implicit
adaptation to task variations, where multiple factors are mixed together in a
single entangled representation. This makes it difficult to interpret which
factors drive performance and can hinder generalization. In this work, we
introduce a disentangled multi-context meta-learning framework that explicitly
assigns each task factor to a distinct context vector. By decoupling these
variations, our approach improves robustness through deeper task understanding
and enhances generalization by enabling context vector sharing across tasks
with shared factors. We evaluate our approach in two domains. First, on a
sinusoidal regression task, our model outperforms baselines on
out-of-distribution tasks and generalizes to unseen sine functions by sharing
context vectors associated with shared amplitudes or phase shifts. Second, in a
quadruped robot locomotion task, we disentangle the robot-specific properties
and the characteristics of the terrain in the robot dynamics model. By
transferring disentangled context vectors acquired from the dynamics model into
reinforcement learning, the resulting policy achieves improved robustness under
out-of-distribution conditions, surpassing the baselines that rely on a single
unified context. Furthermore, by effectively sharing context, our model enables
successful sim-to-real policy transfer to challenging terrains with
out-of-distribution robot-specific properties, using just 20 seconds of real
data from flat terrain, a result not achievable with single-task adaptation.

AI.tldr: A disentangled multi-context meta-learning framework assigns distinct context vectors to task factors, enabling decoupling of variations, better interpretability, robustness, and generalization, with successful sinusoidal regression and sim-to-real transfer in robotics using limited data.
AI.motivation: Meta-learning often relies on entangled representations of task factors, hindering interpretability and generalization. By explicitly disentangling factors into separate context vectors and sharing across tasks with shared factors, the approach aims to improve robustness and transfer.
AI.method: Introduce a framework that maps each task factor to a distinct context vector, decoupling variations and allowing shared contexts across tasks with common factors. Evaluate on sinusoidal regression (OOD generalization via shared amplitude/phase contexts) and a quadruped locomotion setting where dynamics-contexts transfer to RL to improve robustness and enable sim-to-real transfer using only 20 seconds of real data.
AI.result: In sinusoidal regression, the model outperforms baselines on OOD tasks and generalizes to unseen sine functions by sharing contexts for shared amplitudes or phases. In quadruped locomotion, disentangled dynamics contexts transferred to RL yield more robust policies under OOD conditions and enable successful sim-to-real transfer on challenging terrains with minimal real data, outperforming single-unified-context baselines.
AI.conclusion: Disentangled multi-context meta-learning improves robustness and generalization by decoupling task factors and sharing context across tasks. It provides practical benefits in both regression and robotics, including efficient sim-to-real transfer with very limited real data.

title: Learning Yourself: Class-Incremental Semantic Segmentation with Language-Inspired Bootstrapped Disentanglement
summary:
Class-Incremental Semantic Segmentation (CISS) requires continuous learning
of newly introduced classes while retaining knowledge of past classes. By
abstracting mainstream methods into two stages (visual feature extraction and
prototype-feature matching), we identify a more fundamental challenge termed
catastrophic semantic entanglement. This phenomenon involves Prototype-Feature
Entanglement caused by semantic misalignment during the incremental process,
and Background-Increment Entanglement due to dynamic data evolution. Existing
techniques, which rely on visual feature learning without sufficient cues to
distinguish targets, introduce significant noise and errors. To address these
issues, we introduce a Language-inspired Bootstrapped Disentanglement framework
(LBD). We leverage the prior class semantics of pre-trained visual-language
models (e.g., CLIP) to guide the model in autonomously disentangling features
through Language-guided Prototypical Disentanglement and Manifold Mutual
Background Disentanglement. The former guides the disentangling of new
prototypes by treating hand-crafted text features as topological templates,
while the latter employs multiple learnable prototypes and mask-pooling-based
supervision for background-incremental class disentanglement. By incorporating
soft prompt tuning and encoder adaptation modifications, we further bridge the
capability gap of CLIP between dense and sparse tasks, achieving
state-of-the-art performance on both Pascal VOC and ADE20k, particularly in
multi-step scenarios.

AI.tldr: A Language-guided Bootstrapped Disentanglement (LBD) framework for Class-Incremental Semantic Segmentation (CISS) that leverages CLIP-based language semantics to disentangle prototypes and backgrounds, addressing catastrophic semantic entanglement and achieving state-of-the-art results on VOC and ADE20k in multi-step increments.
AI.motivation: CISS methods relying solely on visual feature learning suffer from catastrophic semantic entanglement (Prototype-Feature Entanglement) and Background-Increment Entanglement due to semantic misalignment and evolving data; a language-informed approach using pretrained vision-language models is proposed to restore semantic fidelity across increments.
AI.method: Propose Language-guided Prototypical Disentanglement that uses handcrafted text features as topological templates to guide prototype disentanglement; and Manifold Mutual Background Disentanglement that uses multiple learnable prototypes and mask-pooling-based supervision to disentangle background-increment classes. The framework incorporates soft prompt tuning and encoder adaptation to bridge CLIP performance between dense and sparse tasks.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on Pascal VOC and ADE20k, with notable gains in multi-step incremental scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that leveraging CLIP-style language semantics through targeted disentanglement strategies can mitigate catastrophic semantic entanglement in CISS and improve scalability across incremental steps, bridging dense and sparse segmentation tasks.

title: Curriculum Guided Personalized Subgraph Federated Learning
comment:
Accepted to the CIKM 2025. This is an extended version of the
  original submission
summary:
Subgraph Federated Learning (FL) aims to train Graph Neural Networks (GNNs)
across distributed private subgraphs, but it suffers from severe data
heterogeneity. To mitigate data heterogeneity, weighted model aggregation
personalizes each local GNN by assigning larger weights to parameters from
clients with similar subgraph characteristics inferred from their current model
states. However, the sparse and biased subgraphs often trigger rapid
overfitting, causing the estimated client similarity matrix to stagnate or even
collapse. As a result, aggregation loses effectiveness as clients reinforce
their own biases instead of exploiting diverse knowledge otherwise available.
To this end, we propose a novel personalized subgraph FL framework called
Curriculum guided personalized sUbgraph Federated Learning (CUFL). On the
client side, CUFL adopts Curriculum Learning (CL) that adaptively selects edges
for training according to their reconstruction scores, exposing each GNN first
to easier, generic cross-client substructures and only later to harder,
client-specific ones. This paced exposure prevents early overfitting to biased
patterns and enables gradual personalization. By regulating personalization,
the curriculum also reshapes server aggregation from exchanging generic
knowledge to propagating client-specific knowledge. Further, CUFL improves
weighted aggregation by estimating client similarity using fine-grained
structural indicators reconstructed on a random reference graph. Extensive
experiments on six benchmark datasets confirm that CUFL achieves superior
performance compared to relevant baselines. Code is available at
https://github.com/Kang-Min-Ku/CUFL.git.

AI.tldr: CUFL is a curriculum-guided personalized subgraph federated learning framework that mitigates data heterogeneity by pacing exposure with curriculum learning and refining client similarity estimation for weighted aggregation, achieving superior results across six datasets.
AI.motivation: Subgraph federated learning suffers from severe data heterogeneity and overfitting due to biased subgraphs, which degrades the effectiveness of weighted aggregation. Existing methods fail to adapt to varying subgraph characteristics and may reinforce client biases.
AI.method: On the client side, CUFL employs Curriculum Learning to select training edges by reconstruction scores, exposing easier, generic cross-client substructures before harder, client-specific ones. This paced exposure reduces early overfitting and smooths personalization. The server-side aggregation is regulated to propagate more client-specific knowledge. Client similarity is improved by estimating similarity using fine-grained structural indicators reconstructed on a random reference graph.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on six benchmark datasets show that CUFL outperforms relevant baselines, demonstrating the effectiveness of curriculum-guided personalization and refined similarity-based aggregation. Code is available at the provided GitHub URL.
AI.conclusion: CUFL effectively mitigates data heterogeneity in subgraph FL by pacing personalization through curriculum learning and by refining similarity-based aggregation, enabling robust, personalized GNN performance across diverse subgraphs.

title: Heads or Tails: A Simple Example of Causal Abstractive Simulation
summary:
This note illustrates how a variety of causal abstraction arXiv:1707.00819
arXiv:1812.03789, defined here as causal abstractive simulation, can be used to
formalize a simple example of language model simulation. This note considers
the case of simulating a fair coin toss with a language model. Examples are
presented illustrating the ways language models can fail to simulate, and a
success case is presented, illustrating how this formalism may be used to prove
that a language model simulates some other system, given a causal description
of the system. This note may be of interest to three groups. For practitioners
in the growing field of language model simulation, causal abstractive
simulation is a means to connect ad-hoc statistical benchmarking practices to
the solid formal foundation of causality. Philosophers of AI and philosophers
of mind may be interested as causal abstractive simulation gives a precise
operationalization to the idea that language models are role-playing
arXiv:2402.12422. Mathematicians and others working on causal abstraction may
be interested to see a new application of the core ideas that yields a new
variation of causal abstraction.

AI.tldr: A note shows how causal abstraction (causal abstractive simulation) can formalize language-model simulation, using a fair coin toss example, with explicit failure modes and a successful case, and discusses implications for benchmarking, philosophy, and math.
AI.motivation: To provide a formal foundation for language-model simulation, bridging ad-hoc benchmarking with causal reasoning, and operationalizing the idea that language models can role-play by simulating other systems.
AI.method: Adopts the causal abstraction framework of causal abstractive simulation and applies it to a simple coin-toss scenario simulated by a language model; presents failure and success examples, and explains how a causal description of the target system can be used to prove simulation.
AI.result: Shows both failure modes and a valid success case within the framework; illustrates that the formalism can connect empirical benchmarking with formal causality and appeal to multiple audiences (practitioners, philosophers, mathematicians).
AI.conclusion: Causal abstractive simulation offers a precise operationalization of language-model role-playing and demonstrates a new application of causal abstraction to LM simulation, with potential as a bridging tool across disciplines and for formal analysis of LM-simulation capabilities.

title: TopoNav: Topological Graphs as a Key Enabler for Advanced Object Navigation
summary:
Object Navigation (ObjectNav) has made great progress with large language
models (LLMs), but still faces challenges in memory management, especially in
long-horizon tasks and dynamic scenes. To address this, we propose TopoNav, a
new framework that leverages topological structures as spatial memory. By
building and updating a topological graph that captures scene connections,
adjacency, and semantic meaning, TopoNav helps agents accumulate spatial
knowledge over time, retrieve key information, and reason effectively toward
distant goals. Our experiments show that TopoNav achieves state-of-the-art
performance on benchmark ObjectNav datasets, with higher success rates and more
efficient paths. It particularly excels in diverse and complex environments, as
it connects temporary visual inputs with lasting spatial understanding.

AI.tldr: TopoNav uses a topological graph as spatial memory to accumulate and retrieve long-horizon spatial knowledge for ObjectNav, achieving state-of-the-art navigation performance.
AI.motivation: To address memory management challenges in long-horizon ObjectNav tasks and dynamic scenes by linking transient observations to enduring spatial memory.
AI.method: Build and continuously update a topological graph that encodes scene connections, adjacency, and semantic meaning, enabling knowledge accumulation, key information retrieval, and reasoning toward distant goals.
AI.result: TopoNav achieves state-of-the-art performance on ObjectNav benchmarks with higher success rates and more efficient paths, especially in diverse and complex environments.
AI.conclusion: Topological memory effectively bridges temporary visual inputs with lasting spatial understanding, improving long-horizon object navigation.

title: A Modality-agnostic Multi-task Foundation Model for Human Brain Imaging
summary:
Recent learning-based approaches have made astonishing advances in calibrated
medical imaging like computerized tomography (CT), yet they struggle to
generalize in uncalibrated modalities -- notably magnetic resonance (MR)
imaging, where performance is highly sensitive to the differences in MR
contrast, resolution, and orientation. This prevents broad applicability to
diverse real-world clinical protocols. Here we introduce BrainFM, a
modality-agnostic, multi-task vision foundation model for human brain imaging.
With the proposed "mild-to-severe" intra-subject generation and "real-synth"
mix-up training strategy, BrainFM is resilient to the appearance of acquired
images (e.g., modality, contrast, deformation, resolution, artifacts), and can
be directly applied to five fundamental brain imaging tasks, including image
synthesis for CT and T1w/T2w/FLAIR MRI, anatomy segmentation, scalp-to-cortical
distance, bias field estimation, and registration. We evaluate the efficacy of
BrainFM on eleven public datasets, and demonstrate its robustness and
effectiveness across all tasks and input modalities. Code is available at
https://github.com/jhuldr/BrainFM.

AI.tldr: BrainFM is a modality-agnostic, multi-task brain-imaging foundation model that uses mild-to-severe intra-subject generation and real-synth mix-up training to achieve robust performance across CT and MR tasks (synthesis, segmentation, distance, bias field, registration) across 11 datasets.
AI.motivation: Learning-based methods in calibrated imaging generalize poorly to uncalibrated modalities like MR, where performance is sensitive to contrast, resolution, and orientation, hindering clinical deployment across diverse protocols.
AI.method: Introduce BrainFM, a modality-agnostic multi-task vision foundation model trained with (i) mild-to-severe intra-subject generation and (ii) real-synth mix-up training to produce robust representations. Supports five tasks: CT and T1w/T2w/FLAIR MRI synthesis, anatomy segmentation, scalp-to-cortical distance, bias field estimation, and registration. Evaluated on eleven public datasets.
AI.result: BrainFM demonstrates robustness and effectiveness across all tasks and input modalities, enabling direct application to the five tasks across diverse data sources; code available at GitHub.
AI.conclusion: BrainFM provides a resilient, modality-agnostic brain-imaging foundation model that generalizes across modalities and tasks, addressing the generalization gap in uncalibrated imaging and supporting five core brain imaging tasks with demonstrated efficacy on multiple datasets.

title: Metis: Training Large Language Models with Advanced Low-Bit Quantization
summary:
This work identifies anisotropic parameter distributions as a fundamental
barrier to training large language models (LLMs) with low-bit quantization: a
few dominant singular values create wide numerical ranges that conflict with
the inherent bias of block-wise quantization. This bias disproportionately
preserves high-magnitude values while discarding smaller ones, causing training
instability and low model performance. This work introduces Metis, a training
framework that combines (i) spectral decomposition with random embedding to
efficiently disentangle dominant from long-tail components, compressing broad
distributions into quantization-friendly narrow ranges; (ii) adaptive learning
rates in the spectral domain to amplify underrepresented directions and better
capture diverse features critical for performance; and (iii) a dual-range
regularizer that jointly constrains numerical precision and parameter range
distribution, ensuring stable, unbiased low-bit training. With Metis, FP8
training surpasses FP32 baselines, and FP4 training achieves accuracy
comparable to FP32, paving the way for robust and scalable LLM training under
advanced low-bit quantization. The code implementation for Metis is available
at: https://github.com/typename-yyf/Metis-quantization.

AI.tldr: Identifies anisotropic parameter distributions as a key barrier to low-bit LLM training and presents Metis, a framework that uses spectral decomposition with random embedding, adaptive spectral learning rates, and a dual-range regularizer to compress distributions and stabilize training; FP8 outperforms FP32 baselines and FP4 matches FP32.
AI.motivation: Low-bit quantization for LLM training is hindered by a few dominant singular values that produce wide numerical ranges. This biases block-wise quantization, preserving large values while discarding small ones, leading to training instability and degraded performance. A method is needed to disentangle and stabilize distributions to enable robust low-bit training.
AI.method: Metis combines three components: (i) spectral decomposition with random embedding to separate dominant and long-tail components and compress broad distributions into quantization-friendly ranges; (ii) adaptive learning rates in the spectral domain to amplify underrepresented directions and capture diverse features; (iii) a dual-range regularizer that constrains both numerical precision and parameter-range distribution to ensure stable, unbiased low-bit training.
AI.result: With Metis, FP8 training surpasses FP32 baselines, and FP4 training achieves accuracy comparable to FP32, enabling robust low-bit LLM training. The authors provide a code implementation at the given GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: Metis effectively mitigates anisotropic distribution barriers in low-bit LLM training by disentangling spectral components, adjusting learning dynamics in the spectral domain, and constraining parameter ranges, enabling scalable and stable low-bit quantization-enabled training.

title: Question-to-Knowledge: Multi-Agent Generation of Inspectable Facts for Product Mapping
summary:
Identifying whether two product listings refer to the same Stock Keeping Unit
(SKU) is a persistent challenge in ecommerce, especially when explicit
identifiers are missing and product names vary widely across platforms. Rule
based heuristics and keyword similarity often misclassify products by
overlooking subtle distinctions in brand, specification, or bundle
configuration. To overcome these limitations, we propose Question to Knowledge
(Q2K), a multi agent framework that leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) for
reliable SKU mapping. Q2K integrates: (1) a Reasoning Agent that generates
targeted disambiguation questions, (2) a Knowledge Agent that resolves them via
focused web searches, and (3) a Deduplication Agent that reuses validated
reasoning traces to reduce redundancy and ensure consistency. A human in the
loop mechanism further refines uncertain cases. Experiments on real world
consumer goods datasets show that Q2K surpasses strong baselines, achieving
higher accuracy and robustness in difficult scenarios such as bundle
identification and brand origin disambiguation. By reusing retrieved reasoning
instead of issuing repeated searches, Q2K balances accuracy with efficiency,
offering a scalable and interpretable solution for product integration.

AI.tldr: A multi-agent LLM framework (Q2K) for SKU deduplication/mapping across ecommerce platforms, using targeted questions, focused searches, and reusable reasoning traces, with human-in-the-loop to refine uncertain cases; offers higher accuracy and efficiency than baselines.
AI.motivation: Identifying whether two product listings refer to the same SKU is difficult when explicit identifiers are absent and product names vary; rule-based methods miss subtle distinctions in brand, specs, and bundles, necessitating a scalable, interpretable approach.
AI.method: Propose Q2K, a three-agent system: (1) Reasoning Agent that generates targeted disambiguation questions; (2) Knowledge Agent that resolves them via focused web searches; (3) Deduplication Agent that reuses validated reasoning traces to reduce redundant searches and ensure consistency. A human-in-the-loop handles uncertain cases. Evaluated on real-world consumer goods datasets, showing improved accuracy and robustness, especially for bundles and brand-origin disambiguation.
AI.result: Q2K surpasses strong baselines in accuracy and robustness, notably in bundle identification and brand-origin disambiguation. Reusing retrieved reasoning traces improves efficiency by reducing repeated searches, yielding scalable and interpretable SKU mapping for product integration.
AI.conclusion: The framework offers a scalable, interpretable solution for cross-platform product integration, leveraging LLMs and search-based knowledge with trace reuse to balance accuracy and efficiency.

title: Analyzing Reluctance to Ask for Help When Cooperating With Robots: Insights to Integrate Artificial Agents in HRC
comment: 8 pages, 5 figures. Accepted for IEEE RO-MAN 2025
summary:
As robot technology advances, collaboration between humans and robots will
become more prevalent in industrial tasks. When humans run into issues in such
scenarios, a likely future involves relying on artificial agents or robots for
aid. This study identifies key aspects for the design of future user-assisting
agents. We analyze quantitative and qualitative data from a user study
examining the impact of on-demand assistance received from a remote human in a
human-robot collaboration (HRC) assembly task. We study scenarios in which
users require help and we assess their experiences in requesting and receiving
assistance. Additionally, we investigate participants' perceptions of future
non-human assisting agents and whether assistance should be on-demand or
unsolicited. Through a user study, we analyze the impact that such design
decisions (human or artificial assistant, on-demand or unsolicited help) can
have on elicited emotional responses, productivity, and preferences of humans
engaged in HRC tasks.

AI.tldr: The abstract outlines designing future user-assisting agents for human-robot collaboration, exploring on-demand vs unsolicited help and human vs non-human assistants, and their effects on user emotions, productivity, and preferences through a mixed-method user study.
AI.motivation: To optimize human-robot collaboration by understanding how users want to be assisted and how different forms of assistance affect their experience and performance.
AI.method: Quantitative and qualitative analysis of a user study in an HRC assembly task, focusing on on-demand assistance from a remote human; also examining perceptions of future non-human agents and the choice between on-demand vs unsolicited help.
AI.result: The abstract does not provide concrete results; it states that the study will analyze the impact of these design decisions on emotional responses, productivity, and user preferences.
AI.conclusion: The work aims to inform the design of future user-assisting agents in HRC by clarifying which agent type and assistance mode best support human users.

title: C-DiffDet+: Fusing Global Scene Context with Generative Denoising for High-Fidelity Object Detection
summary:
Fine-grained object detection in challenging visual domains, such as vehicle
damage assessment, presents a formidable challenge even for human experts to
resolve reliably. While DiffusionDet has advanced the state-of-the-art through
conditional denoising diffusion, its performance remains limited by local
feature conditioning in context-dependent scenarios. We address this
fundamental limitation by introducing Context-Aware Fusion (CAF), which
leverages cross-attention mechanisms to integrate global scene context with
local proposal features directly. The global context is generated using a
separate dedicated encoder that captures comprehensive environmental
information, enabling each object proposal to attend to scene-level
understanding. Our framework significantly enhances the generative detection
paradigm by enabling each object proposal to attend to comprehensive
environmental information. Experimental results demonstrate an improvement over
state-of-the-art models on the CarDD benchmark, establishing new performance
benchmarks for context-aware object detection in fine-grained domains

AI.tldr: A cross-attention based Context-Aware Fusion (CAF) integrates global scene context with local object proposals to improve fine-grained detection, outperforming prior diffusion-based methods on CarDD.
AI.motivation: Need to overcome the limitation of local feature conditioning in diffusion-based detectors for fine-grained, context-dependent tasks; challenging domains like vehicle damage require scene-level information for reliable assessments.
AI.method: Introduce Context-Aware Fusion (CAF) that uses cross-attention to fuse a separate global scene encoder with local proposal features, allowing each object proposal to attend to scene-level context.
AI.result: Empirical results show improved performance over state-of-the-art on the CarDD benchmark, establishing new benchmarks for context-aware detection in fine-grained domains.
AI.conclusion: Context-aware global-to-local fusion via CAF enhances generative detection by enabling proposals to attend to environmental information, improving reliability in challenging fine-grained domains.

title: Lagrangian Relaxation for Multi-Action Partially Observable Restless Bandits: Heuristic Policies and Indexability
summary:
Partially observable restless multi-armed bandits have found numerous
applications including in recommendation systems, communication systems, public
healthcare outreach systems, and in operations research. We study multi-action
partially observable restless multi-armed bandits, it is a generalization of
the classical restless multi-armed bandit problem -- 1) each bandit has finite
states, and the current state is not observable, 2) each bandit has finite
actions. In particular, we assume that more than two actions are available for
each bandit. We motivate our problem with the application of public-health
intervention planning. We describe the model and formulate a long term
discounted optimization problem, where the state of each bandit evolves
according to a Markov process, and this evolution is action dependent. The
state of a bandit is not observable but one of finitely many feedback signals
are observable. Each bandit yields a reward, based on the action taken on that
bandit. The agent is assumed to have a budget constraint. The bandits are
assumed to be independent. However, they are weakly coupled at the agent
through the budget constraint.
  We first analyze the Lagrangian bound method for our partially observable
restless bandits. The computation of optimal value functions for finite-state,
finite-action POMDPs is non-trivial. Hence, the computation of Lagrangian
bounds is also challenging. We describe approximations for the computation of
Lagrangian bounds using point based value iteration (PBVI) and online rollout
policy. We further present various properties of the value functions and
provide theoretical insights on PBVI and online rollout policy. We study
heuristic policies for multi-actions PORMAB. Finally, we discuss present
Whittle index policies and their limitations in our model.

AI.tldr: Generalizes restless multi-armed bandits to a multi-action partially observable setting with budget coupling; analyzes Lagrangian bounds and approximation methods (PBVI, online rollout); develops heuristics and discusses Whittle index limitations.
AI.motivation: Addresses the complexity of optimizing finite-state, finite-action POMDPs under a budget constraint, with applications in public-health interventions and other domains requiring sequential decision-making under partial observability and weak coupling.
AI.method: Model: independent bandits with finite states/actions; state evolution is action-dependent Markov process; non-observable bandit states, observable feedback signals; objective: long-term discounted reward; budget constraint couples arms. Approach: (1) Lagrangian bound framework for the partially observable restless bandits; (2) compute/approximate Lagrangian bounds using point-based value iteration (PBVI) and online rollout; (3) analyze properties of value functions and provide theoretical insights on PBVI and rollout; (4) study heuristic policies; (5) discuss Whittle index policies and their limitations in this setting.
AI.result: Gives approximations for Lagrangian bounds via PBVI and online rollout; offers theoretical insights into the value functions and PBVI/rollout performance; evaluates heuristic policies; clarifies limitations of Whittle index in the multi-action PORMAB model.
AI.conclusion: The work provides practical methods to tackle multi-action PORMABs under budget constraints, highlighting computational challenges and limitations of Whittle index approaches; PBVI and online rollout emerge as viable tools for obtaining bounds and guiding heuristics.

title: Towards Open-World Retrieval-Augmented Generation on Knowledge Graph: A Multi-Agent Collaboration Framework
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated strong capabilities in
language understanding and reasoning. However, their dependence on static
training corpora makes them prone to factual errors and knowledge gaps.
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) addresses this limitation by incorporating
external knowledge sources, especially structured Knowledge Graphs (KGs), which
provide explicit semantics and efficient retrieval. Existing KG-based RAG
approaches, however, generally assume that anchor entities are accessible to
initiate graph traversal, which limits their robustness in open world settings
where accurate linking between the query and the entity is unreliable. To
overcome this limitation, we propose AnchorRAG, a novel multi-agent
collaboration framework for open-world RAG without the predefined anchor
entities. Specifically, a predictor agent dynamically identifies candidate
anchor entities by aligning user query terms with KG nodes and initializes
independent retriever agents to conduct parallel multi-hop explorations from
each candidate. Then a supervisor agent formulates the iterative retrieval
strategy for these retriever agents and synthesizes the resulting knowledge
paths to generate the final answer. This multi-agent collaboration framework
improves retrieval robustness and mitigates the impact of ambiguous or
erroneous anchors. Extensive experiments on four public benchmarks demonstrate
that AnchorRAG significantly outperforms existing baselines and establishes new
state-of-the-art results on the real-world question answering tasks.

AI.tldr: AnchorRAG is a multi-agent open-world RAG framework that dynamically identifies anchor entities from a knowledge graph, runs parallel multi-hop retrieval from multiple candidates, and uses a supervisor to coordinate and synthesize paths, improving robustness and achieving state-of-the-art QA results without predefined anchors.
AI.motivation: LLMs relying on static training data can produce factual errors and knowledge gaps. Existing KG-based RAG methods assume accessible anchor entities, limiting robustness in open-world settings with unreliable linking. There is a need for open-world retrieval without predefined anchors.
AI.method: A predictor agent aligns query terms with KG nodes to identify candidate anchor entities. Independent retriever agents start from each candidate and perform parallel multi-hop explorations. A supervisor agent coordinates the retrieval strategy and synthesizes the resulting knowledge paths to produce the final answer.
AI.result: AnchorRAG significantly outperforms existing baselines on four public benchmarks and achieves new state-of-the-art results on real-world QA tasks, demonstrating improved retrieval robustness and effectiveness in open-world settings.
AI.conclusion: AnchorRAG enables robust open-world KG-based RAG without relying on predefined anchors by leveraging multi-agent collaboration, dynamic anchor identification, and coordinated multi-hop retrieval to produce accurate answers.

title: FGO-SLAM: Enhancing Gaussian SLAM with Globally Consistent Opacity Radiance Field
summary:
Visual SLAM has regained attention due to its ability to provide perceptual
capabilities and simulation test data for Embodied AI. However, traditional
SLAM methods struggle to meet the demands of high-quality scene reconstruction,
and Gaussian SLAM systems, despite their rapid rendering and high-quality
mapping capabilities, lack effective pose optimization methods and face
challenges in geometric reconstruction. To address these issues, we introduce
FGO-SLAM, a Gaussian SLAM system that employs an opacity radiance field as the
scene representation to enhance geometric mapping performance. After initial
pose estimation, we apply global adjustment to optimize camera poses and sparse
point cloud, ensuring robust tracking of our approach. Additionally, we
maintain a globally consistent opacity radiance field based on 3D Gaussians and
introduce depth distortion and normal consistency terms to refine the scene
representation. Furthermore, after constructing tetrahedral grids, we identify
level sets to directly extract surfaces from 3D Gaussians. Results across
various real-world and large-scale synthetic datasets demonstrate that our
method achieves state-of-the-art tracking accuracy and mapping performance.

AI.tldr: FGO-SLAM uses a Gaussian-derived opacity radiance field to improve geometry in Visual SLAM, with global pose and sparse point cloud optimization, 3D Gaussian-based surfaces extraction, yielding state-of-the-art tracking and mapping on diverse datasets.
AI.motivation: Traditional SLAM methods struggle to deliver high-quality scene reconstruction; Gaussian SLAM offers fast rendering and good mapping but lacks robust pose optimization and reliable geometric reconstruction.
AI.method: Represent scenes with an opacity radiance field built from 3D Gaussians. After initial pose estimation, perform global adjustment of camera poses and sparse points. Maintain a globally consistent opacity field; incorporate depth distortion and normal consistency losses. Build tetrahedral grids and extract surfaces via level sets directly from 3D Gaussians.
AI.result: Demonstrates state-of-the-art tracking accuracy and mapping performance across real-world and large-scale synthetic datasets, with robust tracking and improved geometric reconstruction.
AI.conclusion: FGO-SLAM achieves superior geometry and pose optimization for Gaussian SLAM by coupling opacity radiance fields with global optimization and surface extraction from 3D Gaussians, enabling reliable large-scale scene reconstruction.

title: DGL-RSIS: Decoupling Global Spatial Context and Local Class Semantics for Training-Free Remote Sensing Image Segmentation
comment:
Submitted to IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
  (TGRS), under review
summary:
