AI.conclusion: Decoding-time STL-constrained decoding provides runtime safety guarantees for robotics foundation models, enabling safe, reliable action generation without retraining and broad applicability to robotic control tasks.

title: LLaVA-Critic-R1: Your Critic Model is Secretly a Strong Policy Model
summary:
In vision-language modeling, critic models are typically trained to evaluate
outputs -- assigning scalar scores or pairwise preferences -- rather than to
generate responses. This separation from policy models, which produce the
responses, is so entrenched that critics are rarely considered for direct
policy use. In this work, we challenge this convention. We propose to
reorganize preference-labeled critic datasets into verifiable training signals
and perform reinforcement learning directly on a base generative model,
producing LLaVA-Critic-R1, a multimodal critic trained to optimize preference
judgments while retaining full generation ability. Surprisingly,
LLaVA-Critic-R1 emerges not only as a top-performing critic but also as a
competitive policy model -- matching or surpassing specialized reasoning VLMs
trained with in-domain data across 26 visual reasoning and understanding
benchmarks, with an average gain of +5.7% over its base model (Qwen-2.5-VL-7B).
Extending this approach to existing strong reasoning VLMs yields
LLaVA-Critic-R1+, which further advances policy performance without sacrificing
critic quality, achieving a SoTA performance of 71.9 on MMMU at the 7B scale.
Finally, we show that the enhanced critic ability benefits inference: applying
self-critique at test time yields an average +13.8% improvement on five
representative reasoning tasks without additional training. Our results reveal
that RL training on critic data can produce a unified model excelling at both
evaluation and generation, offering a simple path toward scalable,
self-improving multimodal systems.

AI.tldr: Reframes critic datasets as actionable RL signals to train a base generative model, yielding a unified model (LLaVA-Critic-R1) that excels as both critic and policy in multimodal tasks, with strong benchmark gains and self-critique capabilities.
AI.motivation: Chronic separation of evaluation critics from policy generators in vision-language models limits performance and scalability. The work investigates whether critic data can directly train a generation-capable agent that both evaluates and responds, enabling self-improvement and unified deployment.
AI.method: Transform preference-labeled critic data into verifiable training signals, perform reinforcement learning on a base generative model to optimize those preferences, producing LLaVA-Critic-R1 which retains full generation ability. Extend to LLaVA-Critic-R1+ by adapting stronger reasoning VLMs. Evaluate on 26 visual reasoning/understanding benchmarks and MMMU, and test self-critique at inference time.
AI.result: LLaVA-Critic-R1 becomes a top-performing critic and a competitive policy, outperforming base models and strong baselines (+5.7% over Qwen-2.5-VL-7B; SoTA MMMU 71.9 at 7B with LLaVA-Critic-R1+). The critic’s abilities transfer to policy performance across 26 benchmarks. Self-critique during inference yields ~13.8% gains on five reasoning tasks without new training.
AI.conclusion: RL training on critic data can yield a unified model that excels at both evaluation and generation, enabling scalable, self-improving multimodal systems, and offering a simple path to leverage critic data for policy optimization.

title: Integrated Multivariate Segmentation Tree for the Analysis of Heterogeneous Credit Data in Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises
summary:
Traditional decision tree models, which rely exclusively on numerical
variables, often encounter difficulties in handling high-dimensional data and
fail to effectively incorporate textual information. To address these
limitations, we propose the Integrated Multivariate Segmentation Tree (IMST), a
comprehensive framework designed to enhance credit evaluation for small and
medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) by integrating financial data with textual
sources. The methodology comprises three core stages: (1) transforming textual
data into numerical matrices through matrix factorization; (2) selecting
salient financial features using Lasso regression; and (3) constructing a
multivariate segmentation tree based on the Gini index or Entropy, with
weakest-link pruning applied to regulate model complexity. Experimental results
derived from a dataset of 1,428 Chinese SMEs demonstrate that IMST achieves an
accuracy of 88.9%, surpassing baseline decision trees (87.4%) as well as
conventional models such as logistic regression and support vector machines
(SVM). Furthermore, the proposed model exhibits superior interpretability and
computational efficiency, featuring a more streamlined architecture and
enhanced risk detection capabilities.

AI.tldr: IMST combines financial data and text features in a 3-stage pipeline to boost SME credit evaluation, achieving 88.9% accuracy on 1,428 Chinese SMEs and outperforming baseline models with better interpretability and efficiency.
AI.motivation: Traditional decision trees rely on numeric variables and struggle with high-dimensional data and textual information. There is a need to leverage textual data alongside financial features to improve SME credit risk assessment while maintaining interpretability and computational efficiency.
AI.method: A three-stage framework: (1) convert textual data to numerical matrices via matrix factorization; (2) select salient financial features using Lasso regression; (3) construct a multivariate segmentation tree based on Gini index or Entropy with weakest-link pruning to control model complexity.
AI.result: On a dataset of 1,428 Chinese SMEs, IMST achieves 88.9% accuracy, surpassing baseline decision trees (87.4%) and traditional models such as logistic regression and SVM, with improved interpretability and computational efficiency due to a streamlined architecture.
AI.conclusion: IMST demonstrates that integrating textual information with financial features via a factorization-based text representation and a sparse, interpretable multivariate segmentation tree yields higher accuracy and efficiency for SME credit evaluation, suggesting potential applicability to other high-dimensional, text-rich domains.

title: LLM-empowered Agents Simulation Framework for Scenario Generation in Service Ecosystem Governance
summary:
As the social environment is growing more complex and collaboration is
deepening, factors affecting the healthy development of service ecosystem are
constantly changing and diverse, making its governance a crucial research
issue. Applying the scenario analysis method and conducting scenario rehearsals
by constructing an experimental system before managers make decisions, losses
caused by wrong decisions can be largely avoided. However, it relies on
predefined rules to construct scenarios and faces challenges such as limited
information, a large number of influencing factors, and the difficulty of
measuring social elements. These challenges limit the quality and efficiency of
generating social and uncertain scenarios for the service ecosystem. Therefore,
we propose a scenario generator design method, which adaptively coordinates
three Large Language Model (LLM) empowered agents that autonomously optimize
experimental schemes to construct an experimental system and generate high
quality scenarios. Specifically, the Environment Agent (EA) generates social
environment including extremes, the Social Agent (SA) generates social
collaboration structure, and the Planner Agent (PA) couples task-role
relationships and plans task solutions. These agents work in coordination, with
the PA adjusting the experimental scheme in real time by perceiving the states
of each agent and these generating scenarios. Experiments on the
ProgrammableWeb dataset illustrate our method generates more accurate scenarios
more efficiently, and innovatively provides an effective way for service
ecosystem governance related experimental system construction.

AI.tldr: Proposes an adaptive, three-agent LLM-powered scenario generator to create high-quality social-uncertainty scenarios for service ecosystem governance, improving efficiency and accuracy over predefined-rule methods.
AI.motivation: Governance of service ecosystems amidst increasing social complexity requires scenario analysis. Traditional scenario generation suffers from limited information, many factors, and difficulty measuring social elements, restricting quality and efficiency.
AI.method: Introduce three coordinating LLM-powered agents: Environment Agent (EA) generates social environments including extremes; Social Agent (SA) designs social collaboration structures; Planner Agent (PA) maps task-role relations and plans solutions. The PA perceives agents' states and adjusts the experimental scheme in real time, enabling autonomous construction of high-quality scenarios. Validation on ProgrammableWeb dataset.
AI.result: The method yields more accurate scenarios more efficiently compared to baseline approaches.
AI.conclusion: An adaptive, agent-based scenario generator enhances governance-relevant scenario construction and offers a novel experimental system for service ecosystem governance.

title: Fail2Progress: Learning from Real-World Robot Failures with Stein Variational Inference
comment:
Project page: sites.google.com/view/fail2progress. 25 pages, 8
  figures. Accepted to the Conference on Robot Learning (CoRL) 2025
summary:
Skill effect models for long-horizon manipulation tasks are prone to failures
in conditions not covered by training data distributions. Therefore, enabling
robots to reason about and learn from failures is necessary. We investigate the
problem of efficiently generating a dataset targeted to observed failures.
After fine-tuning a skill effect model on this dataset, we evaluate the extent
to which the model can recover from failures and minimize future failures. We
propose Fail2Progress, an approach that leverages Stein variational inference
to generate multiple simulation environments in parallel, enabling efficient
data sample generation similar to observed failures. Our method is capable of
handling several challenging mobile manipulation tasks, including transporting
multiple objects, organizing a constrained shelf, and tabletop organization.
Through large-scale simulation and real-world experiments, we demonstrate that
our approach excels at learning from failures across different numbers of
objects. Furthermore, we show that Fail2Progress outperforms several baselines.

AI.tldr: Fail2Progress uses Stein variational inference to generate parallel simulation environments for targeted data collection of failure scenarios in long-horizon manipulation, enabling a skill-effect model to recover from and reduce failures across tasks and object counts, outperforming baselines.
AI.motivation: Long-horizon manipulation skill effect models fail outside training distributions. Efficiently generating data targeted to observed failures is essential to improve robustness and reduce future failures.
AI.method: Propose Fail2Progress, which leverages Stein variational inference to produce multiple simulation environments in parallel that mirror observed failure modes. Fine-tune a skill effect model on the failure-targeted dataset and evaluate recovery and reduction of future failures across tasks (transporting objects, shelf organization, tabletop organization). Demonstrated through large-scale simulation and real-world experiments.
AI.result: The approach learns from failures across varying object counts and outperforms several baselines in both simulation and real-world settings.
AI.conclusion: Fail2Progress provides an effective framework for data-efficient learning from failure in long-horizon manipulation by generating targeted failure data in parallel, improving robustness and generalization to different task configurations.

title: CSFMamba: Cross State Fusion Mamba Operator for Multimodal Remote Sensing Image Classification
comment:
5 pages, 2 figures, accpeted by 2025 IEEE International Geoscience
  and Remote Sensing Symposium(IGARSS 2025),not published yet
summary:
Multimodal fusion has made great progress in the field of remote sensing
image classification due to its ability to exploit the complementary
spatial-spectral information. Deep learning methods such as CNN and Transformer
have been widely used in these domains. State Space Models recently highlighted
that prior methods suffer from quadratic computational complexity. As a result,
modeling longer-range dependencies of spatial-spectral features imposes an
overwhelming burden on the network. Mamba solves this problem by incorporating
time-varying parameters into ordinary SSM and performing hardware optimization,
but it cannot perform feature fusion directly. In order to make full use of
Mamba's low computational burden and explore the potential of internal
structure in multimodal feature fusion, we propose Cross State Fusion Mamba
(CSFMamba) Network. Specifically, we first design the preprocessing module of
remote sensing image information for the needs of Mamba structure, and combine
it with CNN to extract multi-layer features. Secondly, a cross-state module
based on Mamba operator is creatively designed to fully fuse the feature of the
two modalities. The advantages of Mamba and CNN are combined by designing a
more powerful backbone. We capture the fusion relationship between HSI and
LiDAR modalities with stronger full-image understanding. The experimental
results on two datasets of MUUFL and Houston2018 show that the proposed method
outperforms the experimental results of Transformer under the premise of
reducing the network training burden.

AI.tldr: A Cross State Fusion Mamba Network (CSFMamba) fuses HSI and LiDAR using a Mamba-based cross-state module and CNN backbone to achieve higher accuracy with lower training burden than Transformers on MUUFL and Houston2018.
AI.motivation: State Space Models suffer from quadratic complexity when modeling long-range spatial–spectral dependencies; while Mamba reduces computation, it cannot directly fuse multimodal features. The work aims to combine Mamba’s efficiency with effective multimodal fusion.
AI.method: Preprocess remote sensing data for Mamba, use CNN to extract multi-layer features, introduce a cross-state fusion module based on the Mamba operator to fuse HSI and LiDAR modalities, and integrate these into a stronger backbone.
AI.result: The CSFMamba network achieves superior performance compared to Transformer baselines on MUUFL and Houston2018 while reducing the network training burden.
AI.conclusion: Combining Mamba’s efficient time-varying-parameter state-space modeling with a cross-state fusion design enables effective multimodal fusion in remote sensing, yielding better accuracy with lower computation and training cost.

title: An Efficient GNNs-to-KANs Distillation via Self-Attention Dynamic Sampling with Potential for Consumer Electronics Edge Deployment
summary:
Knowledge distillation (KD) is crucial for deploying deep learning models in
resource-constrained edge environments, particularly within the consumer
electronics sector, including smart home devices, wearable technology, and
mobile terminals. These applications place higher demands on model compression
and inference speed, necessitating the transfer of knowledge from Graph Neural
Networks (GNNs) to more efficient Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) models. However,
due to their fixed activation functions and fully connected architecture, MLPs
face challenges in rapidly capturing the complex neighborhood dependencies
learned by GNNs, thereby limiting their performance in edge environments. To
address these limitations, this paper introduces an innovative from GNNs to
Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs) knowledge distillation framework-Self
Attention Dynamic Sampling Distillation (SA-DSD). This study improved Fourier
KAN (FR-KAN) and replaced MLP with the improved FR-KAN+ as the student model.
Through the incorporation of learnable frequency bases and phase-shift
mechanisms, along with algorithmic optimization, FR-KAN significantly improves
its nonlinear fitting capability while effectively reducing computational
complexity. Building on this, a margin-level sampling probability matrix, based
on teacher-student prediction consistency, is constructed, and an adaptive
weighted loss mechanism is designed to mitigate performance degradation in the
student model due to the lack of explicit neighborhood aggregation. Extensive
experiments conducted on six real-world datasets demonstrate that SA-DSD
achieves performance improvements of 3.05%-3.62% over three GNN teacher models
and 15.61% over the FR-KAN+ model. Moreover, when compared with key benchmark
models, SA-DSD achieves a 16.96x reduction in parameter count and a 55.75%
decrease in inference time.

AI.tldr: A knowledge distillation framework SA-DSD transfers knowledge from Graph Neural Networks to a more efficient FR-KAN+ student, improving accuracy and drastically reducing parameters and inference time for edge deployment.
AI.motivation: Edge devices require compact, fast models; MLPs struggle to capture GNN neighborhood aggregation. Transferring rich graph knowledge to lightweight networks (KANs) can preserve performance while meeting resource constraints.
AI.method: SA-DSD uses learnable frequency bases and phase-shift in an improved Fourier-based KAN (FR-KAN+) as the student, introduces a margin-level sampling probability matrix based on teacher–student prediction consistency, and applies an adaptive weighted loss to compensate for the lack of explicit neighborhood aggregation.
AI.result: SA-DSD yields 3.05–3.62% accuracy gains over three GNN teachers and 15.61% over FR-KAN+; achieves 16.96× fewer parameters and 55.75% faster inference on six real-world datasets.
AI.conclusion: SA-DSD effectively bridges GNN-to-KAN knowledge distillation, enhancing nonlinear fitting while markedly reducing model size and latency, enabling practical deployment of GNN-derived capabilities on resource-constrained edge devices.

title: Counterfactual Sensitivity for Faithful Reasoning in Language Models
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) often produce correct answers while relying on
flawed or irrelevant reasoning traces, undermining their trustworthiness in
high-stakes domains. We propose Counterfactual Sensitivity Regularization
(CSR), a lightweight training objective that enforces dependence between
intermediate reasoning and final outputs. CSR introduces automated,
operator-level counterfactual interventions (e.g., swapping "+" with "-")
during training and penalizes models that preserve the same answer under
logically invalid traces. This requires only one additional forward pass per
sample. To measure faithfulness, we introduce Counterfactual Outcome
Sensitivity (COS), which quantifies the impact of such perturbations on model
predictions. Across structured reasoning tasks - arithmetic (GSM8K), logical
deduction (PrOntoQA), and planning (Blocks World) - CSR improves faithfulness
by up to 70 percentage points over standard fine-tuning and process
supervision, with only minor accuracy loss. The learned sensitivity generalizes
to larger models and synergizes with inference-time methods such as
self-consistency. A pilot study on HellaSwag further demonstrates that
extending CSR with semantic perturbations can enhance faithfulness in
commonsense reasoning.

AI.tldr: CSR (Counterfactual Sensitivity Regularization) is a lightweight training objective that enforces faithfulness between intermediate reasoning steps and final outputs by applying automated operator-level counterfactuals during training and penalizing unchanged answers under invalid traces. It uses COS (Counterfactual Outcome Sensitivity) to measure this faithfulness. It yields large faithfulness gains (up to ~70 points) on GSM8K, PrOntoQA, and Blocks World with minimal accuracy loss, generalizes to larger models, and complements inference-time methods like self-consistency; a pilot on HellaSwag suggests extensions to semantic perturbations.
AI.motivation: LLMs often give correct final answers but rely on flawed, irrelevant, or non-faithful reasoning traces, which reduces trust, especially in high-stakes domains. There is a need for training objectives that align intermediate reasoning with final outputs.
AI.method: Introduce CSR, which performs automated, operator-level counterfactual interventions during training (e.g., swapping arithmetic operators like "+" and "-"), and penalizes models that keep the same answer under logically invalid traces. Only one extra forward pass per sample is required. Measure faithfulness with COS, which quantifies how perturbations affect predictions.
AI.result: Across structured reasoning tasks (arithmetic GSM8K, logical deduction PrOntoQA, planning Blocks World), CSR improves faithfulness by up to 70 percentage points over standard fine-tuning and process supervision, with only minor accuracy loss. The sensitivity learned via CSR generalizes to larger models and fits with inference-time methods like self-consistency. A pilot study on HellaSwag indicates semantic perturbations can further enhance faithfulness in commonsense reasoning.
AI.conclusion: CSR provides a lightweight, effective method to increase faithfulness of LLM reasoning by tying intermediate traces to outputs through counterfactual interventions, with COS as a faithful measure. It generalizes across tasks and models and can be combined with existing inference-time strategies; extensions to semantic perturbations show promise for commonsense tasks.

title: Non-conflicting Energy Minimization in Reinforcement Learning based Robot Control
comment:
17 pages, 6 figures. Accepted as Oral presentation at Conference on
  Robot Learning (CoRL) 2025
summary:
Efficient robot control often requires balancing task performance with energy
expenditure. A common approach in reinforcement learning (RL) is to penalize
energy use directly as part of the reward function. This requires carefully
tuning weight terms to avoid undesirable trade-offs where energy minimization
harms task success. In this work, we propose a hyperparameter-free gradient
optimization method to minimize energy expenditure without conflicting with
task performance. Inspired by recent works in multitask learning, our method
applies policy gradient projection between task and energy objectives to derive
policy updates that minimize energy expenditure in ways that do not impact task
performance. We evaluate this technique on standard locomotion benchmarks of
DM-Control and HumanoidBench and demonstrate a reduction of 64% energy usage
while maintaining comparable task performance. Further, we conduct experiments
on a Unitree GO2 quadruped showcasing Sim2Real transfer of energy efficient
policies. Our method is easy to implement in standard RL pipelines with minimal
code changes, is applicable to any policy gradient method, and offers a
principled alternative to reward shaping for energy efficient control policies.

AI.tldr: A hyperparameter-free gradient projection method to minimize energy use in RL without hurting task performance, achieving 64% energy reduction on locomotion benchmarks and demonstrating Sim2Real transfer on a quadruped.
AI.motivation: Energy-efficient control in RL is hampered by the need to tune energy penalties in rewards; a hyperparameter-free method that preserves task performance while reducing energy could simplify learning and improve robustness.
AI.method: Introduce policy gradient projection between task and energy objectives, yielding updates that reduce energy expenditure without impacting task performance; requires no energy-related hyperparameters, compatible with any policy gradient method; inspired by multitask learning.
AI.result: Empirically reduces energy usage by 64% on DM-Control and HumanoidBench with comparable task performance; demonstrates Sim2Real transfer on Unitree GO2 quadruped; easy to implement with minimal code changes.
AI.conclusion: Provides a principled alternative to reward shaping for energy-efficient control, generalizable across policy gradient methods and suitable for real-world deployment thanks to hyperparameter-free formulation.

title: CascadeFormer: A Family of Two-stage Cascading Transformers for Skeleton-based Human Action Recognition
summary:
Skeleton-based human action recognition leverages sequences of human joint
coordinates to identify actions performed in videos. Owing to the intrinsic
spatiotemporal structure of skeleton data, Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs)
have been the dominant architecture in this field. However, recent advances in
transformer models and masked pretraining frameworks open new avenues for
representation learning. In this work, we propose CascadeFormer, a family of
two-stage cascading transformers for skeleton-based human action recognition.
Our framework consists of a masked pretraining stage to learn generalizable
skeleton representations, followed by a cascading fine-tuning stage tailored
for discriminative action classification. We evaluate CascadeFormer across
three benchmark datasets (Penn Action N-UCLA, and NTU RGB+D 60), achieving
competitive performance on all tasks. To promote reproducibility, we release
our code and model checkpoints.

AI.tldr: CascadeFormer introduces a two-stage cascade transformer framework for skeleton-based action recognition, combining masked pretraining with cascading fine-tuning to learn transferable representations and improve discriminative classification, achieving competitive results on Penn Action, N-UCLA, and NTU RGB+D 60; code and checkpoints are released.
AI.motivation: To surpass GCN-centric approaches in skeleton action recognition by leveraging transformer-based masked pretraining for generalizable representations and cascading fine-tuning for discriminative action classification.
AI.method: A two-stage cascade of transformers: (1) masked pretraining on skeleton sequences to learn general representations; (2) cascading fine-tuning tailored for action discrimination. Evaluated on Penn Action, N-UCLA, NTU RGB+D 60; code and model checkpoints released.
AI.result: Competitive performance across the benchmark datasets, demonstrating the viability of cascade transformers for skeleton-based action recognition.
AI.conclusion: Masked pretraining plus cascading fine-tuning is effective for skeleton action recognition, and the authors provide code and checkpoints to facilitate reproducibility.

title: TranCIT: Transient Causal Interaction Toolbox
summary:
Quantifying transient causal interactions from non-stationary neural signals
is a fundamental challenge in neuroscience. Traditional methods are often
inadequate for brief neural events, and advanced, event-specific techniques
have lacked accessible implementations within the Python ecosystem. Here, we
introduce trancit (Transient Causal Interaction Toolbox), an open-source Python
package designed to bridge this gap. TranCIT implements a comprehensive
analysis pipeline, including Granger Causality, Transfer Entropy, and the more
robust Structural Causal Model-based Dynamic Causal Strength (DCS) and relative
Dynamic Causal Strength (rDCS) for accurately detecting event-driven causal
effects. We demonstrate TranCIT's utility by successfully capturing causality
in high-synchrony regimes where traditional methods fail and by identifying the
known transient information flow from hippocampal CA3 to CA1 during sharp-wave
ripple events in real-world data. The package offers a user-friendly, validated
solution for investigating the transient causal dynamics that govern complex
systems.

AI.tldr: Open-source Python toolbox TranCIT for detecting transient causal interactions in non-stationary neural signals, using Granger Causality, Transfer Entropy, and Dynamic Causal Strength (DCS) / relative DCS (rDCS); demonstrated on high-synchrony regimes and hippocampal CA3→CA1 information flow.
AI.motivation: Quantifying event-driven, transient causal interactions in neural data is challenging with traditional methods and there is a lack of accessible Python tools; a user-friendly pipeline is needed.
AI.method: An end-to-end Python package implementing Granger Causality, Transfer Entropy, and Structural Causal Model-based DCS and rDCS to detect event-driven causal effects in non-stationary signals; open-source and validated.
AI.result: Successfully detects causality in high-synchrony regimes where traditional methods fail; identifies transient information flow from hippocampal CA3 to CA1 during sharp-wave ripple events in real data.
AI.conclusion: TranCIT offers a user-friendly, validated solution for investigating transient causal dynamics in complex systems, enabling robust analysis of event-driven neural interactions.

title: Structured AI Decision-Making in Disaster Management
comment:
40 pages, 14 figures, 16 tables. To be published in Nature Scientific
  Reports
summary:
With artificial intelligence (AI) being applied to bring autonomy to
decision-making in safety-critical domains such as the ones typified in the
aerospace and emergency-response services, there has been a call to address the
ethical implications of structuring those decisions, so they remain reliable
and justifiable when human lives are at stake. This paper contributes to
addressing the challenge of decision-making by proposing a structured
decision-making framework as a foundational step towards responsible AI. The
proposed structured decision-making framework is implemented in autonomous
decision-making, specifically within disaster management. By introducing
concepts of Enabler agents, Levels and Scenarios, the proposed framework's
performance is evaluated against systems relying solely on judgement-based
insights, as well as human operators who have disaster experience: victims,
volunteers, and stakeholders. The results demonstrate that the structured
decision-making framework achieves 60.94% greater stability in consistently
accurate decisions across multiple Scenarios, compared to judgement-based
systems. Moreover, the study shows that the proposed framework outperforms
human operators with a 38.93% higher accuracy across various Scenarios. These
findings demonstrate the promise of the structured decision-making framework
for building more reliable autonomous AI applications in safety-critical
contexts.

AI.tldr: A structured decision-making framework for autonomous disaster-management AI improves decision stability and accuracy beyond judgement-based systems and human operators.
AI.motivation: To address ethical and reliability concerns in autonomous, safety-critical decision-making by introducing a formal framework that ensures decisions are more stable and justifiable in high-stakes disaster scenarios.
AI.method: Proposes a structured decision-making framework with Enabler agents, Levels, and Scenarios; implements it in autonomous disaster management; evaluates against judgement-based systems and experienced human operators (victims, volunteers, stakeholders).
AI.result: The framework achieves 60.94% greater stability in consistently accurate decisions across multiple Scenarios versus judgement-based systems and 38.93% higher accuracy than human operators.
AI.conclusion: Structured decision-making frameworks show promise for building more reliable autonomous AI in safety-critical domains, potentially improving trust and accountability in AI-driven disaster response.

title: ManiFlow: A General Robot Manipulation Policy via Consistency Flow Training
summary:
This paper introduces ManiFlow, a visuomotor imitation learning policy for
general robot manipulation that generates precise, high-dimensional actions
conditioned on diverse visual, language and proprioceptive inputs. We leverage
flow matching with consistency training to enable high-quality dexterous action
generation in just 1-2 inference steps. To handle diverse input modalities
efficiently, we propose DiT-X, a diffusion transformer architecture with
adaptive cross-attention and AdaLN-Zero conditioning that enables fine-grained
feature interactions between action tokens and multi-modal observations.
ManiFlow demonstrates consistent improvements across diverse simulation
benchmarks and nearly doubles success rates on real-world tasks across
single-arm, bimanual, and humanoid robot setups with increasing dexterity. The
extensive evaluation further demonstrates the strong robustness and
generalizability of ManiFlow to novel objects and background changes, and
highlights its strong scaling capability with larger-scale datasets. Our
website: maniflow-policy.github.io.

AI.tldr: ManiFlow is a visuomotor imitation policy for general robot manipulation that uses flow matching with consistency training and a diffusion transformer DiT-X to fuse multi-modal inputs, enabling efficient 1-2 step inference and strong performance gains across simulation and real-world robotic tasks.
AI.motivation: To achieve precise, high-dimensional action generation conditioned on diverse sensory inputs (visual, language, proprioceptive) across varied robotic platforms, while ensuring data-efficiency and cross-modal interaction.
AI.method: 1) Flow matching with consistency training for dexterous action generation. 2) DiT-X diffusion transformer with adaptive cross-attention and AdaLN-Zero conditioning to enable fine-grained interactions between action tokens and multi-modal observations. 3) Inference efficiency of 1-2 steps.
AI.result: Outperforms baselines across diverse simulation benchmarks; nearly doubles real-world success rates for single-arm, bimanual, and humanoid setups; robust to novel objects and background changes; exhibits strong scaling with larger datasets.
AI.conclusion: ManiFlow demonstrates robust, scalable, generalizable visuomotor control for dexterous manipulation, with efficient inference and strong cross-modal effectiveness; promising for broad deployment on varied robots and tasks, though real-world generalization to unseen domains merits further testing.

title: Prompt the Unseen: Evaluating Visual-Language Alignment Beyond Supervision
summary:
Vision-Language Models (VLMs) combine a vision encoder and a large language
model (LLM) through alignment training, showing strong performance on
multimodal tasks. A central component in this architecture is the projection
layer, which maps visual features into the LLM's embedding space. Despite its
importance, its ability to generalize to unseen visual concepts has not been
systematically evaluated. To address this, we propose a benchmark for
evaluating projection-layer generalization. We adapt object detection datasets
(rich in fine-grained annotations) into a prompting format and design
train/test splits with disjoint label sets, enabling precise control over seen
and unseen concept separation. Experimental results show that the projection
layer retains about 79 to 88 percent of the performance on unseen classes
compared to seen ones across various settings, suggesting a non-trivial level
of generalization even without explicit alignment supervision on those
concepts. We further analyze this behavior through a mechanistic
interpretability lens. Our findings indicate that the feed-forward network in
the projection layer functions like a key-value memory, processing seen and
unseen tokens in similar ways. This study introduces a new evaluation framework
for alignment generalization and highlights the potential for efficient VLM
training with limited aligned data.

AI.tldr: A benchmark is proposed to test how well the projection layer in Vision-Language Models generalizes to unseen visual concepts. The study finds substantial unseen-effect generalization (about 79–88% of seen performance), and reveals the projection layer behaves like a key-value memory, supporting data-efficient alignment.
AI.motivation: Projection layers map visual features to the LLM space, but their ability to generalize to unseen concepts isn’t well understood. Evaluating this is crucial for data-efficient VLM training.
AI.method: Adapt rich, fine-grained object-detection datasets into a prompting format with train/test splits that have disjoint label sets. Cross-validate seen vs unseen performance and perform a mechanistic interpretability analysis of the projection layer, treating its FFN as a potential key-value memory.
AI.result: Projection layers retain about 79–88% of the performance on unseen classes compared to seen ones across settings, indicating non-trivial generalization. Mechanistic analysis suggests the FFN behaves similarly for seen and unseen tokens.
AI.conclusion: The work provides a new evaluation framework for alignment/generalization in VLMs and supports the possibility of efficient training with limited aligned data.

title: RoFt-Mol: Benchmarking Robust Fine-Tuning with Molecular Graph Foundation Models
summary:
In the era of foundation models, fine-tuning pre-trained models for specific
downstream tasks has become crucial. This drives the need for robust
fine-tuning methods to address challenges such as model overfitting and sparse
labeling. Molecular graph foundation models (MGFMs) face unique difficulties
that complicate fine-tuning. These models are limited by smaller pre-training
datasets and more severe data scarcity for downstream tasks, both of which
require enhanced model generalization. Moreover, MGFMs must accommodate diverse
objectives, including both regression and classification tasks. To better
understand and improve fine-tuning techniques under these conditions, we
classify eight fine-tuning methods into three mechanisms: weight-based,
representation-based, and partial fine-tuning. We benchmark these methods on
downstream regression and classification tasks across supervised and
self-supervised pre-trained models in diverse labeling settings. This extensive
evaluation provides valuable insights and informs the design of a refined
robust fine-tuning method, ROFT-MOL. This approach combines the strengths of
simple post-hoc weight interpolation with more complex weight ensemble
fine-tuning methods, delivering improved performance across both task types
while maintaining the ease of use inherent in post-hoc weight interpolation.

AI.tldr: A study on robust fine-tuning for molecular graph foundation models (MGFMs). Eight fine-tuning methods are categorized into weight-based, representation-based, and partial fine-tuning, and benchmarked on downstream regression and classification tasks with both supervised and self-supervised pretraining under varying labeling settings. The authors propose ROFT-MOL, a robust fine-tuning method that merges simple post-hoc weight interpolation with weight ensemble fine-tuning, achieving improved performance while preserving ease of use.
AI.motivation: MGFMs face limited pre-training data and scarce downstream labels, leading to overfitting and poor generalization. There is a need for robust fine-tuning techniques that handle both regression and classification objectives across different pretraining paradigms (supervised and self-supervised).
AI.method: Classify eight fine-tuning methods into three mechanisms—weight-based, representation-based, and partial fine-tuning—and benchmark them on downstream regression and classification tasks with supervised and self-supervised pre-trained models under diverse labeling settings. Develop ROFT-MOL, a robust fine-tuning approach that combines post-hoc weight interpolation with weight ensemble fine-tuning to achieve better performance with ease of use.
AI.result: ROFT-MOL delivers improved performance across both regression and classification tasks relative to baseline fine-tuning strategies, while maintaining the simplicity of post-hoc weight interpolation. The evaluation also yields insights into the strengths and limitations of different fine-tuning mechanisms under data scarcity.
AI.conclusion: A refined robust fine-tuning framework for molecular graph foundation models—ROFT-MOL—effectively balances performance and usability by integrating weight interpolation with ensemble-based fine-tuning, and highlights directions for robust fine-tuning under limited data and diverse task objectives.

title: Throttling Web Agents Using Reasoning Gates
summary:
AI web agents use Internet resources at far greater speed, scale, and
complexity -- changing how users and services interact. Deployed maliciously or
erroneously, these agents could overload content providers. At the same time,
web agents can bypass CAPTCHAs and other defenses by mimicking user behavior or
flood authentication systems with fake accounts. Yet providers must protect
their services and content from denial-of-service attacks and scraping by web
agents. In this paper, we design a framework that imposes tunable costs on
agents before providing access to resources; we call this Web Agent Throttling.
We start by formalizing Throttling Gates as challenges issued to an agent that
are asymmetric, scalable, robust, and compatible with any agent. Focusing on a
common component -- the language model -- we require the agent to solve
reasoning puzzles, thereby incurring excessive token-generation costs. However,
we find that using existing puzzles, e.g., coding or math, as throttling gates
fails to satisfy our properties. To address this, we introduce rebus-based
Reasoning Gates, synthetic text puzzles that require multi-hop reasoning over
world knowledge (thereby throttling an agent's model). We design a scalable
generation and verification protocol for such reasoning gates. Our framework
achieves computational asymmetry, i.e., the response-generation cost is 9.2x
higher than the generation cost for SOTA models. We further deploy reasoning
gates on a custom website and Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers and evaluate
with real-world web agents. Finally, we discuss the limitations and
environmental impact of real-world deployment of our framework.

AI.tldr: Introduces Web Agent Throttling via rebus-based Reasoning Gates to impose scalable, asymmetric costs on web agents; demonstrates 9.2x cost asymmetry and deploys on MCP and custom sites, with discussion of limitations and environmental impact.
AI.motivation: To protect content providers from denial-of-service and scraping by automated web agents while preserving legitimate access; conventional throttling (e.g., CAPTCHAs) are brittle, scalable to only limited degrees, and may be bypassed.
AI.method: Formalize Throttling Gates; design Reasoning Gates using rebus puzzles that require multi-hop reasoning over world knowledge; develop scalable generation and verification protocol; focus on language models as the common reasoning component; implement on a custom website and Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers; evaluate with real-world web agents.
AI.result: Achieves computational asymmetry with response-generation cost ~9.2× higher than generation cost for SOTA models; deployed and evaluated in a real setting; provides a scalable, compatible throttling approach.
AI.conclusion: Notes limitations and environmental impact of real-world deployment; discusses practical trade-offs and avenues for future improvement.

title: Multi-vessel Interaction-Aware Trajectory Prediction and Collision Risk Assessment
summary:
Accurate vessel trajectory prediction is essential for enhancing situational
awareness and preventing collisions. Still, existing data-driven models are
constrained mainly to single-vessel forecasting, overlooking vessel
interactions, navigation rules, and explicit collision risk assessment. We
present a transformer-based framework for multi-vessel trajectory prediction
with integrated collision risk analysis. For a given target vessel, the
framework identifies nearby vessels. It jointly predicts their future
trajectories through parallel streams encoding kinematic and derived physical
features, causal convolutions for temporal locality, spatial transformations
for positional encoding, and hybrid positional embeddings that capture both
local motion patterns and long-range dependencies. Evaluated on large-scale
real-world AIS data using joint multi-vessel metrics, the model demonstrates
superior forecasting capabilities beyond traditional single-vessel displacement
errors. By simulating interactions among predicted trajectories, the framework
further quantifies potential collision risks, offering actionable insights to
strengthen maritime safety and decision support.

AI.tldr: A transformer-based multi-vessel trajectory predictor with integrated collision risk analysis outperforms single-vessel models on AIS data by modeling inter-vessel interactions and explicit collision risk.
AI.motivation: Current data-driven maritime trajectory models largely forecast for a single vessel and ignore inter-vessel interactions, navigation rules, and explicit collision risk assessment. There is a need for joint multi-vessel prediction and explicit risk analysis to improve safety and decision support.
AI.method: For a target vessel, identify nearby vessels and jointly predict their future trajectories via parallel streams that encode kinematic and derived physical features. Use causal convolutions to capture temporal locality, spatial transformations for positional encoding, and hybrid positional embeddings to capture local motion patterns and long-range dependencies. Train with joint multi-vessel metrics and simulate interactions among predicted trajectories to quantify collision risk.
AI.result: On large-scale real-world AIS data, the approach achieves superior forecasting performance compared to traditional single-vessel displacement-error baselines, as demonstrated by joint multi-vessel metrics. The framework also quantifies collision risk through simulated interactions, providing actionable safety insights.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework advances maritime safety and decision support by delivering accurate multi-vessel trajectory predictions and explicit collision risk assessment; it opens avenues for safer routing and rule-informed decision tools, though scalability and real-time deployment potential warrant further study.

title: Enhancing Fairness in Skin Lesion Classification for Medical Diagnosis Using Prune Learning
summary:
Recent advances in deep learning have significantly improved the accuracy of
skin lesion classification models, supporting medical diagnoses and promoting
equitable healthcare. However, concerns remain about potential biases related
to skin color, which can impact diagnostic outcomes. Ensuring fairness is
challenging due to difficulties in classifying skin tones, high computational
demands, and the complexity of objectively verifying fairness. To address these
challenges, we propose a fairness algorithm for skin lesion classification that
overcomes the challenges associated with achieving diagnostic fairness across
varying skin tones. By calculating the skewness of the feature map in the
convolution layer of the VGG (Visual Geometry Group) network and the patches
and the heads of the Vision Transformer, our method reduces unnecessary
channels related to skin tone, focusing instead on the lesion area. This
approach lowers computational costs and mitigates bias without relying on
conventional statistical methods. It potentially reduces model size while
maintaining fairness, making it more practical for real-world applications.

AI.tldr: Proposes a fairness algorithm for skin lesion classification that reduces skin-tone bias by measuring skewness in CNN feature maps (VGG) and ViT patches/heads to suppress skin-tone related channels, lowering compute and potentially shrinking model size while maintaining fairness.
AI.motivation: To address diagnostic bias across skin tones in deep learning skin lesion classifiers; existing fairness verification is challenging due to skin-tone classification, high compute, and verification complexity.
AI.method: Compute skewness of feature maps in CNN conv layers and ViT patches/heads; identify and suppress channels associated with skin tone; focus on lesion area; avoid traditional statistical fairness methods; reduce computation and model size; applied to skin-lesion classification networks (VGG and ViT).
AI.result: Claims to reduce unnecessary channels related to skin tone, lower computational costs, mitigate bias, no reliance on classical statistics; potential reduction in model size while maintaining fairness; practical for real-world deployment.
AI.conclusion: A practical fairness solution for skin lesion classification across varying skin tones; improves fairness and efficiency, enabling real-world use.

title: TimeCopilot
summary:
We introduce TimeCopilot, the first open-source agentic framework for
forecasting that combines multiple Time Series Foundation Models (TSFMs) with
Large Language Models (LLMs) through a single unified API. TimeCopilot
automates the forecasting pipeline: feature analysis, model selection,
cross-validation, and forecast generation, while providing natural language
explanations and supporting direct queries about the future. The framework is
LLM-agnostic, compatible with both commercial and open-source models, and
supports ensembles across diverse forecasting families. Results on the
large-scale GIFT-Eval benchmark show that TimeCopilot achieves state-of-the-art
probabilistic forecasting performance at low cost. Our framework provides a
practical foundation for reproducible, explainable, and accessible agentic
forecasting systems.

AI.tldr: TimeCopilot is an open-source agentic forecasting framework that unifies multiple Time Series Foundation Models (TSFMs) with LLMs via a single API to automate forecasting and explanations, achieving state-of-the-art probabilistic forecasting on GIFT-Eval at low cost.
AI.motivation: There is a need for an open, scalable, and explainable forecasting framework that can orchestrate diverse TSFMs and LLMs, providing automated workflows (feature analysis, model selection, CV, forecasting) with natural language explanations and future queries.
AI.method: Develop TimeCopilot to connect TSFMs and LLMs through a unified API, automate the forecasting pipeline (feature analysis, model selection, cross-validation, forecast generation), enable ensembles across forecasting families, be LLM-agnostic, provide natural language explanations, support direct future queries, and evaluate on the large-scale GIFT-Eval benchmark.
AI.result: TimeCopilot achieves state-of-the-art probabilistic forecasting performance on GIFT-Eval at low cost.
AI.conclusion: The framework offers a practical foundation for reproducible, explainable, and accessible agentic forecasting systems and is compatible with both open-source and commercial models, supporting ensemble forecasts across forecasting families.

title: Unraveling LLM Jailbreaks Through Safety Knowledge Neurons
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly attracting attention in various
applications. Nonetheless, there is a growing concern as some users attempt to
exploit these models for malicious purposes, including the synthesis of
controlled substances and the propagation of disinformation, a technique known
as "Jailbreak." While some studies have achieved defenses against jailbreak
attacks by modifying output distributions or detecting harmful content, the
exact rationale still remains elusive. In this work, we present a novel
neuron-level interpretability method that focuses on the role of safety-related
knowledge neurons. Unlike existing approaches, our method projects the model's
internal representation into a more consistent and interpretable vocabulary
space. We then show that adjusting the activation of safety-related neurons can
effectively control the model's behavior with a mean ASR higher than 97%.
Building on this insight, we propose SafeTuning, a fine-tuning strategy that
reinforces safety-critical neurons to improve model robustness against
jailbreaks. SafeTuning consistently reduces attack success rates across
multiple LLMs and outperforms all four baseline defenses. These findings offer
a new perspective on understanding and defending against jailbreak attacks.

AI.tldr: Neuron-level interpretability identifies safety-related neurons; by modulating their activation, model behavior can be steered, achieving strong control metrics; a fine-tuning strategy (SafeTuning) reinforces these neurons to defend against jailbreaking across LLMs, outperforming baselines.
AI.motivation: Jailbreak attacks pose safety risks in LLM deployments. Existing defenses (output filtering/detection) are incomplete and their rationale remains unclear. There is a need for deeper, neurony-level understanding of safety mechanisms and more robust defenses.
AI.method: Introduce a neuron-level interpretability method that projects the model’s internal representations into a consistent, interpretable vocabulary space to identify safety-related neurons. Demonstrate that activating these neurons can control the model’s behavior. Propose SafeTuning, a fine-tuning strategy that reinforces safety-critical neurons to improve robustness against jailbreak attempts.
AI.result: Activation of safety-related neurons can effectively control model behavior, achieving a mean attack-success-rate (ASR) higher than 97% in control experiments. SafeTuning reduces jailbreak success across multiple LLMs and outperforms four baseline defenses.
AI.conclusion: A safety-neuron–driven interpretability framework, coupled with SafeTuning, offers a new perspective for understanding and defending against jailbreak attacks, delivering improved robustness over existing defenses.

title: AI-Driven Marine Robotics: Emerging Trends in Underwater Perception and Ecosystem Monitoring
summary:
Marine ecosystems face increasing pressure due to climate change, driving the
need for scalable, AI-powered monitoring solutions. This paper examines the
rapid emergence of underwater AI as a major research frontier and analyzes the
factors that have transformed marine perception from a niche application into a
catalyst for AI innovation. We identify three convergent drivers: environmental
necessity for ecosystem-scale monitoring, democratization of underwater
datasets through citizen science platforms, and researcher migration from
saturated terrestrial computer vision domains. Our analysis reveals how unique
underwater challenges - turbidity, cryptic species detection, expert annotation
bottlenecks, and cross-ecosystem generalization - are driving fundamental
advances in weakly supervised learning, open-set recognition, and robust
perception under degraded conditions. We survey emerging trends in datasets,
scene understanding and 3D reconstruction, highlighting the paradigm shift from
passive observation toward AI-driven, targeted intervention capabilities. The
paper demonstrates how underwater constraints are pushing the boundaries of
foundation models, self-supervised learning, and perception, with
methodological innovations that extend far beyond marine applications to
benefit general computer vision, robotics, and environmental monitoring.

AI.tldr: Underwater AI is rapidly expanding as a research frontier due to environmental monitoring needs, democratized datasets via citizen science, and researchers moving from terrestrial CV; challenges unique to underwater perception drive advances in weak supervision, open-set recognition, and robust perception, with broader implications for foundation models and general CV.
AI.motivation: The abstract identifies environmental necessity for ecosystem-scale monitoring, greater access to underwater data through citizen science, and talent migration from saturated terrestrial CV as the key drivers transforming marine perception from niche to pivotal for AI innovation.
AI.method: A review and analytical synthesis of emerging trends, datasets, scene understanding, and 3D reconstruction in underwater AI, framed as a survey of factors and their consequences for method development and cross-domain impact.
AI.result: Three convergent drivers push underwater AI forward: (1) ecosystem-scale monitoring needs; (2) democratized data via citizen science; (3) migration of researchers into underwater CV. Challenges such as turbidity, cryptic species, annotation bottlenecks, and cross-ecosystem generalization are catalyzing advances in weakly supervised learning, open-set recognition, and robust perception. Trends include datasets, scene understanding, and 3D reconstruction, signaling a shift from passive observation to AI-driven, targeted intervention. Underwater constraints are also advancing foundation models, self-supervised learning, and perception techniques with broad relevance beyond marine domains.
AI.conclusion: Underwater constraints are not merely domain-specific challenges but drivers of fundamental AI advancement with implications for general computer vision, robotics, and environmental monitoring. The research indicates a paradigm shift toward scalable, autonomous, and intervention-ready perception systems, potentially benefiting diverse applications beyond marine contexts.

title: Causal Interpretation of Sparse Autoencoder Features in Vision
summary:
Understanding what sparse auto-encoder (SAE) features in vision transformers
truly represent is usually done by inspecting the patches where a feature's
activation is highest. However, self-attention mixes information across the
entire image, so an activated patch often co-occurs with-but does not cause-the
feature's firing. We propose Causal Feature Explanation (CaFE), which leverages
Effective Receptive Field (ERF). We consider each activation of an SAE feature
to be a target and apply input-attribution methods to identify the image
patches that causally drive that activation. Across CLIP-ViT features, ERF maps
frequently diverge from naive activation maps, revealing hidden context
dependencies (e.g., a "roaring face" feature that requires the co-occurrence of
eyes and nose, rather than merely an open mouth). Patch insertion tests confirm
that CaFE more effectively recovers or suppresses feature activations than
activation-ranked patches. Our results show that CaFE yields more faithful and
semantically precise explanations of vision-SAE features, highlighting the risk
of misinterpretation when relying solely on activation location.

AI.tldr: CaFE is a causal explanation framework for vision transformers with sparse auto-encoder features. It uses Effective Receptive Field (ERF) to identify image patches that causally drive each feature activation, revealing that naive activation maps can be misleading due to cross-patch dependencies in self-attention. Patch-insertion tests show CaFE yields more faithful, semantically precise explanations than activation-ranked patches.
AI.motivation: Self-attention in vision transformers mixes information across the image, so activation locations of SAE features may not causally drive activations. There is a need for causal, context-aware explanations that reveal which patches actually drive a feature.
AI.method: Introduce CaFE. For each activation of an SAE feature, treat it as a target and apply input-attribution methods guided by the Effective Receptive Field (ERF) to identify patches that causally drive that activation. Analyze ERF maps across CLIP-ViT features and validate with patch-insertion tests to compare with activation-based explanations.
AI.result: ERF maps often diverge from naive activation maps, exposing hidden context dependencies (e.g., a roaring face feature depends on co-occurring eyes and nose). Patch-insertion tests show CaFE more reliably recovers or suppresses feature activations than using activation-ranked patches.
AI.conclusion: CaFE provides more faithful and semantically precise explanations of vision-SAE features and cautions against relying solely on activation locations due to potential misinterpretations from self-attention.

title: Forecasting the Ionosphere from Sparse GNSS Data with Temporal-Fusion Transformers
summary:
The ionosphere critically influences Global Navigation Satellite Systems
(GNSS), satellite communications, and Low Earth Orbit (LEO) operations, yet
accurate prediction of its variability remains challenging due to nonlinear
couplings between solar, geomagnetic, and thermospheric drivers. Total Electron
Content (TEC), a key ionospheric parameter, is derived from GNSS observations,
but its reliable forecasting is limited by the sparse nature of global
measurements and the limited accuracy of empirical models, especially during
strong space weather conditions. In this work, we present a machine learning
framework for ionospheric TEC forecasting that leverages Temporal Fusion
Transformers (TFT) to predict sparse ionosphere data. Our approach accommodates
heterogeneous input sources, including solar irradiance, geomagnetic indices,
and GNSS-derived vertical TEC, and applies preprocessing and temporal alignment
strategies. Experiments spanning 2010-2025 demonstrate that the model achieves
robust predictions up to 24 hours ahead, with root mean square errors as low as
3.33 TECU. Results highlight that solar EUV irradiance provides the strongest
predictive signals. Beyond forecasting accuracy, the framework offers
interpretability through attention-based analysis, supporting both operational
applications and scientific discovery. To encourage reproducibility and
community-driven development, we release the full implementation as the
open-source toolkit \texttt{ionopy}.

AI.tldr: A Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT)–based framework for forecasting sparse ionospheric total electron content (TEC) up to 24 hours ahead, integrating solar irradiance, geomagnetic indices, and GNSS-derived TEC; achieves RMSE ~3.33 TECU and offers attention-based interpretability; released as open-source toolkit 'ionopy'.
AI.motivation: Accurate TEC forecasting is challenging due to nonlinear solar–geomagnetic–thermospheric coupling, sparse global measurements, and poor empirical models, especially during strong space weather.
AI.method: A TFT-based forecasting framework that ingests heterogeneous inputs (solar irradiance, geomagnetic indices, GNSS vertical TEC), with preprocessing and temporal alignment; trained/evaluated on 2010–2025 data; interpretable via attention analysis; open-source implementation 'ionopy'.
AI.result: The model provides robust TEC forecasts up to 24 hours ahead, achieving RMSE as low as 3.33 TECU; solar EUV irradiance emerges as the strongest predictive signal; attention analysis enables interpretability for operational and scientific use.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates accurate, interpretable TEC forecasting under sparse data and space weather conditions; supports operational GNSS and space-weather applications; promotes reproducibility through open-source release.

title: Physics Supernova: AI Agent Matches Elite Gold Medalists at IPhO 2025
summary:
Physics provides fundamental laws that describe and predict the natural
world. AI systems aspiring toward more general, real-world intelligence must
therefore demonstrate strong physics problem-solving abilities: to formulate
and apply physical laws for explaining and predicting physical processes. The
International Physics Olympiad (IPhO)--the world's most prestigious physics
competition--offers a rigorous benchmark for this purpose. We introduce Physics
Supernova, an AI agent system with superior physics problem-solving abilities
that match elite IPhO gold medalists. In IPhO 2025 theory problems, Physics
Supernova attains 23.5/30 points, ranking 14th of 406 contestants and
surpassing the median performance of human gold medalists. We extensively
analyzed Physics Supernova's capabilities and flexibility across diverse
physics tasks. These results show that principled tool integration within agent
systems can deliver competitive improvements in solving challenging science
problems. The codes are available at
https://github.com/CharlesQ9/Physics-Supernova.

AI.tldr: AI agent Physics Supernova solves high-level physics problems at elite competition level, matching gold medalists and outperforming the median among them, demonstrating that principled tool integration boosts scientific problem-solving.
AI.motivation: To develop AI systems capable of strong physics problem-solving that generalizes to real-world tasks, using a rigorous benchmark (IPhO) to evaluate progress.
AI.method: Developed Physics Supernova, an AI agent that integrates tools and physics reasoning to tackle IPhO 2025 theory problems; evaluated against top human contestants and analyzed across varied physics tasks; code released for reproducibility.
AI.result: In IPhO 2025 theory problems, Physics Supernova scored 23.5/30, ranked 14th out of 406 contestants, and surpassed the median performance of human gold medalists.
AI.conclusion: principled tool integration within AI agents can yield competitive, scalable improvements in solving challenging science problems and set new benchmarks for AI-assisted scientific problem-solving.

title: AutoDrive-R$^2$: Incentivizing Reasoning and Self-Reflection Capacity for VLA Model in Autonomous Driving
summary:
Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models in autonomous driving systems have
recently demonstrated transformative potential by integrating multimodal
perception with decision-making capabilities. However, the interpretability and
coherence of the decision process and the plausibility of action sequences
remain largely underexplored. To address these issues, we propose
AutoDrive-R$^2$, a novel VLA framework that enhances both reasoning and
self-reflection capabilities of autonomous driving systems through
chain-of-thought (CoT) processing and reinforcement learning (RL).
Specifically, we first propose an innovative CoT dataset named nuScenesR$^2$-6K
for supervised fine-tuning, which effectively builds cognitive bridges between
input information and output trajectories through a four-step logical chain
with self-reflection for validation. Moreover, to maximize both reasoning and
self-reflection during the RL stage, we further employ the Group Relative
Policy Optimization (GRPO) algorithm within a physics-grounded reward framework
that incorporates spatial alignment, vehicle dynamic, and temporal smoothness
criteria to ensure reliable and realistic trajectory planning. Extensive
evaluation results across both nuScenes and Waymo datasets demonstrates the
state-of-the-art performance and robust generalization capacity of our proposed
method.

AI.tldr: Proposes AutoDrive-R^2, a vision-language-action model for autonomous driving that uses chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning and reinforcement learning (RL) to improve interpretability and trajectory plausibility. It introduces nuScenesR^2-6K for supervised CoT, and applies Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) within a physics-grounded reward to produce realistic, smooth trajectories. Achieves state-of-the-art results and strong generalization on nuScenes and Waymo.
AI.motivation: Address the interpretability and coherence gaps in vision-language-action models for autonomous driving, ensuring credible reasoning and plausible action sequences through structured reasoning (CoT) and physics-aware RL.
AI.method: 1) Construct nuScenesR^2-6K, a CoT-focused supervised dataset that maps input information to output trajectories via a four-step logical chain with self-reflection for validation. 2) Fine-tune with chain-of-thought supervision. 3) Use Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) in a reinforcement learning stage with a physics-grounded reward framework that enforces spatial alignment, vehicle dynamics constraints, and temporal smoothness for realistic trajectory planning.
AI.result: Extensive evaluations on nuScenes and Waymo indicate state-of-the-art performance and robust generalization of AutoDrive-R^2.
AI.conclusion: AutoDrive-R^2 advances decision-making in autonomous driving through integrated CoT reasoning and self-reflection, combined with physics-aware RL, achieving superior performance and generalization across major datasets.

title: EVENT-Retriever: Event-Aware Multimodal Image Retrieval for Realistic Captions
summary:
Event-based image retrieval from free-form captions presents a significant
challenge: models must understand not only visual features but also latent
event semantics, context, and real-world knowledge. Conventional
vision-language retrieval approaches often fall short when captions describe
abstract events, implicit causality, temporal context, or contain long, complex
narratives. To tackle these issues, we introduce a multi-stage retrieval
framework combining dense article retrieval, event-aware language model
reranking, and efficient image collection, followed by caption-guided semantic
matching and rank-aware selection. We leverage Qwen3 for article search,
Qwen3-Reranker for contextual alignment, and Qwen2-VL for precise image
scoring. To further enhance performance and robustness, we fuse outputs from
multiple configurations using Reciprocal Rank Fusion (RRF). Our system achieves
the top-1 score on the private test set of Track 2 in the EVENTA 2025 Grand
Challenge, demonstrating the effectiveness of combining language-based
reasoning and multimodal retrieval for complex, real-world image understanding.
The code is available at https://github.com/vdkhoi20/EVENT-Retriever.

AI.tldr: A multi-stage, language-guided multimodal retrieval pipeline for event-based image retrieval using dense article retrieval, event-aware reranking, and caption-guided matching, achieving top-1 on EVENTA 2025 Track 2 private test; code available.
AI.motivation: Captions often describe abstract events, causality, and long narratives requiring world knowledge; existing vision-language retrieval struggles with these cases; need to integrate language reasoning with multimodal retrieval.
AI.method: Multi-stage pipeline: 1) dense article retrieval; 2) event-aware language model reranking for contextual alignment; 3) efficient image collection; 4) caption-guided semantic matching; 5) rank-aware selection; fusion via Reciprocal Rank Fusion across configurations; utilizes Qwen3 for article search, Qwen3-Reranker for alignment, Qwen2-VL for image scoring; code at GitHub.
AI.result: Top-1 on private Track 2 test set in EVENTA 2025 Grand Challenge; demonstrates effectiveness of combining language-based reasoning with multimodal retrieval for complex tasks; showcases robustness via ensemble.
AI.conclusion: Shows that integrating language models with multimodal retrieval improves event-based image understanding; the approach is effective for real-world, complex narratives and can be extended with additional configurations.

title: Disentangling Slow and Fast Temporal Dynamics in Degradation Inference with Hierarchical Differential Models
summary:
Reliable inference of system degradation from sensor data is fundamental to
condition monitoring and prognostics in engineered systems. Since degradation
is rarely observable and measurable, it must be inferred to enable accurate
health assessment and decision-making. This is particularly challenging because
operational variations dominate system behavior, while degradation introduces
only subtle, long-term changes. Consequently, sensor data mainly reflect
short-term operational variability, making it difficult to disentangle the
underlying degradation process. Residual-based methods are widely employed, but
the residuals remain entangled with operational history, often resulting in
noisy and unreliable degradation estimation, particularly in systems with
dynamic responses. Neural Ordinary Equations (NODEs) offer a promising
framework for inferring latent dynamics, but the time-scale separation in
slow-fast systems introduces numerical stiffness and complicates training,
while degradation disentanglement remains difficult. To address these
limitations, we propose a novel Hierarchical Controlled Differential Equation
(H-CDE) framework that incorporates a slow (degradation) and a fast (operation)
CDE component in a unified architecture. It introduces three key innovations: a
multi-scale time integration scheme to mitigate numerical stiffness; a
learnable path transformation that extracts latent degradation drivers to
control degradation evolution; and a novel activation function that enforces
monotonicity on inferred degradation as a regularizer for disentanglement.
Through comprehensive evaluations on both dynamic response (e.g., bridges) and
steady state (e.g., aero-engine) systems, we demonstrate that H-CDE effectively
disentangles degradation from operational dynamics and outperforms
residual-based baselines, yielding more accurate, robust, and interpretable
inference.

AI.tldr: Introduces Hierarchical Controlled Differential Equations (H-CDE) to disentangle degradation from operational dynamics, via slow-degradation and fast-operation CDEs, multi-scale integration, learnable path transformation, and a monotonicity regularizer; shows improved degradation inference over residual baselines across dynamic and steady-state systems.
AI.motivation: Degradation is latent and slowly evolving; operational variability dominates sensor signals; residual-based methods entangle degradation with history and noise, especially in systems with dynamic responses; need a framework that separates slow degradation from fast operation.
AI.method: Propose H-CDE with two coupled CDE components (slow-degradation and fast-operation). Introduce multi-scale time integration to reduce numerical stiffness, a learnable path transformation to extract degradation drivers and control degradation evolution, and a monotonicity-enforcing activation function to regularize and disentangle degradation. Evaluate on dynamic (bridges) and steady-state (aero-engine) systems, comparing to residual-based baselines.
AI.result: H-CDE effectively disentangles degradation from operational dynamics, achieving more accurate, robust, and interpretable degradation inferences; outperforms residual-based methods in both dynamic and steady-state settings.
AI.conclusion: A scalable, principled framework for degradation inference under strong operational variability, applicable to prognostics and condition monitoring; the hierarchical CDE approach addresses stiffness and disentanglement, with broad applicability to engineering systems.

title: An LLM-enabled semantic-centric framework to consume privacy policies
summary:
In modern times, people have numerous online accounts, but they rarely read
the Terms of Service or Privacy Policy of those sites, despite claiming
otherwise, due to the practical difficulty in comprehending them. The mist of
data privacy practices forms a major barrier for user-centred Web approaches,
and for data sharing and reusing in an agentic world. Existing research
proposed methods for using formal languages and reasoning for verifying the
compliance of a specified policy, as a potential cure for ignoring privacy
policies. However, a critical gap remains in the creation or acquisition of
such formal policies at scale. We present a semantic-centric approach for using
state-of-the-art large language models (LLM), to automatically identify key
information about privacy practices from privacy policies, and construct
$\mathit{Pr}^2\mathit{Graph}$, knowledge graph with grounding from Data Privacy
Vocabulary (DPV) for privacy practices, to support downstream tasks. Along with
the pipeline, the $\mathit{Pr}^2\mathit{Graph}$ for the top-100 popular
websites is also released as a public resource, by using the pipeline for
analysis. We also demonstrate how the $\mathit{Pr}^2\mathit{Graph}$ can be used
to support downstream tasks by constructing formal policy representations such
as Open Digital Right Language (ODRL) or perennial semantic Data Terms of Use
(psDToU). To evaluate the technology capability, we enriched the Policy-IE
dataset by employing legal experts to create custom annotations. We benchmarked
the performance of different large language models for our pipeline and
verified their capabilities. Overall, they shed light on the possibility of
large-scale analysis of online services' privacy practices, as a promising
direction to audit the Web and the Internet. We release all datasets and source
code as public resources to facilitate reuse and improvement.

AI.tldr: A semantic-centric pipeline using large language models to extract privacy-practice information from policies, ground it in the Data Privacy Vocabulary as Pr^2Graph, and enable formal policy representations and large-scale auditing; datasets and code released.
AI.motivation: Users rarely read terms and policies, and the lack of scalable, formal representations of privacy practices hinders user-centric Web approaches and data sharing. There is a gap in obtaining scalable, formal privacy policies (policy graphs) for widespread use.
AI.method: A semantic-centric pipeline leveraging state-of-the-art LLMs to identify key privacy-practice information from privacy policies and construct Pr^2Graph grounded in the Data Privacy Vocabulary (DPV). The pipeline is applied to the top-100 websites, enabling downstream tasks by generating formal policy representations such as ODRL or psDToU. The approach is evaluated by enriching the Policy-IE dataset with expert annotations and benchmarking multiple LLMs. All datasets and source code are released.
AI.result: Released Pr^2Graph for the top-100 popular websites and demonstrated how it supports downstream tasks with formal representations (ODRL, psDToU). The authors benchmarked various LLMs and verified capabilities, and released datasets and code publicly.
AI.conclusion: The work enables large-scale analysis and auditing of online privacy practices, highlighting a promising direction for Web privacy governance and reuse of formal privacy representations.

title: Hybrid Autonomy Framework for a Future Mars Science Helicopter
summary:
Autonomous aerial vehicles, such as NASA's Ingenuity, enable rapid planetary
surface exploration beyond the reach of ground-based robots. Thus, NASA is
studying a Mars Science Helicopter (MSH), an advanced concept capable of
performing long-range science missions and autonomously navigating challenging
Martian terrain. Given significant Earth-Mars communication delays and mission
complexity, an advanced autonomy framework is required to ensure safe and
efficient operation by continuously adapting behavior based on mission
objectives and real-time conditions, without human intervention. This study
presents a deterministic high-level control framework for aerial exploration,
integrating a Finite State Machine (FSM) with Behavior Trees (BTs) to achieve a
scalable, robust, and computationally efficient autonomy solution for critical
scenarios like deep space exploration. In this paper we outline key
capabilities of a possible MSH and detail the FSM-BT hybrid autonomy framework
which orchestrates them to achieve the desired objectives. Monte Carlo
simulations and real field tests validate the framework, demonstrating its
robustness and adaptability to both discrete events and real-time system
feedback. These inputs trigger state transitions or dynamically adjust behavior
execution, enabling reactive and context-aware responses. The framework is
middleware-agnostic, supporting integration with systems like F-Prime and
extending beyond aerial robotics.

AI.tldr: Deterministic FSM-BT hybrid autonomy framework for Mars aerial exploration (MSH), robust, scalable, middleware-agnostic; validated by Monte Carlo simulations and field tests.
