AI.motivation: Earth-Mars communication delays and mission complexity require autonomous decision-making that adapts in real-time to objectives and conditions.
AI.method: Integrate Finite State Machine with Behavior Trees into a deterministic high-level controller; event-driven state transitions and BT-based task execution, with Monte Carlo simulations and field tests; middleware-agnostic (e.g., F-Prime).
AI.result: Demonstrated robustness and adaptability to discrete events and real-time feedback; reactive and context-aware behavior; validated in both simulation and real-world tests.
AI.conclusion: FSM-BT hybrid autonomy offers scalable, efficient autonomy for deep-space aerial exploration and can extend beyond aerial robotics with middleware integration.

title: Multi-Level CLS Token Fusion for Contrastive Learning in Endoscopy Image Classification
summary:
We present a unified vision-language framework tailored for ENT endoscopy
image analysis that simultaneously tackles three clinically-relevant tasks:
image classification, image-to-image retrieval, and text-to-image retrieval.
Unlike conventional CNN-based pipelines that struggle to capture cross-modal
semantics, our approach leverages the CLIP ViT-B/16 backbone and enhances it
through Low-Rank Adaptation, multi-level CLS token aggregation, and spherical
feature interpolation. These components collectively enable efficient
fine-tuning on limited medical data while improving representation diversity
and semantic alignment across modalities. To bridge the gap between visual
inputs and textual diagnostic context, we introduce class-specific natural
language prompts that guide the image encoder through a joint training
objective combining supervised classification with contrastive learning. We
validated our framework through participation in the ACM MM'25 ENTRep Grand
Challenge, achieving 95% accuracy and F1-score in classification, Recall@1 of
0.93 and 0.92 for image-to-image and text-to-image retrieval respectively, and
MRR scores of 0.97 and 0.96. Ablation studies demonstrated the incremental
benefits of each architectural component, validating the effectiveness of our
design for robust multimodal medical understanding in low-resource clinical
settings.

AI.tldr: A unified multimodal framework for ENT endoscopy using a CLIP ViT-B/16 backbone enhanced with Low-Rank Adaptation, multi-level CLS token aggregation, and spherical feature interpolation, guided by class-specific prompts; achieves strong classification and retrieval performance in a low-resource clinical setting.
AI.motivation: Conventional CNN-based pipelines struggle to capture cross-modal semantics and perform well with limited medical data. There's a need to align visual ENT endoscopy findings with textual diagnostic context to support classification and retrieval tasks.
AI.method: Fine-tune a CLIP ViT-B/16 backbone with Low-Rank Adaptation, incorporate multi-level CLS token aggregation and spherical feature interpolation. Employ class-specific natural language prompts to guide the image encoder and train with a joint objective combining supervised classification and contrastive learning, enabling image classification, image-to-image retrieval, and text-to-image retrieval.
AI.result: Classification achieves 95% accuracy and F1-score; image-to-image Recall@1 = 0.93; text-to-image Recall@1 = 0.92; MRR scores 0.97 (image-to-image) and 0.96 (text-to-image). Ablation studies show incremental gains from each component.
AI.conclusion: The proposed architecture provides robust multimodal medical understanding in low-resource ENT settings, and its components synergistically improve cross-modal semantic alignment for classification and retrieval tasks.

title: AMCR: A Framework for Assessing and Mitigating Copyright Risks in Generative Models
summary:
Generative models have achieved impressive results in text to image tasks,
significantly advancing visual content creation. However, this progress comes
at a cost, as such models rely heavily on large-scale training data and may
unintentionally replicate copyrighted elements, creating serious legal and
ethical challenges for real-world deployment. To address these concerns,
researchers have proposed various strategies to mitigate copyright risks, most
of which are prompt based methods that filter or rewrite user inputs to prevent
explicit infringement. While effective in handling obvious cases, these
approaches often fall short in more subtle situations, where seemingly benign
prompts can still lead to infringing outputs. To address these limitations,
this paper introduces Assessing and Mitigating Copyright Risks (AMCR), a
comprehensive framework which i) builds upon prompt-based strategies by
systematically restructuring risky prompts into safe and non-sensitive forms,
ii) detects partial infringements through attention-based similarity analysis,
and iii) adaptively mitigates risks during generation to reduce copyright
violations without compromising image quality. Extensive experiments validate
the effectiveness of AMCR in revealing and mitigating latent copyright risks,
offering practical insights and benchmarks for the safer deployment of
generative models.

AI.tldr: AMCR is a framework for assessing and mitigating copyright risks in text-to-image generation, featuring prompt restructuring, attention-based infringement detection, and adaptive risk mitigation to maintain image quality.
AI.motivation: Generative text-to-image models raise copyright concerns due to reliance on large training data and potential replication of protected elements; existing prompt-based filters miss subtle forms of infringement; need a proactive, systematic safety framework for real-world deployment.
AI.method: Propose AMCR with three components: (1) restructure risky prompts into safe/non-sensitive forms, (2) use attention-based similarity analysis to detect partial infringements during generation, (3) adaptively mitigate risks during generation to reduce violations while preserving image quality.
AI.result: Extensive experiments demonstrate AMCR's effectiveness in revealing and mitigating latent copyright risks and provide practical insights and benchmarks for safer deployment.
AI.conclusion: AMCR offers a comprehensive, practical approach to copyright risk mitigation in generative models, enabling safer deployment without sacrificing output quality.

title: Oyster-I: Beyond Refusal -- Constructive Safety Alignment for Responsible Language Models
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) typically deploy safety mechanisms to prevent
harmful content generation. Most current approaches focus narrowly on risks
posed by malicious actors, often framing risks as adversarial events and
relying on defensive refusals. However, in real-world settings, risks also come
from non-malicious users seeking help while under psychological distress (e.g.,
self-harm intentions). In such cases, the model's response can strongly
influence the user's next actions. Simple refusals may lead them to repeat,
escalate, or move to unsafe platforms, creating worse outcomes. We introduce
Constructive Safety Alignment (CSA), a human-centric paradigm that protects
against malicious misuse while actively guiding vulnerable users toward safe
and helpful results. Implemented in Oyster-I (Oy1), CSA combines game-theoretic
anticipation of user reactions, fine-grained risk boundary discovery, and
interpretable reasoning control, turning safety into a trust-building process.
Oy1 achieves state-of-the-art safety among open models while retaining high
general capabilities. On our Constructive Benchmark, it shows strong
constructive engagement, close to GPT-5, and unmatched robustness on the
Strata-Sword jailbreak dataset, nearing GPT-o1 levels. By shifting from
refusal-first to guidance-first safety, CSA redefines the model-user
relationship, aiming for systems that are not just safe, but meaningfully
helpful. We release Oy1, code, and the benchmark to support responsible,
user-centered AI.

AI.tldr: Constructive Safety Alignment (CSA) reframes safety from reflexive refusals to guided, constructive interactions for vulnerable users, implemented in Oyster-I (Oy1) with game-theoretic anticipation, risk boundary discovery, and interpretable reasoning control.
AI.motivation: Real-world safety risks include non-malicious users seeking help while distressed (e.g., self-harm), where blunt refusals can worsen outcomes. Existing safety mainly guards against malicious misuse and adversarial framing; there is a need to balance safety with helpfulness.
AI.method: CSA is implemented in Oyster-I (Oy1) and combines (1) game-theoretic anticipation of user reactions, (2) fine-grained risk boundary discovery, and (3) interpretable reasoning control to steer responses toward safe, constructive guidance rather than outright refusals.
AI.result: Oy1 achieves state-of-the-art safety among open models while preserving high general capabilities. On the Constructive Benchmark, Oy1 shows strong constructive engagement (near GPT-5) and unmatched robustness on the Strata-Sword jailbreak dataset (near GPT-01 levels).
AI.conclusion: Shifting from refusal-first to guidance-first safety redefines the model-user relationship, aiming for systems that are both safe and meaningfully helpful. The authors release Oy1, code, and the benchmark to support responsible, user-centered AI.

title: Geometric Control of Mechanical Systems with Symmetries Based on Sliding Modes
summary:
In this paper, we propose a framework for designing sliding mode controllers
for a class of mechanical systems with symmetry, both unconstrained and
constrained, that evolve on principal fiber bundles. Control laws are developed
based on the reduced motion equations by exploring symmetries, leading to a
sliding mode control strategy where the reaching stage is executed on the base
space, and the sliding stage is performed on the structure group. Thus, design
complexity is reduced, and difficult choices for coordinate representations
when working with a particular Lie group are avoided. For this purpose, a
sliding subgroup is constructed on the structure group based on a kinematic
controller, and the sliding variable will converge to the identity of the state
manifold upon reaching the sliding subgroup. A reaching law based on a general
sliding vector field is then designed on the base space using the local form of
the mechanical connection to drive the sliding variable to the sliding
subgroup, and its time evolution is given according to the appropriate
covariant derivative. Almost global asymptotic stability and local exponential
stability are demonstrated using a Lyapunov analysis. We apply the results to a
fully actuated system (a rigid spacecraft actuated by reaction wheels) and a
subactuated nonholonomic system (unicycle mobile robot actuated by wheels),
which is also simulated for illustration.

AI.tldr: A symmetry-aware sliding mode control framework on principal fiber bundles that splits reaching and sliding stages between base space and structure group, with stability guarantees and applications to spacecraft and unicycle.
AI.motivation: To tackle coordinate- and Lie-group-specific design challenges in sliding mode control for mechanical systems with symmetry, by leveraging reduced dynamics on principal fiber bundles.
AI.method: Build a sliding subgroup on the structure group from a kinematic controller; design a sliding variable converging to the identity; create a reaching law on the base space using the mechanical connection and covariant derivative; prove almost global asymptotic stability and local exponential stability via Lyapunov analysis.
AI.result: Theoretical framework with stability proofs; applied to a fully actuated spacecraft (reaction wheels) and a subactuated unicycle; simulations illustrate the approach.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework reduces design complexity by avoiding specific Lie-group coordinates, achieves robust sliding behavior on the bundle, and is applicable to both fully actuated and subactuated mechanical systems, with stability guarantees.

title: MarkSplatter: Generalizable Watermarking for 3D Gaussian Splatting Model via Splatter Image Structure
summary:
The growing popularity of 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) has intensified the
need for effective copyright protection. Current 3DGS watermarking methods rely
on computationally expensive fine-tuning procedures for each predefined
message. We propose the first generalizable watermarking framework that enables
efficient protection of Splatter Image-based 3DGS models through a single
forward pass. We introduce GaussianBridge that transforms unstructured 3D
Gaussians into Splatter Image format, enabling direct neural processing for
arbitrary message embedding. To ensure imperceptibility, we design a
Gaussian-Uncertainty-Perceptual heatmap prediction strategy for preserving
visual quality. For robust message recovery, we develop a dense
segmentation-based extraction mechanism that maintains reliable extraction even
when watermarked objects occupy minimal regions in rendered views. Project
page: https://kevinhuangxf.github.io/marksplatter.

AI.tldr: A generalizable, single-pass watermarking framework for Splatter Image-based 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) that enables efficient protection, robust extraction, and high imperceptibility via GaussianBridge, perceptual heatmaps, and dense segmentation-based retrieval.
AI.motivation: To address the inefficiency of existing 3DGS watermarking methods that require expensive fine-tuning for each message, and to provide a generalizable, efficient, and robust protection mechanism for 3DGS models.
AI.method: Introduce GaussianBridge to convert unstructured 3D Gaussians into Splatter Image format suitable for neural processing; embed arbitrary messages in a single forward pass; use a Gaussian-Uncertainty-Perceptual heatmap to preserve visual quality; implement dense segmentation-based extraction to reliably recover messages even when watermarked content occupies small screen regions.
AI.result: The framework enables efficient, one-pass watermark embedding and robust extraction while maintaining visual fidelity; demonstrated feasibility through the proposed pipeline and mechanisms, with reliable recovery under challenging rendering scenarios.
AI.conclusion: A novel, generalizable watermarking framework for Splatter Image-based 3DGS models that achieves efficient protection and robust message extraction, with careful imperceptibility control via uncertainty-aware perceptual heatmaps and a dense segmentation-based decoder.

title: Context-Action Embedding Learning for Off-Policy Evaluation in Contextual Bandits
summary:
We consider off-policy evaluation (OPE) in contextual bandits with finite
action space. Inverse Propensity Score (IPS) weighting is a widely used method
for OPE due to its unbiased, but it suffers from significant variance when the
action space is large or when some parts of the context-action space are
underexplored. Recently introduced Marginalized IPS (MIPS) estimators mitigate
this issue by leveraging action embeddings. However, these embeddings do not
minimize the mean squared error (MSE) of the estimators and do not consider
context information. To address these limitations, we introduce Context-Action
Embedding Learning for MIPS, or CAEL-MIPS, which learns context-action
embeddings from offline data to minimize the MSE of the MIPS estimator.
Building on the theoretical analysis of bias and variance of MIPS, we present
an MSE-minimizing objective for CAEL-MIPS. In the empirical studies on a
synthetic dataset and a real-world dataset, we demonstrate that our estimator
outperforms baselines in terms of MSE.

AI.tldr: Proposes CAEL-MIPS to learn context–action embeddings that minimize MSE of the MIPS estimator for off-policy evaluation in contextual bandits, outperforming baselines on synthetic and real data.
AI.motivation: IPS provides unbiased OPE but has high variance in large or underexplored action spaces; MIPS reduces variance with action embeddings but ignores context and does not minimize MSE. There is a need to jointly optimize context-action representations to minimize MSE.
AI.method: Introduce CAEL-MIPS, an objective to learn context-action embeddings from offline data by minimizing the MSE of the MIPS estimator; builds on bias-variance analysis of MIPS to derive an MSE-minimizing objective and shows how embeddings are learned.
AI.result: Empirical studies on synthetic and real-world datasets show CAEL-MIPS achieves lower MSE than baselines, indicating improved OPE performance.
AI.conclusion: Context-action embedding learning tailored to MIPS can reduce estimator MSE in off-policy evaluation for contextual bandits and is effective in practice, particularly for large or underexplored action spaces.

title: How Real Is AI Tutoring? Comparing Simulated and Human Dialogues in One-on-One Instruction
comment:
Proceedings of the 33rd International Conference on Computers in
  Education (ICCE 2025). Asia-Pacific Society for Computers in Education
summary:
Heuristic and scaffolded teacher-student dialogues are widely regarded as
critical for fostering students' higher-order thinking and deep learning.
However, large language models (LLMs) currently face challenges in generating
pedagogically rich interactions. This study systematically investigates the
structural and behavioral differences between AI-simulated and authentic human
tutoring dialogues. We conducted a quantitative comparison using an
Initiation-Response-Feedback (IRF) coding scheme and Epistemic Network Analysis
(ENA). The results show that human dialogues are significantly superior to
their AI counterparts in utterance length, as well as in questioning (I-Q) and
general feedback (F-F) behaviors. More importantly, ENA results reveal a
fundamental divergence in interactional patterns: human dialogues are more
cognitively guided and diverse, centered around a "question-factual
response-feedback" teaching loop that clearly reflects pedagogical guidance and
student-driven thinking; in contrast, simulated dialogues exhibit a pattern of
structural simplification and behavioral convergence, revolving around an
"explanation-simplistic response" loop that is essentially a simple information
transfer between the teacher and student. These findings illuminate key
limitations in current AI-generated tutoring and provide empirical guidance for
designing and evaluating more pedagogically effective generative educational
dialogue systems.

AI.tldr: Human tutoring dialogues superior to AI in length, questioning, and general feedback, with cognitively rich, diverse interaction patterns centered on a question–factual response–feedback loop; AI shows a simplified, information-transfer loop.
AI.motivation: To understand how AI-simulated tutoring dialogues differ from authentic human tutoring, in order to diagnose limitations of current LLM-based tutors and guide the design of more pedagogically effective AI tutoring systems.
AI.method: Quantitative analysis using Initiation-Response-Feedback (IRF) coding and Epistemic Network Analysis (ENA); comparison of human vs AI dialogues on metrics such as utterance length, initiation-question (I-Q), and general feedback (F-F) behaviors.
AI.result: Humans produced longer, more varied dialogues with richer questioning and feedback. ENA reveals a divergent interaction pattern: humans follow a "question–factual response–feedback" loop reflecting pedagogical guidance and student thinking, whereas AI dialogues follow an "explanation–simplistic response" loop indicative of basic information transfer and convergence.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights current limitations of AI-generated tutoring and offers empirical guidance for designing and evaluating more pedagogically effective generative educational dialogue systems.

title: MIRAGE: Multimodal Intention Recognition and Admittance-Guided Enhancement in VR-based Multi-object Teleoperation
summary:
Effective human-robot interaction (HRI) in multi-object teleoperation tasks
faces significant challenges due to perceptual ambiguities in virtual reality
(VR) environments and the limitations of single-modality intention recognition.
This paper proposes a shared control framework that combines a virtual
admittance (VA) model with a Multimodal-CNN-based Human Intention Perception
Network (MMIPN) to enhance teleoperation performance and user experience. The
VA model employs artificial potential fields to guide operators toward target
objects by adjusting admittance force and optimizing motion trajectories. MMIPN
processes multimodal inputs, including gaze movement, robot motions, and
environmental context, to estimate human grasping intentions, helping to
overcome depth perception challenges in VR. Our user study evaluated four
conditions across two factors, and the results showed that MMIPN significantly
improved grasp success rates, while the VA model enhanced movement efficiency
by reducing path lengths. Gaze data emerged as the most crucial input modality.
These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of combining multimodal cues with
implicit guidance in VR-based teleoperation, providing a robust solution for
multi-object grasping tasks and enabling more natural interactions across
various applications in the future.

AI.tldr: A multimodal shared-control framework (Virtual Admittance + MMIPN) enhances VR-based multi-object teleoperation by improving grasp success (MMIPN) and movement efficiency (VA), with gaze as the key modality.
AI.motivation: To address perceptual ambiguities in VR and the limits of single-modality intention recognition in multi-object grasping tasks, enabling more natural and robust human-robot interaction.
AI.method: Propose a shared control framework combining a Virtual Admittance (VA) model using artificial potential fields to guide operators and an MMIPN (Multimodal-CNN-based Human Intention Perception Network) that fuses gaze, robot motions, and environmental context to infer grasping intentions. A user study with four conditions across two factors evaluated grasp success and path length, highlighting modality importance.
AI.result: MMIPN significantly improved grasp success rates; VA improved movement efficiency by shortening path lengths; gaze data emerged as the most crucial input modality.
AI.conclusion: Integrating multimodal cues with implicit guidance yields a robust VR-based teleoperation solution for multi-object grasping, enabling more natural interactions and broader applicability across future HRI tasks.

title: No More Sibling Rivalry: Debiasing Human-Object Interaction Detection
summary:
Detection transformers have been applied to human-object interaction (HOI)
detection, enhancing the localization and recognition of human-action-object
triplets in images. Despite remarkable progress, this study identifies a
critical issue-"Toxic Siblings" bias-which hinders the interaction decoder's
learning, as numerous similar yet distinct HOI triplets interfere with and even
compete against each other both input side and output side to the interaction
decoder. This bias arises from high confusion among sibling
triplets/categories, where increased similarity paradoxically reduces
precision, as one's gain comes at the expense of its toxic sibling's decline.
To address this, we propose two novel debiasing learning
objectives-"contrastive-then-calibration" and "merge-then-split"-targeting the
input and output perspectives, respectively. The former samples sibling-like
incorrect HOI triplets and reconstructs them into correct ones, guided by
strong positional priors. The latter first learns shared features among sibling
categories to distinguish them from other groups, then explicitly refines
intra-group differentiation to preserve uniqueness. Experiments show that we
significantly outperform both the baseline (+9.18% mAP on HICO-Det) and the
state-of-the-art (+3.59% mAP) across various settings.

AI.tldr: Proposes debiasing methods to mitigate Toxic Siblings bias in detection transformers for HOI; introduces contrastive-then-calibration and merge-then-split objectives to improve input and output learning, achieving significant mAP gains on HICO-Det.
AI.motivation: High confusion among similar HOI triplets (sibling categories) causes interference and degraded precision; existing models struggle due to bias across input and output sides of interaction decoder.
AI.method: Two objectives: (1) contrastive-then-calibration: sample sibling-like incorrect HOI triplets and reconstruct correct ones using positional priors; (2) merge-then-split: learn shared features among sibling categories, then refine intra-group differentiation to preserve uniqueness.
AI.result: Significant improvements: +9.18% mAP on HICO-Det over baseline, +3.59% mAP over SOTA across settings.
AI.conclusion: Debiasing objectives effectively address Toxic Siblings bias, enabling better HOI detection with transformers.

title: Missing Data Imputation using Neural Cellular Automata
summary:
When working with tabular data, missingness is always one of the most painful
problems. Throughout many years, researchers have continuously explored better
and better ways to impute missing data. Recently, with the rapid development
evolution in machine learning and deep learning, there is a new trend of
leveraging generative models to solve the imputation task. While the imputing
version of famous models such as Variational Autoencoders or Generative
Adversarial Networks were investigated, prior work has overlooked Neural
Cellular Automata (NCA), a powerful computational model. In this paper, we
propose a novel imputation method that is inspired by NCA. We show that, with
some appropriate adaptations, an NCA-based model is able to address the missing
data imputation problem. We also provide several experiments to evidence that
our model outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of imputation error and
post-imputation performance.

AI.tldr: An NCA-inspired imputation method for tabular missing data that shows competitive performance against state-of-the-art approaches.
AI.motivation: Missing values in tabular data pose a long-standing challenge; while VAEs/GANs have been explored for imputation, Neural Cellular Automata (NCA) have been overlooked, despite potential modeling advantages.
AI.method: Adapt and apply an NCA-based model for imputing missing data, with suitable adaptations; train and evaluate on datasets with missingness; compare against existing imputation methods to assess imputation error and downstream task performance.
AI.result: Experiments indicate the proposed NCA-based imputation method outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both imputation error and post-imputation performance.
AI.conclusion: NCA-based imputation is a viable and competitive approach for missing data in tabular datasets, offering a novel direction beyond traditional generative models.

title: Dynamic Speculative Agent Planning
summary:
Despite their remarkable success in complex tasks propelling widespread
adoption, large language-model-based agents still face critical deployment
challenges due to prohibitive latency and inference costs. While recent work
has explored various methods to accelerate inference, existing approaches
suffer from significant limitations: they either fail to preserve performance
fidelity, require extensive offline training of router modules, or incur
excessive operational costs. Moreover, they provide minimal user control over
the tradeoff between acceleration and other performance metrics. To address
these gaps, we introduce Dynamic Speculative Planning (DSP), an asynchronous
online reinforcement learning framework that provides lossless acceleration
with substantially reduced costs without requiring additional pre-deployment
preparation. DSP explicitly optimizes a joint objective balancing end-to-end
latency against dollar cost, allowing practitioners to adjust a single
parameter that steers the system toward faster responses, cheaper operation, or
any point along this continuum. Experiments on two standard agent benchmarks
demonstrate that DSP achieves comparable efficiency to the fastest lossless
acceleration method while reducing total cost by 30% and unnecessary cost up to
60%. Our code and data are available through
https://github.com/guanyilin428/Dynamic-Speculative-Planning.

AI.tldr: Dynamic Speculative Planning (DSP) is an asynchronous online reinforcement learning framework that achieves lossless acceleration for large-language-model–based agents by jointly optimizing end-to-end latency and dollar cost. It introduces a single tunable parameter to steer the tradeoff among faster responses, cheaper operation, or intermediate points. On two standard agent benchmarks, DSP matches the efficiency of the fastest lossless acceleration method while reducing total cost by about 30% and unnecessary costs by up to 60%.
AI.motivation: Reduce latency and inference costs of LLM-based agents without sacrificing performance fidelity, and without requiring extensive preprocessing or offline training of router modules, while giving practitioners simple control over the speed–cost tradeoff.
AI.method: Propose Dynamic Speculative Planning (DSP), an asynchronous online reinforcement learning framework that optimizes a joint objective over end-to-end latency and dollar cost. It requires no additional pre-deployment preparation and provides a single tunable parameter to guide the system toward faster responses, cheaper operation, or any intermediate point.
AI.result: DSP achieves comparable efficiency to the fastest lossless acceleration method while lowering total cost by ~30% and reducing unnecessary cost by up to 60% on two standard agent benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: DSP offers a practical, controllable path to lossless acceleration for LLM-driven agents, delivering speed–cost tradeoffs without performance loss and with open-source code and data.

title: Generalizing Unsupervised Lidar Odometry Model from Normal to Snowy Weather Conditions
summary:
Deep learning-based LiDAR odometry is crucial for autonomous driving and
robotic navigation, yet its performance under adverse weather, especially
snowfall, remains challenging. Existing models struggle to generalize across
conditions due to sensitivity to snow-induced noise, limiting real-world use.
In this work, we present an unsupervised LiDAR odometry model to close the gap
between clear and snowy weather conditions. Our approach focuses on effective
denoising to mitigate the impact of snowflake noise and outlier points on pose
estimation, while also maintaining computational efficiency for real-time
applications.
  To achieve this, we introduce a Patch Spatial Measure (PSM) module that
evaluates the dispersion of points within each patch, enabling effective
detection of sparse and discrete noise.
  We further propose a Patch Point Weight Predictor (PPWP) to assign adaptive
point-wise weights, enhancing their discriminative capacity within local
regions. To support real-time performance, we first apply an intensity
threshold mask to quickly suppress dense snowflake clusters near the LiDAR, and
then perform multi-modal feature fusion to refine the point-wise weight
prediction, improving overall robustness under adverse weather. Our model is
trained in clear weather conditions and rigorously tested across various
scenarios, including snowy and dynamic. Extensive experimental results confirm
the effectiveness of our method, demonstrating robust performance in both clear
and snowy weather. This advancement enhances the model's generalizability and
paves the way for more reliable autonomous systems capable of operating across
a wider range of environmental conditions.

AI.tldr: Unsupervised LiDAR odometry robust to snow through patch-level denoising and adaptive point weighting for real-time performance.
AI.motivation: LiDAR odometry performance degrades in snowfall due to snowflake noise and outliers; need a generalizable, real-time method that works across clear and snowy conditions.
AI.method: Introduce Patch Spatial Measure (PSM) to detect dispersed noise in patches, and Patch Point Weight Predictor (PPWP) to assign adaptive weights to points. Use an intensity threshold mask to quickly suppress dense snow near the sensor, followed by multi-modal feature fusion to refine weights.
AI.result: Demonstrates robust odometry performance in both clear and snowy weather, with improved generalization and real-time applicability due to efficient denoising and weighted point processing.
AI.conclusion: The proposed patch-based denoising and adaptive weighting framework closes the gap between clear-weather and snowy scenarios, enabling more reliable autonomous systems across diverse environments.

title: InterPose: Learning to Generate Human-Object Interactions from Large-Scale Web Videos
summary:
Human motion generation has shown great advances thanks to the recent
diffusion models trained on large-scale motion capture data. Most of existing
works, however, currently target animation of isolated people in empty scenes.
Meanwhile, synthesizing realistic human-object interactions in complex 3D
scenes remains a critical challenge in computer graphics and robotics. One
obstacle towards generating versatile high-fidelity human-object interactions
is the lack of large-scale datasets with diverse object manipulations. Indeed,
existing motion capture data is typically restricted to single people and
manipulations of limited sets of objects. To address this issue, we propose an
automatic motion extraction pipeline and use it to collect interaction-rich
human motions. Our new dataset InterPose contains 73.8K sequences of 3D human
motions and corresponding text captions automatically obtained from 45.8K
videos with human-object interactions. We perform extensive experiments and
demonstrate InterPose to bring significant improvements to state-of-the-art
methods for human motion generation. Moreover, using InterPose we develop an
LLM-based agent enabling zero-shot animation of people interacting with diverse
objects and scenes.

AI.tldr: A new dataset InterPose with 73.8k sequences of 3D human motions and text captions is automatically extracted from 45.8k videos featuring human-object interactions to enable versatile high-fidelity motion generation and zero-shot animation with an LLM-based agent.
AI.motivation: There is a lack of large-scale, diverse datasets of human-object interactions for training and evaluating 3D motion generation models, hindering realistic animation in complex scenes.
AI.method: An automatic motion extraction pipeline is used to collect interaction-rich human motions and captions from videos, constructing the InterPose dataset; extensive experiments show improvements to state-of-the-art motion generation; an LLM-based agent enables zero-shot animation of people interacting with diverse objects/scenes.
AI.result: InterPose significantly improves state-of-the-art motion generation methods; enables zero-shot animation capabilities via an LLM-based agent for varied objects and scenes.
AI.conclusion: The dataset fills a critical data gap for human-object interactions, enabling scalable, high-fidelity motion generation and interactive animation in diverse environments, with practical use in graphics and robotics.

title: IndiaWeatherBench: A Dataset and Benchmark for Data-Driven Regional Weather Forecasting over India
summary:
Regional weather forecasting is a critical problem for localized climate
adaptation, disaster mitigation, and sustainable development. While machine
learning has shown impressive progress in global weather forecasting, regional
forecasting remains comparatively underexplored. Existing efforts often use
different datasets and experimental setups, limiting fair comparison and
reproducibility. We introduce IndiaWeatherBench, a comprehensive benchmark for
data-driven regional weather forecasting focused on the Indian subcontinent.
IndiaWeatherBench provides a curated dataset built from high-resolution
regional reanalysis products, along with a suite of deterministic and
probabilistic metrics to facilitate consistent training and evaluation. To
establish strong baselines, we implement and evaluate a range of models across
diverse architectures, including UNets, Transformers, and Graph-based networks,
as well as different boundary conditioning strategies and training objectives.
While focused on India, IndiaWeatherBench is easily extensible to other
geographic regions. We open-source all raw and preprocessed datasets, model
implementations, and evaluation pipelines to promote accessibility and future
development. We hope IndiaWeatherBench will serve as a foundation for advancing
regional weather forecasting research. Code is available at
https://github.com/tung-nd/IndiaWeatherBench.

AI.tldr: IndiaWeatherBench introduces a regional weather forecasting benchmark for the Indian subcontinent, providing a curated high-resolution dataset, standardized metrics, diverse model baselines, and open-source tools to improve reproducibility and fair comparison in regional forecasting.
AI.motivation: Regional forecasting lags global models and lacks standardized datasets/metrics, hindering fair comparisons and reproducibility. The work aims to accelerate development for India’s localized climate adaptation and disaster mitigation.
AI.method: Assemble a curated dataset from high-resolution regional reanalysis for India; define deterministic and probabilistic evaluation metrics; implement and evaluate diverse baselines (UNets, Transformers, Graph networks) with various boundary-conditioning strategies and training objectives; release datasets, code, and evaluation pipelines.
AI.result: Established a benchmark with strong baselines across architectures, demonstrated feasibility of standardized evaluation, and provided open-source resources (data, models, pipelines) for reproducibility and regional forecasting research in India and beyond.
AI.conclusion: IndiaWeatherBench provides a reusable foundation for regional weather forecasting research, enabling fair comparisons and extensibility to other regions through open data and tools.

title: EigenBench: A Comparative Behavioral Measure of Value Alignment
summary:
Aligning AI with human values is a pressing unsolved problem. To address the
lack of quantitative metrics for value alignment, we propose EigenBench: a
black-box method for comparatively benchmarking language models' values. Given
an ensemble of models, a constitution describing a value system, and a dataset
of scenarios, our method returns a vector of scores quantifying each model's
alignment to the given constitution. To produce these scores, each model judges
the outputs of other models across many scenarios, and these judgments are
aggregated with EigenTrust (Kamvar et al, 2003), yielding scores that reflect a
weighted-average judgment of the whole ensemble. EigenBench uses no ground
truth labels, as it is designed to quantify traits for which reasonable judges
may disagree on the correct label. Using prompted personas, we test whether
EigenBench scores are more sensitive to the model or the prompt: we find that
most of the variance is explained by the prompt, but a small residual
quantifies the disposition of the model itself.

AI.tldr: A black-box benchmarking method (EigenBench) to quantify language models' alignment to a given value constitution using peer judgments and EigenTrust, without ground-truth labels.
AI.motivation: There is a lack of quantitative metrics for value alignment; a need for objective, label-free comparison of how well models adhere to specified values across scenarios and prompts.
AI.method: Using an ensemble of models, a supplied constitution, and scenario data, each model judges outputs of other models. Aggregated via EigenTrust to yield model-alignment scores relative to the constitution. No ground-truth labels are required. The study also uses prompted personas to assess whether scores are more sensitive to the model or to the prompt.
AI.result: EigenBench outputs a vector of alignment scores; most observed variance is explained by the prompt, with a smaller residual attributable to the model disposition.
AI.conclusion: EigenBench provides a practical, ground-truth-free metric for comparing model alignment to a specified value system and for studying how prompts influence measured alignment, while enabling decomposition of prompt-driven vs model-driven variance.

title: Align-Then-stEer: Adapting the Vision-Language Action Models through Unified Latent Guidance
comment: The first three authors contributed equally
summary:
Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models pre-trained on large, diverse datasets
show remarkable potential for general-purpose robotic manipulation. However, a
primary bottleneck remains in adapting these models to downstream tasks,
especially when the robot's embodiment or the task itself differs from the
pre-training data. This discrepancy leads to a significant mismatch in action
distributions, demanding extensive data and compute for effective fine-tuning.
To address this challenge, we introduce \textbf{Align-Then-stEer
(\texttt{ATE})}, a novel, data-efficient, and plug-and-play adaptation
framework. \texttt{ATE} first aligns disparate action spaces by constructing a
unified latent space, where a variational autoencoder constrained by reverse KL
divergence embeds adaptation actions into modes of the pre-training action
latent distribution. Subsequently, it steers the diffusion- or flow-based VLA's
generation process during fine-tuning via a guidance mechanism that pushes the
model's output distribution towards the target domain. We conduct extensive
experiments on cross-embodiment and cross-task manipulation in both simulation
and real world. Compared to direct fine-tuning of representative VLAs, our
method improves the average multi-task success rate by up to \textbf{9.8\%} in
simulation and achieves a striking \textbf{32\% success rate gain} in a
real-world cross-embodiment setting. Our work presents a general and
lightweight solution that greatly enhances the practicality of deploying VLA
models to new robotic platforms and tasks.

AI.tldr: A data-efficient, plug-and-play adaptation framework Align-Then-stEer (ATE) for Vision-Language-Action models that aligns heterogeneous action spaces via a variational autoencoder with reverse KL, then guides the model during fine-tuning to the target domain; yields improved cross-embodiment and cross-task performance.
AI.motivation: VLA models pretrained on large, diverse data show strong potential, but adapting them to downstream tasks with different robot embodiments or tasks causes action-distribution mismatch that requires large data and compute for fine-tuning.
AI.method: 1) Align action spaces by constructing a unified latent space using a variational autoencoder constrained by reverse KL divergence to embed adaptation actions into modes of the pre-training action latent distribution. 2) During fine-tuning, steer (guide) diffusion- or flow-based VLA generation toward the target domain by a guidance mechanism that shifts output distributions.
AI.result: Experiments in cross-embodiment and cross-task manipulation show substantial gains: up to 9.8% average multi-task success rate improvement in simulation, and a 32% real-world success rate gain in cross-embodiment settings, compared to direct fine-tuning of representative VLAs.
AI.conclusion: ATE provides a general, lightweight, plug-and-play solution that significantly improves the practicality of deploying VLA models to new robotic platforms and tasks.

title: Secure and Scalable Face Retrieval via Cancelable Product Quantization
comment: 14 pages and 2 figures, accepted by PRCV2025
summary:
Despite the ubiquity of modern face retrieval systems, their retrieval stage
is often outsourced to third-party entities, posing significant risks to user
portrait privacy. Although homomorphic encryption (HE) offers strong security
guarantees by enabling arithmetic computations in the cipher space, its high
computational inefficiency makes it unsuitable for real-time, real-world
applications. To address this issue, we propose Cancelable Product
Quantization, a highly efficient framework for secure face representation
retrieval. Our hierarchical two-stage framework comprises: (i) a
high-throughput cancelable PQ indexing module for fast candidate filtering, and
(ii) a fine-grained cipher-space retrieval module for final precise face
ranking. A tailored protection mechanism is designed to secure the indexing
module for cancelable biometric authentication while ensuring efficiency.
Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method achieves an
decent balance between effectiveness, efficiency and security.

AI.tldr: Proposes Cancelable Product Quantization (CPQ), a two-stage secure face retrieval framework that combines fast, cancelable PQ indexing with a fine-grained cipher-space ranking to balance privacy, efficiency, and accuracy.
AI.motivation: Outsourcing face retrieval raises portrait privacy risks. Homomorphic encryption (HE) offers security but is too slow for real-time use; there is a need for efficient, secure retrieval approaches.
AI.method: A hierarchical two-stage framework: (i) a high-throughput cancelable PQ indexing module for fast candidate filtering; (ii) a fine-grained cipher-space retrieval module for precise ranking. Includes a tailored protection mechanism to secure the indexing module for cancelable biometric authentication while maintaining efficiency.
AI.result: Experiments on benchmark datasets show a decent balance between effectiveness, efficiency, and security, indicating practical viability.
AI.conclusion: The CPQ framework provides an efficient, privacy-preserving solution for face retrieval, achieving favorable trade-offs and potential applicability in real-world systems.

title: An Evolutionary Multi-objective Optimization for Replica-Exchange-based Physics-informed Operator Learning Network
summary:
In this paper, we propose an evolutionary Multi-objective Optimization for
Replica-Exchange-based Physics-informed Operator learning Network, which is a
novel operator learning network to efficiently solve parametric partial
differential equations. In forward and inverse settings, this operator learning
network only admits minimum requirement of noisy observational data. While
physics-informed neural networks and operator learning approaches such as Deep
Operator Networks and Fourier Neural Operators offer promising alternatives to
traditional numerical solvers, they struggle with balancing operator and
physics losses, maintaining robustness under noisy or sparse data, and
providing uncertainty quantification. The proposed framework addresses these
limitations by integrating: (i) evolutionary multi-objective optimization to
adaptively balance operator and physics-based losses in the Pareto front; (ii)
replica exchange stochastic gradient Langevin dynamics to improve global
parameter-space exploration and accelerate convergence; and (iii) built-in
Bayesian uncertainty quantification from stochastic sampling. The proposed
operator learning method is tested numerically on several different problems
including one-dimensional Burgers equation and the time-fractional mixed
diffusion-wave equation. The results indicate that our framework consistently
outperforms the general operator learning methods in accuracy, noise
robustness, and the ability to quantify uncertainty.

AI.tldr: Proposes an evolutionary multi-objective optimization framework for a Replica-Exchange-based Physics-informed Operator Learning Network to solve parametric PDEs, achieving higher accuracy, noise robustness, and Bayesian uncertainty quantification, with experiments on Burgers and a time-fractional diffusion–wave equation.
AI.motivation: Address core limitations of physics-informed neural networks and operator learning methods: difficulty balancing operator and physics losses, sensitivity to noisy or sparse data, and lack of reliable uncertainty quantification; aim to enable accurate forward/inverse solvers with minimal data.
AI.method: Integrates three components: (1) evolutionary multi-objective optimization to adaptively balance operator and physics losses along the Pareto front; (2) replica-exchange stochastic gradient Langevin dynamics to enhance global exploration and accelerate convergence; (3) built-in Bayesian uncertainty quantification via stochastic sampling.
AI.result: The framework consistently outperforms standard operator learning methods in accuracy, robustness to noise, and capability to quantify uncertainty across tested problems.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach effectively tackles loss-balance, robustness, and uncertainty quantification challenges in operator learning for parametric PDEs, offering improved forward/inverse solutions with limited data.

title: mFARM: Towards Multi-Faceted Fairness Assessment based on HARMs in Clinical Decision Support
summary:
The deployment of Large Language Models (LLMs) in high-stakes medical
settings poses a critical AI alignment challenge, as models can inherit and
amplify societal biases, leading to significant disparities. Existing fairness
evaluation methods fall short in these contexts as they typically use
simplistic metrics that overlook the multi-dimensional nature of medical harms.
This also promotes models that are fair only because they are clinically inert,
defaulting to safe but potentially inaccurate outputs. To address this gap, our
contributions are mainly two-fold: first, we construct two large-scale,
controlled benchmarks (ED-Triage and Opioid Analgesic Recommendation) from
MIMIC-IV, comprising over 50,000 prompts with twelve race x gender variants and
three context tiers. Second, we propose a multi-metric framework -
Multi-faceted Fairness Assessment based on hARMs ($mFARM$) to audit fairness
for three distinct dimensions of disparity (Allocational, Stability, and
Latent) and aggregate them into an $mFARM$ score. We also present an aggregated
Fairness-Accuracy Balance (FAB) score to benchmark and observe trade-offs
between fairness and prediction accuracy. We empirically evaluate four
open-source LLMs (Mistral-7B, BioMistral-7B, Qwen-2.5-7B, Bio-LLaMA3-8B) and
their finetuned versions under quantization and context variations. Our
findings showcase that the proposed $mFARM$ metrics capture subtle biases more
effectively under various settings. We find that most models maintain robust
performance in terms of $mFARM$ score across varying levels of quantization but
deteriorate significantly when the context is reduced. Our benchmarks and
evaluation code are publicly released to enhance research in aligned AI for
healthcare.

AI.tldr: Introduces two large, controlled MIMIC-IV–based benchmarks (ED-Triage and Opioid Analgesic Recommendation) with 50k prompts across 12 race×gender variants and 3 context tiers, and a multi-metric fairness framework (mFARM) plus FAB score to evaluate fairness–accuracy trade-offs in healthcare LLMs; empirically shows mFARM detects biases more effectively, with context sensitivity affecting fairness, and releases benchmarks/code.
AI.motivation: High-stakes medical AI can inherit societal biases; existing fairness metrics are insufficient for multi-dimensional medical harms, risking clinically inert but inaccurate outputs. There is a need for comprehensive, interpretable fairness auditing in healthcare LLMs.
AI.method: Construct two large-scale benchmarks from MIMIC-IV (ED-Triage and Opioid Analgesic Recommendation) with over 50k prompts across 12 race×gender variants and 3 context tiers. Propose Multi-faceted Fairness Assessment based on hARMs (mFARM) to audit three disparity dimensions—Allocational, Stability, Latent—and aggregate them into an mFARM score; introduce an aggregated Fairness-Accuracy Balance (FAB) score. Evaluate four open-source LLMs (and their finetuned/quantized variants) under varying context settings.
AI.result: mFARM metrics detect subtle biases better than traditional metrics. Most models keep robust mFARM performance across different quantization levels but degrade significantly when context is reduced. Benchmarks and evaluation code are publicly released to support research in healthcare-aligned AI.
AI.conclusion: The proposed benchmarks and the mFARM/FAB framework enable more nuanced fairness auditing in healthcare LLMs, highlighting the importance of context and multi-dimensional disparities, and providing resources to advance aligned AI in medicine.

title: A Geometric Method for Base Parameter Analysis in Robot Inertia Identification Based on Projective Geometric Algebra
summary:
This paper proposes a novel geometric method for analytically determining the
base inertial parameters of robotic systems. The rigid body dynamics is
reformulated using projective geometric algebra, leading to a new
identification model named ``tetrahedral-point (TP)" model. Based on the rigid
body TP model, coefficients in the regresoor matrix of the identification model
are derived in closed-form, exhibiting clear geometric interpretations.
Building directly from the dynamic model, three foundational principles for
base parameter analysis are proposed: the shared points principle, fixed points
principle, and planar rotations principle. With these principles, algorithms
are developed to automatically determine all the base parameters. The core
algorithm, referred to as Dynamics Regressor Nullspace Generator (DRNG),
achieves $O(1)$-complexity theoretically following an $O(N)$-complexity
preprocessing stage, where $N$ is the number of rigid bodies. The proposed
method and algorithms are validated across four robots: Puma560, Unitree Go2, a
2RRU-1RRS parallel kinematics mechanism (PKM), and a 2PRS-1PSR PKM. In all
cases, the algorithms successfully identify the complete set of base
parameters. Notably, the approach demonstrates high robustness and
computational efficiency, particularly in the cases of PKMs. Through the
comprehensive demonstrations, the method is shown to be general, robust, and
efficient.

AI.tldr: Analytical base-parameter identification for robots via a projective geometric algebra framework, introducing the tetrahedral-point model and a robust, efficient DRNG algorithm with O(1) per-regressor complexity after O(N) preprocessing; validated on multiple robots.
AI.motivation: Accurate, analytic determination of base inertial parameters is essential for precise robot dynamics and control; existing methods may be inefficient, opaque, or limited in handling complex configurations. The authors propose a geometry-driven, closed-form approach to improve robustness and speed, especially for parallel kinematic machines.
AI.method: Reform dynamics with projective geometric algebra; define tetrahedral-point (TP) model; derive regression coefficients in closed form with clear geometric meaning; propose three principles (shared points, fixed points, planar rotations) to guide base-parameter extraction; implement Dynamics Regressor Nullspace Generator (DRNG) with O(1) per-parameter complexity after an O(N) preprocessing; apply to four robots.
AI.result: Successfully identifies the complete base-parameter sets for Puma560, Unitree Go2, 2RRU-1RRS PKM, and 2PRS-1PSR PKM; demonstrates robustness and computational efficiency, particularly for PKMs.
AI.conclusion: The approach is general, robust, and efficient for analytic base-parameter identification; the TP model and DRNG provide insights and practical tools for accurate robot dynamics modeling.

title: Aligned Anchor Groups Guided Line Segment Detector
comment:
Accepted at the 8th Chinese Conference on Pattern Recognition and
  Computer Vision (PRCV 2025). 14 pages, supplementary material attached
summary:
This paper introduces a novel line segment detector, the Aligned Anchor
Groups guided Line Segment Detector (AAGLSD), designed to detect line segments
from images with high precision and completeness. The algorithm employs a
hierarchical approach to extract candidate pixels with different saliency
levels, including regular anchors and aligned anchor groups. AAGLSD initiates
from these aligned anchor groups, sequentially linking anchors and updating the
currently predicted line segment simultaneously. The final predictions are
derived through straightforward validation and merging of adjacent line
segments, avoiding complex refinement strategies. AAGLSD is evaluated on
various datasets and quantitative experiments demonstrate that the proposed
method can effectively extract complete line segments from input images
compared to other advanced line segment detectors. The implementation is
available at https://github.com/LLiDaBao/AAGLSD.

AI.tldr: AAGLSD is a hierarchical line segment detector that uses aligned anchor groups to progressively link anchors into complete line segments with simple validation and merging, achieving high precision and completeness.
AI.motivation: Existing line segment detectors often struggle to recover complete line segments with high accuracy; a detector that leverages hierarchical saliency and aligned anchor groups can improve completeness and precision without heavy refinement.
AI.method: Extract candidate pixels through a hierarchical process with regular anchors and aligned anchor groups; begin from aligned groups, sequentially link anchors while updating the current predicted line segment; finalize by validating and merging adjacent segments, avoiding complex refinement.
AI.result: Evaluations on multiple datasets show that AAGLSD effectively extracts complete line segments and outperforms or matches state-of-the-art LSD methods; code is available at the provided GitHub URL.
AI.conclusion: AAGLSD provides an efficient, accurate line segment detection framework that achieves high completeness with simple post-processing and without heavy refinement, supported by public code.

title: Valid Property-Enhanced Contrastive Learning for Targeted Optimization & Resampling for Novel Drug Design
summary:
Efficiently steering generative models toward pharmacologically relevant
regions of chemical space remains a major obstacle in molecular drug discovery
under low-data regimes. We present VECTOR+: Valid-property-Enhanced Contrastive
Learning for Targeted Optimization and Resampling, a framework that couples
property-guided representation learning with controllable molecule generation.
VECTOR+ applies to both regression and classification tasks and enables
interpretable, data-efficient exploration of functional chemical space. We
evaluate on two datasets: a curated PD-L1 inhibitor set (296 compounds with
experimental $IC_{50}$ values) and a receptor kinase inhibitor set (2,056
molecules by binding mode). Despite limited training data, VECTOR+ generates
novel, synthetically tractable candidates. Against PD-L1 (PDB 5J89), 100 of
8,374 generated molecules surpass a docking threshold of $-15.0$ kcal/mol, with
the best scoring $-17.6$ kcal/mol compared to the top reference inhibitor
($-15.4$ kcal/mol). The best-performing molecules retain the conserved biphenyl
pharmacophore while introducing novel motifs. Molecular dynamics (250 ns)
confirm binding stability (ligand RMSD < $2.5$ angstroms). VECTOR+ generalizes
to kinase inhibitors, producing compounds with stronger docking scores than
established drugs such as brigatinib and sorafenib. Benchmarking against JT-VAE
and MolGPT across docking, novelty, uniqueness, and Tanimoto similarity
highlights the superior performance of our method. These results position our
work as a robust, extensible approach for property-conditioned molecular design
in low-data settings, bridging contrastive learning and generative modeling for
reproducible, AI-accelerated discovery.

AI.tldr: VECTOR+ is a property-guided, contrastive-learning–driven framework for targeted molecular optimization under low data, achieving novel, synthetically tractable ligands with strong docking and MD stability, outperforming JT-VAE and MolGPT on PD-L1 and kinase targets.
AI.motivation: Overcome data scarcity in drug discovery to steer generative models toward pharmacologically relevant chemical space; provide interpretable, data-efficient exploration of functional space.
AI.method: Integrates property-guided representation learning (contrastive) with controllable molecule generation; applicable to regression/classification; evaluates on PD-L1 inhibitor set (296 IC50 values) and kinase inhibitor set (2,056 molecules by binding mode); benchmarks docking; uses MD validation; compares to JT-VAE and MolGPT.
AI.result: Generates 8,374 candidates; 100 exceed docking threshold of -15.0 kcal/mol; best at -17.6 kcal/mol vs top reference -15.4; preserves biphenyl pharmacophore with novel motifs; MD 250 ns shows ligand RMSD < 2.5 Å; generalizes to kinase inhibitors with stronger docking than brigatinib/sorafenib; outperforms JT-VAE and MolGPT on docking, novelty, uniqueness, Tanimoto similarity.
AI.conclusion: VECTOR+ is a robust, extensible approach for property-conditioned molecular design in low-data settings, linking contrastive learning and generative modeling for reproducible AI-accelerated discovery; adaptable to broader pharmacological targets.

title: Generative KI für TA
comment: Written in German. To appear in Proceedings of NTA11 2025
summary:
Many scientists use generative AI in their scientific work. People working in
technology assessment (TA) are no exception. TA's approach to generative AI is
twofold: on the one hand, generative AI is used for TA work, and on the other
hand, generative AI is the subject of TA research. After briefly outlining the
phenomenon of generative AI and formulating requirements for its use in TA, the
following article discusses in detail the structural causes of the problems
associated with it. Although generative AI is constantly being further
developed, the structurally induced risks remain. The article concludes with
proposed solutions and brief notes on their feasibility, as well as some
examples of the use of generative AI in TA work.

AI.tldr: Generative AI is both a tool and a subject of technology assessment (TA); the article identifies structurally rooted risks that persist as AI evolves, outlines TA-use requirements, proposes feasibility-aware solutions, and provides usage examples in TA.
AI.motivation: To understand how generative AI affects TA practice and research, guiding safe and effective integration by identifying structural risk factors and proposing mitigations.
AI.method: Conceptual/analytic paper that (1) analyzes structural causes of AI-related problems in TA, (2) formulates requirements for using AI in TA, (3) discusses proposed solutions with feasibility considerations, and (4) presents examples of AI use in TA.
AI.result: Locks in the persistence of structurally induced risks despite ongoing AI development; offers a set of solutions with notes on feasibility and illustrates such usage with TA examples.
AI.conclusion: Structural risks associated with generative AI persist; addressing them requires the proposed measures and ongoing TA research/practice to balance benefits with governance and reliability concerns.

title: Learning Social Heuristics for Human-Aware Path Planning
summary:
Social robotic navigation has been at the center of numerous studies in
recent years. Most of the research has focused on driving the robotic agent
along obstacle-free trajectories, respecting social distances from humans, and
predicting their movements to optimize navigation. However, in order to really
be socially accepted, the robots must be able to attain certain social norms
that cannot arise from conventional navigation, but require a dedicated
learning process. We propose Heuristic Planning with Learned Social Value
(HPLSV), a method to learn a value function encapsulating the cost of social
navigation, and use it as an additional heuristic in heuristic-search path
planning. In this preliminary work, we apply the methodology to the common
social scenario of joining a queue of people, with the intention of
generalizing to further human activities.

AI.tldr: A framework to learn a social-valued heuristic for navigation (HPLSV) and apply it to queue-joining; aims to generalize social norms beyond standard obstacle avoidance.
AI.motivation: Robots must exhibit socially acceptable behavior that standard navigation cannot guarantee; social norms need to be learned and encoded as costs.
AI.method: Learn a value function capturing the cost of socially compliant navigation and use it as an auxiliary heuristic in heuristic-search path planning; demonstrated in the common scenario of joining a queue.
AI.result: Preliminary work with an initial demonstration; no extensive empirical results reported.
AI.conclusion: Suggests that learning social costs as part of planning can improve social acceptance; future work to broaden scenarios and evaluate performance.

title: Diffusion-Based Image-to-Brain Signal Generation with Cross-Attention Mechanisms for Visual Prostheses
summary:
Visual prostheses have shown great potential in restoring vision for blind
individuals. On the one hand, researchers have been continuously improving the
brain decoding framework of visual prostheses by leveraging the powerful image
generation capabilities of diffusion models. On the other hand, the brain
encoding stage of visual prostheses struggles to generate brain signals with
sufficient biological similarity. Although existing works have recognized this
problem, the quality of predicted stimuli still remains a critical issue, as
existing approaches typically lack supervised signals from real brain responses
to validate the biological plausibility of predicted stimuli. To address this
issue, we propose a novel image-to-brain framework based on denoising diffusion
probabilistic models (DDPMs) enhanced with cross-attention mechanisms. Our
framework consists of two key architectural components: a pre-trained CLIP
visual encoder that extracts rich semantic representations from input images,
and a cross-attention enhanced U-Net diffusion model that learns to reconstruct
biologically plausible brain signals through iterative denoising. Unlike
conventional generative models that rely on simple concatenation for
conditioning, our cross-attention modules enable dynamic interaction between
visual features and brain signal representations, facilitating fine-grained
alignment during the generation process. We evaluate our framework on two
multimodal datasets (THINGS-EEG2 and THINGS-MEG) to demonstrate its
effectiveness in generating biologically plausible brain signals. Moreover, we
visualize the training and test M/EEG topographies for all subjects on both
datasets to intuitively demonstrate the intra-subject variations and
inter-subject variations in M/EEG signals.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-based image-to-brain framework with cross-attention, conditioning a DDPM using CLIP-derived visual features to generate biologically plausible brain signals, evaluated on THINGS-EEG2 and THINGS-MEG with subject-wise topography analyses.
AI.motivation: Despite advances in visual prostheses, brain encoding often yields brain signals lacking biological plausibility; there's a need for supervised signals from real brain responses to validate and improve stimulus generation.
AI.method: Two-stage architecture: a pre-trained CLIP visual encoder extracts semantic features from input images; a cross-attention enhanced U-Net diffusion model learns to reconstruct brain signals through iterative denoising, with cross-attention enabling dynamic interaction between visual features and brain representations; training on two multimodal datasets (THINGS-EEG2, THINGS-MEG).
AI.result: The approach yields biologically plausible brain signals and captures intra- and inter-subject variability, with visualizations of training/test M/EEG topographies demonstrating alignment with expected patterns.
AI.conclusion: Cross-attention diffusion with CLIP conditioning improves brain encoding for visual prostheses by producing more biologically plausible brain signals and enabling interpretable, subject-aware topographical analyses; it addresses supervised signal limitations and shows promise for enhancing brain-initiated prosthetic decoding.

title: DELTA: Variational Disentangled Learning for Privacy-Preserving Data Reprogramming
comment:
10 pages, 5 figures, 3 Tables. Accepted at IEEE International
  Conference on Data Mining (ICDM) 2025
summary:
In real-world applications, domain data often contains identifiable or
sensitive attributes, is subject to strict regulations (e.g., HIPAA, GDPR), and
requires explicit data feature engineering for interpretability and
transparency. Existing feature engineering primarily focuses on advancing
downstream task performance, often risking privacy leakage. We generalize this
learning task under such new requirements as Privacy-Preserving Data
Reprogramming (PPDR): given a dataset, transforming features to maximize target
attribute prediction accuracy while minimizing sensitive attribute prediction
accuracy. PPDR poses challenges for existing systems: 1) generating
high-utility feature transformations without being overwhelmed by a large
search space, and 2) disentangling and eliminating sensitive information from
utility-oriented features to reduce privacy inferability. To tackle these
challenges, we propose DELTA, a two-phase variational disentangled generative
learning framework. Phase I uses policy-guided reinforcement learning to
discover feature transformations with downstream task utility, without any
regard to privacy inferability. Phase II employs a variational LSTM seq2seq
encoder-decoder with a utility-privacy disentangled latent space design and
adversarial-causal disentanglement regularization to suppress privacy signals
during feature generation. Experiments on eight datasets show DELTA improves
predictive performance by ~9.3% and reduces privacy leakage by ~35%,
demonstrating robust, privacy-aware data transformation.

AI.tldr: A two-phase framework (DELTA) for privacy-preserving feature reprogramming that boosts task accuracy while reducing leakage of sensitive information.
AI.motivation: Real-world data often contain identifiable or sensitive attributes and are subject to privacy regulations. Traditional feature engineering focuses on utility and can leak private information, necessitating methods that balance performance with privacy.
AI.method: Phase I uses policy-guided reinforcement learning to discover feature transformations that maximize downstream utility without considering privacy. Phase II uses a variational LSTM seq2seq with a utility-privacy disentangled latent space and adversarial-causal regularization to suppress privacy signals during feature generation.
AI.result: Evaluated on eight datasets, DELTA improves downstream predictive performance by approximately 9.3% and reduces privacy leakage by about 35%.
AI.conclusion: DELTA enables robust, privacy-aware data transformation by decoupling utility and privacy signals, yielding improved task performance with reduced privacy leakage.

title: AGI as Second Being: The Structural-Generative Ontology of Intelligence
summary:
Artificial intelligence is often measured by the range of tasks it can
perform. Yet wide ability without depth remains only an imitation. This paper
proposes a Structural-Generative Ontology of Intelligence: true intelligence
exists only when a system can generate new structures, coordinate them into
reasons, and sustain its identity over time. These three conditions --
generativity, coordination, and sustaining -- define the depth that underlies
real intelligence. Current AI systems, however broad in function, remain
surface simulations because they lack this depth. Breadth is not the source of
intelligence but the growth that follows from depth. If future systems were to
meet these conditions, they would no longer be mere tools, but could be seen as
a possible Second Being, standing alongside yet distinct from human existence.

AI.tldr: Proposes a depth-centric ontology of intelligence where true intelligence requires generativity, coordination, and sustaining identity; breadth alone is insufficient. Future systems fulfilling these conditions could become a 'Second Being' beyond mere tools.
AI.motivation: Current AI reflects broad functionality but often lacks depth; there is a need to distinguish surface-level simulations from genuine intelligence and to define criteria that capture enduring, purposeful behavior.
AI.method: Introduce Structural-Generative Ontology of Intelligence: define three core conditions—generativity (ability to create new structures), coordination (organize these structures into reasons), and sustaining (maintain identity over time)—and argue that these yield depth that enables real intelligence.
AI.result: A theoretical framework and set of criteria for intelligence depth, suggesting that systems meeting these conditions would transcend tool-like status and approach a 'Second Being'; lacks empirical validation but provides a basis for future research.
AI.conclusion: Depth is the source of true intelligence, not breadth; current AI is surface-level; future systems meeting the three conditions could achieve persistent, autonomous intelligence and reshape human-AI coexistence.

title: Systematic Evaluation of Trade-Offs in Motion Planning Algorithms for Optimal Industrial Robotic Work Cell Design
comment:
This work has been accepted to IFAC for publication under a Creative
  Commons Licence CC-BY-NC-ND
summary:
The performance of industrial robotic work cells depends on optimizing
various hyperparameters referring to the cell layout, such as robot base
placement, tool placement, and kinematic design. Achieving this requires a
bilevel optimization approach, where the high-level optimization adjusts these
hyperparameters, and the low-level optimization computes robot motions.
However, computing the optimal robot motion is computationally infeasible,
introducing trade-offs in motion planning to make the problem tractable. These
trade-offs significantly impact the overall performance of the bilevel
optimization, but their effects still need to be systematically evaluated. In
this paper, we introduce metrics to assess these trade-offs regarding
optimality, time gain, robustness, and consistency. Through extensive
simulation studies, we investigate how simplifications in motion-level
optimization affect the high-level optimization outcomes, balancing
computational complexity with solution quality. The proposed algorithms are
applied to find the time-optimal kinematic design for a modular robot in two
palletization scenarios.

AI.tldr: Proposes metrics to evaluate trade-offs in motion-level simplifications within bilevel optimization for industrial robotic work cells; uses simulations to study the impact on high-level design and applies to time-optimal kinematic design in palletization.
AI.motivation: High-level optimization of hyperparameters (e.g., base/tool placement, kinematic design) depends on low-level motion planning, which is computationally expensive. Simplifications introduce trade-offs whose effects on overall performance are not yet quantified.
AI.method: Introduce metrics for optimality, time gain, robustness, and consistency to assess motion-level trade-offs. Conduct extensive simulations to study how simplified motion planning affects high-level optimization outcomes. Apply the framework to find time-optimal kinematic designs for a modular robot in two palletization scenarios.
AI.result: The metrics enable systematic evaluation of trade-offs between motion-level simplifications and high-level optimization outcomes. Simulation results illustrate the impact on solution quality and computational effort, guiding how to balance complexity and performance.
AI.conclusion: The proposed metrics and framework provide a systematic approach to quantify and balance trade-offs in bilevel optimization for robotic work cells, demonstrated via time-optimal kinematic design in palletization scenarios.

title: OmniReason: A Temporal-Guided Vision-Language-Action Framework for Autonomous Driving
summary:
Recent advances in vision-language models (VLMs) have demonstrated impressive
spatial reasoning capabilities for autonomous driving, yet existing methods
predominantly focus on static scene understanding while neglecting the
essential temporal dimension of real-world driving scenarios. To address this
critical limitation, we propose the OmniReason framework, which establishes
robust spatiotemporal reasoning by jointly modeling dynamic 3D environments and
their underlying decision-making processes. Our work makes two fundamental
advances: (1) We introduce OmniReason-Data, two large-scale
vision-language-action (VLA) datasets with dense spatiotemporal annotations and
natural language explanations, generated through a novel
hallucination-mitigated auto-labeling pipeline that ensures both physical
plausibility and temporal coherence; (2) We develop the OmniReason-Agent
architecture, which integrates a sparse temporal memory module for persistent
scene context modeling and an explanation generator that produces
human-interpretable decision rationales, facilitated by our spatiotemporal
knowledge distillation approach that effectively captures spatiotemporal causal
reasoning patterns. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate state-of-the-art
performance, where OmniReason-Agent achieves significant improvements in both
open-loop planning tasks and visual question answering (VQA) benchmarks, while
establishing new capabilities for interpretable, temporally-aware autonomous
vehicles operating in complex, dynamic environments.

AI.tldr: OmniReason introduces spatiotemporal reasoning for vision-language models in autonomous driving via OmniReason-Data and OmniReason-Agent, achieving state-of-the-art planning and VQA with interpretable, temporally coherent explanations.
AI.motivation: Current VLMs excel at static scene understanding but neglect the temporal dynamics essential for real-world driving, limiting robust decision-making and interpretability in dynamic environments.
AI.method: Two large-scale VLA datasets (OmniReason-Data) with dense spatiotemporal annotations and explanations, created via a hallucination-mitigated auto-labeling pipeline. An OmniReason-Agent architecture with a sparse temporal memory for persistent scene context, an explanation generator for human-interpretable rationales, and spatiotemporal knowledge distillation to capture causal patterns.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance on open-loop planning tasks and VQA benchmarks in dynamic driving scenarios, with enhanced interpretability and temporally-aware decision reasoning.
AI.conclusion: The framework advances robust spatiotemporal reasoning for autonomous vehicles, enabling better planning and explainable decisions in dynamic environments, while establishing a scalable data-and-model approach that could extend to broader spatiotemporal AI tasks.

title: Robust Spatiotemporal Forecasting Using Adaptive Deep-Unfolded Variational Mode Decomposition
comment: Under review in IEEE Signal Processing Letter
summary:
Accurate spatiotemporal forecasting is critical for numerous complex systems
but remains challenging due to complex volatility patterns and spectral
entanglement in conventional graph neural networks (GNNs). While
decomposition-integrated approaches like variational mode graph convolutional
