network (VMGCN) improve accuracy through signal decomposition, they suffer from
computational inefficiency and manual hyperparameter tuning. To address these
limitations, we propose the mode adaptive graph network (MAGN) that transforms
iterative variational mode decomposition (VMD) into a trainable neural module.
Our key innovations include (1) an unfolded VMD (UVMD) module that replaces
iterative optimization with a fixed-depth network to reduce the decomposition
time (by 250x for the LargeST benchmark), and (2) mode-specific learnable
bandwidth constraints ({\alpha}k ) adapt spatial heterogeneity and eliminate
manual tuning while preventing spectral overlap. Evaluated on the LargeST
benchmark (6,902 sensors, 241M observations), MAGN achieves an 85-95% reduction
in the prediction error over VMGCN and outperforms state-of-the-art baselines.

AI.tldr: MAGN introduces an unfolded variational mode decomposition to a mode-adaptive graph network for spatiotemporal forecasting, achieving large speedups and substantial error reductions compared to VMGCN.
AI.motivation: Conventional graph neural networks struggle with spectral entanglement and volatile dynamics in spatiotemporal data. Variational mode graph convolutional networks (VMGCN) improve accuracy via signal decomposition but suffer from computational inefficiency and reliance on manual hyperparameters. There is a need for a trainable, efficient decomposition module to enable scalable, accurate forecasting.
AI.method: Introduce an unfolded variational mode decomposition (UVMD) module that replaces iterative optimization with a fixed-depth neural network, reducing decomposition time. Incorporate mode-specific learnable bandwidth constraints (α_k) to adapt to spatial heterogeneity and prevent spectral overlap, forming the mode adaptive graph network (MAGN) end-to-end.
AI.result: On LargeST (6,902 sensors, 241M observations), MAGN yields an 85-95% reduction in prediction error compared with VMGCN and achieves substantial performance gains over state-of-the-art baselines; decomposition time is reduced by ~250x for LargeST tests.
AI.conclusion: MAGN successfully stabilizes and accelerates spatiotemporal forecasting by substituting iterative decomposition with a trainable UVMD module and learnable bandwidths, reducing manual tuning while boosting accuracy; the approach scales to large sensor networks and may generalize to other domains requiring spectral decomposition.

title: LLMs for LLMs: A Structured Prompting Methodology for Long Legal Documents
summary:
The rise of Large Language Models (LLMs) has had a profoundly transformative
effect on a number of fields and domains. However, their uptake in Law has
proven more challenging due to the important issues of reliability and
transparency. In this study, we present a structured prompting methodology as a
viable alternative to the often expensive fine-tuning, with the capability of
tacking long legal documents from the CUAD dataset on the task of information
retrieval. Each document is first split into chunks via a system of chunking
and augmentation, addressing the long document problem. Then, alongside an
engineered prompt, the input is fed into QWEN-2 to produce a set of answers for
each question. Finally, we tackle the resulting candidate selection problem
with the introduction of the Distribution-based Localisation and Inverse
Cardinality Weighting heuristics. This approach leverages a general purpose
model to promote long term scalability, prompt engineering to increase
reliability and the two heuristic strategies to reduce the impact of the black
box effect. Whilst our model performs up to 9\% better than the previously
presented method, reaching state-of-the-art performance, it also highlights the
limiting factor of current automatic evaluation metrics for question answering,
serving as a call to action for future research. However, the chief aim of this
work is to underscore the potential of structured prompt engineering as a
useful, yet under-explored, tool in ensuring accountability and responsibility
of AI in the legal domain, and beyond.

AI.tldr: Structured prompting with chunking and two heuristics achieves state-of-the-art QA on CUAD for legal document retrieval without fine-tuning, though evaluation metrics for QA may limit reliability.
AI.motivation: Address reliability, transparency, and scalability of LLMs in the legal domain by reducing reliance on costly fine-tuning and enabling handling of long documents while promoting accountable AI.
AI.method: Chunk long legal documents via a chunking/augmentation system; use engineered prompts; feed into QWEN-2 to generate answers per question; apply Distribution-based Localisation and Inverse Cardinality Weighting to select final answers, leveraging a general-purpose model for scalability and prompt-based reliability.
AI.result: Achieves up to ~9% improvement over prior methods and reaches state-of-the-art on the CUAD dataset; also highlights limitations of current automatic QA evaluation metrics.
AI.conclusion: Structured prompt engineering is a promising tool to enhance accountability and responsibility of AI in legal domains (and beyond), warranting further research.

title: Enhancing Reliability in LLM-Integrated Robotic Systems: A Unified Approach to Security and Safety
summary:
Integrating large language models (LLMs) into robotic systems has
revolutionised embodied artificial intelligence, enabling advanced
decision-making and adaptability. However, ensuring reliability, encompassing
both security against adversarial attacks and safety in complex environments,
remains a critical challenge. To address this, we propose a unified framework
that mitigates prompt injection attacks while enforcing operational safety
through robust validation mechanisms. Our approach combines prompt assembling,
state management, and safety validation, evaluated using both performance and
security metrics. Experiments show a 30.8% improvement under injection attacks
and up to a 325% improvement in complex environment settings under adversarial
conditions compared to baseline scenarios. This work bridges the gap between
safety and security in LLM-based robotic systems, offering actionable insights
for deploying reliable LLM-integrated mobile robots in real-world settings. The
framework is open-sourced with simulation and physical deployment demos at
https://llmeyesim.vercel.app/

AI.tldr: A unified framework for secure and safe LLM-enabled robots that mitigates prompt injection and enforces safety via validation, showing resilience in adversarial settings.
AI.motivation: Reliability in LLM-augmented robotics requires addressing both security threats (prompt injections) and safety in complex environments.
AI.method: Integrates prompt assembling, state management, and safety validation with robust validation mechanisms; evaluated on performance and security metrics; open-source with simulation and real-world demos.
AI.result: 30.8% improvement under prompt injection attacks; up to 325% improvement in complex environments under adversarial conditions versus baselines.
AI.conclusion: Brings together safety and security in LLM-based robotics; provides actionable guidance for deploying reliable LLM-integrated mobile robots; open-source demos available.

title: Multimodal Iterative RAG for Knowledge Visual Question Answering
summary:
While Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have significantly advanced
multimodal understanding, their performance remains limited on
knowledge-intensive visual questions that require external knowledge beyond the
image. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) has become a promising solution for
providing models with external knowledge, its conventional single-pass
framework often fails to gather sufficient knowledge. To overcome this
limitation, we propose MI-RAG, a Multimodal Iterative RAG framework that
leverages reasoning to enhance retrieval and update reasoning over newly
retrieved knowledge across modalities. At each iteration, MI-RAG leverages an
accumulated reasoning record to dynamically formulate a multi-query. These
queries then drive a joint search across heterogeneous knowledge bases
containing both visually-grounded and textual knowledge. The newly acquired
knowledge is synthesized into the reasoning record, progressively refining
understanding across iterations. Experiments on challenging benchmarks,
including Encyclopedic VQA, InfoSeek, and OK-VQA, show that MI-RAG
significantly improves both retrieval recall and answer accuracy, establishing
a scalable approach for compositional reasoning in knowledge-intensive VQA.

AI.tldr: MI-RAG introduces an iterative, reasoning-guided multimodal RAG that formulates multi-queries from an accumulated reasoning record and searches across visually-grounded and textual KBs, progressively refining knowledge for knowledge-intensive VQA, achieving better retrieval and accuracy on Encyclopedic VQA, InfoSeek, and OK-VQA.
AI.motivation: Single-pass RAG often struggles to gather enough external knowledge for complex, knowledge-heavy visual questions. An iterative, reasoning-driven, multimodal retrieval approach is needed to improve knowledge gathering and integration over multiple steps.
AI.method: At each iteration, MI-RAG uses an accumulated reasoning record to dynamically formulate a multi-query that drives a joint search across heterogeneous knowledge bases containing both visually-grounded and textual knowledge. Newly retrieved knowledge is synthesized into the reasoning record, updating and refining understanding across iterations.
AI.result: The approach yields significant improvements in both retrieval recall and answer accuracy on challenging benchmarks (Encyclopedic VQA, InfoSeek, OK-VQA), demonstrating a scalable path for compositional reasoning in knowledge-intensive VQA.
AI.conclusion: MI-RAG provides a scalable, iterative multimodal retrieval-and-reasoning framework that enhances knowledge-intensive VQA by progressively incorporating diverse knowledge sources and refining reasoning across iterations.

title: Why Pool When You Can Flow? Active Learning with GFlowNets
summary:
The scalability of pool-based active learning is limited by the computational
cost of evaluating large unlabeled datasets, a challenge that is particularly
acute in virtual screening for drug discovery. While active learning strategies
such as Bayesian Active Learning by Disagreement (BALD) prioritize informative
samples, it remains computationally intensive when scaled to libraries
containing billions samples. In this work, we introduce BALD-GFlowNet, a
generative active learning framework that circumvents this issue. Our method
leverages Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets) to directly sample objects in
proportion to the BALD reward. By replacing traditional pool-based acquisition
with generative sampling, BALD-GFlowNet achieves scalability that is
independent of the size of the unlabeled pool. In our virtual screening
experiment, we show that BALD-GFlowNet achieves a performance comparable to
that of standard BALD baseline while generating more structurally diverse
molecules, offering a promising direction for efficient and scalable molecular
discovery.

AI.tldr: BALD-GFlowNet is a scalable generative active learning method using GFlowNets to sample molecules by BALD reward, achieving pool-size independent scalability while matching BALD performance and increasing molecular diversity.
AI.motivation: Pool-based active learning faces prohibitive computational costs on massive unlabeled datasets, especially in virtual screening of billions of compounds; BALD prioritizes informative samples but remains expensive; there is a need for scalable acquisition strategies.
AI.method: Replace pool-based acquisition with a GFlowNet that samples objects with probability proportional to BALD reward; BALD-GFlowNet directly samples molecules, avoiding evaluation of the full unlabeled pool; integrates BALD scoring with generative sampling.
AI.result: In virtual screening experiments, BALD-GFlowNet matches standard BALD performance while generating more structurally diverse molecules; scalability is independent of unlabeled pool size, enabling efficient exploration of large libraries.
AI.conclusion: BALD-GFlowNet offers a scalable, efficient approach for molecular discovery, enabling BALD-like informativeness with generative sampling; a promising direction for large-scale drug discovery.

title: An Epidemiological Knowledge Graph extracted from the World Health Organization's Disease Outbreak News
summary:
The rapid evolution of artificial intelligence (AI), together with the
increased availability of social media and news for epidemiological
surveillance, are marking a pivotal moment in epidemiology and public health
research. Leveraging the power of generative AI, we use an ensemble approach
which incorporates multiple Large Language Models (LLMs) to extract valuable
actionable epidemiological information from the World Health Organization (WHO)
Disease Outbreak News (DONs). DONs is a collection of regular reports on global
outbreaks curated by the WHO and the adopted decision-making processes to
respond to them. The extracted information is made available in a daily-updated
dataset and a knowledge graph, referred to as eKG, derived to provide a nuanced
representation of the public health domain knowledge. We provide an overview of
this new dataset and describe the structure of eKG, along with the services and
tools used to access and utilize the data that we are building on top. These
innovative data resources open altogether new opportunities for epidemiological
research, and the analysis and surveillance of disease outbreaks.

AI.tldr: An ensemble of LLMs extracts actionable epidemiological information from WHO DONs to create a daily-updated dataset and a knowledge graph (eKG) for enhanced outbreak surveillance.
AI.motivation: AI advances and increased access to social media and news for epidemiological surveillance create opportunities to extract structured knowledge from WHO DONs, supporting timely decision-making and research.
AI.method: Apply an ensemble of Large Language Models to parse DONs and extract structured epidemiological entities (e.g., events, locations, dates, signals, responses). Build a daily-updated dataset and a knowledge graph (eKG); describe the data structure and provide access services/tools.
AI.result: Produced a daily-updated dataset and eKG; the work outlines the structure of the eKG and the services/tools used to access the data, enabling new epidemiological analyses.
AI.conclusion: Innovative data resources (the dataset and eKG) open new opportunities for epidemiological research and improved disease outbreak surveillance.

title: Adaptive Navigation Strategy for Low-Thrust Proximity Operations in Circular Relative Orbit
comment:
This work has been accepted and presented at the 35th AAS/AIAA Space
  Flight Mechanics Meeting, 2025, Kaua'i, Hawai
summary:
This paper presents an adaptive observer-based navigation strategy for
spacecraft in Circular Relative Orbit (CRO) scenarios, addressing challenges in
proximity operations like formation flight and uncooperative target inspection.
The proposed method adjusts observer gains based on the estimated state to
achieve fast convergence and low noise sensitivity in state estimation. A
Lyapunov-based analysis ensures stability and accuracy, while simulations using
vision-based sensor data validate the approach under realistic conditions.
Compared to classical observers with time-invariant gains, the proposed method
enhances trajectory tracking precision and reduces control input switching,
making it a promising solution for autonomous spacecraft localization and
control.

AI.tldr: An adaptive observer with state-dependent gains for Circular Relative Orbit navigation, ensuring fast convergence and low noise sensitivity; Lyapunov-based stability guarantees; validated via vision-based simulations; outperforms fixed-gain observers in tracking accuracy and reduces control switching, aiding autonomous spacecraft localization and control in proximity operations.
AI.motivation: Proximity operations (formation flying, uncooperative target inspection) demand fast, robust state estimation under measurement noise. Classical time-invariant observers struggle with varying conditions and may exhibit slower convergence and higher sensitivity to noise.
AI.method: Introduce adaptive observer gains updated based on the estimated state. Provide Lyapunov-based stability analysis to guarantee convergence and accuracy. Validate through simulations using vision-based sensor data under realistic conditions, and compare performance against classical fixed-gain observers in terms of trajectory tracking precision and control input switching.
AI.result: Stability and accuracy are established via Lyapunov analysis. Simulations with vision-based sensing show enhanced trajectory tracking precision and reduced control-input switching compared to time-invariant observers.
AI.conclusion: The proposed adaptive observer approach is a promising solution for autonomous spacecraft localization and control in circular relative orbit proximity operations, with potential applicability to formation flight and uncooperative target inspection; future work could explore experimental validation and robustness to real-world sensing delays.

title: SWAGSplatting: Semantic-guided Water-scene Augmented Gaussian Splatting
comment: Submitted to SIGGRAPH Asia 2025 Technical Communications
summary:
Accurate 3D reconstruction in underwater environments remains a complex
challenge due to issues such as light distortion, turbidity, and limited
visibility. AI-based techniques have been applied to address these issues,
however, existing methods have yet to fully exploit the potential of AI,
particularly in integrating language models with visual processing. In this
paper, we propose a novel framework that leverages multimodal cross-knowledge
to create semantic-guided 3D Gaussian Splatting for robust and high-fidelity
deep-sea scene reconstruction. By embedding an extra semantic feature into each
Gaussian primitive and supervised by the CLIP extracted semantic feature, our
method enforces semantic and structural awareness throughout the training. The
dedicated semantic consistency loss ensures alignment with high-level scene
understanding. Besides, we propose a novel stage-wise training strategy,
combining coarse-to-fine learning with late-stage parameter refinement, to
further enhance both stability and reconstruction quality. Extensive results
show that our approach consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods on
SeaThru-NeRF and Submerged3D datasets across three metrics, with an improvement
of up to 3.09 dB on average in terms of PSNR, making it a strong candidate for
applications in underwater exploration and marine perception.

AI.tldr: Proposes semantic-guided 3D Gaussian Splatting for underwater scene reconstruction by integrating language-driven semantics (via CLIP) into Gaussian primitives, with a semantic consistency loss and stage-wise coarse-to-fine training, achieving state-of-the-art PSNR gains on underwater datasets.
AI.motivation: Underwater 3D reconstruction is challenged by light distortion, turbidity, and limited visibility, and current AI methods do not fully exploit semantic information or language-vision synergy to guide geometry and texture in reconstruction.
AI.method: A multimodal cross-knowledge framework that embeds semantic features into each Gaussian primitive and uses CLIP-derived semantics for supervision. Introduces a semantic consistency loss to align reconstruction with high-level scene understanding, and employs a stage-wise training strategy combining coarse-to-fine learning with late-stage parameter refinement.
AI.result: The approach consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods on SeaThru-NeRF and Submerged3D datasets across three metrics, with an average PSNR improvement of up to 3.09 dB.
AI.conclusion: Semantic-guided 3D Gaussian Splatting offers robust, high-fidelity deep-sea reconstructions and holds promise for advancing underwater exploration and marine perception.

title: Task-Aware Adaptive Modulation: A Replay-Free and Resource-Efficient Approach For Continual Graph Learning
summary:
Continual Graph Learning(CGL)focuses on acquiring new knowledge while
retaining previously learned information, essential for real-world graph
applications. Current methods grapple with two main issues:1) The
Stability-Plasticity Dilemma: Replay-based methods often create an imbalance
between the Dilemma, while incurring significant storage costs.2) The
Resource-Heavy Pre-training: Leading replay-free methods critically depend on
extensively pre-trained backbones, this reliance imposes a substantial resource
burden.In this paper, we argue that the key to overcoming these challenges lies
not in replaying data or fine-tuning the entire network, but in dynamically
modulating the internal computational flow of a frozen backbone. We posit that
lightweight, task-specific modules can effectively steer a GNN's reasoning
process. Motivated by this insight, we propose Task-Aware Adaptive
Modulation(TAAM), a replay-free, resource-efficient approach that charts a new
path for navigating the stability-plasticity dilemma. TAAM's core is its Neural
Synapse Modulators(NSM), which are trained and then frozen for each task to
store expert knowledge. A pivotal prototype-guided strategy governs these
modulators: 1) For training, it initializes a new NSM by deep-copying from a
similar past modulator to boost knowledge transfer. 2) For inference, it
selects the most relevant frozen NSM for each task. These NSMs insert into a
frozen GNN backbone to perform fine-grained, node-attentive modulation of its
internal flow-different from the static perturbations of prior methods.
Extensive experiments show that TAAM comprehensively outperforms
state-of-the-art methods across six GCIL benchmark datasets. The code will be
released upon acceptance of the paper.

AI.tldr: TAAM is a replay-free, resource-efficient continual graph learning framework that uses per-task Neural Synapse Modulators (NSMs) inserted into a frozen GNN backbone to dynamically modulate computation, trained per task and frozen, with a prototype-guided strategy for training and inference. It achieves state-of-the-art performance on six GCIL datasets.
AI.motivation: Address two main problems in continual graph learning: stability-plasticity dilemma and resource-heavy pre-training; aim to avoid replay and full-network fine-tuning by dynamic, lightweight modulation of a frozen backbone.
AI.method: Propose Task-Aware Adaptive Modulation (TAAM) using Neural Synapse Modulators (NSMs) inserted into a frozen GNN. Train NSMs per task, then freeze. Use prototype-guided strategy: deep-copy from similar past modulator to initialize a new NSM; during inference, select the most relevant NSM for each task.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show TAAM outperforms state-of-the-art methods across six GCIL benchmarks; code release promised.
AI.conclusion: TAAM demonstrates that replay-free, resource-efficient continual graph learning is achievable by learned, task-specific modulators that steer a frozen backbone, offering a new path beyond data replay and full fine-tuning.

title: Rewarding Explainability in Drug Repurposing with Knowledge Graphs
comment: 9 pages, 4 figures, accepted at conference IJCAI 2025
summary:
Knowledge graphs (KGs) are powerful tools for modelling complex,
multi-relational data and supporting hypothesis generation, particularly in
applications like drug repurposing. However, for predictive methods to gain
acceptance as credible scientific tools, they must ensure not only accuracy but
also the capacity to offer meaningful scientific explanations. This paper
presents a novel approach REx, for generating scientific explanations based in
link prediction in knowledge graphs. It employs reward and policy mechanisms
that consider desirable properties of scientific explanation to guide a
reinforcement learning agent in the identification of explanatory paths within
a KG. The approach further enriches explanatory paths with domain-specific
ontologies, ensuring that the explanations are both insightful and grounded in
established biomedical knowledge. We evaluate our approach in drug repurposing
using three popular knowledge graph benchmarks. The results clearly demonstrate
its ability to generate explanations that validate predictive insights against
biomedical knowledge and that outperform the state-of-the-art approaches in
predictive performance, establishing REx as a relevant contribution to advance
AI-driven scientific discovery.

AI.tldr: REx uses reinforcement learning to generate explanatory, ontology-grounded paths in knowledge graphs for drug repurposing, achieving explainable and improved predictive performance over state-of-the-art.
AI.motivation: To ensure KG-based predictions are both accurate and scientifically explainable, addressing trust and utility in biomedical AI.
AI.method: A reinforcement learning agent with reward and policy mechanisms guided by properties of scientific explanations identifies explanatory KG paths; these paths are enriched with domain ontologies to ground biomedical knowledge.
AI.result: Evaluations on three knowledge graph benchmarks for drug repurposing show that explanations validate predictive insights against biomedical knowledge and that REx outperforms state-of-the-art predictive approaches.
AI.conclusion: REx contributes to credible AI-driven scientific discovery by coupling explainable explanations with stronger predictions in biomedical KG tasks.

title: Human-Inspired Soft Anthropomorphic Hand System for Neuromorphic Object and Pose Recognition Using Multimodal Signals
summary:
The human somatosensory system integrates multimodal sensory feedback,
including tactile, proprioceptive, and thermal signals, to enable comprehensive
perception and effective interaction with the environment. Inspired by the
biological mechanism, we present a sensorized soft anthropomorphic hand
equipped with diverse sensors designed to emulate the sensory modalities of the
human hand. This system incorporates biologically inspired encoding schemes
that convert multimodal sensory data into spike trains, enabling
highly-efficient processing through Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs). By
utilizing these neuromorphic signals, the proposed framework achieves 97.14%
accuracy in object recognition across varying poses, significantly
outperforming previous studies on soft hands. Additionally, we introduce a
novel differentiator neuron model to enhance material classification by
capturing dynamic thermal responses. Our results demonstrate the benefits of
multimodal sensory fusion and highlight the potential of neuromorphic
approaches for achieving efficient, robust, and human-like perception in
robotic systems.

AI.tldr: Sensorized soft anthropomorphic hand with multimodal sensing and neuromorphic SNN processing achieves high object recognition and material classification via a differentiator neuron, highlighting efficient, human-like perception.
AI.motivation: Emulate human hand sensing (tactile, proprioceptive, thermal); enable efficient processing with neuromorphic methods; improve robustness across poses; capture thermal dynamics for material discrimination.
AI.method: Develop a soft hand with diverse sensors; encode multimodal data into spike trains using biologically inspired schemes; process with Spiking Neural Networks; introduce a differentiator neuron model for dynamic thermal responses; fuse modalities.
AI.result: Achieves 97.14% accuracy in object recognition across varying poses, outperforming prior soft-hand studies; differentiator neuron enhances material classification via dynamic thermal signals; demonstrates benefits of multimodal fusion and neuromorphic efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Neuromorphic, multimodal sensing enables efficient, robust, human-like perception in robotics; potential for advancing soft-handed manipulation and perception.

title: Adaptive Contrast Adjustment Module: A Clinically-Inspired Plug-and-Play Approach for Enhanced Fetal Plane Classification
summary:
Fetal ultrasound standard plane classification is essential for reliable
prenatal diagnosis but faces inherent challenges, including low tissue
contrast, boundary ambiguity, and operator-dependent image quality variations.
To overcome these limitations, we propose a plug-and-play adaptive contrast
adjustment module (ACAM), whose core design is inspired by the clinical
practice of doctors adjusting image contrast to obtain clearer and more
discriminative structural information. The module employs a shallow
texture-sensitive network to predict clinically plausible contrast parameters,
transforms input images into multiple contrast-enhanced views through
differentiable mapping, and fuses them within downstream classifiers. Validated
on a multi-center dataset of 12,400 images across six anatomical categories,
the module consistently improves performance across diverse models, with
accuracy of lightweight models increasing by 2.02 percent, accuracy of
traditional models increasing by 1.29 percent, and accuracy of state-of-the-art
models increasing by 1.15 percent. The innovation of the module lies in its
content-aware adaptation capability, replacing random preprocessing with
physics-informed transformations that align with sonographer workflows while
improving robustness to imaging heterogeneity through multi-view fusion. This
approach effectively bridges low-level image features with high-level
semantics, establishing a new paradigm for medical image analysis under
real-world image quality variations.

AI.tldr: A plug-and-play adaptive contrast adjustment module (ACAM) for fetal ultrasound plane classification improves model accuracy across models by learning contrast parameters via a shallow network to create multiple contrast-enhanced views for robust, physics-informed, multi-view fusion.
AI.motivation: Ultrasound images suffer from low tissue contrast, boundary ambiguity, and operator-dependent variability. There is a need for a content-aware, robust preprocessing step that bridges low-level features to high-level semantic classification.
AI.method: Introduce ACAM, a plug-and-play module with a shallow texture-sensitive network predicting contrast parameters. It generates multiple contrast-enhanced views through differentiable mappings and fuses them within downstream classifiers. The approach mirrors clinical contrast adjustment and uses physics-informed transformations for robustness across imaging heterogeneity.
AI.result: Validated on 12,400 images across six anatomical categories, ACAM improves accuracy: lightweight models +2.02%, traditional models +1.29%, state-of-the-art models +1.15%.
AI.conclusion: ACAM provides content-aware, physics-informed adaptive contrast adjustments that align with sonographer workflows, improving robustness to image quality variations and bridging low-level features with high-level semantics, suggesting a new paradigm for medical image analysis.

title: Attribute Fusion-based Classifier on Framework of Belief Structure
summary:
Dempster-Shafer Theory (DST) provides a powerful framework for modeling
uncertainty and has been widely applied to multi-attribute classification
tasks. However, traditional DST-based attribute fusion-based classifiers suffer
from oversimplified membership function modeling and limited exploitation of
the belief structure brought by basic probability assignment (BPA), reducing
their effectiveness in complex real-world scenarios. This paper presents an
enhanced attribute fusion-based classifier that addresses these limitations
through two key innovations. First, we adopt a selective modeling strategy that
utilizes both single Gaussian and Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs) for membership
function construction, with model selection guided by cross-validation and a
tailored evaluation metric. Second, we introduce a novel method to transform
the possibility distribution into a BPA by combining simple BPAs derived from
normalized possibility distributions, enabling a much richer and more flexible
representation of uncertain information. Furthermore, we apply the belief
structure-based BPA generation method to the evidential K-Nearest Neighbors
classifier, enhancing its ability to incorporate uncertainty information into
decision-making. Comprehensive experiments on benchmark datasets are conducted
to evaluate the performance of the proposed attribute fusion-based classifier
and the enhanced evidential K-Nearest Neighbors classifier in comparison with
both evidential classifiers and conventional machine learning classifiers. The
results demonstrate that our proposed classifier outperforms the best existing
evidential classifier, achieving an average accuracy improvement of 4.84%,
while maintaining low variance, thus confirming its superior effectiveness and
robustness.

AI.tldr: Enhanced DST-based attribute fusion classifier with selective Gaussian/GMM membership modeling and a BPA transformation from possibility distributions; also enriches evidential KNN with improved BPA generation. Demonstrates 4.84% average accuracy gain over the best existing evidential classifier with low variance on benchmark datasets.
AI.motivation: DST-based attribute fusion classifiers are limited by oversimplified membership functions and underutilization of the belief structure from BPA. A richer uncertainty representation and model selection strategy are needed to improve robustness in real-world multi-attribute classification.
AI.method: 1) Selective membership modeling using both single Gaussian and Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs); model selection guided by cross-validation and a tailored evaluation metric. 2) Transform possibility distributions into a BPA by combining simple BPAs derived from normalized possibility distributions, enabling richer uncertainty representation. 3) Apply the BPA generation method to evidential K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) to enhance uncertainty-aware decision-making.
AI.result: The proposed classifier achieves an average accuracy improvement of 4.84% over the best existing evidential classifier with low variance on benchmark datasets, outperforming both evidential and conventional ML classifiers.
AI.conclusion: The approach demonstrates superior effectiveness and robustness by leveraging a richer belief representation and adaptive membership modeling. It also extends the evidential KNN framework with enhanced BPA-based uncertainty handling, with strong empirical performance on benchmarks.

title: Re-evaluating LLM-based Heuristic Search: A Case Study on the 3D Packing Problem
summary:
The art of heuristic design has traditionally been a human pursuit. While
Large Language Models (LLMs) can generate code for search heuristics, their
application has largely been confined to adjusting simple functions within
human-crafted frameworks, leaving their capacity for broader innovation an open
question. To investigate this, we tasked an LLM with building a complete solver
for the constrained 3D Packing Problem. Direct code generation quickly proved
fragile, prompting us to introduce two supports: constraint
scaffolding--prewritten constraint-checking code--and iterative
self-correction--additional refinement cycles to repair bugs and produce a
viable initial population. Notably, even within a vast search space in a greedy
process, the LLM concentrated its efforts almost exclusively on refining the
scoring function. This suggests that the emphasis on scoring functions in prior
work may reflect not a principled strategy, but rather a natural limitation of
LLM capabilities. The resulting heuristic was comparable to a human-designed
greedy algorithm, and when its scoring function was integrated into a
human-crafted metaheuristic, its performance rivaled established solvers,
though its effectiveness waned as constraints tightened. Our findings highlight
two major barriers to automated heuristic design with current LLMs: the
engineering required to mitigate their fragility in complex reasoning tasks,
and the influence of pretrained biases, which can prematurely narrow the search
for novel solutions.

AI.tldr: LLMs can build a complete solver for a constrained problem using scaffolding and iterative self-correction, but their improvements center on scoring functions; performance is competitive with human heuristics yet fragile and biased, limiting broader automated innovation.
AI.motivation: To test whether large language models can move beyond patching human-designed frameworks to create autonomous, effective heuristics for a nontrivial optimization task (constrained 3D packing) and to understand the role of model biases and engineering in such advances.
AI.method: Task an LLM with building a complete solver for constrained 3D packing, introduce constraint scaffolding (prewritten constraint checks) and iterative self-correction (refinement cycles) to repair bugs and bootstrap a viable initial population. Analyze the model’s focus within a large search space, compare its output to a human-designed greedy algorithm, and test the scoring function within a metaheuristic framework.
AI.result: The LLM concentrated most refinement effort on the scoring function, producing a heuristic comparable to a human greedy algorithm. Incorporating the LLM-derived scoring into a human-crafted metaheuristic yielded performance rivaling established solvers, though effectiveness declined as constraints tightened. Two major barriers emerged: (1) engineering to mitigate the model’s fragility in complex reasoning tasks, and (2) pretrained biases that narrow exploration and suppress novel solutions.
AI.conclusion: Current LLMs can automate substantial portions of heuristic design but remain constrained by fragility and priors. The emphasis on scoring functions may reflect model biases more than a principled design strategy, and overcoming these barriers will be necessary for broader, more innovative automated heuristic design.

title: Sem-RaDiff: Diffusion-Based 3D Radar Semantic Perception in Cluttered Agricultural Environments
summary:
Accurate and robust environmental perception is crucial for robot autonomous
navigation. While current methods typically adopt optical sensors (e.g.,
camera, LiDAR) as primary sensing modalities, their susceptibility to visual
occlusion often leads to degraded performance or complete system failure. In
this paper, we focus on agricultural scenarios where robots are exposed to the
risk of onboard sensor contamination. Leveraging radar's strong penetration
capability, we introduce a radar-based 3D environmental perception framework as
a viable alternative. It comprises three core modules designed for dense and
accurate semantic perception: 1) Parallel frame accumulation to enhance
signal-to-noise ratio of radar raw data. 2) A diffusion model-based
hierarchical learning framework that first filters radar sidelobe artifacts
then generates fine-grained 3D semantic point clouds. 3) A specifically
designed sparse 3D network optimized for processing large-scale radar raw data.
We conducted extensive benchmark comparisons and experimental evaluations on a
self-built dataset collected in real-world agricultural field scenes. Results
demonstrate that our method achieves superior structural and semantic
prediction performance compared to existing methods, while simultaneously
reducing computational and memory costs by 51.3% and 27.5%, respectively.
Furthermore, our approach achieves complete reconstruction and accurate
classification of thin structures such as poles and wires-which existing
methods struggle to perceive-highlighting its potential for dense and accurate
3D radar perception.

AI.tldr: Radar-based 3D environmental perception for agriculture using parallel frame accumulation, diffusion-model hierarchical learning for denoising and semantic reconstruction, and a sparse 3D network; on real-field data, it improves accuracy and efficiency and can reconstruct thin structures that are hard for optical methods.
AI.motivation: Optical sensors suffer from occlusion and contamination in agricultural environments. Radar offers penetration and robustness, but existing radar-based methods struggle with noise, clutter, and large-scale data. A dense, efficient radar-based 3D semantic pipeline is needed for reliable autonomous farming.
AI.method: Three core modules: (1) parallel frame accumulation to boost radar signal-to-noise ratio; (2) a diffusion model-based hierarchical learning framework that first filters radar sidelobe artifacts and then generates fine-grained 3D semantic point clouds; (3) a sparse 3D network optimized for processing large-scale radar raw data.
AI.result: On a self-built real-world agricultural dataset, the approach achieves superior structural and semantic predictions over existing methods, while reducing computation cost by 51.3% and memory usage by 27.5%. It also enables complete reconstruction and accurate classification of thin structures (e.g., poles, wires) that prior methods struggle to perceive.
AI.conclusion: The proposed radar-based framework shows strong potential for dense and accurate 3D radar perception in agricultural environments, offering robustness to sensor contamination and occlusion with notable efficiency gains.

title: Sequential Difference Maximization: Generating Adversarial Examples via Multi-Stage Optimization
summary:
Efficient adversarial attack methods are critical for assessing the
robustness of computer vision models. In this paper, we reconstruct the
optimization objective for generating adversarial examples as "maximizing the
difference between the non-true labels' probability upper bound and the true
label's probability," and propose a gradient-based attack method termed
Sequential Difference Maximization (SDM). SDM establishes a three-layer
optimization framework of "cycle-stage-step." The processes between cycles and
between iterative steps are respectively identical, while optimization stages
differ in terms of loss functions: in the initial stage, the negative
probability of the true label is used as the loss function to compress the
solution space; in subsequent stages, we introduce the Directional Probability
Difference Ratio (DPDR) loss function to gradually increase the non-true
labels' probability upper bound by compressing the irrelevant labels'
probabilities. Experiments demonstrate that compared with previous SOTA
methods, SDM not only exhibits stronger attack performance but also achieves
higher attack cost-effectiveness. Additionally, SDM can be combined with
adversarial training methods to enhance their defensive effects. The code is
available at https://github.com/X-L-Liu/SDM.

AI.tldr: A gradient-based adversarial attack (SDM) reframes the objective as maximizing the gap between the non-true labels' probability upper bound and the true label's probability, using a three-layer cycle-stage-step framework with stage-specific losses to progressively worsen the model's predictions. It achieves stronger, more cost-effective attacks and can bolster defenses when combined with adversarial training.
AI.motivation: To improve the effectiveness and efficiency of adversarial attacks for evaluating CV model robustness, addressing limitations of prior methods in how the objective is optimized and how attack progress is structured.
AI.method: Introduce Sequential Difference Maximization (SDM) with a cycle-stage-step optimization: cycles and steps are structurally identical, but loss functions differ by stage. Stage 1 minimizes the true-label probability (negative true probability) to compress the solution space. Stages 2+ deploy the Directional Probability Difference Ratio (DPDR) loss to gradually raise the upper bound of non-true label probabilities by shrinking irrelevant labels, thereby increasing the difference between non-true upper bound and true probability. This is a gradient-based attack that can be combined with adversarial training.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations show SDM achieves stronger attack performance than state-of-the-art methods and higher attack cost-effectiveness. The approach also complements adversarial training, enhancing defensive effects. Code is available at the provided GitHub repository.
AI.conclusion: SDM provides a new, effective optimization objective and practical attack framework that yields stronger, more efficient adversarial examples and can contribute to improving defenses when used with adversarial training.

title: Flow Matters: Directional and Expressive GNNs for Heterophilic Graphs
summary:
In heterophilic graphs, where neighboring nodes often belong to different
classes, conventional Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) struggle due to their
reliance on local homophilous neighborhoods. Prior studies suggest that
modeling edge directionality in such graphs can increase effective homophily
and improve classification performance. Simultaneously, recent work on
polynomially expressive GNNs shows promise in capturing higher-order
interactions among features. In this work, we study the combined effect of edge
directionality and expressive message passing on node classification in
heterophilic graphs. Specifically, we propose two architectures: (1) a
polynomially expressive GAT baseline (Poly), and (2) a direction-aware variant
(Dir-Poly) that separately aggregates incoming and outgoing edges. Both models
are designed to learn permutation-equivariant high-degree polynomials over
input features, while remaining scalable with no added time complexity.
Experiments on five benchmark heterophilic datasets show that our Poly model
consistently outperforms existing baselines, and that Dir-Poly offers
additional gains on graphs with inherent directionality (e.g., Roman Empire),
achieving state-of-the-art results. Interestingly, on undirected graphs,
introducing artificial directionality does not always help, suggesting that the
benefit of directional message passing is context-dependent. Our findings
highlight the complementary roles of edge direction and expressive feature
modeling in heterophilic graph learning.

AI.tldr: Two scalable, permutation-equivariant GNNs (Poly and Dir-Poly) leverage high-degree polynomial feature learning and edge directionality to improve node classification on heterophilic graphs; Poly is strong across datasets, Dir-Poly yields state-of-the-art on graphs with directionality; benefits of directionality are dataset-dependent.
AI.motivation: Heterophilic graphs violate the local homophily assumption, causing standard GNNs to underperform. Incorporating edge direction and higher-order feature interactions may increase effective homophily and expressive power.
AI.method: Poly: a polynomially expressive GAT baseline. Dir-Poly: extends Poly by separately aggregating incoming and outgoing edges. Both learn permutation-equivariant high-degree polynomials over input features and are designed to be scalable with no added time complexity.
AI.result: Poly consistently outperforms existing baselines on five heterophilic datasets. Dir-Poly provides additional gains on graphs with inherent directionality (e.g., Roman Empire), achieving state-of-the-art results. On undirected graphs, artificially introducing directionality does not always help.
AI.conclusion: Directionality and expressive feature modeling play complementary roles in heterophilic graph learning, with the benefit of directional message passing being dataset/context dependent.

title: Exploring Diffusion Models for Generative Forecasting of Financial Charts
summary:
Recent advances in generative models have enabled significant progress in
tasks such as generating and editing images from text, as well as creating
videos from text prompts, and these methods are being applied across various
fields. However, in the financial domain, there may still be a reliance on
time-series data and a continued focus on transformer models, rather than on
diverse applications of generative models. In this paper, we propose a novel
approach that leverages text-to-image model by treating time-series data as a
single image pattern, thereby enabling the prediction of stock price trends.
Unlike prior methods that focus on learning and classifying chart patterns
using architectures such as ResNet or ViT, we experiment with generating the
next chart image from the current chart image and an instruction prompt using
diffusion models. Furthermore, we introduce a simple method for evaluating the
generated chart image against ground truth image. We highlight the potential of
leveraging text-to-image generative models in the financial domain, and our
findings motivate further research to address the current limitations and
expand their applicability.

AI.tldr: Proposes using text-to-image diffusion models to forecast stock price trends by converting time-series charts into images and generating the next chart image from the current image with an instruction prompt; introduces a simple image-based evaluation method and advocates broader research in applying generative models to finance.
AI.motivation: Financial ML has heavily relied on time-series modeling and transformers; there is a need to explore diverse uses of generative image models and assess their applicability to financial prediction tasks.
AI.method: Treat time-series data as a single image pattern; generate the next chart image from the current chart image and an instruction prompt using diffusion models; introduce a simple method to evaluate the generated image against a ground-truth chart image.
AI.result: The paper proposes this approach and an evaluation method, highlighting the potential of text-to-image generative models in finance; no quantitative results are reported in the abstract, but findings are positioned to motivate further research.
AI.conclusion: Text-to-image generative models can be leveraged in the financial domain; the work encourages additional research to address current limitations and broaden applicability in forecasting and chart-based tasks.

title: Language-Guided Long Horizon Manipulation with LLM-based Planning and Visual Perception
summary:
Language-guided long-horizon manipulation of deformable objects presents
significant challenges due to high degrees of freedom, complex dynamics, and
the need for accurate vision-language grounding. In this work, we focus on
multi-step cloth folding, a representative deformable-object manipulation task
that requires both structured long-horizon planning and fine-grained visual
perception. To this end, we propose a unified framework that integrates a Large
Language Model (LLM)-based planner, a Vision-Language Model (VLM)-based
perception system, and a task execution module. Specifically, the LLM-based
planner decomposes high-level language instructions into low-level action
primitives, bridging the semantic-execution gap, aligning perception with
action, and enhancing generalization. The VLM-based perception module employs a
SigLIP2-driven architecture with a bidirectional cross-attention fusion
mechanism and weight-decomposed low-rank adaptation (DoRA) fine-tuning to
achieve language-conditioned fine-grained visual grounding. Experiments in both
simulation and real-world settings demonstrate the method's effectiveness. In
simulation, it outperforms state-of-the-art baselines by 2.23, 1.87, and 33.3
on seen instructions, unseen instructions, and unseen tasks, respectively. On a
real robot, it robustly executes multi-step folding sequences from language
instructions across diverse cloth materials and configurations, demonstrating
strong generalization in practical scenarios. Project page:
https://language-guided.netlify.app/

AI.tldr: Unified LLM-guided planning and VLM-based perception for long-horizon deformable-object manipulation (cloth folding), achieving strong generalization across seen/unseen tasks and real-world robustness.
AI.motivation: Deformable-object manipulation is hard due to high degrees of freedom, complex dynamics, and the need for reliable language grounding; cloth folding requires long-horizon planning and fine-grained perception.
AI.method: A unified framework combining (1) an LLM-based planner that decomposes high-level instructions into action primitives, bridging semantic-execution gap; (2) a VLM-based perception module built on SigLIP2 with bidirectional cross-attention fusion and DoRA-based fine-tuning for language-conditioned visual grounding; (3) a task execution module to carry out actions. Evaluated in simulation and real robot.
AI.result: Simulation: outperforms state-of-the-art baselines by 2.23, 1.87, and 33.3 on seen instructions, unseen instructions, and unseen tasks. Real robot: robust multi-step folding across diverse cloth materials/configurations, showing strong generalization.
AI.conclusion: The proposed LLM-VLM unified framework effectively bridges semantics and perception to enable language-guided long-horizon manipulation of deformable objects, with notable generalization and real-world applicability. A project page is provided.

title: Surface Defect Detection with Gabor Filter Using Reconstruction-Based Blurring U-Net-ViT
summary:
This paper proposes a novel approach to enhance the accuracy and reliability
of texture-based surface defect detection using Gabor filters and a blurring
U-Net-ViT model. By combining the local feature training of U-Net with the
global processing of the Vision Transformer(ViT), the model effectively detects
defects across various textures. A Gaussian filter-based loss function removes
background noise and highlights defect patterns, while Salt-and-Pepper(SP)
masking in the training process reinforces texture-defect boundaries, ensuring
robust performance in noisy environments. Gabor filters are applied in
post-processing to emphasize defect orientation and frequency characteristics.
Parameter optimization, including filter size, sigma, wavelength, gamma, and
orientation, maximizes performance across datasets like MVTec-AD, Surface Crack
Detection, and Marble Surface Anomaly Dataset, achieving an average Area Under
the Curve(AUC) of 0.939. The ablation studies validate that the optimal filter
size and noise probability significantly enhance defect detection performance.

AI.tldr: A novel texture-based defect-detection framework combining blurring U-Net-ViT, Gaussian-loss, SP masking, and Gabor post-processing, achieving ~0.939 AUC across datasets.
AI.motivation: To boost accuracy and robustness of texture-based surface defect detection under noise by fusing local (U‑Net) and global (ViT) features and effective noise suppression.
AI.method: Proposes a blurring U-Net-ViT architecture; Gaussian-filter loss to suppress background noise; Salt-and-Pepper masking during training; post-processing with Gabor filters; parameter optimization (size, sigma, wavelength, gamma, orientation) across datasets (MVTec-AD, Surface Crack Detection, Marble); ablation studies.
AI.result: Average AUC of 0.939 across datasets; ablation confirms optimal filter size and noise probability are key contributors to performance.
AI.conclusion: The approach yields robust defect detection across textures by integrating local and global features with targeted noise suppression and orientation/frequency emphasis, with parameter tuning driving gains across datasets.

title: ProCause: Generating Counterfactual Outcomes to Evaluate Prescriptive Process Monitoring Methods
summary:
Prescriptive Process Monitoring (PresPM) is the subfield of Process Mining
that focuses on optimizing processes through real-time interventions based on
event log data. Evaluating PresPM methods is challenging due to the lack of
ground-truth outcomes for all intervention actions in datasets. A generative
deep learning approach from the field of Causal Inference (CI), RealCause, has
been commonly used to estimate the outcomes for proposed intervention actions
to evaluate a new policy. However, RealCause overlooks the temporal
dependencies in process data, and relies on a single CI model architecture,
TARNet, limiting its effectiveness. To address both shortcomings, we introduce
ProCause, a generative approach that supports both sequential (e.g., LSTMs) and
non-sequential models while integrating multiple CI architectures (S-Learner,
T-Learner, TARNet, and an ensemble). Our research using a simulator with known
ground truths reveals that TARNet is not always the best choice; instead, an
ensemble of models offers more consistent reliability, and leveraging LSTMs
shows potential for improved evaluations when temporal dependencies are
present. We further validate ProCause's practical effectiveness through a
real-world data analysis, ensuring a more reliable evaluation of PresPM
methods.

AI.tldr: ProCause enhances the evaluation of Prescriptive Process Monitoring by combining multiple causal inference architectures with both sequential and non-sequential models to handle temporal dependencies, outperforming single-model baselines like TARNet in both simulated and real-world data.
AI.motivation: Evaluating PresPM is challenging due to missing ground-truth outcomes for intervention actions. RealCause relies on a single CI model (TARNet) and ignores temporal dependencies, limiting reliability. There's a need for a generative, flexible framework that models temporal dynamics and combines multiple CI approaches.
AI.method: ProCause supports both sequential (e.g., LSTMs) and non-sequential models for estimating intervention outcomes, and integrates multiple CI learners (S-Learner, T-Learner, TARNet, plus an ensemble). It uses a simulator with known ground truths to assess performance and validates findings with real-world data analyses.
AI.result: An ensemble of CI models provides more consistent and reliable evaluations than any single model, including TARNet. LSTMs offer improvements when temporal dependencies exist. TARNet is not universally the best choice. ProCause yields more robust evaluation results in simulated settings and shows practical effectiveness on real data.
AI.conclusion: A flexible, generative evaluation framework (ProCause) that incorporates both sequential/non-sequential models and multiple CI architectures improves PresPM evaluation accuracy and reliability, guiding better policy design for real-time interventions.

title: Explainability-Driven Dimensionality Reduction for Hyperspectral Imaging
summary:
Hyperspectral imaging (HSI) provides rich spectral information for precise
material classification and analysis; however, its high dimensionality
introduces a computational burden and redundancy, making dimensionality
reduction essential. We present an exploratory study into the application of
post-hoc explainability methods in a model--driven framework for band
selection, which reduces the spectral dimension while preserving predictive
performance. A trained classifier is probed with explanations to quantify each
band's contribution to its decisions. We then perform deletion--insertion
evaluations, recording confidence changes as ranked bands are removed or
reintroduced, and aggregate these signals into influence scores. Selecting the
highest--influence bands yields compact spectral subsets that maintain accuracy
and improve efficiency. Experiments on two public benchmarks (Pavia University
and Salinas) demonstrate that classifiers trained on as few as 30 selected
bands match or exceed full--spectrum baselines while reducing computational
requirements. The resulting subsets align with physically meaningful, highly
discriminative wavelength regions, indicating that model--aligned,
explanation-guided band selection is a principled route to effective
dimensionality reduction for HSI.

AI.tldr: Post-hoc explainability-guided band selection yields compact, high-performance hyperspectral subsets (as few as 30 bands) that match or exceed full-spectrum classifiers while reducing computation.
AI.motivation: Hyperspectral data are high-dimensional; dimensionality reduction is needed to cut computation while preserving accuracy. Existing methods may be ad hoc; this work proposes using model explanations to identify and select the most influential spectral bands for classification.
AI.method: Train a classifier on hyperspectral data; use post-hoc explanations to quantify each band's contribution; conduct deletion–insertion analyses to obtain band influence scores; select top-influence bands to form a reduced spectral subset; evaluate on Pavia University and Salinas datasets, comparing to full-spectrum baselines.
AI.result: Compact subsets (≈30 bands) achieve accuracy that matches or exceeds full-spectrum baselines while reducing computation; the selected bands correspond to physically meaningful discriminative wavelengths.
AI.conclusion: Explanation-guided, model-aligned band selection provides a principled, effective approach for dimensionality reduction in hyperspectral imaging with preserved predictive performance.

title: Physics-Informed Machine Learning with Adaptive Grids for Optical Microrobot Depth Estimation
comment:
2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS
  2025)
summary:
Optical microrobots actuated by optical tweezers (OT) offer great potential
for biomedical applications such as cell manipulation and microscale assembly.
These tasks demand accurate three-dimensional perception to ensure precise
control in complex and dynamic biological environments. However, the
transparent nature of microrobots and low-contrast microscopic imaging
challenge conventional deep learning methods, which also require large
annotated datasets that are costly to obtain. To address these challenges, we
propose a physics-informed, data-efficient framework for depth estimation of
optical microrobots. Our method augments convolutional feature extraction with
physics-based focus metrics, such as entropy, Laplacian of Gaussian, and
gradient sharpness, calculated using an adaptive grid strategy. This approach
allocates finer grids over microrobot regions and coarser grids over background
areas, enhancing depth sensitivity while reducing computational complexity. We
evaluate our framework on multiple microrobot types and demonstrate significant
improvements over baseline models. Specifically, our approach reduces mean
squared error (MSE) by over 60% and improves the coefficient of determination
(R^2) across all test cases. Notably, even when trained on only 20% of the
available data, our model outperforms ResNet50 trained on the full dataset,
highlighting its robustness under limited data conditions. Our code is
available at: https://github.com/LannWei/CBS2025.

AI.tldr: A physics-informed, data-efficient depth estimation framework for optical microrobots that uses adaptive grids and physics-based focus metrics to improve depth sensing with limited data, achieving substantial performance gains and robust generalization; code available.
AI.motivation: To address depth estimation challenges due to transparent microrobots, low-contrast imaging, and scarce annotated data in optical microrobot manipulation tasks.
AI.method: Augments convolutional feature extraction with physics-based focus metrics (entropy, Laplacian of Gaussian, gradient sharpness) computed on an adaptive grid that concentrates computation on microrobot regions, yielding improved depth sensitivity with reduced compute.
AI.result: Achieves over 60% reduction in mean squared error and higher R^2 across test cases; robust when trained on only 20% of data, outperforming ResNet50 trained on full data.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates a robust, data-efficient, physics-informed approach for 3D depth estimation of optical microrobots in challenging imaging environments; code released at GitHub.

title: UPGS: Unified Pose-aware Gaussian Splatting for Dynamic Scene Deblurring
summary:
Reconstructing dynamic 3D scenes from monocular video has broad applications
in AR/VR, robotics, and autonomous navigation, but often fails due to severe
motion blur caused by camera and object motion. Existing methods commonly
follow a two-step pipeline, where camera poses are first estimated and then 3D
Gaussians are optimized. Since blurring artifacts usually undermine pose
estimation, pose errors could be accumulated to produce inferior reconstruction
results. To address this issue, we introduce a unified optimization framework
by incorporating camera poses as learnable parameters complementary to 3DGS
attributes for end-to-end optimization. Specifically, we recast camera and
object motion as per-primitive SE(3) affine transformations on 3D Gaussians and
formulate a unified optimization objective. For stable optimization, we
introduce a three-stage training schedule that optimizes camera poses and
Gaussians alternatively. Particularly, 3D Gaussians are first trained with
poses being fixed, and then poses are optimized with 3D Gaussians being
untouched. Finally, all learnable parameters are optimized together. Extensive
experiments on the Stereo Blur dataset and challenging real-world sequences
demonstrate that our method achieves significant gains in reconstruction
quality and pose estimation accuracy over prior dynamic deblurring methods.

AI.tldr: End-to-end optimization that jointly learns camera poses and a 3D Gaussian-based scene representation for dynamic scenes from monocular video, boosting reconstruction and pose accuracy under motion blur.
AI.motivation: Motion blur contaminates pose estimation and degrades dynamic scene reconstruction; a unified optimization can mitigate error accumulation by coupling pose and scene representation.
AI.method: Model dynamic scenes as per-primitive SE(3) affine transformations on 3D Gaussians (3DGS); formulate a unified objective; three-stage training: train Gaussians with fixed poses, optimize poses with fixed Gaussians, then joint optimization.
AI.result: Significant gains in reconstruction quality and pose estimation accuracy on Stereo Blur dataset and real-world sequences compared to prior dynamic deblurring methods.
AI.conclusion: Unified pose-and-scene optimization improves robustness to motion blur and yields better reconstruction and pose estimates; demonstrates effectiveness of end-to-end coupling of camera Poses and 3D Gaussian scene representation.

title: Fairness in Federated Learning: Trends, Challenges, and Opportunities
summary:
At the intersection of the cutting-edge technologies and privacy concerns,
Federated Learning (FL) with its distributed architecture, stands at the
forefront in a bid to facilitate collaborative model training across multiple
clients while preserving data privacy. However, the applicability of FL systems
is hindered by fairness concerns arising from numerous sources of heterogeneity
that can result in biases and undermine a system's effectiveness, with skewed
predictions, reduced accuracy, and inefficient model convergence. This survey
thus explores the diverse sources of bias, including but not limited to, data,
client, and model biases, and thoroughly discusses the strengths and
limitations inherited within the array of the state-of-the-art techniques
utilized in the literature to mitigate such disparities in the FL training
process. We delineate a comprehensive overview of the several notions,
theoretical underpinnings, and technical aspects associated with fairness and
their adoption in FL-based multidisciplinary environments. Furthermore, we
examine salient evaluation metrics leveraged to measure fairness
quantitatively. Finally, we envisage exciting open research directions that
have the potential to drive future advancements in achieving fairer FL
frameworks, in turn, offering a strong foundation for future research in this
pivotal area.

AI.tldr: A comprehensive survey of fairness in federated learning, analyzing bias sources, mitigation techniques, evaluation metrics, and future research directions.
AI.motivation: Federated Learning enables privacy-preserving, collaborative model training across multiple clients, but fairness is hindered by heterogeneity among data, clients, and models, leading to biased predictions, reduced accuracy, and slower convergence.
AI.method: Systematic literature review and synthesis that categorize bias types (data, client, model), summarize fairness notions and theoretical underpinnings, evaluate mitigation techniques, discuss evaluation metrics, and outline open research directions across multidisciplinary FL applications.
AI.result: Provides a detailed taxonomy of fairness notions, bias sources, and mitigation strategies; assesses strengths/limitations of existing approaches; surveys evaluation metrics; and highlights gaps and promising future directions for fairer FL.
AI.conclusion: Achieving fairer FL requires addressing heterogeneity-induced biases; the survey lays a foundational framework, clarifies theoretical and practical aspects, and proposes future research avenues to advance fairness in FL.

title: When Agents go Astray: Course-Correcting SWE Agents with PRMs
summary:
Large Language Model (LLM) agents are increasingly deployed for complex,
multi-step software engineering (SWE) tasks. However, their trajectories often
contain costly inefficiencies, such as redundant exploration, looping, and
failure to terminate once a solution is reached. Prior work has largely treated
these errors in a post-hoc manner, diagnosing failures only after execution. In
this paper, we introduce SWE-PRM, an inference-time Process Reward Model (PRM)
that intervenes during execution to detect and course-correct trajectory-level
errors. Our PRM design leverages a taxonomy of common inefficiencies and
delivers lightweight, interpretable feedback without modifying the underlying
policy. On SWE-bench Verified, closed-source PRMs improve resolution from 40.0%
to 50.6% (+10.6 p.p.), with the largest gains on medium and hard tasks. Among
feedback strategies, taxonomy-guided PRMs outperform unguided or explicit
action-prescriptive variants, increasing success rate while reducing trajectory
length. These benefits come at an acceptable added inference cost of as low as
$0.2, making PRMs a practical and scalable mechanism for improving SWE agents'
reliability and efficiency.

AI.tldr: SWE-PRM introduces an inference-time Process Reward Model to detect and fix trajectory-level inefficiencies in LLM-based SWE agents, boosting success rates and efficiency with minimal cost.
AI.motivation: To reduce costly trajectory inefficiencies (e.g., redundant exploration, looping, and failure to terminate) in LLM-driven SWE tasks, addressing the lack of real-time, during-execution correction found in prior post-hoc analyses.
AI.method: Apply a taxonomy of common inefficiencies to provide lightweight, interpretable feedback via an inference-time Process Reward Model that intervenes during execution without altering the underlying policy; evaluate on SWE-bench Verified with closed-source PRMs; compare taxonomy-guided vs unguided and action-prescriptive variants.
AI.result: Resolution improved from 40.0% to 50.6% (+10.6 percentage points); largest gains on medium and hard tasks; taxonomy-guided PRMs outperform unguided or action-prescriptive variants; higher success rate and shorter trajectories; added inference cost as low as $0.2.
AI.conclusion: Inference-time PRMs offer a practical, scalable mechanism to improve SWE agents’ reliability and efficiency by correcting trajectory-level errors without retraining, with taxonomy-guided strategies delivering the best performance at modest cost.

title: OpenGuide: Assistive Object Retrieval in Indoor Spaces for Individuals with Visual Impairments
summary:
Indoor built environments like homes and offices often present complex and
cluttered layouts that pose significant challenges for individuals who are
blind or visually impaired, especially when performing tasks that involve
locating and gathering multiple objects. While many existing assistive
technologies focus on basic navigation or obstacle avoidance, few systems
provide scalable and efficient multi-object search capabilities in real-world,
partially observable settings. To address this gap, we introduce OpenGuide, an
assistive mobile robot system that combines natural language understanding with
vision-language foundation models (VLM), frontier-based exploration, and a
Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP) planner. OpenGuide
interprets open-vocabulary requests, reasons about object-scene relationships,
and adaptively navigates and localizes multiple target items in novel
environments. Our approach enables robust recovery from missed detections
through value decay and belief-space reasoning, resulting in more effective
exploration and object localization. We validate OpenGuide in simulated and
real-world experiments, demonstrating substantial improvements in task success
rate and search efficiency over prior methods. This work establishes a
foundation for scalable, human-centered robotic assistance in assisted living
environments.

AI.tldr: OpenGuide is a robotic system that uses language, vision-language models, frontier exploration, and POMDP planning to efficiently locate multiple objects for visually impaired users, with robust recovery from missed detections; validated in simulation and on real hardware.
AI.motivation: Indoor cluttered layouts and partial observability in homes/offices create significant barriers for blind/VI users performing multi-object search. Existing assistive tech focuses on navigation/obstacle avoidance and lacks scalable, open-vocabulary, multi-object search in real-world settings.
AI.method: OpenGuide integrates open-vocabulary natural language understanding with vision-language foundation models to reason about object–scene relationships, uses frontier-based exploration for informative sensing, and employs a POMDP planner with belief-space reasoning and value decay to recover from missed detections. Evaluation includes both simulated and real-world experiments.
AI.result: Demonstrates substantial improvements in task success rate and search efficiency over prior methods, with robust recovery from missed detections and improved exploration in novel environments.
AI.conclusion: Provides a foundation for scalable, human-centered robotic assistance in assisted living, enabling flexible multi-object search in cluttered indoor environments and paving the way for broader adoption and future enhancements.

title: SegDINO: An Efficient Design for Medical and Natural Image Segmentation with DINO-V3
summary:
The DINO family of self-supervised vision models has shown remarkable
transferability, yet effectively adapting their representations for
segmentation remains challenging. Existing approaches often rely on heavy
decoders with multi-scale fusion or complex upsampling, which introduce
substantial parameter overhead and computational cost. In this work, we propose
SegDINO, an efficient segmentation framework that couples a frozen DINOv3
backbone with a lightweight decoder. SegDINO extracts multi-level features from
the pretrained encoder, aligns them to a common resolution and channel width,
and utilizes a lightweight MLP head to directly predict segmentation masks.
This design minimizes trainable parameters while preserving the
representational power of foundation features. Extensive experiments across six
benchmarks, including three medical datasets (TN3K, Kvasir-SEG, ISIC) and three
natural image datasets (MSD, VMD-D, ViSha), demonstrate that SegDINO
consistently achieves state-of-the-art performance compared to existing
methods. Code is available at https://github.com/script-Yang/SegDINO.

AI.tldr: SegDINO presents an efficient segmentation method by freezing a DINOv3 backbone and using a lightweight MLP decoder to produce segmentation masks from multi-level features, achieving state-of-the-art results across six benchmarks (three medical, three natural) with reduced parameter count.
AI.motivation: Segmentation with self-supervised DINO features is hindered by heavy decoders and high computational costs. There is a need for an efficient approach that preserves the power of foundation features while minimizing trainable parameters.
AI.method: Freeze the pretrained DINOv3 encoder to extract multi-level features. Align features to a common resolution and channel width. Apply a lightweight MLP head to directly predict segmentation masks, avoiding heavy decoders or complex upsampling. Trainable parameters are minimized while leveraging strong foundation features.
AI.result: Segmentations achieve state-of-the-art performance consistently across six benchmarks, including three medical datasets (TN3K, Kvasir-SEG, ISIC) and three natural-image datasets (MSD, VMD-D, ViSha). Code is available at the provided URL.
AI.conclusion: Efficiently leveraging frozen foundation representations with a compact decoder can deliver strong segmentation performance with reduced parameter overhead, making SegDINO a practical, high-performance segmentation framework.

authors: Enguerrand De Rautlin De La Roy
title: XAI-Driven Machine Learning System for Driving Style Recognition and Personalized Recommendations
summary:
Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly used in the automotive industry
for applications such as driving style classification, which aims to improve
road safety, efficiency, and personalize user experiences. While deep learning
(DL) models, such as Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, excel at this
task, their black-box nature limits interpretability and trust. This paper
proposes a machine learning (ML)-based method that balances high accuracy with
interpretability. We introduce a high-quality dataset, CARLA-Drive, and
leverage ML techniques like Random Forest (RF), Gradient Boosting (XGBoost),
and Support Vector Machine (SVM), which are efficient, lightweight, and
interpretable. In addition, we apply the SHAP (Shapley Additive Explanations)
explainability technique to provide personalized recommendations for safer
driving. Achieving an accuracy of 0.92 on a three-class classification task
with both RF and XGBoost classifiers, our approach matches DL models in
performance while offering transparency and practicality for real-world
deployment in intelligent transportation systems.

AI.tldr: An interpretable ML pipeline (RF, XGBoost, SVM) for driving style classification using CARLA-Drive, achieving 0.92 accuracy and SHAP-based explanations to enable personalized safety recommendations, matching DL performance with greater transparency.
AI.motivation: To improve road safety, efficiency, and personalized user experience in automotive AI while addressing the lack of interpretability in deep learning models.
AI.method: Introduce CARLA-Drive dataset; compare RF, Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), and SVM; apply SHAP explanations for interpretability; provide personalized driving safety recommendations; emphasize lightweight and practical deployment.
AI.result: Achieves 0.92 accuracy on a three-class task with RF and XGBoost; performance comparable to DL models; SHAP provides interpretable insights; suitable for real-world ITS deployment.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that accurate, interpretable ML models can match DL performance in driving style classification and enhance trust and practicality for deployment in intelligent transportation systems.

title: Towards Agents That Know When They Don't Know: Uncertainty as a Control Signal for Structured Reasoning
summary:
Large language model (LLM) agents are increasingly deployed in structured
