biomedical data environments, yet they often produce fluent but overconfident
outputs when reasoning over complex multi-table data. We introduce an
uncertainty-aware agent for query-conditioned multi-table summarization that
leverages two complementary signals: (i) retrieval uncertainty--entropy over
multiple table-selection rollouts--and (ii) summary uncertainty--combining
self-consistency and perplexity. Summary uncertainty is incorporated into
reinforcement learning (RL) with Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO),
while both retrieval and summary uncertainty guide inference-time filtering and
support the construction of higher-quality synthetic datasets.
  On multi-omics benchmarks, our approach improves factuality and calibration,
nearly tripling correct and useful claims per summary (3.0\(\rightarrow\)8.4
internal; 3.6\(\rightarrow\)9.9 cancer multi-omics) and substantially improving
downstream survival prediction (C-index 0.32\(\rightarrow\)0.63). These results
demonstrate that uncertainty can serve as a control signal--enabling agents to
abstain, communicate confidence, and become more reliable tools for complex
structured-data environments.

AI.tldr: Uncertainty-aware LLM agents improve reliability in query-conditioned multi-table biomedical summarization by using retrieval and summary uncertainty, with GRPO-based RL, boosting factuality and downstream predictions.
AI.motivation: LLMs in structured biomedical data environments often produce fluent but overconfident outputs when reasoning over complex multi-table sets; there is a need for uncertainty-aware mechanisms to improve factuality, calibration, and reliability.
AI.method: Introduce two complementary uncertainty signals: retrieval uncertainty (entropy over multiple table-selection rollouts) and summary uncertainty (self-consistency and perplexity). Use summary uncertainty in reinforcement learning via Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO); use both uncertainties to guide inference-time filtering and to construct higher-quality synthetic datasets.
AI.result: On multi-omics benchmarks, factuality and calibration improve; correct and useful claims per summary nearly tripled (from 3.0 to 8.4 internal; 3.6 to 9.9 cancer multi-omics); downstream survival prediction substantially improved (C-index 0.32 to 0.63).
AI.conclusion: Uncertainty can serve as a control signal enabling agents to abstain, communicate confidence, and become more reliable tools for complex structured-data environments.

title: U-ARM : Ultra low-cost general teleoperation interface for robot manipulation
summary:
We propose U-Arm, a low-cost and rapidly adaptable leader-follower
teleoperation framework designed to interface with most of commercially
available robotic arms. Our system supports teleoperation through three
structurally distinct 3D-printed leader arms that share consistent control
logic, enabling seamless compatibility with diverse commercial robot
configurations. Compared with previous open-source leader-follower interfaces,
we further optimized both the mechanical design and servo selection, achieving
a bill of materials (BOM) cost of only \$50.5 for the 6-DoF leader arm and
\$56.8 for the 7-DoF version. To enhance usability, we mitigate the common
challenge in controlling redundant degrees of freedom by %engineering methods
mechanical and control optimizations. Experimental results demonstrate that
U-Arm achieves 39\% higher data collection efficiency and comparable task
success rates across multiple manipulation scenarios compared with Joycon,
another low-cost teleoperation interface. We have open-sourced all CAD models
of three configs and also provided simulation support for validating
teleoperation workflows. We also open-sourced real-world manipulation data
collected with U-Arm. The project website is
https://github.com/MINT-SJTU/LeRobot-Anything-U-Arm.

AI.tldr: U-Arm is a low-cost, rapidly adaptable leader-follower teleoperation framework for a wide range of commercial robotic arms, with three 3D-printed configurations, ~$50–$57 BOM, improved data collection efficiency (39%) and comparable task success to Joycon, plus open-source CAD, simulation, and real-world data.
AI.motivation: Need for affordable, adaptable teleoperation interfaces that work across many arm configurations; reduce cost and complexity; address redundancy in DOF.
AI.method: Three structurally distinct, 3D-printed leader arms share a consistent control logic; optimized mechanical design and servo selection; controlled experiments comparing against Joycon; BOM calculation; open source CAD, simulation, and collected data.
AI.result: BOM costs: $50.5 (6-DoF) and $56.8 (7-DoF); 39% higher data collection efficiency; comparable task success rates across manipulation scenarios; open-source CAD for all configs; simulation support; real-world manipulation data.
AI.conclusion: U-Arm provides a cost-effective, adaptable teleoperation framework with broad hardware compatibility and useful open-source resources, enabling faster development and validation of teleoperation workflows.

title: Satellite Image Utilization for Dehazing with Swin Transformer-Hybrid U-Net and Watershed loss
summary:
Satellite imagery plays a crucial role in various fields; however,
atmospheric interference and haze significantly degrade image clarity and
reduce the accuracy of information extraction. To address these challenges,
this paper proposes a hybrid dehazing framework that integrates Swin
Transformer and U-Net to balance global context learning and local detail
restoration, called SUFERNOBWA. The proposed network employs SwinRRDB, a Swin
Transformer-based Residual-in-Residual Dense Block, in both the encoder and
decoder to effectively extract features. This module enables the joint learning
of global contextual information and fine spatial structures, which is crucial
for structural preservation in satellite image. Furthermore, we introduce a
composite loss function that combines L2 loss, guided loss, and a novel
watershed loss, which enhances structural boundary preservation and ensures
pixel-level accuracy. This architecture enables robust dehazing under diverse
atmospheric conditions while maintaining structural consistency across restored
images. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms
state-of-the-art models on both the RICE and SateHaze1K datasets. Specifically,
on the RICE dataset, the proposed approach achieved a PSNR of 33.24 dB and an
SSIM of 0.967, which is a significant improvement over existing method. This
study provides an effective solution for mitigating atmospheric interference in
satellite imagery and highlights its potential applicability across diverse
remote sensing applications.

AI.tldr: Hybrid SUFERNOBWA dehazing framework combining Swin Transformer and U-Net with SwinRRDB blocks and a watershed-guided loss, achieving state-of-the-art PSNR/SSIM on RICE and SateHaze1K.
AI.motivation: Atmospheric haze degrades satellite imagery, reducing information extraction accuracy. A model that balances global context with local detail while preserving structural integrity is needed.
AI.method: Proposes SUFERNOBWA, a hybrid architecture that uses SwinRRDB blocks in both encoder and decoder to capture global context and fine spatial details. It employs a composite loss combining L2, guided loss, and a novel watershed loss to enhance boundary preservation and pixel-level accuracy.
AI.result: Outperforms existing methods on RICE and SateHaze1K datasets. On RICE, achieves PSNR 33.24 dB and SSIM 0.967, indicating substantial improvement in both fidelity and structural preservation.
AI.conclusion: The approach provides an effective solution for mitigating atmospheric interference in satellite imagery, delivering robust dehazing with preserved structural consistency, applicable across diverse remote sensing tasks.

title: Crystal Structure Prediction with a Geometric Permutation-Invariant Loss Function
summary:
Crystalline structure prediction remains an open challenge in materials
design. Despite recent advances in computational materials science, accurately
predicting the three-dimensional crystal structures of organic materials--an
essential first step for designing materials with targeted properties--remains
elusive. In this work, we address the problem of molecular assembly, where a
set $\mathcal{S}$ of identical rigid molecules is packed to form a crystalline
structure. Existing state-of-the-art models typically rely on computationally
expensive, iterative flow-matching approaches. We propose a novel loss function
that correctly captures key geometric molecular properties while maintaining
permutation invariance over $\mathcal{S}$. We achieve this via a differentiable
linear assignment scheme based on the Sinkhorn algorithm. Remarkably, we show
that even a simple regression using our method {\em SinkFast} significantly
outperforms more complex flow-matching approaches on the COD-Cluster17
benchmark, a curated subset of the Crystallography Open Database (COD).

AI.tldr: SinkFast: a differentiable Sinkhorn-based loss for molecular assembly that is permutation-invariant and outperforms flow-matching on COD-Cluster17.
AI.motivation: Predicting the 3D crystal structures of organic materials remains a challenging problem; existing state-of-the-art flow-matching approaches are computationally expensive. There is a need for an efficient, geometry-aware, permutation-invariant loss.
AI.method: Introduce a differentiable linear assignment scheme based on the Sinkhorn algorithm to create a permutation-invariant loss over a set of identical rigid molecules; apply this loss to simple regression (SinkFast).
AI.result: Regression with SinkFast significantly outperforms more complex flow-matching methods on the COD-Cluster17 benchmark.
AI.conclusion: A simple, differentiable, permutation-invariant Sinkhorn-based loss effectively improves molecular assembly-based crystal structure prediction and offers a lighter alternative to flow-matching approaches.

title: AppCopilot: Toward General, Accurate, Long-Horizon, and Efficient Mobile Agent
summary:
With the raid evolution of large language models and multimodal foundation
models, the mobile-agent landscape has proliferated without converging on the
fundamental challenges. This paper identifies four core problems that must be
solved for mobile agents to deliver practical, scalable impact: (1)
generalization across tasks, modalities, apps, and devices; (2) accuracy,
specifically precise on-screen interaction and click targeting; (3)
long-horizon capability for sustained, multi-step goals; and (4) efficiency,
specifically high-performance runtime on resource-constrained devices. We
present AppCopilot, a multimodal, multi-agent, general-purpose on-device
assistant that operates across applications and constitutes a full-stack,
closed-loop system from data to deployment. AppCopilot operationalizes this
position through an end-to-end autonomous pipeline spanning data collection,
training, deployment, high-quality and efficient inference, and mobile
application development. At the model layer, it integrates multimodal
foundation models with robust Chinese-English support. At the reasoning and
control layer, it combines chain-of-thought reasoning, hierarchical task
planning and decomposition, and multi-agent collaboration. At the execution
layer, it enables user personalization and experiential adaptation, voice
interaction, function calling, cross-app and cross-device orchestration, and
comprehensive mobile app support. The system design incorporates
profiling-driven optimization for latency, memory, and energy across
heterogeneous hardware. Empirically, AppCopilot achieves significant
improvements along all four dimensions: stronger generalization,
higher-precision on-screen actions, more reliable long-horizon task completion,
and faster, more resource-efficient runtime.

AI.tldr: AppCopilot presents a multimodal, on-device, multi-agent mobile assistant designed to generalize across tasks, achieve precise on-screen actions, plan long-horizon goals, and run efficiently on resource-constrained devices, via an end-to-end full-stack pipeline and optimized architecture.
AI.motivation: Mobile agent systems struggle to generalize across tasks, achieve precise interaction, maintain long-horizon planning, and operate efficiently on constrained hardware. On-device solutions can improve privacy, latency, and energy efficiency while enabling broad applicability across apps and devices.
AI.method: End-to-end autonomous pipeline from data collection to deployment and efficient inference. Model layer with multimodal foundation models and robust bilingual support; reasoning/control with chain-of-thought, hierarchical task planning and multi-agent collaboration; execution layer featuring personalization, voice, function calling, cross-app/cross-device orchestration, and comprehensive mobile app support. System optimizes latency, memory, and energy via profiling-driven adaptation across heterogeneous hardware.
AI.result: AppCopilot achieves notable improvements across four core dimensions: stronger generalization across tasks/modalities/apps/devices; higher-precision on-screen actions; more reliable long-horizon task completion; and faster, more resource-efficient runtime.
AI.conclusion: A full-stack, on-device mobile-agent framework that integrates multimodal models, advanced planning, and cross-app orchestration, demonstrating practical feasibility and providing a blueprint for scalable, efficient mobile AI assistants.

title: Coral: A Unifying Abstraction Layer for Composable Robotics Software
summary:
Despite the multitude of excellent software components and tools available in
the robotics and broader software engineering communities, successful
integration of software for robotic systems remains a time-consuming and
challenging task for users of all knowledge and skill levels. And with robotics
software often being built into tightly coupled, monolithic systems, even minor
alterations to improve performance, adjust to changing task requirements, or
deploy to new hardware can require significant engineering investment. To help
solve this problem, this paper presents Coral, an abstraction layer for
building, deploying, and coordinating independent software components that
maximizes composability to allow for rapid system integration without modifying
low-level code. Rather than replacing existing tools, Coral complements them by
introducing a higher-level abstraction that constrains the integration process
to semantically meaningful choices, reducing the configuration burden without
limiting adaptability to diverse domains, systems, and tasks. We describe Coral
in detail and demonstrate its utility in integrating software for scenarios of
increasing complexity, including LiDAR-based SLAM and multi-robot corrosion
mitigation tasks. By enabling practical composability in robotics software,
Coral offers a scalable solution to a broad range of robotics system
integration challenges, improving component reusability, system
reconfigurability, and accessibility to both expert and non-expert users. We
release Coral open source.

AI.tldr: Coral provides a higher-level abstraction layer that enables composable, independent software components in robotics, improving integration, reusability, and configurability without modifying low-level code; demonstrated on LiDAR-SLAM and multi-robot tasks; open-sourced.
AI.motivation: Robotics software is often tightly coupled and monolithic, making integration and adaptation time-consuming; users across skill levels struggle to assemble reliable systems from diverse components; there is a need for a layer that constrains integration to semantically meaningful choices to reduce configuration burden while preserving adaptability.
AI.method: Introduce Coral as an abstraction layer for building, deploying, and coordinating software components; it complements existing tools by providing high-level constraints that guide integration; describes Coral architecture and semantics; demonstrates on LiDAR-based SLAM and multi-robot corrosion mitigation tasks; evaluations revolve around composability, reusability, and configurability; open-source release.
AI.result: Coral improves practical composability in robotics software, enabling rapid integration, better component reusability, system reconfigurability, and accessibility for both expert and non-expert users; reduces configuration burden while supporting diverse domains; case studies show enabling integration of LiDAR-SLAM and multi-robot tasks without modifying low-level code.
AI.conclusion: Coral offers a scalable solution to robotics system integration challenges by providing a higher-level abstraction that complements existing tools, enhancing composability and accessibility; open-source release to foster adoption.

title: Look Beyond: Two-Stage Scene View Generation via Panorama and Video Diffusion
summary:
Novel view synthesis (NVS) from a single image is highly ill-posed due to
large unobserved regions, especially for views that deviate significantly from
the input. While existing methods focus on consistency between the source and
generated views, they often fail to maintain coherence and correct view
alignment across long-range or looped trajectories. We propose a model that
addresses this by decomposing single-view NVS into a 360-degree scene
extrapolation followed by novel view interpolation. This design ensures
long-term view and scene consistency by conditioning on keyframes extracted and
warped from a generated panoramic representation. In the first stage, a
panorama diffusion model learns the scene prior from the input perspective
image. Perspective keyframes are then sampled and warped from the panorama and
used as anchor frames in a pre-trained video diffusion model, which generates
novel views through a proposed spatial noise diffusion process. Compared to
prior work, our method produces globally consistent novel views -- even in loop
closure scenarios -- while enabling flexible camera control. Experiments on
diverse scene datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing
methods in generating coherent views along user-defined trajectories. Our
implementation is available at https://github.com/YiGuYT/LookBeyond.

AI.tldr: A two-stage NVS method that first extrapolates a 360-degree panorama from a single image and then warps keyframes into a video diffusion model, achieving globally coherent views along arbitrary trajectories, including loop closures.
AI.motivation: Single-image novel view synthesis is highly ill-posed; existing methods struggle to maintain long-range coherence and handle loop closure. A global scene prior and stable anchors are needed to ensure consistent views across trajectories.
AI.method: Stage 1: Learn a panorama diffusion model from the input perspective image to capture a 360-degree scene prior; sample and warp perspective keyframes from the panorama to serve as anchors. Stage 2: Use a pre-trained video diffusion model conditioned on these anchors and a spatial noise diffusion process to generate novel views along a user-defined trajectory.
AI.result: The approach yields globally consistent novel views along long trajectories and loop closures, outperforming existing methods on diverse scene datasets. Code is released by the authors.
AI.conclusion: A two-stage panorama-to-video diffusion framework provides long-term view and scene consistency, flexible camera control, and robust performance for single-image NVS.

title: Causal SHAP: Feature Attribution with Dependency Awareness through Causal Discovery
comment:
Published in 2025 International Joint Conference on Neural Networks
  (IJCNN). IEEE, 2025
summary:
Explaining machine learning (ML) predictions has become crucial as ML models
are increasingly deployed in high-stakes domains such as healthcare. While
SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) is widely used for model interpretability,
it fails to differentiate between causality and correlation, often
misattributing feature importance when features are highly correlated. We
propose Causal SHAP, a novel framework that integrates causal relationships
into feature attribution while preserving many desirable properties of SHAP. By
combining the Peter-Clark (PC) algorithm for causal discovery and the
Intervention Calculus when the DAG is Absent (IDA) algorithm for causal
strength quantification, our approach addresses the weakness of SHAP.
Specifically, Causal SHAP reduces attribution scores for features that are
merely correlated with the target, as validated through experiments on both
synthetic and real-world datasets. This study contributes to the field of
Explainable AI (XAI) by providing a practical framework for causal-aware model
explanations. Our approach is particularly valuable in domains such as
healthcare, where understanding true causal relationships is critical for
informed decision-making.

AI.tldr: Causal SHAP combines SHAP with PC discovery and IDA causal strength to separate causal from correlational feature attributions, mitigating SHAP's misattribution due to correlated features.
AI.motivation: SHAP struggles to distinguish causality from correlation, leading to misleading attributions in high-stakes domains; there is a need for causal-aware explanations, especially in healthcare.
AI.method: Integrate the PC algorithm for causal discovery with the IDA algorithm to quantify causal strengths, then adjust SHAP-based attributions to reflect causal relationships—reducing scores for non-causal correlated features while preserving SHAP-like properties.
AI.result: Empirical validation on synthetic and real-world datasets shows attribution reductions for merely correlated features and improved differentiation between causal and correlated features, supporting practical utility in XAI.
AI.conclusion: Provides a practical, causal-aware attribution framework that preserves SHAP's useful properties while addressing its causal limitations, with particular value for healthcare and other high-stakes domains.

title: GridMind: LLMs-Powered Agents for Power System Analysis and Operations
comment: 11 pages, 9 figures, 2 tables. Work under review
summary:
The complexity of traditional power system analysis workflows presents
significant barriers to efficient decision-making in modern electric grids.
This paper presents GridMind, a multi-agent AI system that integrates Large
Language Models (LLMs) with deterministic engineering solvers to enable
conversational scientific computing for power system analysis. The system
employs specialized agents coordinating AC Optimal Power Flow and N-1
contingency analysis through natural language interfaces while maintaining
numerical precision via function calls. GridMind addresses workflow
integration, knowledge accessibility, context preservation, and expert
decision-support augmentation. Experimental evaluation on IEEE test cases
demonstrates that the proposed agentic framework consistently delivers correct
solutions across all tested language models, with smaller LLMs achieving
comparable analytical accuracy with reduced computational latency. This work
establishes agentic AI as a viable paradigm for scientific computing,
demonstrating how conversational interfaces can enhance accessibility while
preserving numerical rigor essential for critical engineering applications.

AI.tldr: GridMind is a multi-agent AI system that blends LLMs with deterministic power-system solvers to enable conversational scientific computing for AC OPF and N-1 contingency analysis, preserving numerical precision while improving accessibility and workflow integration.
AI.motivation: Traditional power system analysis workflows are complex and impede timely decision-making. There is a need to fuse natural language interfaces with rigorous engineering solvers to improve accessibility, knowledge reuse, and expert decision-support without sacrificing numerical rigor.
AI.method: Design and implement GridMind with specialized agents that coordinate AC Optimal Power Flow and N-1 contingency analysis via natural language interfaces, while preserving numerical precision through function calls to deterministic solvers. Evaluate on IEEE test cases to assess accuracy and latency across language models.
AI.result: The agentic framework consistently yields correct solutions across all tested language models. Smaller LLMs achieve comparable analytical accuracy with reduced computational latency.
AI.conclusion: Agentic AI is a viable paradigm for scientific computing; conversational interfaces can enhance accessibility and collaboration while maintaining the numerical rigor essential for critical engineering applications.

title: Classification of Vision-Based Tactile Sensors: A Review
summary:
Vision-based tactile sensors (VBTS) have gained widespread application in
robotic hands, grippers and prosthetics due to their high spatial resolution,
low manufacturing costs, and ease of customization. While VBTSs have common
design features, such as a camera module, they can differ in a rich diversity
of sensing principles, material compositions, multimodal approaches, and data
interpretation methods. Here, we propose a novel classification of VBTS that
categorizes the technology into two primary sensing principles based on the
underlying transduction of contact into a tactile image: the Marker-Based
Transduction Principle and the Intensity-Based Transduction Principle.
Marker-Based Transduction interprets tactile information by detecting marker
displacement and changes in marker density. In contrast, Intensity-Based
Transduction maps external disturbances with variations in pixel values.
Depending on the design of the contact module, Marker-Based Transduction can be
further divided into two subtypes: Simple Marker-Based (SMB) and Morphological
Marker-Based (MMB) mechanisms. Similarly, the Intensity-Based Transduction
Principle encompasses the Reflective Layer-based (RLB) and Transparent
Layer-Based (TLB) mechanisms. This paper provides a comparative study of the
hardware characteristics of these four types of sensors including various
combination types, and discusses the commonly used methods for interpreting
tactile information. This~comparison reveals some current challenges faced by
VBTS technology and directions for future research.

AI.tldr: A proposed two-principle taxonomy for vision-based tactile sensors (VBTS): Marker-Based and Intensity-Based transduction, with SMB/MMB subtypes under Marker-Based and RLB/TLB under Intensity-Based, accompanied by a hardware-focused comparison and a discussion of interpretation methods, challenges, and future directions.
AI.motivation: To organize the diverse VBTS designs into a coherent framework, enabling standardized comparison of hardware characteristics and interpretation strategies across architectures.
AI.method: A literature-driven comparative study that (i) defines a four-type taxonomy (SMB, MMB, RLB, TLB) based on transduction principles, (ii) surveys hardware configurations and combinations within these types, and (iii) reviews common tactile-information interpretation methods, culminating in a synthesis of challenges and future directions.
AI.result: Introduction of a two-principle classification of VBTS (Marker-Based vs Intensity-Based) with two subtypes each (SMB/MMB; RLB/TLB); a hardware-oriented comparison across the four types, and a discussion of prevailing interpretation methods; identification of key challenges and suggested directions for future research.
AI.conclusion: The taxonomy clarifies the VBTS landscape, enabling more systematic hardware design and interpretation strategies, and highlights practical challenges and research gaps to guide future work.

title: Quantization Meets OOD: Generalizable Quantization-aware Training from a Flatness Perspective
summary:
Current quantization-aware training (QAT) methods primarily focus on
enhancing the performance of quantized models on in-distribution (I.D) data,
while overlooking the potential performance degradation on out-of-distribution
(OOD) data. In this paper, we first substantiate this problem through rigorous
experiment, showing that QAT can lead to a significant OOD generalization
performance degradation. Further, we find the contradiction between the
perspective that flatness of loss landscape gives rise to superior OOD
generalization and the phenomenon that QAT lead to a sharp loss landscape, can
cause the above problem. Therefore, we propose a flatness-oriented QAT method,
FQAT, to achieve generalizable QAT. Specifically, i) FQAT introduces a
layer-wise freezing mechanism to mitigate the gradient conflict issue between
dual optimization objectives (i.e., vanilla QAT and flatness). ii) FQAT
proposes an disorder-guided adaptive freezing algorithm to dynamically
determines which layers to freeze at each training step, effectively addressing
the challenges caused by interference between layers. A gradient disorder
metric is designed to help the algorithm identify unstable layers during
training. Extensive experiments on influential OOD benchmark demonstrate the
superiority of our method over state-of-the-art baselines under both I.D and
OOD image classification tasks.

AI.tldr: QAT improves ID accuracy but harms OOD generalization; FQAT introduces layer-wise freezing and a disorder-guided adaptive freezing strategy to align optimization with loss flatness, yielding better ID and OOD performance.
AI.motivation: Existing QAT methods optimize for in-distribution accuracy and often degrade performance on out-of-distribution data. There is a tension between flatness of the loss landscape (often linked to good OOD generalization) and QAT’s tendency to sharpen the landscape.
AI.method: Propose FQAT: (1) layer-wise freezing to reduce gradient conflicts between vanilla QAT objectives and flatness objectives; (2) a disorder-guided adaptive freezing algorithm that dynamically selects which layers to freeze each step using a gradient disorder metric to identify unstable layers; (3) evaluation on standard OOD benchmarks for image classification showing improved generalization.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on influential OOD benchmarks show FQAT outperforms state-of-the-art baselines on both ID and OOD image classification tasks, indicating better generalization under distribution shifts.
AI.conclusion: FQAT offers a practical QAT framework that promotes loss flatness and reduces inter-layer interference, achieving superior generalization for quantized models on both in-distribution and out-of-distribution data.

title: Predicting Multi-Type Talented Students in Secondary School Using Semi-Supervised Machine Learning
summary:
Talent identification plays a critical role in promoting student development.
However, traditional approaches often rely on manual processes or focus
narrowly on academic achievement, and typically delaying intervention until the
higher education stage. This oversight overlooks diverse non-academic talents
and misses opportunities for early intervention. To address this gap, this
study introduces TalentPredictor, a novel semi-supervised multi-modal neural
network that combines Transformer, LSTM, and ANN architectures. This model is
designed to predict seven different talent types--academic, sport, art,
leadership, service, technology, and others--in secondary school students
within an offline educational setting. Drawing on existing offline educational
data from 1,041 local secondary students, TalentPredictor overcomes the
limitations of traditional talent identification methods. By clustering various
award records into talent categories and extracting features from students'
diverse learning behaviors, it achieves high prediction accuracy (0.908
classification accuracy, 0.908 ROCAUC). This demonstrates the potential of
machine learning to identify diverse talents early in student development.

AI.tldr: Semi-supervised multi-modal TalentPredictor predicts seven talent types in secondary students using offline data, achieving 0.908 accuracy and ROC-AUC; addresses early talent identification beyond academics.
AI.motivation: Identify diverse non-academic talents early; current talent ID methods rely on manual processes and focus on academic achievement, delaying intervention; opportunity for early support in secondary education.
AI.method: Proposes TalentPredictor, a semi-supervised multi-modal neural network integrating Transformer, LSTM, and ANN; clusters award records into talent categories; extracts features from students' learning behaviors; trained on 1,041 offline local secondary students.
AI.result: Achieves 0.908 classification accuracy and 0.908 ROC-AUC on the offline dataset.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates potential of machine learning to identify diverse talents early in student development and enable timely interventions.

title: UI-TARS-2 Technical Report: Advancing GUI Agent with Multi-Turn Reinforcement Learning
summary:
The development of autonomous agents for graphical user interfaces (GUIs)
presents major challenges in artificial intelligence. While recent advances in
native agent models have shown promise by unifying perception, reasoning,
action, and memory through end-to-end learning, open problems remain in data
scalability, multi-turn reinforcement learning (RL), the limitations of
GUI-only operation, and environment stability. In this technical report, we
present UI-TARS-2, a native GUI-centered agent model that addresses these
challenges through a systematic training methodology: a data flywheel for
scalable data generation, a stabilized multi-turn RL framework, a hybrid GUI
environment that integrates file systems and terminals, and a unified sandbox
platform for large-scale rollouts. Empirical evaluation demonstrates that
UI-TARS-2 achieves significant improvements over its predecessor UI-TARS-1.5.
On GUI benchmarks, it reaches 88.2 on Online-Mind2Web, 47.5 on OSWorld, 50.6 on
WindowsAgentArena, and 73.3 on AndroidWorld, outperforming strong baselines
such as Claude and OpenAI agents. In game environments, it attains a mean
normalized score of 59.8 across a 15-game suite-roughly 60% of human-level
performance-and remains competitive with frontier proprietary models (e.g.,
OpenAI o3) on LMGame-Bench. Additionally, the model can generalize to
long-horizon information-seeking tasks and software engineering benchmarks,
highlighting its robustness across diverse agent tasks. Detailed analyses of
training dynamics further provide insights into achieving stability and
efficiency in large-scale agent RL. These results underscore UI-TARS-2's
potential to advance the state of GUI agents and exhibit strong generalization
to real-world interactive scenarios.

AI.tldr: UI-TARS-2 is a native GUI-centered agent that tackles data scalability, multi-turn RL stability, and environment limitations via a data flywheel, stabilized multi-turn RL, a hybrid GUI environment, and large-scale sandbox rollouts; it yields strong GUI benchmark performance, competitive game scores, and broad generalization.
AI.motivation: Address core AI challenges in GUI agents: data scalability for RL, effective multi-turn decision making, GUI-only operation limitations, and unstable training in large-scale agent systems.
AI.method: Introduce UI-TARS-2 with (1) a data flywheel to scale data generation, (2) a stabilized multi-turn RL framework, (3) a hybrid GUI environment integrating file systems and terminals, and (4) a unified sandbox platform for large-scale rollouts.
AI.result: On GUI benchmarks: 88.2 Online-Mind2Web, 47.5 OSWorld, 50.6 WindowsAgentArena, 73.3 AndroidWorld; in game environments: mean normalized score 59.8 across 15 games (~60% of human performance); competitive with frontier models (e.g., OpenAI o3); generalizes to long-horizon information-seeking tasks and software-engineering benchmarks; training dynamics provide insights into stability and efficiency.
AI.conclusion: UI-TARS-2 advances GUI agents with improved scalability, stability, and generalization, showing robust performance across GUI and game tasks and promising applicability to real-world interactive scenarios.

title: Fault-tolerant Model Predictive Control for Spacecraft
comment: The paper has been submitted to CDC2025
summary:
Given the cost and critical functions of satellite constellations, ensuring
mission longevity and safe decommissioning is essential for space
sustainability. This article presents a Model Predictive Control for spacecraft
trajectory and setpoint stabilization under multiple actuation failures. The
proposed solution allows us to efficiently control the faulty spacecraft
enabling safe navigation towards servicing or collision-free trajectories. The
proposed scheme ensures closed-loop asymptotic stability and is shown to be
recursively feasible. We demonstrate its efficacy through open-source numerical
results and realistic experiments using the ATMOS platform.

AI.tldr: An MPC framework for fault-tolerant spacecraft control under actuation failures, delivering stable, feasible trajectories for servicing or collision-free paths; validated numerically and on ATMOS experiments.
AI.motivation: Ensure space mission longevity and safe decommissioning by enabling fault-tolerant control of faulty spacecraft to maintain safe trajectories.
AI.method: Model Predictive Control for trajectory and setpoint stabilization under multiple actuation failures, with proofs of closed-loop asymptotic stability and recursive feasibility; validation through open-source numerical results and ATMOS-based experiments.
AI.result: Demonstrates closed-loop asymptotic stability and recursive feasibility; shows effective fault-tolerant trajectory control in simulations and realistic experiments.
AI.conclusion: The MPC approach provides robust, fault-tolerant navigation for servicing or collision-free trajectories, contributing to space sustainability and safe decommissioning.

title: Pose as Clinical Prior: Learning Dual Representations for Scoliosis Screening
summary:
Recent AI-based scoliosis screening methods primarily rely on large-scale
silhouette datasets, often neglecting clinically relevant postural
asymmetries-key indicators in traditional screening. In contrast, pose data
provide an intuitive skeletal representation, enhancing clinical
interpretability across various medical applications. However, pose-based
scoliosis screening remains underexplored due to two main challenges: (1) the
scarcity of large-scale, annotated pose datasets; and (2) the discrete and
noise-sensitive nature of raw pose coordinates, which hinders the modeling of
subtle asymmetries. To address these limitations, we introduce
Scoliosis1K-Pose, a 2D human pose annotation set that extends the original
Scoliosis1K dataset, comprising 447,900 frames of 2D keypoints from 1,050
adolescents. Building on this dataset, we introduce the Dual Representation
Framework (DRF), which integrates a continuous skeleton map to preserve spatial
structure with a discrete Postural Asymmetry Vector (PAV) that encodes
clinically relevant asymmetry descriptors. A novel PAV-Guided Attention (PGA)
module further uses the PAV as clinical prior to direct feature extraction from
the skeleton map, focusing on clinically meaningful asymmetries. Extensive
experiments demonstrate that DRF achieves state-of-the-art performance.
Visualizations further confirm that the model leverages clinical asymmetry cues
to guide feature extraction and promote synergy between its dual
representations. The dataset and code are publicly available at
https://zhouzi180.github.io/Scoliosis1K/.

AI.tldr: A pose-based scoliosis screening framework (DRF) using the extended Scoliosis1K-Pose dataset achieves state-of-the-art results by fusing a continuous skeleton map with a discrete Postural Asymmetry Vector (PAV), guided by a PAV-Guided Attention module; dataset and code are released.
AI.motivation: To address (1) scarcity of large-scale, annotated pose datasets for scoliosis screening and (2) the noise and discreteness of pose coordinates that hamper modeling subtle asymmetries, while enhancing clinical interpretability of pose-based methods.
AI.method: Extend Scoliosis1K to Scoliosis1K-Pose with 447,900 frames of 2D keypoints from 1,050 adolescents. Propose a Dual Representation Framework (DRF) that combines a continuous skeleton map to preserve spatial structure with a discrete Postural Asymmetry Vector (PAV) encoding clinically relevant asymmetry descriptors. Introduce a PAV-Guided Attention (PGA) module that uses PAV as a clinical prior to guide feature extraction from the skeleton map, focusing on meaningful asymmetries.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show DRF achieves state-of-the-art performance. Visualizations indicate the model leverages clinical asymmetry cues to guide feature extraction and reveals synergy between the dual representations.
AI.conclusion: DRF demonstrates the effectiveness of dual representations and the PGA module in clinically meaningful pose-based scoliosis screening; the dataset and code are publicly available for further research.

title: Tabular Diffusion Counterfactual Explanations
summary:
Counterfactual explanations methods provide an important tool in the field of
{interpretable machine learning}. Recent advances in this direction have
focused on diffusion models to explain a deep classifier. However, these
techniques have predominantly focused on problems in computer vision. In this
paper, we focus on tabular data typical in finance and the social sciences and
propose a novel guided reverse process for categorical features based on an
approximation to the Gumbel-softmax distribution. Furthermore, we study the
effect of the temperature $\tau$ and derive a theoretical bound between the
Gumbel-softmax distribution and our proposed approximated distribution. We
perform experiments on several large-scale credit lending and other tabular
datasets, assessing their performance in terms of the quantitative measures of
interpretability, diversity, instability, and validity. These results indicate
that our approach outperforms popular baseline methods, producing robust and
realistic counterfactual explanations.

AI.tldr: Introduces a diffusion-based counterfactual explainer for tabular data with categorical features using a Gumbel-softmax-like approximation; provides a theoretical bound on distributions and shows superior performance vs baselines on credit lending datasets.
AI.motivation: Addresses the need for interpretable explanations in tabular data (finance/social sciences) and extends diffusion-based counterfactuals beyond computer vision, handling categorical features.
AI.method: Proposes a guided reverse process for categorical features via an approximation to the Gumbel-softmax distribution; analyzes the effect of temperature τ; derives a theoretical bound between Gumbel-softmax and the proposed distribution; evaluates on large-scale credit lending and other tabular datasets.
AI.result: Outperforms popular baselines in interpretability, diversity, instability, and validity; produces robust and realistic counterfactual explanations; demonstrates effectiveness on credit lending and other tabular datasets.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method provides more robust and realistic counterfactual explanations for tabular data and contributes theoretical insight through a distribution bound, with demonstrated superiority over existing baselines in finance-related datasets.

title: The Landscape of Agentic Reinforcement Learning for LLMs: A Survey
summary:
The emergence of agentic reinforcement learning (Agentic RL) marks a paradigm
shift from conventional reinforcement learning applied to large language models
(LLM RL), reframing LLMs from passive sequence generators into autonomous,
decision-making agents embedded in complex, dynamic worlds. This survey
formalizes this conceptual shift by contrasting the degenerate single-step
Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) of LLM-RL with the temporally extended,
partially observable Markov decision processes (POMDPs) that define Agentic RL.
Building on this foundation, we propose a comprehensive twofold taxonomy: one
organized around core agentic capabilities, including planning, tool use,
memory, reasoning, self-improvement, and perception, and the other around their
applications across diverse task domains. Central to our thesis is that
reinforcement learning serves as the critical mechanism for transforming these
capabilities from static, heuristic modules into adaptive, robust agentic
behavior. To support and accelerate future research, we consolidate the
landscape of open-source environments, benchmarks, and frameworks into a
practical compendium. By synthesizing over five hundred recent works, this
survey charts the contours of this rapidly evolving field and highlights the
opportunities and challenges that will shape the development of scalable,
general-purpose AI agents.

AI.tldr: Comprehensive survey of Agentic RL: formalizes agenticRL as temporally extended POMDPs, offers a twofold taxonomy of capabilities and applications, argues reinforcement learning is key to adaptive agent behavior, and provides a practical compendium of environments, benchmarks, and frameworks, synthesizing 500+ works to map opportunities and challenges.
AI.motivation: To move beyond passive LLM RL (single-step MDPs) toward autonomous agents operating in dynamic, partially observable worlds; formalize the paradigm, identify core capabilities, and accelerate progress through shared resources.
AI.method: Develop a conceptual framework contrasting single-step MDPs with POMDPs; propose a twofold taxonomy: (1) agentic capabilities (planning, tool use, memory, reasoning, self-improvement, perception) and (2) applications across domains; synthesize 500+ recent works; consolidate open-source environments, benchmarks, and frameworks into a practical compendium.
AI.result: A formal framework and dual taxonomy for Agentic RL, plus a consolidated compendium of environments/benchmarks/frameworks. The survey maps the field’s landscape, clarifies opportunities and challenges, and provides guidance toward scalable, general-purpose AI agents.
AI.conclusion: Reinforcement learning is the critical mechanism for transforming agentic capabilities from static modules into adaptive, robust behaviors; the field is rapidly evolving, with a clear research roadmap and resource base to guide future work.

title: Manipulation as in Simulation: Enabling Accurate Geometry Perception in Robots
summary:
Modern robotic manipulation primarily relies on visual observations in a 2D
color space for skill learning but suffers from poor generalization. In
contrast, humans, living in a 3D world, depend more on physical properties-such
as distance, size, and shape-than on texture when interacting with objects.
Since such 3D geometric information can be acquired from widely available depth
cameras, it appears feasible to endow robots with similar perceptual
capabilities. Our pilot study found that using depth cameras for manipulation
is challenging, primarily due to their limited accuracy and susceptibility to
various types of noise. In this work, we propose Camera Depth Models (CDMs) as
a simple plugin on daily-use depth cameras, which take RGB images and raw depth
signals as input and output denoised, accurate metric depth. To achieve this,
we develop a neural data engine that generates high-quality paired data from
simulation by modeling a depth camera's noise pattern. Our results show that
CDMs achieve nearly simulation-level accuracy in depth prediction, effectively
bridging the sim-to-real gap for manipulation tasks. Notably, our experiments
demonstrate, for the first time, that a policy trained on raw simulated depth,
without the need for adding noise or real-world fine-tuning, generalizes
seamlessly to real-world robots on two challenging long-horizon tasks involving
articulated, reflective, and slender objects, with little to no performance
degradation. We hope our findings will inspire future research in utilizing
simulation data and 3D information in general robot policies.

AI.tldr: Proposes Camera Depth Models (CDMs) that denoise and convert raw depth from RGB-D cameras into accurate metric depth using a neural data engine trained on simulated noise patterns; demonstrates near-simulation depth accuracy and zero-shot sim-to-real transfer for long-horizon robotic manipulation without real-world fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: Robotic manipulation often relies on 2D RGB streams, which generalize poorly; humans use 3D geometric cues. Depth cameras offer 3D information but suffer from noise and inaccuracies, hindering real-world transfer. A reliable, easy-to-deploy depth perception module could bridge the sim-to-real gap.
AI.method: Introduce Camera Depth Models (CDMs) as a plugin for common depth cameras. Use a neural data engine that creates high-quality RGB-D paired data from simulation by modeling the camera's noise. Train CDMs to output denoised, accurate metric depth from RGB images and raw depth maps.
AI.result: CDMs achieve nearly simulation-level depth accuracy, enabling policies trained on simulated depth to transfer to real robots without real-world fine-tuning. Demonstrated on two long-horizon tasks with articulated, reflective, and slender objects, showing limited performance degradation in real-world transfer.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging simulated data and 3D depth information via CDMs can bridge the sim-to-real gap in manipulation policies, encouraging further exploration of depth-based perception and simulation-to-reality transfer.

title: Spotlighter: Revisiting Prompt Tuning from a Representative Mining View
summary:
CLIP's success has demonstrated that prompt tuning can achieve robust
cross-modal semantic alignment for tasks ranging from open-domain recognition
to fine-grained classification. However, redundant or weakly relevant feature
components introduce noise and incur unnecessary computational costs. In this
work, we propose Spotlighter, a lightweight token-selection framework that
simultaneously enhances accuracy and efficiency in prompt tuning. Spotlighter
evaluates each visual token's activation from both sample-wise and
semantic-wise perspectives and retains only the top-scoring tokens for
downstream prediction. A class-specific semantic memory bank of learned
prototypes refines this selection, ensuring semantic representativeness and
compensating for discarded features. To further prioritize informative signals,
we introduce a two-level ranking mechanism that dynamically weights
token--prototype interactions. Across 11 few-shot benchmarks, Spotlighter
outperforms CLIP by up to 11.19\% in harmonic mean accuracy and achieves up to
0.8K additional FPS, with only 21 extra parameters. These results establish
Spotlighter as an effective and scalable baseline for prompt tuning. Code for
our method will be available at
https://github.com/greatest-gourmet/Spotlighter.

AI.tldr: Spotlighter is a lightweight token-selection framework for prompt tuning in CLIP that jointly uses sample-wise and semantic-wise token activations, a class-specific semantic memory bank, and a two-level ranking to select the most informative visual tokens, improving accuracy and efficiency with minimal parameter overhead.
AI.motivation: Redundant or weakly relevant visual features introduce noise and increase computation in prompt tuning for cross-modal alignment. A compact, effective token selection mechanism is needed to boost accuracy while reducing cost.
AI.method: Spotlighter evaluates each visual token's activation from both sample-wise and semantic-wise perspectives and retains the top-scoring tokens. It uses a class-specific semantic memory bank of learned prototypes to refine selection and compensate for discarded features. A two-level ranking mechanism dynamically weights token–prototype interactions to prioritize informative signals.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on 11 few-shot benchmarks shows Spotlighter outperforms CLIP by up to 11.19 percentage points in harmonic mean accuracy and delivers up to ~0.8K additional FPS, with only 21 extra parameters.
AI.conclusion: Spotlighter provides an effective and scalable baseline for prompt tuning by reducing noise and computation while maintaining or improving accuracy, with minimal parameter overhead.

title: An Explainable Gaussian Process Auto-encoder for Tabular Data
summary:
Explainable machine learning has attracted much interest in the community
where the stakes are high. Counterfactual explanations methods have become an
important tool in explaining a black-box model. The recent advances have
leveraged the power of generative models such as an autoencoder. In this paper,
we propose a novel method using a Gaussian process to construct the
auto-encoder architecture for generating counterfactual samples. The resulting
model requires fewer learnable parameters and thus is less prone to
overfitting. We also introduce a novel density estimator that allows for
searching for in-distribution samples. Furthermore, we introduce an algorithm
for selecting the optimal regularization rate on density estimator while
searching for counterfactuals. We experiment with our method in several
large-scale tabular datasets and compare with other auto-encoder-based methods.
The results show that our method is capable of generating diversified and
in-distribution counterfactual samples.

AI.tldr: GP-guided auto-encoder for counterfactuals with a density estimator and regularization-rate selection, yielding diverse, in-distribution counterfactuals with fewer parameters.
AI.motivation: Explainable ML in high-stakes settings requires counterfactual explanations that are both in-distribution and diverse, while avoiding overfitting; leverages Gaussian processes to shape the auto-encoder and density estimation to guide sampling.
AI.method: Construct an auto-encoder architecture guided by a Gaussian process; introduce a novel density estimator to identify in-distribution samples; develop an algorithm to select the optimal regularization rate of the density estimator while searching for counterfactuals; evaluate on large-scale tabular datasets and compare with other auto-encoder-based methods.
AI.result: The method can generate diversified and in-distribution counterfactual samples and demonstrates competitive performance against existing auto-encoder-based approaches on large tabular datasets.
AI.conclusion: A GP-guided auto-encoder with a density estimator and regularization-rate selection effectively produces diverse, in-distribution counterfactual explanations with fewer parameters, addressing overfitting and scalability concerns in explainable ML.

title: IPG: Incremental Patch Generation for Generalized Adversarial Patch Training
summary:
The advent of adversarial patches poses a significant challenge to the
robustness of AI models, particularly in the domain of computer vision tasks
such as object detection. In contradistinction to traditional adversarial
examples, these patches target specific regions of an image, resulting in the
malfunction of AI models. This paper proposes Incremental Patch Generation
(IPG), a method that generates adversarial patches up to 11.1 times more
efficiently than existing approaches while maintaining comparable attack
performance. The efficacy of IPG is demonstrated by experiments and ablation
studies including YOLO's feature distribution visualization and adversarial
training results, which show that it produces well-generalized patches that
effectively cover a broader range of model vulnerabilities. Furthermore,
IPG-generated datasets can serve as a robust knowledge foundation for
constructing a robust model, enabling structured representation, advanced
reasoning, and proactive defenses in AI security ecosystems. The findings of
this study suggest that IPG has considerable potential for future utilization
not only in adversarial patch defense but also in real-world applications such
as autonomous vehicles, security systems, and medical imaging, where AI models
must remain resilient to adversarial attacks in dynamic and high-stakes
environments.

AI.tldr: IPG speeds up adversarial patch generation (up to 11.1x) with comparable attack efficacy, enabling broader vulnerability coverage and potential defensive and real-world applications.
AI.motivation: Adversarial patches disrupt CV systems by attacking targeted image regions, posing robustness challenges. There is a need for more efficient, scalable patch-generation methods to study vulnerabilities and to build defenses across domains.
AI.method: Introduce Incremental Patch Generation (IPG), an iterative approach that generates patches with improved efficiency. The work includes ablation studies and visualizations (e.g., YOLO feature distributions) and leverages adversarial training to produce patches that generalize across models.
AI.result: IPG achieves up to 11.1× efficiency gains over existing approaches while maintaining comparable attack performance. The generated patches generalize well to cover broader model vulnerabilities, and IPG-derived datasets can support robust model construction and defense strategies.
AI.conclusion: IPG holds promise for future use in adversarial patch defense and real-world applications (autonomous vehicles, security, medical imaging), where AI models must remain resilient in dynamic, high-stakes environments.

title: DarkVRAI: Capture-Condition Conditioning and Burst-Order Selective Scan for Low-light RAW Video Denoising
summary:
Low-light RAW video denoising is a fundamentally challenging task due to
severe signal degradation caused by high sensor gain and short exposure times,
which are inherently limited by video frame rate requirements. To address this,
we propose DarkVRAI, a novel framework that achieved first place in the AIM
2025 Low-light RAW Video Denoising Challenge. Our method introduces two primary
contributions: (1) a successful application of a conditioning scheme for image
denoising, which explicitly leverages capture metadata, to video denoising to
guide the alignment and denoising processes, and (2) a Burst-Order Selective
Scan (BOSS) mechanism that effectively models long-range temporal dependencies
within the noisy video sequence. By synergistically combining these components,
DarkVRAI demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on a rigorous and realistic
benchmark dataset, setting a new standard for low-light video denoising.

AI.tldr: DarkVRAI introduces a conditioning scheme that leverages capture metadata for video denoising, plus a Burst-Order Selective Scan (BOSS) to model long-range temporal dependencies, achieving state-of-the-art results and winning the AIM 2025 Low-light RAW Video Denoising Challenge.
AI.motivation: Low-light RAW video denoising is severely challenging due to noise amplification from high sensor gain and short exposure times, which are constrained by video frame rates. There is a need to effectively utilize available capture metadata and long-range temporal information to improve denoising performance while maintaining video coherence.
AI.method: 1) A conditioning scheme that uses capture metadata to guide alignment and denoising in a video denoising pipeline. 2) Burst-Order Selective Scan (BOSS), a mechanism that models long-range temporal dependencies across the noisy frame sequence to improve denoising stability and quality.
AI.result: DarkVRAI achieved first place in the AIM 2025 Low-light RAW Video Denoising Challenge and demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on a rigorous benchmark dataset.
AI.conclusion: The combination of metadata-conditioned denoising and long-range temporal modeling via BOSS effectively addresses the challenges of low-light RAW video denoising, setting a new standard and offering a path for further research in leveraging capture metadata and temporal structure.

title: DTRNet: Dynamic Token Routing Network to Reduce Quadratic Costs in Transformers
summary:
Transformers achieve state-of-the-art results across many tasks, but their
uniform application of quadratic self-attention to every token at every layer
makes them computationally expensive. We introduce DTRNet (Dynamic Token
Routing Network), an improved Transformer architecture that allows tokens to
dynamically skip the quadratic cost of cross-token mixing while still receiving
lightweight linear updates. By preserving the MLP module and reducing the
attention cost for most tokens to linear, DTRNet ensures that every token is
explicitly updated while significantly lowering overall computation. This
design offers an efficient and effective alternative to standard dense
attention. Once trained, DTRNet blocks routes only ~10% of tokens through
attention at each layer while maintaining performance comparable to a full
Transformer. It consistently outperforms routing-based layer skipping methods
such as MoD and D-LLM in both accuracy and memory at matched FLOPs, while
routing fewer tokens to full attention. Its efficiency gains, scales with
sequence length, offering significant reduction in FLOPs for long-context
inputs. By decoupling token updates from attention mixing, DTRNet substantially
reduces the quadratic share of computation, providing a simple, efficient, and
scalable alternative to Transformers.

AI.tldr: DTRNet speeds up Transformers by routing only a small subset of tokens to full attention while keeping lightweight updates for the rest.
AI.motivation: Reduce the quadratic cost of self-attention in Transformers, enabling efficient processing of long sequences without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.method: Introduce Dynamic Token Routing Network (DTRNet) that preserves the MLP module and routes only about 10% of tokens through full attention per layer. The remaining tokens receive linear updates, effectively decoupling token updates from attention. DTRNet compares against routing-based layer-skipping methods like MoD and D-LLM and demonstrates reduced FLOPs with maintained performance.
AI.result: DTRNet achieves comparable performance to a full Transformer at markedly lower FLOPs by routing fewer tokens to full attention (~10%). It outperforms routing-based methods in accuracy and memory at matched FLOPs, and its efficiency scales with sequence length, yielding larger FLOP reductions on long-context inputs.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling token updates from attention significantly reduces the quadratic component of Transformer computation, providing a simple, efficient, and scalable alternative for long-context processing.

title: Seeing More, Saying More: Lightweight Language Experts are Dynamic Video Token Compressors
summary:
Recent advancements in large video-language models have revolutionized video
understanding tasks. However, their efficiency is significantly constrained by
processing high volumes of visual tokens. Existing token compression strategies
apply a fixed compression ratio, ignoring the variability in semantic density
among different video clips. Consequently, this lead to inadequate
representation of information-rich clips due to insufficient tokens and
unnecessary computation on static or content-poor ones. To address this, we
propose LangDC, a Language-aware Dynamic Token Compressor. LangDC leverages a
lightweight language model to describe video clips, converting them into soft
caption tokens as visual representations. Trained with our proposed semantic
density-aware supervision, LangDC aims to 1) cover key visual cues necessary
for downstream task reasoning and 2) dynamically adjust compression ratios
based on scene richness, reflected by descriptions length. Our design mimics
how humans dynamically express what they see: complex scenes (seeing more)
elicit more detailed language to convey nuances (saying more), whereas simpler
scenes are described with fewer words. Experimental results show that our
method reduces FLOPs by 49% compared to VideoGPT+ while maintaining competitive
performance. Furthermore, qualitative results demonstrate our approach
adaptively adjusts the token compression ratio based on video segment richness.

AI.tldr: LangDC uses a lightweight language model to convert video clips into soft caption tokens and dynamically adjusts token compression based on semantic density, reducing compute while preserving task performance.
AI.motivation: Video-language models are bottlenecked by processing大量 visual tokens; fixed compression ratios fail to reflect scene richness, leading to under- or over-compression across clips.
AI.method: A lightweight language model describes video clips into soft tokens as visual representations; semantic density-aware supervision trains the system to preserve key cues; compression ratio is dynamically adjusted by the length/complexity of descriptions; evaluation shows reduced FLOPs with competitive accuracy.
AI.result: The approach achieves about 49% FLOPs reduction compared to VideoGPT+ while maintaining competitive performance; qualitative results show adaptive token compression aligned with scene richness.
AI.conclusion: Language-aware dynamic token compression can effectively balance information preservation and compute efficiency by modulating token quantity according to semantic density of scenes.

title: Superposition in Graph Neural Networks
summary:
Interpreting graph neural networks (GNNs) is difficult because message
passing mixes signals and internal channels rarely align with human concepts.
We study superposition, the sharing of directions by multiple features,
directly in the latent space of GNNs. Using controlled experiments with
unambiguous graph concepts, we extract features as (i) class-conditional
centroids at the graph level and (ii) linear-probe directions at the node
level, and then analyze their geometry with simple basis-invariant diagnostics.
Across GCN/GIN/GAT we find: increasing width produces a phase pattern in
overlap; topology imprints overlap onto node-level features that pooling
partially remixes into task-aligned graph axes; sharper pooling increases axis
alignment and reduces channel sharing; and shallow models can settle into
metastable low-rank embeddings. These results connect representational geometry
with concrete design choices (width, pooling, and final-layer activations) and
suggest practical approaches for more interpretable GNNs.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes how GNN architectural choices (width, pooling, depth) shape distributed latent representations, focusing on feature superposition and overlap in GCN/GIN/GAT, and shows how topology and pooling affect axis alignment, with implications for interpretable design.
AI.motivation: Interpreting GNNs is difficult because message passing blends signals; the study seeks to quantify how multiple features share latent directions and how architecture controls this geometry.
AI.method: Controlled experiments across GCN, GIN, and GAT. Features are extracted as (i) graph-level class-conditional centroids and (ii) node-level linear-probe directions. Geometry is analyzed with simple, basis-invariant diagnostics to measure overlap and alignment.
AI.result: Width affects overlap with a phase-like pattern; topology can imprint overlap on node features; pooling partially remixes node signals into task-relevant graph axes; sharper pooling increases axis alignment and reduces channel sharing; shallow models can converge to metastable low-rank embeddings.
AI.conclusion: Representational geometry links to design choices (width, pooling, final activations) and suggests practical routes for more interpretable GNNs by controlling how signals align in latent space.

title: Towards Integrating Multi-Spectral Imaging with Gaussian Splatting
summary:
We present a study of how to integrate color (RGB) and multi-spectral imagery
(red, green, red-edge, and near-infrared) into the 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS)
framework, a state-of-the-art explicit radiance-field-based method for fast and
high-fidelity 3D reconstruction from multi-view images. While 3DGS excels on
RGB data, naive per-band optimization of additional spectra yields poor
reconstructions due to inconsistently appearing geometry in the spectral
domain. This problem is prominent, even though the actual geometry is the same,
regardless of spectral modality. To investigate this, we evaluate three
strategies: 1) Separate per-band reconstruction with no shared structure. 2)
Splitting optimization, in which we first optimize RGB geometry, copy it, and
then fit each new band to the model by optimizing both geometry and band
representation. 3) Joint, in which the modalities are jointly optimized,
optionally with an initial RGB-only phase. We showcase through quantitative
metrics and qualitative novel-view renderings on multi-spectral datasets the
effectiveness of our dedicated optimized Joint strategy, increasing overall
spectral reconstruction as well as enhancing RGB results through spectral
cross-talk. We therefore suggest integrating multi-spectral data directly into
the spherical harmonics color components to compactly model each Gaussian's
multi-spectral reflectance. Moreover, our analysis reveals several key
trade-offs in when and how to introduce spectral bands during optimization,
offering practical insights for robust multi-modal 3DGS reconstruction.

AI.tldr: Joint optimization of RGB and multi-spectral data within 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) outperforms separate or staged strategies, improving spectral fidelity and providing cross-modal benefits to RGB; multi-spectral reflectance is best modeled via spherical-harmonics color components per Gaussian.
AI.motivation: Naive per-band optimization of additional spectra in 3DGS leads to inconsistently appearing geometry across spectral domains, despite identical underlying geometry. A robust fusion of multi-spectral data is needed to achieve accurate, coherent 3D reconstructions across modalities.
AI.method: Compare three strategies on multi-spectral data: (1) separate per-band reconstruction with no shared structure; (2) split optimization by first optimizing RGB geometry, copying it, then fitting each new band with joint geometry and band representation; (3) joint optimization across modalities, optionally after an initial RGB-only phase. Propose integrating multi-spectral data into the spherical-harmonics color components to model each Gaussian’s multi-spectral reflectance.
AI.result: Quantitative metrics and qualitative novel-view renderings on multi-spectral datasets show the dedicated Joint strategy yields better spectral reconstruction and also enhances RGB results via spectral cross-talk.
AI.conclusion: Joint, multispectral-aware optimization within 3DGS, with SH-based modeling of multi-spectral reflectance, is advantageous. The work also discusses trade-offs regarding when to introduce spectral bands during optimization and provides practical insights for robust multi-modal 3DGS reconstruction.

title: SCOUT: Toward Sub-Quadratic Attention via Segment Compression for Optimized Utility in Transformers
summary:
Transformers have demonstrated strong performance across a wide range of
sequence modeling tasks, but their quadratic attention complexity limits
scalability to long sequences. Linear models such as Mamba and sliding-window
attention (SWA) address this by mixing tokens through recurrent or localized
operations with fixed-size memory, achieving efficient inference. However,
these methods risk degrading performance on long sequences due to their
inability to retain detailed information from distant tokens. We propose SCOUT
(Segment Compression for Optimized Utility in Transformers), a hybrid
architecture that compresses tokens locally within fixed-size segments and
applies attention only over these compressed representations. Each token
embedding is first enriched via a linear local mixer, Mamba or SWA, that
integrates recent context. Then, instead of attending to all previous tokens,
each token sparsely attends to a small number of compressed checkpoint tokens
that summarize the input history. This design retains much of the expressivity
of full attention while substantially reducing the computational and memory
cost. By attending to compressed history rather than all previous tokens, SCOUT
incurs slightly higher memory than purely linear models, but its growth rate
remains sub-quadratic and far more scalable than that of full Transformers. We
analyze SCOUT's computational and memory efficiency and evaluate it empirically
on long-context language modeling and reasoning tasks. SCOUT with both Mamba
and SWA mixers outperforms strong long-sequence baselines under the same
computational budget, matches full-attention Transformers on language modeling
and common-sense reasoning tasks at 400M and 1.3B scales. Moreover, our SCOUT
achieves higher end-to-end throughput than SOTA models, while delivering
comparable results on long sequence benchmarks.

AI.tldr: SCOUT is a hybrid Transformer that compresses token history per fixed segments and attends to a small set of compressed checkpoint tokens, combining linear local mixers (Mamba/SWA) with sparse attention to achieve sub-quadratic complexity while preserving expressivity. It outperforms strong long-sequence baselines under the same budget and matches full-attention transformers on key tasks at large scales, with higher throughput than state-of-the-art models.
AI.motivation: To overcome the quadratic attention bottleneck in Transformers for long sequences, while maintaining performance; linear models (Mamba/SWA) are efficient but risk losing distant information, so a method that preserves historic detail with controlled compression is sought.
AI.method: 1) Enrich each token via a local linear mixer (Mamba or SWA) to integrate recent context. 2) Segment history into fixed-size chunks and locally compress tokens within each segment. 3) Have each token attend sparsely to a small number of compressed checkpoint tokens that summarize the input history, instead of attending to all prior tokens. 4) Analyze computational/memory efficiency and evaluate on long-context language modeling and reasoning tasks, comparing Mamba and SWA variants.
AI.result: SCOUT with both Mamba and SWA mixers outperforms strong long-sequence baselines under the same computational budget, matches full-attention Transformers on language modeling and common-sense reasoning tasks at scales of 400M and 1.3B parameters, and achieves higher end-to-end throughput than SOTA models while delivering comparable results on long-sequence benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: SCOUT offers a practical path to scalable long-context modeling by blending local mixing with segment-level compression and sparse attention to history summaries, achieving sub-quadratic growth and near full-attention performance; it preserves expressivity with only modest memory overhead compared to purely linear models, and opens avenues for further exploration across tasks and mixers.

title: AI-driven Dispensing of Coral Reseeding Devices for Broad-scale Restoration of the Great Barrier Reef
summary:
Coral reefs are on the brink of collapse, with climate change, ocean
acidification, and pollution leading to a projected 70-90% loss of coral
species within the next decade. Restoration efforts are crucial, but their
success hinges on introducing automation to upscale efforts. We present
automated deployment of coral re-seeding devices powered by artificial
intelligence, computer vision, and robotics. Specifically, we perform automated
substrate classification, enabling detection of areas of the seafloor suitable
for coral growth, thus significantly reducing reliance on human experts and
increasing the range and efficiency of restoration. Real-world testing of the
algorithms on the Great Barrier Reef leads to deployment accuracy of 77.8%,
sub-image patch classification of 89.1%, and real-time model inference at 5.5
frames per second. Further, we present and publicly contribute a large
collection of annotated substrate image data to foster future research in this
area.

AI.tldr: Automated coral restoration using AI-driven substrate classification and robotics achieves real-world deployment accuracy and fast inference, plus a public dataset.
AI.motivation: Coral reefs face severe decline from climate change, acidification, and pollution; restoration requires scalable approaches beyond manual labor.
AI.method: Automated deployment of coral re-seeding devices leveraging AI, computer vision, and robotics to classify substrate and identify suitable seafloor areas in real time.
AI.result: Real-world testing on the Great Barrier Reef yielded deployment accuracy 77.8%, sub-image patch classification 89.1%, and real-time inference at 5.5 frames per second; a large annotated substrate image dataset was released publicly.
AI.conclusion: Automation can scale restoration efforts and reduce dependence on human experts, and the shared dataset will accelerate future research.

title: Weather-Dependent Variations in Driver Gaze Behavior: A Case Study in Rainy Conditions
comment:
Accepted at the 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular
  Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
summary:
Rainy weather significantly increases the risk of road accidents due to
reduced visibility and vehicle traction. Understanding how experienced drivers
adapt their visual perception through gaze behavior under such conditions is
critical for designing robust driver monitoring systems (DMS) and for informing
advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS). This case study investigates the eye
gaze behavior of a driver operating the same highway route under both clear and
rainy conditions. To this end, gaze behavior was analyzed by a two-step
clustering approach: first, clustering gaze points within 10-second intervals,
and then aggregating cluster centroids into meta-clusters. This, along with
Markov transition matrices and metrics such as fixation duration, gaze
elevation, and azimuth distributions, reveals meaningful behavioral shifts.
While the overall gaze behavior focused on the road with occasional mirror
checks remains consistent, rainy conditions lead to more frequent dashboard
glances, longer fixation durations, and higher gaze elevation, indicating
increased cognitive focus. These findings offer valuable insight into visual
attention patterns under adverse conditions and highlight the potential of
leveraging gaze modeling to aid in the design of more robust ADAS and DMS.

AI.tldr: Rainy driving alters gaze behavior: more dashboard glances, longer fixations, and higher gaze elevation, though road-focused attention persists; a two-step clustering plus Markov analysis reveals adaptive visual strategies useful for ADAS/DMS design.
AI.motivation: Under adverse weather, reduced visibility and traction raise crash risk. Understanding how experienced drivers adapt their gaze can inform robust driver monitoring systems (DMS) and advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS).
AI.method: A case study analyzing eye gaze of a single driver on the same highway route under clear and rainy conditions. Gaze points clustered within 10-second windows, then cluster centroids aggregated into meta-clusters. Markov transition matrices and metrics (fixation duration, gaze elevation, azimuth) used to compare conditions.
AI.result: Rainy conditions increase dashboard glances, prolong fixation durations, and elevate gaze, indicating higher cognitive focus, while road-focused attention remains dominant and mirror checks are still present. The two-step clustering and derived metrics reveal meaningful shifts in gaze behavior under rain.
