AI.tldr: A framework that uses resurgence theory and Borel analysis of a perturbative partition function Z(g) to extract global information from divergent series, yielding critical objective values that guide local optimizers.
AI.motivation: Local gradient methods lack global information about the objective landscape, making them sensitive to initialization and prone to suboptimal convergence. The paper proposes leveraging global information encoded in divergent asymptotic series to obtain principled global guidance.
AI.method: Compute Z(g)=∫ e^{-L(θ)/g} dθ for small g; extract its asymptotic series, perform a Borel transform, and locate singularities in the Borel plane. Each singularity corresponds to a critical objective value of L. Use these target values to steer local optimization (e.g., learning-rate adaptation, escaping basins).
AI.result: The authors claim a one-to-one correspondence between Borel plane singularities and critical objective values, providing theoretically grounded global targets that guide optimization beyond local gradients.
AI.conclusion: If practical, this resurgence-based framework could offer principled global information to augment local optimizers, potentially improving convergence and robustness. Real-world applicability depends on the ability to compute/approximate Z(g) and accurately identify Borel singularities in high dimensions.

title: Novel Category Discovery with X-Agent Attention for Open-Vocabulary Semantic Segmentation
summary:
Open-vocabulary semantic segmentation (OVSS) conducts pixel-level
classification via text-driven alignment, where the domain discrepancy between
base category training and open-vocabulary inference poses challenges in
discriminative modeling of latent unseen category. To address this challenge,
existing vision-language model (VLM)-based approaches demonstrate commendable
performance through pre-trained multi-modal representations. However, the
fundamental mechanisms of latent semantic comprehension remain underexplored,
making the bottleneck for OVSS. In this work, we initiate a probing experiment
to explore distribution patterns and dynamics of latent semantics in VLMs under
inductive learning paradigms. Building on these insights, we propose X-Agent,
an innovative OVSS framework employing latent semantic-aware ``agent'' to
orchestrate cross-modal attention mechanisms, simultaneously optimizing latent
semantic dynamic and amplifying its perceptibility. Extensive benchmark
evaluations demonstrate that X-Agent achieves state-of-the-art performance
while effectively enhancing the latent semantic saliency.

AI.tldr: Proposes X-Agent, a latent-semantic–aware OVSS framework that probes latent semantics in VLMs and uses an agent to orchestrate cross-modal attention; achieves state-of-the-art results and enhances latent semantic saliency.
AI.motivation: OVSS struggles with domain shift between base categories and open vocabulary, and latent semantic comprehension in VLMs remains underexplored. A probing study can reveal how latent semantics behave under inductive learning and guide better modeling.
AI.method: Conduct a probing analysis of latent semantics in vision-language models under inductive learning to understand distribution and dynamics; design X-Agent, a latent semantic–aware agent that orchestrates cross-modal attention and jointly optimizes latent semantic dynamics and perceptibility.
AI.result: Extensive benchmarks show state-of-the-art OVSS performance and a notable improvement in latent semantic saliency, demonstrating the efficacy of latent-semantic–aware control in cross-modal reasoning.
AI.conclusion: Latent semantics can be effectively leveraged in OVSS via an agent-driven cross-modal attention mechanism; the proposed X-Agent framework advances OVSS by improving both performance and the visibility of latent categories, with implications for broader open-world recognition.

title: AT Loss: Advanced Torrential Loss Function for Precipitation Forecasting
summary:
Accurate precipitation forecasting is becoming increasingly important in the
context of climate change. In response, machine learning-based approaches have
recently gained attention as an emerging alternative to traditional methods
such as numerical weather prediction and climate models. Nonetheless, many
recent approaches still rely on off-the-shelf loss functions, and even the more
advanced ones merely involve optimization processes based on the critical
success index (CSI). The problem, however, is that CSI may become ineffective
during extended dry periods when precipitation remains below the threshold,
rendering it less than ideal as a criterion for optimization. To address this
limitation, we introduce a simple penalty expression and reinterpret it as a
quadratic unconstrained binary optimization (QUBO) formulation. Ultimately, the
resulting QUBO formulation is relaxed into a differentiable advanced torrential
(AT) loss function through an approximation process. The proposed AT loss
demonstrates its superiority through the Lipschitz constant, forecast
performance evaluations, consistency experiments, and ablation studies with the
operational model.

AI.tldr: A simple penalty-based QUBO reformulation yields a differentiable advanced torrential (AT) loss that addresses CSI’s poor performance during extended dry spells, improving precipitation forecasting.
AI.motivation: CSI-based losses can be ineffective when precipitation remains below threshold for long periods. There is a need for a loss function that remains informative across dry spells and improves ML-based precipitation forecasts.
AI.method: Introduce a penalty expression and reinterpret it as a quadratic unconstrained binary optimization (QUBO) problem. Relax the QUBO into a differentiable advanced torrential (AT) loss via an approximation. Evaluate via Lipschitz constant analyses, forecast performance, consistency experiments, and ablation studies with an operational model.
AI.result: The AT loss demonstrates superiority across the evaluation metrics, showing improved forecast performance and stability in comparisons and ablation studies.
AI.conclusion: The AT loss provides a simple, effective alternative to CSI-based optimization for precipitation forecasting and demonstrates robust performance in both controlled evaluations and with an operational model.

title: SAR-NAS: Lightweight SAR Object Detection with Neural Architecture Search
summary:
Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) object detection faces significant challenges
from speckle noise, small target ambiguities, and on-board computational
constraints. While existing approaches predominantly focus on SAR-specific
architectural modifications, this paper explores the application of the
existing lightweight object detector, i.e., YOLOv10, for SAR object detection
and enhances its performance through Neural Architecture Search (NAS).
Specifically, we employ NAS to systematically optimize the network structure,
especially focusing on the backbone architecture search. By constructing an
extensive search space and leveraging evolutionary search, our method
identifies a favorable architecture that balances accuracy, parameter
efficiency, and computational cost. Notably, this work introduces NAS to SAR
object detection for the first time. The experimental results on the
large-scale SARDet-100K dataset demonstrate that our optimized model
outperforms existing SAR detection methods, achieving superior detection
accuracy while maintaining lower computational overhead. We hope this work
offers a novel perspective on leveraging NAS for real-world applications.

AI.tldr: NAS-driven backbone search enhances a lightweight SAR detector (YOLOv10) for SAR object detection, achieving higher accuracy with lower compute on SARDet-100K.
AI.motivation: SAR imagery suffers from speckle noise, small target ambiguities, and on-board compute constraints. Existing SAR-specific architectural tweaks are limited; applying NAS could balance accuracy and efficiency for SAR detection.
AI.method: Construct a large search space for backbone architectures within a YOLOv10 framework tailored to SAR, apply evolutionary search to discover efficient architectures, and evaluate on the SARDet-100K dataset.
AI.result: Found an optimized backbone that yields superior detection accuracy with lower computational overhead compared to existing SAR detectors on SARDet-100K; this work marks the first NAS application to SAR object detection.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that NAS can effectively optimize SAR detectors, offering a favorable accuracy/efficiency trade-off and opening new avenues for NAS-guided real-world SAR detection.

title: Causal Sensitivity Identification using Generative Learning
comment:
11 pages, 7 figures, Accepted at the IJCAI 2025 Workshop on Causal
  Learning for Recommendation Systems (CLRS). [OpenReview link:
  https://openreview.net/pdf?id=f5cR7BzBSx ]
summary:
In this work, we propose a novel generative method to identify the causal
impact and apply it to prediction tasks. We conduct causal impact analysis
using interventional and counterfactual perspectives. First, applying
interventions, we identify features that have a causal influence on the
predicted outcome, which we refer to as causally sensitive features, and
second, applying counterfactuals, we evaluate how changes in the cause affect
the effect. Our method exploits the Conditional Variational Autoencoder (CVAE)
to identify the causal impact and serve as a generative predictor. We are able
to reduce confounding bias by identifying causally sensitive features. We
demonstrate the effectiveness of our method by recommending the most likely
locations a user will visit next in their spatiotemporal trajectory influenced
by the causal relationships among various features. Experiments on the
large-scale GeoLife [Zheng et al., 2010] dataset and the benchmark Asia
Bayesian network validate the ability of our method to identify causal impact
and improve predictive performance.

AI.tldr: A generative, CVAE-based approach to causal impact analysis that identifies causally sensitive features via interventions and evaluates counterfactuals, improving prediction tasks and reducing confounding, demonstrated on GeoLife trajectories and an Asia Bayesian network.
AI.motivation: To enable causal interpretation and bias reduction in predictive models by explicitly distinguishing features that causally influence the outcome from those that do not, and by evaluating how changes in causes affect effects through counterfactuals.
AI.method: Use interventional analysis to identify causally sensitive features that influence the predicted outcome; use counterfactuals to assess how changes in the causes affect the outcome. Leverage a Conditional Variational Autoencoder (CVAE) as a generative predictor to model the data and capture causal relationships, thereby reducing confounding bias and enabling causal impact identification. Validate on spatiotemporal trajectory prediction (GeoLife) and a benchmark Asia Bayesian network.
AI.result: Demonstrates the ability to identify causal impact and improve predictive performance, achieving more accurate next-location recommendations on GeoLife and favorable results on the Asia Bayesian network benchmark, while reducing confounding bias.
AI.conclusion: The CVAE-based causal impact framework provides a scalable method to perform causal analysis within generative prediction models, effectively identifying causal features and counterfactual effects, with empirical validation on large-scale real-world and benchmark datasets.

title: Multi-Representation Adapter with Neural Architecture Search for Efficient Range-Doppler Radar Object Detection
summary:
Detecting objects efficiently from radar sensors has recently become a
popular trend due to their robustness against adverse lighting and weather
conditions compared with cameras. This paper presents an efficient object
detection model for Range-Doppler (RD) radar maps. Specifically, we first
represent RD radar maps with multi-representation, i.e., heatmaps and grayscale
images, to gather high-level object and fine-grained texture features. Then, we
design an additional Adapter branch, an Exchanger Module with two modes, and a
Primary-Auxiliary Fusion Module to effectively extract, exchange, and fuse
features from the multi-representation inputs, respectively. Furthermore, we
construct a supernet with various width and fusion operations in the Adapter
branch for the proposed model and employ a One-Shot Neural Architecture Search
method to further improve the model's efficiency while maintaining high
performance. Experimental results demonstrate that our model obtains favorable
accuracy and efficiency trade-off. Moreover, we achieve new state-of-the-art
performance on RADDet and CARRADA datasets with mAP@50 of 71.9 and 57.1,
respectively.

AI.tldr: An efficient radar object detector that fuses multi-representation RD radar maps via novel Adapter/Exchanger/Fusion modules and NAS-optimized architecture, achieving SOTA on RADDet and CARRADA.
AI.motivation: Radar sensors are robust to adverse lighting and weather; Range-Doppler maps are rich but require effective feature extraction and efficient architectures. Multi-representation inputs can capture both high-level semantics and textures, and architecture search can optimize performance-efficiency trade-offs.
AI.method: Represent RD radar maps with multi-representation (heatmaps and grayscale images). Introduce an Adapter branch, an Exchanger Module with two modes, and a Primary-Auxiliary Fusion Module to extract, exchange, and fuse features from multi-representations. Build a supernet with varying widths and fusion operations in the Adapter branch and apply One-Shot Neural Architecture Search to find efficient architectures.
AI.result: The model achieves favorable accuracy-efficiency trade-offs and sets new state-of-the-art on RADDet and CARRADA with mAP@50 of 71.9 and 57.1, respectively.
AI.conclusion: Multi-representation RD radar inputs combined with specialized exchange/fusion modules and NAS-optimized architecture can significantly boost radar-based object detection performance and efficiency across challenging datasets.

title: DPF-CM: A Data Processing Framework with Privacy-Preserving Vector Databases for Chinese Medical LLMs Training and Deployment
summary:
Current open-source training pipelines for Chinese medical language models
predominantly emphasize optimizing training methodologies to enhance the
performance of large language models (LLMs), yet lack comprehensive exploration
into training data processing. To address this gap, we propose DPF-CM, a
holistic Data Processing Framework for Chinese Medical LLMs training and
deployment. DPF-CM comprises two core modules. The first module is a data
processing pipeline tailored for model training. Beyond standard data
processing operations, we (1) introduce a chained examples context-learning
strategy to generate question-oriented instructions to mitigate the lack of
instruction content, and (2) implement an ensemble-based filtering mechanism
for preference data curation that averages multiple reward models to suppress
noisy samples. The second module focuses on privacy preservation during model
deployment. To prevent privacy risks from the inadvertent exposure of training
data, we propose a Privacy Preserving Vector Database (PPVD) approach, which
involves model memory search, high-risk database construction, secure database
construction, and match-and-replace, four key stages to minimize privacy
leakage during inference collectively. Experimental results show that DPF-CM
significantly improves model accuracy, enabling our trained Chinese medical LLM
to achieve state-of-the-art performance among open-source counterparts.
Moreover, the framework reduces training data privacy leakage by 27%.

AI.tldr: DPF-CM provides a holistic, two-module framework for Chinese medical LLMs, combining data processing (with chained context-learning and ensemble data filtering) and privacy-preserving deployment (PPVD). It delivers state-of-the-art open-source accuracy and reduces training-data privacy leakage by 27%.
AI.motivation: Current open-source Chinese medical LLM pipelines focus on training methodologies but neglect end-to-end data processing and privacy considerations in deployment. There is a need to improve data quality, instruction content, and privacy safeguards in open-source pipelines.
AI.method: Module 1 data processing: a specialized training data pipeline that (a) uses a chained examples context-learning strategy to generate question-oriented instructions, and (b) employs an ensemble-based filtering mechanism that averages multiple reward models to suppress noisy samples. Module 2 privacy-preserving deployment: Privacy Preserving Vector Database (PPVD) with four stages—model memory search, high-risk database construction, secure database construction, and match-and-replace—to minimize privacy leakage during inference.
AI.result: Empirical results show significant gains in model accuracy, achieving state-of-the-art performance among open-source Chinese medical LLMs, and a 27% reduction in training data privacy leakage.
AI.conclusion: DPF-CM offers a practical, end-to-end blueprint for robust open-source Chinese medical LLMs, addressing both data quality and privacy. Its modular design enables adoption and adaptation in related domains and languages.

title: Cross-Domain Few-Shot Segmentation via Ordinary Differential Equations over Time Intervals
summary:
Cross-domain few-shot segmentation (CD-FSS) not only enables the segmentation
of unseen categories with very limited samples, but also improves cross-domain
generalization ability within the few-shot segmentation framework. Currently,
existing CD-FSS studies typically design multiple independent modules to
enhance the cross-domain generalization ability of feature representations.
However, the independence among these modules hinders the effective flow of
knowledge, making it difficult to fully leverage their collective potential. In
contrast, this paper proposes an all-in-one module based on ordinary
differential equations and Fourier transform, resulting in a structurally
concise method--Few-Shot Segmentation over Time Intervals (FSS-TIs). FSS-TIs
assumes the existence of an ODE relationship between the spectra (including
amplitude and phase spectra) of domain-specific features and domain-agnostic
features. This ODE formulation yields an iterative transformation process along
a sequence of time intervals, while simultaneously applying affine
transformations with randomized perturbations to the spectra. In doing so, the
exploration of domain-agnostic feature representation spaces and the simulation
of diverse potential target-domain distributions are reformulated as an
optimization process over the intrinsic parameters of the ODE. Moreover, we
strictly constrain the support-sample selection during target-domain
fine-tuning so that it is consistent with the requirements of real-world
few-shot segmentation tasks. For evaluation, we introduce five datasets from
substantially different domains and define two sets of cross-domain few-shot
segmentation tasks to comprehensively analyze the performance of FSS-TIs.
Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of FSS-TIs over existing
CD-FSS methods, and in-depth ablation studies further validate the cross-domain
adaptability of FSS-TIs.

AI.tldr: An all-in-one ODE-Fourier module (FSS-TIs) for cross-domain few-shot segmentation; transforms domain-specific to domain-agnostic features via spectra evolution over time intervals with randomized affine perturbations; optimized ODE parameters and careful support sampling for real-world few-shot tasks; validated across five diverse datasets and two CD-FSS task settings, outperforming prior methods.
AI.motivation: To overcome fragmentation and limited knowledge flow in existing cross-domain few-shot segmentation (CD-FSS) methods by proposing a unified, principled module that can generalize across domains.
AI.method: Formulate feature spectra (amplitude and phase) as linked by an ordinary differential equation (ODE) that evolves over a sequence of time intervals. At each interval, perform affine transformations with randomized perturbations on the spectra to explore domain-agnostic representations. Treat the optimization of the ODE's intrinsic parameters as the learning objective, and constrain support-sample selection to mirror real-world few-shot settings.
AI.result: Outperforms existing CD-FSS methods across evaluated tasks. Ablation studies confirm the cross-domain adaptability and the effectiveness of the unified ODE-Fourier approach.
AI.conclusion: An all-in-one, concise framework (FSS-TIs) successfully unifies spectral-domain transformations via ODE dynamics to enhance cross-domain generalization in few-shot segmentation.

title: CbLDM: A Diffusion Model for recovering nanostructure from pair distribution function
summary:
Nowadays, the nanostructure inverse problem is an attractive problem that
helps researchers to understand the relationship between the properties and the
structure of nanomaterials. This article focuses on the problem of using PDF to
recover the nanostructure, which this article views as a conditional generation
problem. This article propose a deep learning model CbLDM, Condition-based
Latent Diffusion Model. Based on the original latent diffusion model, the
sampling steps of the diffusion model are reduced and the sample generation
efficiency is improved by using the conditional prior to estimate conditional
posterior distribution, which is the approximated distribution of p(z|x). In
addition, this article uses the Laplacian matrix instead of the distance matrix
to recover the nanostructure, which can reduce the reconstruction error.
Finally, this article compares CbLDM with existing models which were used to
solve the nanostructure inverse problem, and find that CbLDM demonstrates
significantly higher prediction accuracy than these models, which reflects the
ability of CbLDM to solve the nanostructure inverse problem and the potential
to cope with other continuous conditional generation tasks.

AI.tldr: CbLDM: a conditional latent diffusion model to recover nanostructures from PDFs, using a conditional prior for p(z|x) and Laplacian-based reconstruction, achieving higher accuracy than prior methods.
AI.motivation: To solve the nanostructure inverse problem and understand the relationship between properties and structure by leveraging PDFs and conditional generation.
AI.method: Develop CbLDM, a conditional latent diffusion model; reduce diffusion sampling steps; estimate conditional posterior p(z|x) via a conditional prior; replace distance matrix with Laplacian for reconstruction; compare against existing models.
AI.result: CbLDM achieves significantly higher prediction accuracy than existing models on the nanostructure inverse problem.
AI.conclusion: CbLDM demonstrates the feasibility and effectiveness of conditional latent diffusion approaches in nanostructure reconstruction and may generalize to other continuous conditional generation tasks.

title: Guided Model-based LiDAR Super-Resolution for Resource-Efficient Automotive scene Segmentation
summary:
High-resolution LiDAR data plays a critical role in 3D semantic segmentation
for autonomous driving, but the high cost of advanced sensors limits
large-scale deployment. In contrast, low-cost sensors such as 16-channel LiDAR
produce sparse point clouds that degrade segmentation accuracy. To overcome
this, we introduce the first end-to-end framework that jointly addresses LiDAR
super-resolution (SR) and semantic segmentation. The framework employs joint
optimization during training, allowing the SR module to incorporate semantic
cues and preserve fine details, particularly for smaller object classes. A new
SR loss function further directs the network to focus on regions of interest.
The proposed lightweight, model-based SR architecture uses significantly fewer
parameters than existing LiDAR SR approaches, while remaining easily compatible
with segmentation networks. Experiments show that our method achieves
segmentation performance comparable to models operating on high-resolution and
costly 64-channel LiDAR data.

AI.tldr: End-to-end LiDAR super-resolution (SR) + semantic segmentation framework that jointly optimizes SR with segmentation, using a lightweight SR model and a ROI-focused loss to improve performance on sparse 16-channel LiDAR, achieving segmentation comparable to 64-channel high-resolution data.
AI.motivation: Low-cost 16-channel LiDAR yields sparse points; high-resolution 64-channel sensors are expensive; need a method to boost segmentation accuracy without expensive hardware.
AI.method: Joint training of an SR module and a segmentation network; SR module incorporates semantic cues; novel SR loss directs focus to regions of interest; lightweight, model-based SR architecture compatible with existing segmentation networks.
AI.result: Experiments show segmentation performance comparable to models operating on high-resolution 64-channel LiDAR data, despite starting from low-resolution input.
AI.conclusion: End-to-end SR-guided segmentation can compensate for low-cost sensor sparsity, enabling effective 3D semantic segmentation with cheaper hardware; the SR module is lightweight and easily integrated with segmentation networks.

title: Learn to Jump: Adaptive Random Walks for Long-Range Propagation through Graph Hierarchies
comment: Presented at ComBayNS Workshop (oral) at IJCNN 2025
summary:
Message-passing architectures struggle to sufficiently model long-range
dependencies in node and graph prediction tasks. We propose a novel approach
exploiting hierarchical graph structures and adaptive random walks to address
this challenge. Our method introduces learnable transition probabilities that
decide whether the walk should prefer the original graph or travel across
hierarchical shortcuts. On a synthetic long-range task, we demonstrate that our
approach can exceed the theoretical bound that constrains traditional
approaches operating solely on the original topology. Specifically, walks that
prefer the hierarchy achieve the same performance as longer walks on the
original graph. These preliminary findings open a promising direction for
efficiently processing large graphs while effectively capturing long-range
dependencies.

AI.tldr: Proposes a hierarchical graph approach with adaptive random walks using learnable transition probabilities to favor either the original graph or hierarchical shortcuts. Demonstrates that hierarchy-aware walks can match or exceed the performance of longer walks on the original graph on a synthetic long-range task, suggesting efficient long-range dependency capture in large graphs.
AI.motivation: Message-passing architectures often fail to model long-range dependencies efficiently. The method aims to leverage hierarchical graph structures and controllable walks to propagate information across distant nodes with fewer steps.
AI.method: Introduce learnable transition probabilities that decide whether a random walk should stay on the original graph or traverse hierarchical shortcuts. Use adaptive random walks on a hierarchical graph to capture long-range dependencies. Evaluate on a synthetic long-range task by comparing hierarchy-preferring walks to standard long walks on the original graph.
AI.result: Walks that prefer the hierarchical shortcuts achieve the same performance as longer walks on the original graph and can surpass traditional theoretical bounds that apply when only original topology is used.
AI.conclusion: Hierarchical shortcuts with adaptive random walks offer a promising and efficient direction for processing large graphs, enabling effective long-range dependency capture without requiring excessively long walks.

title: Prior-Guided Residual Diffusion: Calibrated and Efficient Medical Image Segmentation
summary:
Ambiguity in medical image segmentation calls for models that capture full
conditional distributions rather than a single point estimate. We present
Prior-Guided Residual Diffusion (PGRD), a diffusion-based framework that learns
voxel-wise distributions while maintaining strong calibration and practical
sampling efficiency. PGRD embeds discrete labels as one-hot targets in a
continuous space to align segmentation with diffusion modeling. A coarse prior
predictor provides step-wise guidance; the diffusion network then learns the
residual to the prior, accelerating convergence and improving calibration. A
deep diffusion supervision scheme further stabilizes training by supervising
intermediate time steps. Evaluated on representative MRI and CT datasets, PGRD
achieves higher Dice scores and lower NLL/ECE values than Bayesian, ensemble,
Probabilistic U-Net, and vanilla diffusion baselines, while requiring fewer
sampling steps to reach strong performance.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-based medical image segmentation method (PGRD) that learns voxel-wise distributions via prior-guided residual diffusion, improving calibration and efficiency and outperforming baselines.
AI.motivation: Medical image segmentation ambiguity necessitates modeling full conditional distributions with calibrated probabilities; aim to improve uncertainty quantification and sampling efficiency.
AI.method: PGRD framework: embed discrete labels as one-hot targets in continuous diffusion space; coarse prior predictor provides step-wise guidance; diffusion network learns residual to the prior; deep diffusion supervision across intermediate time steps.
AI.result: On MRI and CT datasets, PGRD achieves higher Dice scores and lower NLL/ECE than Bayesian methods, ensembles, Probabilistic U-Net, and vanilla diffusion baselines; requires fewer sampling steps for strong performance.
AI.conclusion: PGRD delivers better calibrated segmentation distributions with efficient sampling, highlighting the value of prior-guided diffusion for medical image segmentation and uncertainty quantification.

title: Distillation of a tractable model from the VQ-VAE
summary:
Deep generative models with discrete latent space, such as the
Vector-Quantized Variational Autoencoder (VQ-VAE), offer excellent data
generation capabilities, but, due to the large size of their latent space,
their probabilistic inference is deemed intractable. We demonstrate that the
VQ-VAE can be distilled into a tractable model by selecting a subset of latent
variables with high probabilities. This simple strategy is particularly
efficient, especially if the VQ-VAE underutilizes its latent space, which is,
indeed, very often the case. We frame the distilled model as a probabilistic
circuit, and show that it preserves expressiveness of the VQ-VAE while
providing tractable probabilistic inference. Experiments illustrate competitive
performance in density estimation and conditional generation tasks, challenging
the view of the VQ-VAE as an inherently intractable model.

AI.tldr: A simple subset-based distillation of VQ-VAE to a tractable probabilistic circuit preserves expressiveness and enables efficient inference, yielding competitive density estimation and conditional generation results.
AI.motivation: To address the perceived intractability of probabilistic inference in discrete latent-space models like VQ-VAE by exploiting underutilization of latent space and distilling to a tractable representation.
AI.method: Select high-probability latent variables from the VQ-VAE, construct a probabilistic circuit for the distilled model, ensuring maintained expressiveness and tractable inference.
AI.result: Experiments show competitive density estimation and conditional generation, challenging the view of VQ-VAE as inherently intractable.
AI.conclusion: The distilled probabilistic circuit provides a tractable, expressive surrogate for VQ-VAE, enabling practical inference and challenging assumptions about the intractability of discrete latent-space models.

title: Image Quality Enhancement and Detection of Small and Dense Objects in Industrial Recycling Processes
comment:
Event: Seventeenth International Conference on Quality Control by
  Artificial Vision (QCAV2025), 2025, Yamanashi Prefecture, Japan
summary:
This paper tackles two key challenges: detecting small, dense, and
overlapping objects (a major hurdle in computer vision) and improving the
quality of noisy images, especially those encountered in industrial
environments. [1, 2]. Our focus is on evaluating methods built on supervised
deep learning. We perform an analysis of these methods, using a newly de-
veloped dataset comprising over 10k images and 120k in- stances. By evaluating
their performance, accuracy, and com- putational efficiency, we identify the
most reliable detection systems and highlight the specific challenges they
address in industrial applications. This paper also examines the use of deep
learning models to improve image quality in noisy industrial environments. We
introduce a lightweight model based on a fully connected convolutional network.
Addition- ally, we suggest potential future directions for further enhanc- ing
the effectiveness of the model. The repository of the dataset and proposed
model can be found at: https://github.com/o-messai/SDOOD,
https://github.com/o-messai/DDSRNet

AI.tldr: A benchmarking study of supervised DL detectors for small, dense, overlapping objects and noisy industrial images using a new 10k-image, 120k-instance dataset; introduces a lightweight FCN-based image-quality model; identifies reliable detectors, efficiency tradeoffs, and future directions; datasets and code are released.
AI.motivation: Industrial inspection requires accurate detection of tiny, densely packed, and overlapping objects and robust image quality under noise. Current supervised DL methods face challenges in these industrial settings.
AI.method: Compile a new dataset (>10,000 images with ~120,000 instances); perform comprehensive evaluation of supervised deep learning detectors focusing on small, dense, and overlapping objects; assess performance and computational efficiency; develop a lightweight fully connected convolutional network (FCN) to improve image quality in noisy industrial environments; provide repository links to data and model.
AI.result: The study identifies which detectors are most reliable in industrial scenarios and highlights key challenges (e.g., handling small/overlapping objects, noise robustness) while quantifying performance-efficiency tradeoffs; introduces a lightweight FCN-based model for image quality enhancement; provides public datasets and model implementations.
AI.conclusion: Future work should aim to further improve the FCN-based model’s effectiveness and robustness in diverse industrial conditions; the work is accompanied by public datasets and model/code releases to support reproducibility and further research.

title: Evaluating the stability of model explanations in instance-dependent cost-sensitive credit scoring
summary:
Instance-dependent cost-sensitive (IDCS) classifiers offer a promising
approach to improving cost-efficiency in credit scoring by tailoring loss
functions to instance-specific costs. However, the impact of such loss
functions on the stability of model explanations remains unexplored in
literature, despite increasing regulatory demands for transparency. This study
addresses this gap by evaluating the stability of Local Interpretable
Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME) and SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP)
when applied to IDCS models. Using four publicly available credit scoring
datasets, we first assess the discriminatory power and cost-efficiency of IDCS
classifiers, introducing a novel metric to enhance cross-dataset comparability.
We then investigate the stability of SHAP and LIME feature importance rankings
under varying degrees of class imbalance through controlled resampling. Our
results reveal that while IDCS classifiers improve cost-efficiency, they
produce significantly less stable explanations compared to traditional models,
particularly as class imbalance increases, highlighting a critical trade-off
between cost optimization and interpretability in credit scoring. Amid
increasing regulatory scrutiny on explainability, this research underscores the
pressing need to address stability issues in IDCS classifiers to ensure that
their cost advantages are not undermined by unstable or untrustworthy
explanations.

AI.tldr: IDCS classifiers boost cost-efficiency but yield unstable explanations (SHAP/LIME) under class imbalance; highlights a trade-off between cost optimization and interpretability in credit scoring.
AI.motivation: Address the gap in understanding how instance-dependent, cost-sensitive loss functions affect the stability of model explanations, amid regulatory pressure for transparent credit scoring.
AI.method: Evaluate IDCS classifiers on four public credit datasets; assess discriminatory power and cost-efficiency; introduce a cross-dataset comparability metric; analyze SHAP and LIME stability under resampling-driven class imbalance.
AI.result: IDCS improves cost-efficiency but leads to significantly less stable SHAP/LIME explanations compared to traditional models, especially as class imbalance increases.
AI.conclusion: There is a critical trade-off between cost optimization and explainability; regulatory demands require stabilizing explanations for IDCS; further work needed to address stability issues to preserve trust in cost-efficient credit scoring.

title: Street-Level Geolocalization Using Multimodal Large Language Models and Retrieval-Augmented Generation
summary:
Street-level geolocalization from images is crucial for a wide range of
essential applications and services, such as navigation, location-based
recommendations, and urban planning. With the growing popularity of social
media data and cameras embedded in smartphones, applying traditional computer
vision techniques to localize images has become increasingly challenging, yet
highly valuable. This paper introduces a novel approach that integrates
open-weight and publicly accessible multimodal large language models with
retrieval-augmented generation. The method constructs a vector database using
the SigLIP encoder on two large-scale datasets (EMP-16 and OSV-5M). Query
images are augmented with prompts containing both similar and dissimilar
geolocation information retrieved from this database before being processed by
the multimodal large language models. Our approach has demonstrated
state-of-the-art performance, achieving higher accuracy compared against three
widely used benchmark datasets (IM2GPS, IM2GPS3k, and YFCC4k). Importantly, our
solution eliminates the need for expensive fine-tuning or retraining and scales
seamlessly to incorporate new data sources. The effectiveness of
retrieval-augmented generation-based multimodal large language models in
geolocation estimation demonstrated by this paper suggests an alternative path
to the traditional methods which rely on the training models from scratch,
opening new possibilities for more accessible and scalable solutions in GeoAI.

AI.tldr: Retrieval-augmented multimodal LLMs with a SigLIP-based vector database achieve SOTA street-level geolocation on EMP-16/OSV-5M, outperforming IM2GPS, IM2GPS3k, and YFCC4k without fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: Geolocalization from street-level images is valuable for navigation, recommendations, and urban planning. Traditional CV approaches require heavy retraining and may not scale well; retrieval-augmented, open-weight LLMs offer a scalable alternative.
AI.method: Construct a vector database using the SigLIP encoder on EMP-16 and OSV-5M datasets. Augment query images with prompts containing retrieved similar and dissimilar geolocation information from this database, then process with open-weight multimodal LLMs using retrieval-augmented generation.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art accuracy on three benchmarks (IM2GPS, IM2GPS3k, YFCC4k) and does not require fine-tuning, enabling easy addition of new data sources.
AI.conclusion: Retrieval-augmented generation with multimodal LLMs provides a scalable, accessible alternative to training models from scratch for geo-localization, enabling seamless incorporation of new data sources in GeoAI.

title: Accelerating PDE Solvers with Equation-Recast Neural Operator Preconditioning
summary:
The computational overhead of traditional numerical solvers for partial
differential equations (PDEs) remains a critical bottleneck for large-scale
parametric studies and design optimization. We introduce a Minimal-Data
Parametric Neural Operator Preconditioning (MD-PNOP) framework, which
establishes a new paradigm for accelerating parametric PDE solvers while
strictly preserving physical constraints. The key idea is to recast the
residual from parameter deviation as additional source term, where any trained
neural operator can be used to refine the solution in an offline fashion. This
directly addresses the fundamental extrapolation limitation of neural
operators, enabling extrapolative generalization of any neural operator trained
at a single parameter setting across a wide range of configurations without any
retraining. The neural operator predictions are then embedded into iterative
PDE solvers as improved initial guesses, thereby reducing convergence
iterations without sacrificing accuracy. Unlike purely data-driven approaches,
MD-PNOP guarantees that the governing equations remain fully enforced,
eliminating concerns about loss of physics or interpretability. The framework
is architecture-agnostic and is demonstrated using both Deep Operator Networks
(DeepONet) and Fourier Neural Operators (FNO) for Boltzmann transport equation
solvers in neutron transport applications. We demonstrated that neural
operators trained on a single set of constant parameters successfully
accelerate solutions with heterogeneous, sinusoidal, and discontinuous
parameter distributions. Besides, MD-PNOP consistently achieves ~50% reduction
in computational time while maintaining full order fidelity for fixed-source,
single-group eigenvalue, and multigroup coupled eigenvalue problems.

AI.tldr: MD-PNOP is a physics-preserving framework that uses neural operators to refine PDE solutions offline, enabling extrapolative speedups for parametric PDE solvers without retraining and achieving ~50% time reduction while maintaining full-order accuracy.
AI.motivation: Speed up large-scale parametric PDE studies and design optimization while strictly enforcing governing equations and preserving interpretability; address extrapolation limits of neural operators by enabling generalization from a single trained parameter setting.
AI.method: Treat the residual from parameter deviation as an additional source term. Train a neural operator (e.g., DeepONet or FNO) at one parameter setting and embed its predictions into iterative solvers as better initial guesses. This offline refinement reduces iterations while preserving physics; architecture-agnostic and demonstrated on Boltzmann transport equations for neutron transport with various parameter distributions.
AI.result: Consistent ~50% reduction in wall-clock time with full-order fidelity across fixed-source, single-group eigenvalue, and multigroup coupled eigenvalue problems; the approach generalizes to heterogeneous, sinusoidal, and discontinuous parameter distributions without retraining.
AI.conclusion: MD-PNOP offers a physics-consistent, data-efficient route to accelerate parametric PDE solvers. It enables extrapolative generalization of neural operators trained at a single parameter setting and integrates seamlessly with existing solvers, potentially broadening the applicability of operator learning in computational physics.

title: AgroSense: An Integrated Deep Learning System for Crop Recommendation via Soil Image Analysis and Nutrient Profiling
summary:
Meeting the increasing global demand for food security and sustainable
farming requires intelligent crop recommendation systems that operate in real
time. Traditional soil analysis techniques are often slow, labor-intensive, and
not suitable for on-field decision-making. To address these limitations, we
introduce AgroSense, a deep-learning framework that integrates soil image
classification and nutrient profiling to produce accurate and contextually
relevant crop recommendations. AgroSense comprises two main components: a Soil
Classification Module, which leverages ResNet-18, EfficientNet-B0, and Vision
Transformer architectures to categorize soil types from images; and a Crop
Recommendation Module, which employs a Multi-Layer Perceptron, XGBoost,
LightGBM, and TabNet to analyze structured soil data, including nutrient
levels, pH, and rainfall. We curated a multimodal dataset of 10,000 paired
samples drawn from publicly available Kaggle repositories, approximately 50,000
soil images across seven classes, and 25,000 nutrient profiles for experimental
evaluation. The fused model achieves 98.0% accuracy, with a precision of 97.8%,
a recall of 97.7%, and an F1-score of 96.75%, while RMSE and MAE drop to 0.32
and 0.27, respectively. Ablation studies underscore the critical role of
multimodal coupling, and statistical validation via t-tests and ANOVA confirms
the significance of our improvements. AgroSense offers a practical, scalable
solution for real-time decision support in precision agriculture and paves the
way for future lightweight multimodal AI systems in resource-constrained
environments.

AI.tldr: AgroSense is a multimodal deep-learning framework that integrates soil image classification and nutrient profiling to deliver real-time, context-aware crop recommendations, achieving high accuracy on a 10k-sample multimodal dataset.
AI.motivation: To address the slow, labor-intensive nature of traditional soil analysis and enable on-field, real-time decision-making for sustainable farming and global food security.
AI.method: Two modules: (1) Soil Classification Module leveraging ResNet-18, EfficientNet-B0, and Vision Transformer to categorize soil types from images; (2) Crop Recommendation Module using MLP, XGBoost, LightGBM, and TabNet to analyze structured soil data (nutrient levels, pH, rainfall). A multimodal fused model trained on a dataset with 10,000 paired samples, ~50,000 soil images across seven classes, and 25,000 nutrient profiles. Evaluation includes accuracy, precision, recall, F1, RMSE, MAE; ablation studies on multimodal coupling; statistical validation via t-tests and ANOVA.
AI.result: The fused model achieves 98.0% accuracy, precision 97.8%, recall 97.7%, F1-score 96.75%. RMSE 0.32 and MAE 0.27. Ablation studies show multimodal coupling is critical; statistical tests (t-tests, ANOVA) confirm significance of improvements.
AI.conclusion: AgroSense offers a practical, scalable, real-time decision-support solution for precision agriculture and sets the stage for lightweight multimodal AI systems suitable for resource-constrained environments.

title: The Geometry of Nonlinear Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Reward maximization, safe exploration, and intrinsic motivation are often
studied as separate objectives in reinforcement learning (RL). We present a
unified geometric framework, that views these goals as instances of a single
optimization problem on the space of achievable long-term behavior in an
environment. Within this framework, classical methods such as policy mirror
descent, natural policy gradient, and trust-region algorithms naturally
generalize to nonlinear utilities and convex constraints. We illustrate how
this perspective captures robustness, safety, exploration, and diversity
objectives, and outline open challenges at the interface of geometry and deep
RL.

AI.tldr: A geometric framework unifies reward maximization, safe exploration, and intrinsic motivation as optimization over the space of achievable long-term behavior in RL; classical policy optimization methods (mirror descent, natural policy gradient, TRPO) generalize within this lens to nonlinear utilities and convex constraints, capturing robustness, safety, exploration, and diversity, with open geometric/deep-RL challenges ahead.
AI.motivation: Reinforcement learning often treats reward maximization, safe exploration, and intrinsic motivation as separate objectives. A single geometric view over long-term achievable behavior can unify these goals, enable principled trade-offs, and extend optimization methods to handle nonlinear utilities and convex constraints.
AI.method: Propose a unified geometric framework on the space of achievable long-term behavior in an environment. Within this framework, interpret reward, safety, and intrinsic motivation as instances of a single optimization problem. Show that classical policy optimization methods—policy mirror descent, natural policy gradient, and trust-region algorithms—naturally generalize to nonlinear utilities and convex constraints. Demonstrate how robustness, safety, exploration, and diversity objectives arise under this perspective.
AI.result: The framework provides a cohesive lens that recovers and generalizes established RL optimization methods for a wide class of objectives, including nonlinear utilities and convex constraints. It clarifies how robustness, safety, exploration, and diversity can be integrated within a single geometric view, and offers a structured path for combining these objectives in deep RL.
AI.conclusion: The work highlights open challenges at the interface of geometry and deep RL and calls for further research to develop and apply the geometric perspective to more complex, deep RL settings.

title: M3Ret: Unleashing Zero-shot Multimodal Medical Image Retrieval via Self-Supervision
summary:
Medical image retrieval is essential for clinical decision-making and
translational research, relying on discriminative visual representations. Yet,
current methods remain fragmented, relying on separate architectures and
training strategies for 2D, 3D, and video-based medical data. This
modality-specific design hampers scalability and inhibits the development of
unified representations. To enable unified learning, we curate a large-scale
hybrid-modality dataset comprising 867,653 medical imaging samples, including
2D X-rays and ultrasounds, RGB endoscopy videos, and 3D CT scans. Leveraging
this dataset, we train M3Ret, a unified visual encoder without any
modality-specific customization. It successfully learns transferable
representations using both generative (MAE) and contrastive (SimDINO)
self-supervised learning (SSL) paradigms. Our approach sets a new
state-of-the-art in zero-shot image-to-image retrieval across all individual
modalities, surpassing strong baselines such as DINOv3 and the text-supervised
BMC-CLIP. More remarkably, strong cross-modal alignment emerges without paired
data, and the model generalizes to unseen MRI tasks, despite never observing
MRI during pretraining, demonstrating the generalizability of purely visual
self-supervision to unseen modalities. Comprehensive analyses further validate
the scalability of our framework across model and data sizes. These findings
deliver a promising signal to the medical imaging community, positioning M3Ret
as a step toward foundation models for visual SSL in multimodal medical image
understanding.

AI.tldr: M3Ret introduces a unified visual encoder trained on a large-scale hybrid-modality medical dataset, using self-supervised learning (MAE and SimDINO) to achieve state-of-the-art zero-shot image-to-image retrieval across 2D, 3D, and video modalities, with cross-modal alignment emerging without paired data and good generalization to unseen MRI tasks.
AI.motivation: Current medical image retrieval methods rely on modality-specific architectures and training strategies, hindering scalability and the development of unified representations. A single, modality-agnostic model could enable efficient cross-modal retrieval and generalization to unseen modalities.
AI.method: Curate a large-scale hybrid-modality dataset with 867,653 samples (2D X-rays and ultrasounds, RGB endoscopy videos, 3D CT scans). Train M3Ret, a unified visual encoder with no modality-specific customization, using self-supervised learning via MAE (generative) and SimDINO (contrastive). Evaluate zero-shot image-to-image retrieval across modalities, analyze cross-modal alignment without paired data, and test generalization to unseen MRI tasks. Conduct scalability analyses across model and data sizes.
AI.result: Achieves new state-of-the-art in zero-shot image-to-image retrieval across all modalities, outperforming baselines such as DINOv3 and text-supervised BMC-CLIP. Cross-modal alignment emerges without paired data, and the model generalizes to unseen MRI tasks despite no MRI during pretraining. Analyses demonstrate scalability of the framework with varying model and data sizes.
AI.conclusion: Purely visual self-supervision can yield transferable, cross-modally aligned representations on a unified multimodal medical dataset, advancing toward foundation models for visual SSL in multimodal medical image understanding.

title: Benchmarking Optimizers for Large Language Model Pretraining
summary:
The recent development of Large Language Models (LLMs) has been accompanied
by an effervescence of novel ideas and methods to better optimize the loss of
deep learning models. Claims from those methods are myriad: from faster
convergence to removing reliance on certain hyperparameters. However, the
diverse experimental protocols used to validate these claims make direct
comparisons between methods challenging. This study presents a comprehensive
evaluation of recent optimization techniques across standardized LLM
pretraining scenarios, systematically varying model size, batch size, and
training duration. Through careful tuning of each method, we provide guidance
to practitioners on which optimizer is best suited for each scenario. For
researchers, our work highlights promising directions for future optimization
research. Finally, by releasing our code and making all experiments fully
reproducible, we hope our efforts can help the development and rigorous
benchmarking of future methods.

AI.tldr: A comprehensive, reproducible benchmark of recent LLM optimization methods across standardized pretraining scenarios, yielding practical guidance and identifying future research directions.
AI.motivation: Experimental protocols for optimizer comparisons are inconsistent, hindering fair comparisons. A standardized benchmark is needed to guide practitioners and direct future research.
AI.method: Systematic evaluation of recent optimization techniques across standardized LLM pretraining setups, varying model size, batch size, and training duration; careful tuning of each method; release of code for reproducibility.
AI.result: Practical recommendations on which optimizer suits each scenario; identification of promising research directions; demonstration of reproducibility through code release.
AI.conclusion: Benchmarking and reproducibility are essential for advancing optimization methods in LLM pretraining; the study provides a reference for practitioners and researchers and a foundation for rigorous future work.

title: Identity-Preserving Text-to-Video Generation via Training-Free Prompt, Image, and Guidance Enhancement
summary:
Identity-preserving text-to-video (IPT2V) generation creates videos faithful
to both a reference subject image and a text prompt. While fine-tuning large
pretrained video diffusion models on ID-matched data achieves state-of-the-art
results on IPT2V, data scarcity and high tuning costs hinder broader
improvement. We thus introduce a Training-Free Prompt, Image, and Guidance
Enhancement (TPIGE) framework that bridges the semantic gap between the video
description and the reference image and design sampling guidance that enhances
identity preservation and video quality, achieving performance gains at minimal
cost.Specifically, we first propose Face Aware Prompt Enhancement, using GPT-4o
to enhance the text prompt with facial details derived from the reference
image. We then propose Prompt Aware Reference Image Enhancement, leveraging an
identity-preserving image generator to refine the reference image, rectifying
conflicts with the text prompt. The above mutual refinement significantly
improves input quality before video generation. Finally, we propose ID-Aware
Spatiotemporal Guidance Enhancement, utilizing unified gradients to optimize
identity preservation and video quality jointly during generation.Our method
outperforms prior work and is validated by automatic and human evaluations on a
1000 video test set, winning first place in the ACM Multimedia 2025
Identity-Preserving Video Generation Challenge, demonstrating state-of-the-art
performance and strong generality. The code is available at
https://github.com/Andyplus1/IPT2V.git.

AI.tldr: A training-free IPT2V framework (TPIGE) improves identity preservation and video quality by jointly refining prompts, reference images, and guidance, achieving state-of-the-art results on IPT2V with minimal cost; demonstrated on a 1000-video test set and winning ACM Multimedia 2025.
AI.motivation: Data scarcity and high tuning costs hinder identity-preserving text-to-video generation. There is a need for training-free methods to bridge semantic gaps between a reference image and a text prompt, while maintaining video quality and identity fidelity.
AI.method: TPIGE consists of three mutually reinforcing components: (1) Face Aware Prompt Enhancement uses GPT-4o to enrich the text prompt with facial details from the reference image; (2) Prompt Aware Reference Image Enhancement uses an identity-preserving image generator to refine the reference image to align better with the text prompt; (3) ID-Aware Spatiotemporal Guidance Enhancement employs unified gradients to jointly optimize identity preservation and video quality during generation.
AI.result: Outperforms prior work on IPT2V, validated by automatic and human evaluations on a 1000-video test set; achieved first place in the ACM Multimedia 2025 Identity-Preserving Video Generation Challenge; code released at the provided GitHub link, indicating good generality.
AI.conclusion: A training-free framework with mutual prompt/image refinement and unified guidance can achieve state-of-the-art IPT2V performance with low cost and strong generality. It reduces dependence on large-scale ID-tuned models, though it relies on external models (GPT-4o and an identity-preserving image generator) and may raise considerations regarding latency and resource use.

title: Hierarchical Motion Captioning Utilizing External Text Data Source
summary:
This paper introduces a novel approach to enhance existing motion captioning
methods, which directly map representations of movement to high-level
descriptive captions (e.g., ``a person doing jumping jacks"). The existing
methods require motion data annotated with high-level descriptions (e.g.,
``jumping jacks"). However, such data is rarely available in existing
motion-text datasets, which additionally do not include low-level motion
descriptions. To address this, we propose a two-step hierarchical approach.
First, we employ large language models to create detailed descriptions
corresponding to each high-level caption that appears in the motion-text
datasets (e.g., ``jumping while synchronizing arm extensions with the opening
and closing of legs" for ``jumping jacks"). These refined annotations are used
to retrain motion-to-text models to produce captions with low-level details.
Second, we introduce a pioneering retrieval-based mechanism. It aligns the
detailed low-level captions with candidate high-level captions from additional
text data sources, and combine them with motion features to fabricate precise
high-level captions. Our methodology is distinctive in its ability to harness
knowledge from external text sources to greatly increase motion captioning
accuracy, especially for movements not covered in existing motion-text
datasets. Experiments on three distinct motion-text datasets (HumanML3D, KIT,
and BOTH57M) demonstrate that our method achieves an improvement in average
performance (across BLEU-1, BLEU-4, CIDEr, and ROUGE-L) ranging from 6% to 50%
compared to the state-of-the-art M2T-Interpretable.

AI.tldr: Incorporates large language models to generate detailed low-level annotations for high-level motion captions and uses a retrieval-based alignment with external text to improve motion-to-text captioning, achieving substantial gains over SOTA on three datasets.
AI.motivation: Addresses the lack of low-level motion descriptions and limited high-level captions in motion-text datasets by enriching annotations and leveraging external textual knowledge.
AI.method: 1) Use LLMs to produce detailed low-level descriptions for each high-level caption; 2) retrain motion-to-text models with refined annotations to produce captions with low-level detail; 3) apply a retrieval-based mechanism to align detailed captions with candidate high-level captions from external text sources, combining with motion features to generate precise high-level captions.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on HumanML3D, KIT, and BOTH57M shows improvements in BLEU-1, BLEU-4, CIDEr, and ROUGE-L over state-of-the-art M2T-Interpretable, with gains ranging from 6% to 50%.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging external textual knowledge and hierarchical annotation substantially boosts motion captioning accuracy, including movements not covered in existing datasets.

title: Uirapuru: Timely Video Analytics for High-Resolution Steerable Cameras on Edge Devices
summary:
Real-time video analytics on high-resolution cameras has become a popular
technology for various intelligent services like traffic control and crowd
monitoring. While extensive work has been done on improving analytics accuracy
with timing guarantees, virtually all of them target static viewpoint cameras.
In this paper, we present Uirapuru, a novel framework for real-time, edge-based
video analytics on high-resolution steerable cameras. The actuation performed
by those cameras brings significant dynamism to the scene, presenting a
critical challenge to existing popular approaches such as frame tiling. To
address this problem, Uirapuru incorporates a comprehensive understanding of
camera actuation into the system design paired with fast adaptive tiling at a
per-frame level. We evaluate Uirapuru on a high-resolution video dataset,
augmented by pan-tilt-zoom (PTZ) movements typical for steerable cameras and on
real-world videos collected from an actual PTZ camera. Our experimental results
show that Uirapuru provides up to 1.45x improvement in accuracy while
respecting specified latency budgets or reaches up to 4.53x inference speedup
with on-par accuracy compared to state-of-the-art static camera approaches.

AI.tldr: Uiarapuru: an actuation-aware, edge-based real-time analytics framework for high-res steerable cameras that uses per-frame adaptive tiling to handle PTZ movements, achieving higher accuracy or faster inference than static-camera baselines.
AI.motivation: Camera actuation (PTZ) introduces dynamic viewpoints that invalidate static tiling assumptions and complicate real-time analytics; a system design that factors actuation is needed to maintain latency and accuracy.
AI.method: Integrates camera actuation model into the analytics pipeline and develops fast per-frame adaptive tiling that responds to PTZ state; evaluates on a high-res dataset with simulated PTZ movements and on a real PTZ camera; measures accuracy under latency budgets and inference speed.
AI.result: Up to 1.45x accuracy improvement within latency budgets; or up to 4.53x faster inference with comparable accuracy relative to state-of-the-art static-camera methods.
AI.conclusion: Actuation-aware adaptive tiling significantly improves real-time high-res video analytics on steerable cameras, enabling robust performance under dynamic viewpoints and practical deployment.

title: Prior-Guided Flow Matching for Target-Aware Molecule Design with Learnable Atom Number
summary:
Structure-based drug design (SBDD), aiming to generate 3D molecules with high
binding affinity toward target proteins, is a vital approach in novel drug
discovery. Although recent generative models have shown great potential, they
suffer from unstable probability dynamics and mismatch between generated
molecule size and the protein pockets geometry, resulting in inconsistent
quality and off-target effects. We propose PAFlow, a novel target-aware
molecular generation model featuring prior interaction guidance and a learnable
atom number predictor. PAFlow adopts the efficient flow matching framework to
model the generation process and constructs a new form of conditional flow
matching for discrete atom types. A protein-ligand interaction predictor is
incorporated to guide the vector field toward higher-affinity regions during
generation, while an atom number predictor based on protein pocket information
is designed to better align generated molecule size with target geometry.
Extensive experiments on the CrossDocked2020 benchmark show that PAFlow
achieves a new state-of-the-art in binding affinity (up to -8.31 Avg. Vina
Score), simultaneously maintains favorable molecular properties.

AI.tldr: PAFlow is a target-aware flow-based generative model for structure-based drug design that uses prior interaction guidance and an atom-number predictor to align chemistry with pocket geometry, achieving state-of-the-art binding affinity on CrossDocked2020.
AI.motivation: Address unstable probability dynamics and size-geometry mismatch in existing SBDD generative models, which cause inconsistent quality and off-target effects.
AI.method: Uses an efficient flow matching framework with a novel conditional flow matching for discrete atom types; incorporates a protein-ligand interaction predictor to guide the generation toward higher-affinity regions; introduces an atom number predictor based on protein pocket geometry to better match generated molecule size to targets.
AI.result: On CrossDocked2020, PAFlow achieves state-of-the-art binding affinity with Avg. Vina Score up to -8.31 while maintaining favorable molecular properties.
AI.conclusion: Target-aware flow-based generation with interaction guidance and adaptive molecule sizing advances SBDD, potentially reducing off-targets and improving quality and affinity of generated molecules.

title: Unsupervised Ultra-High-Resolution UAV Low-Light Image Enhancement: A Benchmark, Metric and Framework
summary:
Low light conditions significantly degrade Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs)
performance in critical applications. Existing Low-light Image Enhancement
(LIE) methods struggle with the unique challenges of aerial imagery, including
Ultra-High Resolution (UHR), lack of paired data, severe non-uniform
illumination, and deployment constraints. To address these issues, we propose
three key contributions. First, we present U3D, the first unsupervised UHR UAV
dataset for LIE, with a unified evaluation toolkit. Second, we introduce the
Edge Efficiency Index (EEI), a novel metric balancing perceptual quality with
key deployment factors: speed, resolution, model complexity, and memory
footprint. Third, we develop U3LIE, an efficient framework with two
training-only designs-Adaptive Pre-enhancement Augmentation (APA) for input
normalization and a Luminance Interval Loss (L_int) for exposure control. U3LIE
achieves SOTA results, processing 4K images at 23.8 FPS on a single GPU, making
it ideal for real-time on-board deployment. In summary, these contributions
provide a holistic solution (dataset, metric, and method) for advancing robust
24/7 UAV vision. The code and datasets are available at
https://github.com/lwCVer/U3D_Toolkit.

AI.tldr: Proposes U3D dataset, Edge Efficiency Index (EEI), and U3LIE framework to enable unsupervised LIE for ultra-high-res UAV imagery with real-time on-board performance.
AI.motivation: Low-light UAV imagery faces severe challenges: lack of paired data, severe non-uniform illumination, ultra-high resolution (UHR), and deployment constraints. Existing LIE methods underperform for aerial data and real-time on-board processing is desired.
AI.method: 1) U3D – first unsupervised UHR UAV Low-Light Image Enhancement dataset with a unified evaluation toolkit; 2) EEI – Edge Efficiency Index, a metric balancing perceptual quality with deployment factors (speed, resolution, model complexity, memory); 3) U3LIE – a light-weight framework with APA (Adaptive Pre-enhancement Augmentation) for input normalization and L_int (Luminance Interval Loss) for exposure control; optimized for 4K at 23.8 FPS on a single GPU.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art results and real-time (4K at 23.8 FPS on a single GPU) performance; demonstrates effectiveness of the dataset, metric, and method; code and datasets are released.
AI.conclusion: Provides a holistic solution (dataset, metric, and method) for advancing robust 24/7 UAV vision and enabling real-time low-light perception on UAVs; facilitates future research and practical deployment.

title: Unsupervised Identification and Replay-based Detection (UIRD) for New Category Anomaly Detection in ECG Signal
summary:
In clinical practice, automatic analysis of electrocardiogram (ECG) is widely
applied to identify irregular heart rhythms and other electrical anomalies of
the heart, enabling timely intervention and potentially improving clinical
outcomes. However, due to the limited samples in certain types of ECG signals,
the class imbalance issues pose a challenge for ECG-based detection. In
addition, as the volume of patient data grows, long-term storage of all
historical data becomes increasingly burdensome as training samples to
recognize new patterns and classify existing ECG signals accurately. Therefore,
to enhance the performance of anomaly detection while addressing storage
limitations, we propose a pseudo-replay based semi-supervised continual
learning framework, which consists of two components: unsupervised
identification and replay-based detection. For unsupervised identification, an
unsupervised generative adversarial network (GAN)-based framework is integrated
to detect novel patterns. Besides, instead of directly storing all historical
data, a pseudo replay-based learning strategy is proposed which utilizes a
generator to learn the data distribution for each individual task. When a new
task arises, the generator synthesizes pseudo data representative of previous
learnt classes, enabling the model to detect both the existed patterns and the
newly presented anomalies. The effectiveness of the proposed framework is
validated in four public ECG datasets, which leverages supervised
classification problems for anomaly detection. The experimental results show
that the developed approach is very promising in identifying novel anomalies
while maintaining good performance on detecting existing ECG signals.

AI.tldr: Proposes a pseudo-replay based semi-supervised continual learning framework for ECG anomaly detection to handle class imbalance and data storage limits, combining unsupervised GAN-based novelty detection with pseudo data replay to retain prior knowledge while detecting new anomalies.
AI.motivation: ECG anomaly detection suffers from class imbalance and rapid growth of data; storing all historical samples for continual learning is impractical; need a method that detects novel patterns while preserving performance on known classes and reduces storage.
AI.method: A two-component framework: (1) unsupervised identification using GAN-based approach to detect novel patterns; (2) pseudo-replay learning: a generator synthesizes pseudo-data representing previously learned classes for integration during training on new tasks, enabling detection of both old and new anomalies without storing raw data.
AI.result: Validated on four public ECG datasets; results show effective identification of novel anomalies and maintenance of strong detection performance on existing ECG signals; demonstrates promise for anomaly detection under class-imbalance and storage constraints.
AI.conclusion: The pseudo-replay semi-supervised continual learning framework offers a viable solution for ECG anomaly detection under practical constraints, combining novelty detection with memory-efficient rehearsal to manage evolving data distributions.

title: Enhancing Partially Relevant Video Retrieval with Robust Alignment Learning
summary:
Partially Relevant Video Retrieval (PRVR) aims to retrieve untrimmed videos
partially relevant to a given query. The core challenge lies in learning robust
query-video alignment against spurious semantic correlations arising from
inherent data uncertainty: 1) query ambiguity, where the query incompletely
characterizes the target video and often contains uninformative tokens, and 2)
partial video relevance, where abundant query-irrelevant segments introduce
contextual noise in cross-modal alignment. Existing methods often focus on
enhancing multi-scale clip representations and retrieving the most relevant
clip. However, the inherent data uncertainty in PRVR renders them vulnerable to
distractor videos with spurious similarities, leading to suboptimal
performance. To fill this research gap, we propose Robust Alignment Learning
(RAL) framework, which explicitly models the uncertainty in data. Key
innovations include: 1) we pioneer probabilistic modeling for PRVR by encoding
videos and queries as multivariate Gaussian distributions. This not only
quantifies data uncertainty but also enables proxy-level matching to capture
the variability in cross-modal correspondences; 2) we consider the
heterogeneous informativeness of query words and introduce learnable confidence
gates to dynamically weight similarity. As a plug-and-play solution, RAL can be
seamlessly integrated into the existing architectures. Extensive experiments
across diverse retrieval backbones demonstrate its effectiveness.

AI.tldr: Proposes Robust Alignment Learning (RAL) for Partially Relevant Video Retrieval by modeling data uncertainty with Gaussian video/query representations and learnable confidence gates; a plug-and-play framework that improves cross-modal alignment and robustness against distractors.
AI.motivation: PRVR is hindered by data uncertainty: query ambiguity and partial relevance cause spurious correlations and noisy cross-modal alignment; existing methods focusing on multi-scale clips struggle with distractor videos.
AI.method: Encode videos and queries as multivariate Gaussian distributions to capture uncertainty, use proxy-level matching to handle cross-modal variability, and introduce learnable confidence gates to weight word informativeness; designed as a plug-and-play module that can be integrated into existing architectures.
AI.result: Extensive experiments across diverse retrieval backbones demonstrate effectiveness, showing improved robustness and alignment over strong baselines in PRVR tasks.
AI.conclusion: RAL pioneers probabilistic modeling for PRVR, enabling uncertainty quantification and dynamic alignment weighting; it can be integrated into current architectures to improve performance under data noise.

title: Prediction, Generation of WWTPs microbiome community structures and Clustering of WWTPs various feature attributes using DE-BP model, SiTime-GAN model and DPNG-EPMC ensemble clustering algorithm with modulation of microbial ecosystem health
comment:
48 pages,25 figures, three major research sections: Prediction,
  Generation and Clustering
summary:
Microbiomes not only underpin Earth's biogeochemical cycles but also play
crucial roles in both engineered and natural ecosystems, such as the soil,
wastewater treatment, and the human gut. However, microbiome engineering faces
significant obstacles to surmount to deliver the desired improvements in
microbiome control. Here, we use the backpropagation neural network (BPNN),
optimized through differential evolution (DE-BP), to predict the microbial
composition of activated sludge (AS) systems collected from wastewater
treatment plants (WWTPs) located worldwide. Furthermore, we introduce a novel
clustering algorithm termed Directional Position Nonlinear Emotional Preference
Migration Behavior Clustering (DPNG-EPMC). This method is applied to conduct a
clustering analysis of WWTPs across various feature attributes. Finally, we
employ the Similar Time Generative Adversarial Networks (SiTime-GAN), to
synthesize novel microbial compositions and feature attributes data. As a
result, we demonstrate that the DE-BP model can provide superior predictions of
the microbial composition. Additionally, we show that the DPNG-EPMC can be
applied to the analysis of WWTPs under various feature attributes. Finally, we
demonstrate that the SiTime-GAN model can generate valuable incremental
synthetic data. Our results, obtained through predicting the microbial
community and conducting analysis of WWTPs under various feature attributes,
develop an understanding of the factors influencing AS communities.

AI.tldr: DE-BP (differential evolution-optimized backpropagation neural network) accurately predicts microbial composition in activated sludge (AS) across global WWTPs. A novel clustering method, DPNG-EPMC, analyzes WWTPs by feature attributes. SiTime-GAN generates synthetic microbial compositions and features. Together, they reveal factors shaping AS communities and enable data-driven microbiome engineering.
AI.motivation: Microbiomes drive biogeochemical cycles and engineering of ecosystems (soil, wastewater, human gut). Improving microbiome control in WWTPs can enhance treatment efficiency and ecological understanding.
AI.method: 1) Train a differential evolution-optimized backpropagation neural network (DE-BP) to predict microbial composition in activated sludge from WWTPs worldwide. 2) Apply a novel clustering algorithm—Direction Nonlinear Emotional Preference Migration Clustering (DPNG-EPMC)—to cluster WWTPs by multiple feature attributes. 3) Use a Similar Time GAN (SiTime-GAN) to synthesize new microbial compositions and feature data.
AI.result: DE-BP achieves superior predictive performance for microbial composition. DPNG-EPMC provides a meaningful clustering of WWTPs across feature attributes. SiTime-GAN yields valuable incremental synthetic data, expanding the dataset for modeling.
AI.conclusion: Integrating DE-BP, DPNG-EPMC, and SiTime-GAN advances understanding of factors shaping activated sludge communities and offers tools for improved microbiome engineering and data augmentation in WWTP contexts.

title: RibPull: Implicit Occupancy Fields and Medial Axis Extraction for CT Ribcage Scans
comment:
This paper is currently being reviewed for a conference submission.
  If accepted an extended manuscript will be published and the code will be
  released
summary:
We present RibPull, a methodology that utilizes implicit occupancy fields to
bridge computational geometry and medical imaging. Implicit 3D representations
use continuous functions that handle sparse and noisy data more effectively
than discrete methods. While voxel grids are standard for medical imaging, they
suffer from resolution limitations, topological information loss, and
inefficient handling of sparsity. Coordinate functions preserve complex
geometrical information and represent a better solution for sparse data
representation, while allowing for further morphological operations. Implicit
