this study propose a Geometric-Structural Dual-Guided Network (GSD-Net), which
integrates geometric and structural cues to improve robustness against noisy
annotations. It incorporates a Geometric Distance-Aware module that dynamically
adjusts pixel-level weights using geometric features, thereby strengthening
supervision in reliable regions while suppressing noise. A Structure-Guided
Label Refinement module further refines labels with structural priors, and a
Knowledge Transfer module enriches supervision and improves sensitivity to
local details. To comprehensively assess its effectiveness, we evaluated
GSD-Net on six publicly available datasets: four containing three types of
simulated label noise, and two with multi-expert annotations that reflect
real-world subjectivity and labeling inconsistencies. Experimental results
demonstrate that GSD-Net achieves state-of-the-art performance under noisy
annotations, achieving improvements of 2.52% on Kvasir, 22.76% on Shenzhen,
8.87% on BU-SUC, and 4.59% on BraTS2020 under SR simulated noise. The codes of
this study are available at https://github.com/ortonwang/GSD-Net.

AI.tldr: A three-module network (GSD-Net) uses geometric distance-aware weighting, structural label refinement, and knowledge transfer to robustly segment medical images with noisy annotations, achieving state-of-the-art performance on six datasets.
AI.motivation: Noisy and subjective annotations in medical image segmentation hinder learning; robust methods leveraging geometric and structural priors are needed to suppress noise and preserve local details.
AI.method: Geometric Distance-Aware module dynamically adjusts pixel-level weights using geometric cues to emphasize reliable regions; Structure-Guided Label Refinement module refines labels with structural priors; Knowledge Transfer module enriches supervision to improve sensitivity to local details. Evaluated on six datasets, including four with simulated label noise (three noise types) and two with multi-expert annotations.
AI.result: Claims state-of-the-art performance under noisy annotations, reporting improvements under SR simulated noise: 2.52% on Kvasir, 22.76% on Shenzhen, 8.87% on BU-SUC, and 4.59% on BraTS2020. Public code available at the provided GitHub URL.
AI.conclusion: GSD-Net demonstrates robustness to annotation noise through geometric/structural priors and transfer learning, with potential applicability to real-world noisy datasets; future work could extend to other modalities, noise types, and efficiency improvements.

title: RNN Generalization to Omega-Regular Languages
comment:
7 pages, 3 figures. To be published in OVERLAY 2025, 7th
  International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Formal Verification,
  Logic, Automata, and Synthesis. See https://overlay.uniud.it/workshop/2025/
summary:
B\"uchi automata (BAs) recognize $\omega$-regular languages defined by formal
specifications like linear temporal logic (LTL) and are commonly used in the
verification of reactive systems. However, BAs face scalability challenges when
handling and manipulating complex system behaviors. As neural networks are
increasingly used to address these scalability challenges in areas like model
checking, investigating their ability to generalize beyond training data
becomes necessary. This work presents the first study investigating whether
recurrent neural networks (RNNs) can generalize to $\omega$-regular languages
derived from LTL formulas. We train RNNs on ultimately periodic $\omega$-word
sequences to replicate target BA behavior and evaluate how well they generalize
to out-of-distribution sequences. Through experiments on LTL formulas
corresponding to deterministic automata of varying structural complexity, from
3 to over 100 states, we show that RNNs achieve high accuracy on their target
$\omega$-regular languages when evaluated on sequences up to $8 \times$ longer
than training examples, with $92.6\%$ of tasks achieving perfect or
near-perfect generalization. These results establish the feasibility of neural
approaches for learning complex $\omega$-regular languages, suggesting their
potential as components in neurosymbolic verification methods.

AI.tldr: Trains RNNs to imitate Büchi automata behavior for omega-regular languages derived from LTL; demonstrates strong generalization to sequences up to 8× longer than training data, with 92.6% tasks perfect or near-perfect, suggesting neural approaches can complement neurosymbolic verification.
AI.motivation: Büchi automata are fundamental for recognizing omega-regular languages from LTL specifications but do not scale well. Investigating whether neural networks can generalize to omega-regular tasks could offer scalable, neurosymbolic verification approaches.
AI.method: Train recurrent neural networks on ultimately periodic omega-word sequences to replicate target Büchi automata behavior. Evaluate generalization on out-of-distribution sequences derived from LTL formulas corresponding to deterministic automata of varying structural complexity (3 to >100 states). Assess accuracy on sequences up to 8× longer than training data.
AI.result: RNNs achieve high accuracy on their target omega-regular languages when evaluated on sequences up to eight times longer than training; 92.6% of tasks achieve perfect or near-perfect generalization.
AI.conclusion: This study demonstrates the feasibility of learning complex omega-regular languages with neural models and supports their role as components in neurosymbolic verification methods, enabling scalable handling of omega-regular properties.

title: Faster and Better: Reinforced Collaborative Distillation and Self-Learning for Infrared-Visible Image Fusion
summary:
Infrared and visible image fusion plays a critical role in enhancing scene
perception by combining complementary information from different modalities.
Despite recent advances, achieving high-quality image fusion with lightweight
models remains a significant challenge. To bridge this gap, we propose a novel
collaborative distillation and self-learning framework for image fusion driven
by reinforcement learning. Unlike conventional distillation, this approach not
only enables the student model to absorb image fusion knowledge from the
teacher model, but more importantly, allows the student to perform
self-learning on more challenging samples to enhance its capabilities.
Particularly, in our framework, a reinforcement learning agent explores and
identifies a more suitable training strategy for the student.The agent takes
both the student's performance and the teacher-student gap as inputs, which
leads to the generation of challenging samples to facilitate the student's
self-learning. Simultaneously, it dynamically adjusts the teacher's guidance
strength based on the student's state to optimize the knowledge transfer.
Experimental results demonstrate that our method can significantly improve
student performance and achieve better fusion results compared to existing
techniques.

AI.tldr: Proposes a collaborative distillation and self-learning framework for infrared–visible image fusion using reinforcement learning to tailor training strategies; enhances lightweight student models by enabling challenging self-learning and adaptive teacher guidance.
AI.motivation: Lightweight fusion models struggle to achieve high-quality fusion; there is a need for effective, efficient training strategies to transfer knowledge from a teacher and improve learning on hard samples.
AI.method: A reinforcement learning agent governs a teacher–student fusion framework: the agent selects challenging samples for the student’s self-learning and adjusts the teacher’s guidance strength based on the student’s state, using inputs of student performance and the teacher–student gap; the agent also generates training strategies and modulates knowledge transfer to optimize fusion quality.
AI.result: Experimental results show significant improvements in the student’s performance and superior fusion quality over existing techniques.
AI.conclusion: The collaborative distillation with RL-guided self-learning effectively enhances infrared–visible image fusion in lightweight models by smartly balancing knowledge transfer and self-learning.

title: MoPEQ: Mixture of Mixed Precision Quantized Experts
summary:
Large Language and Vision Models using a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE)
architecture pose significant challenges for deployment due to their
computational and memory demands. Mixed Precision Quantization assigns
different precisions to different layers of an LLM/VLM based on layer
sensitivity and importance within the model. In this work, we propose a Post
Training Quantization algorithm, MoPEQ, that assigns optimal bit width to each
expert. Our method balances accuracy and model size by analyzing each expert's
sensitivity using Hessian trace approximation instead of relying on the
activation frequency of the expert. This per-expert granularity approach
clusters similar experts to maintain model performance while reducing memory
requirements. The experimental results on VLMEvalKit benchmark datasets using
State-of-the-art VLMs Deepseek-VL2 -tiny, -small, -base, and MolmoE models
demonstrate that our mixed precision quantized MoEs achieve competitive
accuracy with substantial improvements in memory footprint compared to
uniform-precision baseline methods. We perform a comprehensive study to analyze
the impact of expert activation frequency and sensitivity using Hessian trace
approximation at both layer-wise and model-wide expert precision allocation of
2, 3, and 4 bits to provide a thorough understanding of mixed precision
quantization of VLM-MoEs.

AI.tldr: Proposes MoPEQ, a post-training quantization method for mixture-of-experts (MoE) in vision-language models that assigns per-expert bitwidths (2–4 bits) using Hessian trace sensitivity rather than activation frequency, to achieve memory reductions with competitive accuracy.
AI.motivation: MoEs in large LLMs/VLMs have high compute and memory demands, and uniform-precision quantization wastes capacity. A per-expert, sensitivity-aware quantization could significantly reduce memory while preserving performance. Hessian-based sensitivity may better reflect importance than activation frequency.
AI.method: Post-Training Quantization (MoPEQ) assigns optimal bit widths to each expert by estimating sensitivity via Hessian trace approximation. Experts are clustered to maintain performance while reducing memory. Evaluates layer-wise and model-wide precision allocations (2,3,4 bits) on VLMEvalKit datasets using state-of-the-art VLMs Deepseek-VL2 (tiny, small, base) and MolmoE models, comparing against uniform-precision baselines.
AI.result: MoPEQ achieves competitive accuracy with substantial memory-footprint reductions compared with uniform precision baselines. The study analyzes the impact of expert activation frequency vs Hessian-based sensitivity at both layer-wise and model-wide levels across 2, 3, and 4-bit allocations, demonstrating robustness of per-expert mixed precision quantization for VLM MoEs.
AI.conclusion: Per-expert Hessian-based sensitivity, combined with clustering, enables effective mixed-precision quantization for MoEs in VLMs, yielding meaningful memory savings with minimal loss of accuracy across diverse models and bitwidth settings.

title: Towards High-Fidelity, Identity-Preserving Real-Time Makeup Transfer: Decoupling Style Generation
summary:
We present a novel framework for real-time virtual makeup try-on that
achieves high-fidelity, identity-preserving cosmetic transfer with robust
temporal consistency. In live makeup transfer applications, it is critical to
synthesize temporally coherent results that accurately replicate fine-grained
makeup and preserve user's identity. However, existing methods often struggle
to disentangle semitransparent cosmetics from skin tones and other identify
features, causing identity shifts and raising fairness concerns. Furthermore,
current methods lack real-time capabilities and fail to maintain temporal
consistency, limiting practical adoption. To address these challenges, we
decouple makeup transfer into two steps: transparent makeup mask extraction and
graphics-based mask rendering. After the makeup extraction step, the makeup
rendering can be performed in real time, enabling live makeup try-on. Our
makeup extraction model trained on pseudo-ground-truth data generated via two
complementary methods: a graphics-based rendering pipeline and an unsupervised
k-means clustering approach. To further enhance transparency estimation and
color fidelity, we propose specialized training objectives, including
alpha-weighted reconstruction and lip color losses. Our method achieves robust
makeup transfer across diverse poses, expressions, and skin tones while
preserving temporal smoothness. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our
approach outperforms existing baselines in capturing fine details, maintaining
temporal stability, and preserving identity integrity.

AI.tldr: A real-time, identity-preserving makeup transfer framework that achieves temporally coherent results by decoupling makeup extraction and rendering and training on pseudo-ground-truth data.
AI.motivation: There is a need for realistic, temporally stable makeup transfer that preserves user identity and fairness, while existing methods struggle with disentangling semi-transparent cosmetics from skin tones, suffer from identity shifts, and lack real-time performance.
AI.method: Decouple makeup transfer into two steps: transparent makeup mask extraction and graphics-based mask rendering. Train the extractor on pseudo-ground-truth data generated via a graphics-based rendering pipeline and unsupervised k-means clustering. Use specialized losses (alpha-weighted reconstruction, lip color losses) to improve transparency estimation and color fidelity. Enable real-time rendering for live makeup try-on, with temporal consistency objectives likely guiding the training.
AI.result: The approach achieves robust makeup transfer across diverse poses, expressions, and skin tones while preserving temporal smoothness. Experiments show superiority over baselines in capturing fine details, maintaining temporal stability, and preserving identity integrity.
AI.conclusion: This framework offers a practical path for real-time, high-fidelity makeup transfer that preserves user identity and temporal consistency, addressing prior disentanglement and real-time limitations and demonstrating strong performance across varied conditions.

title: Is RL fine-tuning harder than regression? A PDE learning approach for diffusion models
summary:
We study the problem of learning the optimal control policy for fine-tuning a
given diffusion process, using general value function approximation. We develop
a new class of algorithms by solving a variational inequality problem based on
the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equations. We prove sharp statistical rates
for the learned value function and control policy, depending on the complexity
and approximation errors of the function class. In contrast to generic
reinforcement learning problems, our approach shows that fine-tuning can be
achieved via supervised regression, with faster statistical rate guarantees.

AI.tldr: Proposes a variational-inequality (VI) approach based on Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equations to fine-tune diffusion processes. Shows sharp statistical rates for learned value functions and policies with function-class complexity, and argues that fine-tuning can be achieved via supervised regression rather than generic RL.
AI.motivation: To achieve sample-efficient, theoretically grounded fine-tuning of diffusion processes by exploiting HJB structure, avoiding the inefficiency of general RL, and obtaining sharp rates that depend on function-class complexity and approximation error.
AI.method: Develop a new class of algorithms that solve a variational inequality derived from the HJB equations using general value function approximation. The analysis yields explicit statistical rates for both the value function and the control policy, in terms of the complexity and approximation error of the function class.
AI.result: The approach yields sharp, problem-dependent statistical rates for learned value functions and policies. It demonstrates that fine-tuning can be effectively performed via supervised regression with faster rates compared to generic RL settings.
AI.conclusion: Framing diffusion process fine-tuning as a VI problem grounded in HJB theory enables sample-efficient learning, bridging optimal control and RL, and providing concrete rate guarantees that depend on function-class complexity and approximation error.

title: RiverScope: High-Resolution River Masking Dataset
summary:
Surface water dynamics play a critical role in Earth's climate system,
influencing ecosystems, agriculture, disaster resilience, and sustainable
development. Yet monitoring rivers and surface water at fine spatial and
temporal scales remains challenging -- especially for narrow or sediment-rich
rivers that are poorly captured by low-resolution satellite data. To address
this, we introduce RiverScope, a high-resolution dataset developed through
collaboration between computer science and hydrology experts. RiverScope
comprises 1,145 high-resolution images (covering 2,577 square kilometers) with
expert-labeled river and surface water masks, requiring over 100 hours of
manual annotation. Each image is co-registered with Sentinel-2, SWOT, and the
SWOT River Database (SWORD), enabling the evaluation of cost-accuracy
trade-offs across sensors -- a key consideration for operational water
monitoring. We also establish the first global, high-resolution benchmark for
river width estimation, achieving a median error of 7.2 meters -- significantly
outperforming existing satellite-derived methods. We extensively evaluate deep
networks across multiple architectures (e.g., CNNs and transformers),
pretraining strategies (e.g., supervised and self-supervised), and training
datasets (e.g., ImageNet and satellite imagery). Our best-performing models
combine the benefits of transfer learning with the use of all the multispectral
PlanetScope channels via learned adaptors. RiverScope provides a valuable
resource for fine-scale and multi-sensor hydrological modeling, supporting
climate adaptation and sustainable water management.

AI.tldr: Introduces RiverScope, a high-resolution, multi-sensor river/water dataset with global width-benchmark, enabling fine-scale monitoring and training of deep models for accurate width estimation.
AI.motivation: Address the lack of high-resolution, annotated surface-water data for narrow or sediment-rich rivers, which are poorly captured by low-resolution satellites, and support climate adaptation and water management.
AI.method: Assembles 1,145 high-res images (2,577 km^2) with expert masks; co-registers with Sentinel-2, SWOT, and SWORD; creates a global high-res river width benchmark (7.2 m median error); evaluates CNNs/transformers, pretraining (supervised/self-supervised), and datasets; uses transfer learning with multispectral PlanetScope channels via learned adaptors.
AI.result: Global, high-res river-width benchmark achieved with 7.2 m median error; dataset enables cost-accuracy trade-off evaluation across sensors; best models leverage transfer learning and multispectral channels, outperforming existing methods; RiverScope provides a resource for fine-scale hydrological modeling.
AI.conclusion: RiverScope fills a critical data gap for fine-scale river monitoring and multi-sensor hydrological modeling, supporting climate adaptation and sustainable water management.

title: Federated learning over physical channels: adaptive algorithms with near-optimal guarantees
summary:
In federated learning, communication cost can be significantly reduced by
transmitting the information over the air through physical channels. In this
paper, we propose a new class of adaptive federated stochastic gradient descent
(SGD) algorithms that can be implemented over physical channels, taking into
account both channel noise and hardware constraints. We establish theoretical
guarantees for the proposed algorithms, demonstrating convergence rates that
are adaptive to the stochastic gradient noise level. We also demonstrate the
practical effectiveness of our algorithms through simulation studies with deep
learning models.

AI.tldr: Adaptive federated SGD over wireless channels with over-the-air transmission; provides convergence guarantees adaptive to gradient noise and demonstrates practical effectiveness via DL simulations.
AI.motivation: Federated learning faces high communication costs. Over-the-air transmission can reduce this cost, but introduces channel noise and hardware constraints. There is a need for algorithms that adapt to stochastic gradient noise while being implementable on physical channels.
AI.method: Introduce a new class of adaptive federated SGD algorithms designed for operation over physical channels, explicitly accounting for channel noise and hardware constraints; provide theoretical convergence guarantees.
AI.result: Theoretical convergence rates that are adaptive to the stochastic gradient noise level; empirical validation via simulations on deep learning models showing practical effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive over-the-air federated SGD is feasible and effective under realistic channel conditions, offering reduced communication costs without sacrificing convergence reliability.

title: GenCompositor: Generative Video Compositing with Diffusion Transformer
summary:
Video compositing combines live-action footage to create video production,
serving as a crucial technique in video creation and film production.
Traditional pipelines require intensive labor efforts and expert collaboration,
resulting in lengthy production cycles and high manpower costs. To address this
issue, we automate this process with generative models, called generative video
compositing. This new task strives to adaptively inject identity and motion
information of foreground video to the target video in an interactive manner,
allowing users to customize the size, motion trajectory, and other attributes
of the dynamic elements added in final video. Specifically, we designed a novel
Diffusion Transformer (DiT) pipeline based on its intrinsic properties. To
maintain consistency of the target video before and after editing, we revised a
light-weight DiT-based background preservation branch with masked token
injection. As to inherit dynamic elements from other sources, a DiT fusion
block is proposed using full self-attention, along with a simple yet effective
foreground augmentation for training. Besides, for fusing background and
foreground videos with different layouts based on user control, we developed a
novel position embedding, named Extended Rotary Position Embedding (ERoPE).
Finally, we curated a dataset comprising 61K sets of videos for our new task,
called VideoComp. This data includes complete dynamic elements and high-quality
target videos. Experiments demonstrate that our method effectively realizes
generative video compositing, outperforming existing possible solutions in
fidelity and consistency.

AI.tldr: Diffusion Transformer-based VideoComp: an interactive generative video compositing pipeline that preserves the background, fuses a foreground with the target video, and supports user control; introduces Extended Rotary Position Embedding (ERoPE) and a 61k-video dataset; outperforms baselines in fidelity and consistency.
AI.motivation: Traditional video compositing pipelines are labor-intensive and slow. Automating this process with generative models enables interactive control over foreground identity, motion, size, and trajectory while maintaining consistency of the edited video.
AI.method: A Diffusion Transformer (DiT) pipeline with a light-weight background preservation branch using masked token injection; a DiT fusion block employing full self-attention for integrating foreground dynamics; simple foreground augmentation during training; Extended Rotary Position Embedding (ERoPE) for fusing background and foreground with different layouts; a curated dataset VideoComp with 61k video sets for training.
AI.result: Experiments show the proposed method effectively achieves generative video compositing, outperforming existing possible solutions in fidelity and consistency.
AI.conclusion: The DiT-based VideoComp approach, together with ERoPE and the fusion block, enables interactive, high-fidelity, and consistent generative video compositing, supported by a substantial VideoComp dataset.

title: Surrogate Benchmarks for Model Merging Optimization
summary:
Model merging techniques aim to integrate the abilities of multiple models
into a single model. Most model merging techniques have hyperparameters, and
their setting affects the performance of the merged model. Because several
existing works show that tuning hyperparameters in model merging can enhance
the merging outcome, developing hyperparameter optimization algorithms for
model merging is a promising direction. However, its optimization process is
computationally expensive, particularly in merging LLMs. In this work, we
develop surrogate benchmarks for optimization of the merging hyperparameters to
realize algorithm development and performance comparison at low cost. We define
two search spaces and collect data samples to construct surrogate models to
predict the performance of a merged model from a hyperparameter. We demonstrate
that our benchmarks can predict the performance of merged models well and
simulate optimization algorithm behaviors.

AI.tldr: Surrogate benchmarks are proposed to enable low-cost hyperparameter optimization for model merging by building data-driven surrogate models over two search spaces to predict merging performance and simulate optimization dynamics.
AI.motivation: Hyperparameter tuning in model merging is computationally expensive, especially for large language models. There is a need for fast, comparable benchmarking and algorithm development tools.
AI.method: Define two search spaces for merging hyperparameters, collect data samples, and fit surrogate models that predict merged-model performance from hyperparameters. Use these surrogates to evaluate and simulate optimization algorithms.
AI.result: The surrogate benchmarks accurately predict the performance of merged models and can emulate the behavior of optimization algorithms at a much lower cost.
AI.conclusion: Surrogate benchmarks are effective for accelerating research in hyperparameter optimization for model merging, enabling rapid development, comparison, and fair benchmarking of optimization methods.

title: TeRA: Rethinking Text-driven Realistic 3D Avatar Generation
summary:
In this paper, we rethink text-to-avatar generative models by proposing TeRA,
a more efficient and effective framework than the previous SDS-based models and
general large 3D generative models. Our approach employs a two-stage training
strategy for learning a native 3D avatar generative model. Initially, we
distill a decoder to derive a structured latent space from a large human
reconstruction model. Subsequently, a text-controlled latent diffusion model is
trained to generate photorealistic 3D human avatars within this latent space.
TeRA enhances the model performance by eliminating slow iterative optimization
and enables text-based partial customization through a structured 3D human
representation. Experiments have proven our approach's superiority over
previous text-to-avatar generative models in subjective and objective
evaluation.

AI.tldr: TeRA introduces a two-stage text-to-3D avatar generation pipeline that distills a structured latent space from a large human reconstruction model and trains a text-controlled latent diffusion model to generate photorealistic 3D avatars, outperforming SDS-based and large 3D models while enabling partial text-based customization.
AI.motivation: Efficient, high-quality text-to-3D avatar generation is hampered by slow optimization in SDS-based methods and the inefficiency of large 3D generative models; there is a need for a native 3D avatar latent space that supports partial textual control.
AI.method: Stage 1: distill a decoder from a large human reconstruction model to obtain a structured latent space suitable for 3D avatars. Stage 2: train a text-controlled latent diffusion model to synthesize photorealistic avatars within that latent space, enabling direct text-based control without iterative optimization.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations show TeRA surpasses prior text-to-avatar methods in both subjective quality and objective metrics.
AI.conclusion: TeRA delivers a more efficient and effective 3D avatar generation framework, enabling partial text-based customization via a structured 3D representation and avoiding slow optimization common in prior approaches.

title: DynaGuard: A Dynamic Guardrail Model With User-Defined Policies
summary:
Guardian models are used to supervise and moderate the outputs of user-facing
chatbots, enforcing guardrails and detecting bad behaviors. Standard guardian
models like LlamaGuard detect predefined, static categories of harms. We
propose dynamic guardian models that evaluate text based on user-defined
policies, making them useful for different application domains that are not
addressed by standard guardian models. Our dynamic guardian models can be used
for fast detection of policy violations or with chain-of-thought reasoning that
articulates and justifies the model outputs. Our dynamic guardian models match
static models in detection accuracy for static harm categories while
identifying violations of free-form policies with accuracy comparable to
frontier reasoning models in a fraction of the time.

AI.tldr: Dynamic guardian models evaluate text against user-defined policies, enabling domain-specific moderation beyond static harm categories. They can provide fast policy-violation detection and optional chain-of-thought reasoning, matching static guards on static harms and approaching frontier reasoning models for free-form policies with lower latency.
AI.motivation: Address the rigidity of static guardrails by introducing adaptable guardians that can enforce diverse, user-specified policies across different application domains.
AI.method: Introduce dynamic guardian models that score content based on user-defined policies. They can operate in fast detection mode or with chain-of-thought reasoning to justify outputs. Comparative evaluation shows parity with static models on static harms and comparable accuracy to advanced reasoning models on free-form policies, with reduced computation time.
AI.result: Dynamic guardians achieve similar accuracy to static guardians for predefined harms and exhibit accuracy close to frontier reasoning models when detecting violations of free-form policies, all while operating faster than full-fledged reasoning systems.
AI.conclusion: Dynamic, policy-driven guardian models offer flexible, domain-adaptive moderation that preserves accuracy for known harms and provides efficient handling of custom policies, with the option to generate justificatory reasoning.

title: Anisotropic Fourier Features for Positional Encoding in Medical Imaging
comment: 13 pages, 3 figures, 2 tables, to be published in ShapeMI MICCAI 2025
summary:
The adoption of Transformer-based architectures in the medical domain is
growing rapidly. In medical imaging, the analysis of complex shapes - such as
organs, tissues, or other anatomical structures - combined with the often
anisotropic nature of high-dimensional images complicates these adaptations. In
this study, we critically examine the role of Positional Encodings (PEs),
arguing that commonly used approaches may be suboptimal for the specific
challenges of medical imaging. Sinusoidal Positional Encodings (SPEs) have
proven effective in vision tasks, but they struggle to preserve Euclidean
distances in higher-dimensional spaces. Isotropic Fourier Feature Positional
Encodings (IFPEs) have been proposed to better preserve Euclidean distances,
but they lack the ability to account for anisotropy in images. To address these
limitations, we propose Anisotropic Fourier Feature Positional Encoding (AFPE),
a generalization of IFPE that incorporates anisotropic, class-specific, and
domain-specific spatial dependencies. We systematically benchmark AFPE against
commonly used PEs on multi-label classification in chest X-rays, organ
classification in CT images, and ejection fraction regression in
echocardiography. Our results demonstrate that choosing the correct PE can
significantly improve model performance. We show that the optimal PE depends on
the shape of the structure of interest and the anisotropy of the data. Finally,
our proposed AFPE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art PEs in all tested
anisotropic settings. We conclude that, in anisotropic medical images and
videos, it is of paramount importance to choose an anisotropic PE that fits the
data and the shape of interest.

AI.tldr: Anisotropic Fourier Feature Positional Encoding (AFPE) improves Transformer performance on anisotropic medical images by capturing shape- and domain-specific spatial dependencies, outperforming traditional isotropic encodings.
AI.motivation: Current positional encodings (SPEs and IFPEs) struggle with preserving Euclidean distances in high-dimensional and anisotropic medical images. There is a need for an anisotropic, domain-aware PE that matches the data structure and target shapes in medical imaging.
AI.method: Introduce AFPE, a generalization of IFPE that incorporates anisotropic, class-specific, and domain-specific spatial dependencies. Systematically benchmark AFPE against common PEs on tasks including multi-label chest X-ray classification, CT organ classification, and echocardiography ejection fraction regression.
AI.result: AFPE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art PEs in all tested anisotropic settings. The optimal PE depends on the shape of the structure and the data anisotropy, and selecting an appropriate anisotropic PE yields notable performance gains across tasks.
AI.conclusion: For anisotropic medical images and videos, adopting an anisotropic PE that aligns with the data and target shape is crucial; AFPE provides a superior encoding choice in such settings.

title: Understanding sparse autoencoder scaling in the presence of feature manifolds
summary:
Sparse autoencoders (SAEs) model the activations of a neural network as
linear combinations of sparsely occurring directions of variation (latents).
The ability of SAEs to reconstruct activations follows scaling laws w.r.t. the
number of latents. In this work, we adapt a capacity-allocation model from the
neural scaling literature (Brill, 2024) to understand SAE scaling, and in
particular, to understand how "feature manifolds" (multi-dimensional features)
influence scaling behavior. Consistent with prior work, the model recovers
distinct scaling regimes. Notably, in one regime, feature manifolds have the
pathological effect of causing SAEs to learn far fewer features in data than
there are latents in the SAE. We provide some preliminary discussion on whether
or not SAEs are in this pathological regime in the wild.

AI.tldr: SAEs exhibit multiple scaling regimes when allocated capacity, analyzed via a capacity-allocation model; notably, feature manifolds can cause pathological underutilization of latents, with preliminary questions about its occurrence in practice.
AI.motivation: Understand how SAE performance and latent-feature utilization scale with model capacity and data structure, leveraging a capacity-allocation framework from the neural scaling literature to account for multi-dimensional feature manifolds.
AI.method: Adapt a capacity-allocation model to SAEs to derive scaling regimes and examine the influence of feature manifolds on the number of learned latent features.
AI.result: The model reveals distinct scaling regimes; in one regime, feature manifolds have a pathological effect, driving SAEs to learn far fewer features than available latents; preliminary discussion on whether this regime occurs in real data.
AI.conclusion: SAE scaling behavior is regime-dependent, with a potential pathological regime driven by feature manifolds; further empirical validation is needed to assess practical relevance and to guide SAE design.

title: Enhancing Fitness Movement Recognition with Attention Mechanism and Pre-Trained Feature Extractors
comment:
6 pages,9 figures, 2025 28th International Conference on Computer and
  Information Technology (ICCIT)
summary:
Fitness movement recognition, a focused subdomain of human activity
recognition (HAR), plays a vital role in health monitoring, rehabilitation, and
personalized fitness training by enabling automated exercise classification
from video data. However, many existing deep learning approaches rely on
computationally intensive 3D models, limiting their feasibility in real-time or
resource-constrained settings. In this paper, we present a lightweight and
effective framework that integrates pre-trained 2D Convolutional Neural
Networks (CNNs) such as ResNet50, EfficientNet, and Vision Transformers (ViT)
with a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network enhanced by spatial attention.
These models efficiently extract spatial features while the LSTM captures
temporal dependencies, and the attention mechanism emphasizes informative
segments. We evaluate the framework on a curated subset of the UCF101 dataset,
achieving a peak accuracy of 93.34\% with the ResNet50-based configuration.
Comparative results demonstrate the superiority of our approach over several
state-of-the-art HAR systems. The proposed method offers a scalable and
real-time-capable solution for fitness activity recognition with broader
applications in vision-based health and activity monitoring.

AI.tldr: A lightweight, real-time fitness activity recognition framework using 2D CNNs (ResNet50, EfficientNet, ViT) and an LSTM with spatial attention, achieving 93.34% on a curated UCF101 subset, outperforming several state-of-the-art HAR methods while reducing computation compared to 3D models.
AI.motivation: Mitigate the computational burden of 3D deep models for video-based HAR in fitness contexts and enable real-time or resource-constrained deployment, by leveraging efficient 2D feature extractors plus temporal modeling.
AI.method: Extract spatial features per frame with pre-trained 2D CNNs/ViT (ResNet50, EfficientNet, ViT). Feed frame features into an LSTM enhanced with a spatial attention mechanism to emphasize informative video segments and capture temporal dynamics. Evaluate on a curated UCF101 fitness subset.
AI.result: Achieved peak accuracy of 93.34% with the ResNet50-based configuration. Outperformed several state-of-the-art HAR systems on the same subset, demonstrating better balance of accuracy and efficiency for real-time fitness activity recognition.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates a scalable, real-time-capable framework for video-based fitness activity recognition that leverages 2D feature extractors and attention-augmented temporal modeling, with potential applications in vision-based health monitoring.

title: Mix-modal Federated Learning for MRI Image Segmentation
summary:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) image segmentation is crucial in diagnosing
and treating many diseases, such as brain tumors. Existing MRI image
segmentation methods mainly fall into a centralized multimodal paradigm, which
is inapplicable in engineering non-centralized mix-modal medical scenarios. In
this situation, each distributed client (hospital) processes multiple mixed MRI
modalities, and the modality set and image data for each client are diverse,
suffering from extensive client-wise modality heterogeneity and data
heterogeneity. In this paper, we first formulate non-centralized mix-modal MRI
image segmentation as a new paradigm for federated learning (FL) that involves
multiple modalities, called mix-modal federated learning (MixMFL). It
distinguishes from existing multimodal federating learning (MulMFL) and
cross-modal federating learning (CroMFL) paradigms. Then, we proposed a novel
modality decoupling and memorizing mix-modal federated learning framework
(MDM-MixMFL) for MRI image segmentation, which is characterized by a modality
decoupling strategy and a modality memorizing mechanism. Specifically, the
modality decoupling strategy disentangles each modality into modality-tailored
and modality-shared information. During mix-modal federated updating,
corresponding modality encoders undergo tailored and shared updating,
respectively. It facilitates stable and adaptive federating aggregation of
heterogeneous data and modalities from distributed clients. Besides, the
modality memorizing mechanism stores client-shared modality prototypes
dynamically refreshed from every modality-tailored encoder to compensate for
incomplete modalities in each local client. It further benefits modality
aggregation and fusion processes during mixmodal federated learning. Extensive
experiments on two public datasets for MRI image segmentation demonstrate the
effectiveness and superiority of our methods.

AI.tldr: Proposes MDM-MixMFL, a mix-modal federated learning framework for non-centralized MRI segmentation that decouples modality information into tailored and shared parts and uses a memorizing mechanism to handle incomplete modalities, improving performance across heterogeneous clients.
AI.motivation: Addresses severe modality and data heterogeneity in non-centralized multi-modal FL for MRI segmentation; existing MulMFL/CroMFL and centralized methods fail when clients have different modality sets and data distributions.
AI.method: Introduce mix-modal FL paradigm (MixMFL) and the MDM-MixMFL framework with modality decoupling (modality-tailored and modality-shared encoders) and modality memorizing mechanism that stores prototypes refreshed from tailored encoders; tailored/shared updating during aggregation; prototypes help with incomplete modalities.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on two public MRI datasets show improved segmentation performance and robustness over baselines (improved aggregation, stability, adaptability).
AI.conclusion: MDM-MixMFL effectively enables stable, adaptive mix-modal FL for MRI segmentation in non-centralized heterogeneous scenarios, offering a viable path for real-world multi-institution collaborative learning.

title: Motion-Refined DINOSAUR for Unsupervised Multi-Object Discovery
comment:
To appear at ICCVW 2025. Xinrui Gong and Oliver Hahn - both authors
  contributed equally. Code: https://github.com/visinf/mr-dinosaur
summary:
Unsupervised multi-object discovery (MOD) aims to detect and localize
distinct object instances in visual scenes without any form of human
supervision. Recent approaches leverage object-centric learning (OCL) and
motion cues from video to identify individual objects. However, these
approaches use supervision to generate pseudo labels to train the OCL model. We
address this limitation with MR-DINOSAUR -- Motion-Refined DINOSAUR -- a
minimalistic unsupervised approach that extends the self-supervised pre-trained
OCL model, DINOSAUR, to the task of unsupervised multi-object discovery. We
generate high-quality unsupervised pseudo labels by retrieving video frames
without camera motion for which we perform motion segmentation of unsupervised
optical flow. We refine DINOSAUR's slot representations using these pseudo
labels and train a slot deactivation module to assign slots to foreground and
background. Despite its conceptual simplicity, MR-DINOSAUR achieves strong
multi-object discovery results on the TRI-PD and KITTI datasets, outperforming
the previous state of the art despite being fully unsupervised.

AI.tldr: MR-DINOSAUR is a minimal unsupervised approach that extends the pre-trained OCL model DINOSAUR for multi-object discovery by using motion-based pseudo labels from frames with no camera motion, refining slot representations and a slot-deactivation module, achieving state-of-the-art results on TRI-PD and KITTI without supervision.
AI.motivation: Unsupervised multi-object discovery currently relies on supervision or labeled pseudo-labels to train object-centric learning models. There is a need for fully unsupervised methods that can discover and localize distinct objects using motion cues alone.
AI.method: Start from a self-supervised pre-trained OCL model (DINOSAUR). Retrieve video frames with no camera motion and perform motion segmentation via unsupervised optical flow to generate high-quality pseudo labels. Use these labels to refine DINOSAUR's slot representations and train a slot deactivation module that assigns slots to foreground vs. background, enabling multi-object discovery without supervision.
AI.result: MR-DINOSAUR achieves strong multi-object discovery performance on the TRI-PD and KITTI datasets and outperforms previous state-of-the-art methods while remaining fully unsupervised.
AI.conclusion: A simple yet effective unsupervised MOD framework that leverages motion-based pseudo labeling to refine slot-based object representations, demonstrating competitive results without human supervision.

title: FastVGGT: Training-Free Acceleration of Visual Geometry Transformer
summary:
Foundation models for 3D vision have recently demonstrated remarkable
capabilities in 3D perception. However, scaling these models to long-sequence
image inputs remains a significant challenge due to inference-time
inefficiency. In this work, we present a detailed analysis of VGGT, a
state-of-the-art feed-forward visual geometry model and identify its primary
bottleneck. Visualization further reveals a token collapse phenomenon in the
attention maps. Motivated by these findings, we explore the potential of token
merging in the feed-forward visual geometry model. Owing to the unique
architectural and task-specific properties of 3D models, directly applying
existing merging techniques proves challenging. To this end, we propose
FastVGGT, which, for the first time, leverages token merging in the 3D domain
through a training-free mechanism for accelerating VGGT. we devise a unique
token partitioning strategy tailored to 3D architectures and tasks, effectively
eliminating redundant computation while preserving VGGT's powerful
reconstruction capacity. Extensive experiments on multiple 3D geometry
benchmarks validate the effectiveness of our approach. Notably, with 1000 input
images, FastVGGT achieves a 4x speedup over VGGT while mitigating error
accumulation in long-sequence scenarios. These findings underscore the
potential of token merging as a principled solution for scalable 3D vision
systems. Code is available at: https://mystorm16.github.io/fastvggt/.

AI.tldr: FastVGGT introduces a training-free token merging strategy tailored for 3D vision transformers, achieving significant speedups (4x with 1000 input images) while reducing error accumulation and preserving reconstruction ability.
AI.motivation: Scaling foundation models for 3D vision to long-sequence inputs is hampered by inference-time inefficiency. Observations of VGGT bottlenecks and token collapse in attention maps motivate a decomposition strategy that eliminates redundant computation without sacrificing 3D reconstruction quality.
AI.method: Propose FastVGGT, a training-free token merging framework for 3D VGGT. It uses a novel token partitioning strategy designed for 3D architectures and tasks, enabling selective merging to remove redundancy while maintaining reconstruction capability.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on multiple 3D geometry benchmarks show 4x speedup with 1000 input images and reduced error accumulation in long-sequence scenarios; code is provided.
AI.conclusion: Token merging is a principled approach to scale 3D vision systems, and tailoring merging strategies to 3D architectures yields practical gains without additional training.
